text.wiki:
Sapporo (札幌市, Sapporo-shi) is the fifth largest city in Japan, and the largest city on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is the capital city of Hokkaido Prefecture and its Ishikari Subprefecture, and numbers among the nation's ordinance-designated city. Sapporo lies in the southwest of Hokkaido, within the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, which is a tributary stream of the Ishikari. Sapporo is considered the cultural, economical, and political center of Hokkaido.  
As with most of Hokkaido, the Sapporo area was settled by the indigenous Ainu people, beginning over 15,000 years ago. Starting in the late 19th century, Sapporo saw increasing settlement by Japanese migrants. Sapporo hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Olympics ever held in Asia, and the second Olympic games held in Japan after the 1964 Summer Olympics. The Sapporo Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup and two games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
The annual Sapporo Snow Festival draws more than 2 million tourists from abroad. Other notable sites include the Sapporo Beer Museum, which is the only beer museum in Japan, and the Sapporo TV Tower located in Odori Park. It is home to Hokkaido University, just north of Sapporo Station. The city is served by Okadama Airport, and New Chitose Airport in nearby Chitose. 


== Etymology ==
Sapporo's name was taken from Ainuic "sat poro pet" (サッ・ポロ・ペッ), which can be translated as the "dry, great river", a reference to the Toyohira River.


== History ==


=== Early history ===
Before its establishment, the area occupied by Sapporo (known as the Ishikari Plain) was home to a number of indigenous Ainu settlements. In 1866, at the end of the Edo period, construction began on a canal through the area, encouraging a number of early settlers to establish Sapporo village.In 1868, the officially recognized year celebrated as the "birth" of Sapporo, the new Meiji government concluded that the existing administrative center of Hokkaido, which at the time was the port of Hakodate, was in an unsuitable location for defense and further development of the island. As a result, it was determined that a new capital on the Ishikari Plain should be established. The plain itself provided an unusually large expanse of flat, well drained land which is relatively uncommon in the otherwise mountainous geography of Hokkaido.
During 1870–1871, Kuroda Kiyotaka, vice-chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi), approached the American government for assistance in developing the land. As a result, Horace Capron, Secretary of Agriculture under President Ulysses S. Grant, became an oyatoi gaikokujin and was appointed as a special advisor to the commission. Construction began around Odori Park, which still remains as a green ribbon of recreational land bisecting the central area of the city. The city closely followed a grid plan with streets at right-angles to form city blocks.
The continuing expansion of the Japanese into Hokkaido continued, mainly due to migration from the main island of Honshu immediately to the south, and the prosperity of Hokkaido and particularly its capital grew to the point that the Development Commission was deemed unnecessary and was abolished in 1882.
Edwin Dun came to Sapporo to establish sheep and cattle ranches in 1876. He also demonstrated pig raising and the making of butter, cheese, ham and sausage. He was married twice, to Japanese women. He once went back to the US in 1883 but returned to Japan as a secretary of government.
William S. Clark, who was the president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the University of Massachusetts Amherst), came to be the founding vice-president of the Sapporo Agricultural College (now Hokkaido University) for only eight months from 1876 to 1877. He taught academic subjects in science and lectured on the Bible as an "ethics" course, introducing Christian principles to the first entering class of the College.
In 1880, the entire area of Sapporo was renamed as "Sapporo-ku" (Sapporo Ward), and a railroad between Sapporo and Temiya, Otaru was laid. That year the Hōheikan, a hotel and reception facility for visiting officials and dignitaries, was erected adjacent to the Odori Park. It was later moved to Nakajima Park where it remains today. Two years later, with the abolition of the Kaitaku-shi, Hokkaidō was divided into three prefectures: Hakodate, Sapporo, and Nemuro. The name of the urban district in Sapporo remained Sapporo-ku, while the rest of the area in Sapporo-ku was changed to Sapporo-gun. The office building of Sapporo-ku was also located in the urban district.Sapporo, Hakodate, and Nemuro Prefectures were abolished in 1886, and Hokkaidō government office building, an American-neo-baroque-style structure with red bricks, constructed in 1888. The last squad of the Tondenhei, the soldiers pioneering Hokkaido, settled in the place where the area of Tonden in Kita-ku, Sapporo is currently located. Sapporo-ku administered surrounding Sapporo-gun until 1899, when the new district system was announced. After that year, Sapporo-ku was away from the control of Sapporo-gun. The "ku" (district) enforced from 1899 was an autonomy which was a little bigger than towns, and smaller than cities. In Hokkaido at that time, Hakodate-ku and Otaru-ku also existed.
Gallery
		
		


=== 20th century ===
In 1907, the Tohoku Imperial University was established in Sendai Miyagi Prefecture, and Sapporo Agricultural College was controlled by the University. Parts of neighbouring villages including Sapporo Village, Naebo Village, Kami Shiroishi Village, and districts where the Tonden-hei had settled, were integrated into Sapporo-ku in 1910.
The Sapporo Streetcar was opened in 1918, and Hokkaido Imperial University was established in Sapporo-ku, as the fifth Imperial University in Japan. Another railroad operated in Sapporo, the Jōzankei Railroad, which was ultimately abolished in 1969.
In 1922, the new city system was announced by the Tokyo government, and Sapporo-ku was officially changed to Sapporo City. The Sapporo Municipal Bus System was started in 1930. In 1937, Sapporo was chosen as the site of the 1940 Winter Olympics, but due to the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, this was cancelled the next year. Maruyama Town was integrated as a part of Chūō-ku in 1940, and the Okadama Airport was constructed in 1942.
The first Sapporo Snow Festival was held in 1950. In the same year, adjacent Shiroishi Village was integrated into Sapporo City, rendered as a part of Shiroishi-ku, and Atsubetsu-ku. In 1955, Kotoni Town, the entire Sapporo Village, and Shinoro Village were merged into Sapporo, becoming a part of the current Chūō-ku, Kita-ku, Higashi-ku, Nishi-ku, and Teine-ku. The expansion of Sapporo continued, with the merger of Toyohira Town in 1961, and Teine Town in 1967, each becoming a part of Toyohira-ku, Kiyota-ku, and Teine-ku.The ceremony commemorating the 100th anniversary of the foundation of Sapporo and Hokkaido was held in 1968. The Sapporo Municipal Subway system was inaugurated in 1971, which made Sapporo the fourth city in Japan to have a subway system. From February 3 to 13, 1972, the 1972 Winter Olympics were held, the first Winter Olympics held in Asia. On April 1 of the same year, Sapporo was designated as one of the cities designated by government ordinance, and seven wards were established. The last ever public performance by the opera singer, Maria Callas, was in Sapporo at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan on 11 November 1974. The Sapporo Municipal Subway was expanded when the Tōzai line started operation in 1976, and the Tōhō line was opened in 1988. In 1989, Atsubetsu-ku and Teine-ku were separated from Shiroishi-ku and Nishi-ku. Annual events in Sapporo were started, such as the Pacific Music Festival in 1990, and Yosakoi Sōran Festival in 1992. A professional football club, Consadole Sapporo, was established in 1996. In 1997, Kiyota-ku was separated from Toyohira-ku. In the same year, Hokkaidō Takushoku Bank, a Hokkaido-based bank with headquarters in Odori, went bankrupt.
Gallery
		
		
		


=== 21st century ===
In 2001 the construction of the Sapporo Dome was completed, and in 2002 the Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup; Germany vs Saudi Arabia, Argentina vs England and Italy vs Ecuador, all of which were in the first round. Fumio Ueda, was elected as Sapporo mayor for the first time in 2003. Sapporo became the home to a Nippon Professional Baseball team, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters, in 2004, which won the 2006 Japan Series, and the victory parade was held on Ekimae-Dōri (a street in front of Sapporo Station) in February 2007.
The 34th G8 summit took place in Tōyako in 2008, and a number of people including anti-globalisation activists marched in the heart of the city to protest. Police officers were gathered in Sapporo from all over Japan, and the news reported that four people were arrested in the demonstrations.The Hokkaidō Shinkansen line, which currently connects Honshu to Hakodate through the Seikan Tunnel, is planned to link to Sapporo by 2030.
Gallery
		


== Geography ==

Sapporo is a city located in the southwest part of Ishikari Plain and the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, a tributary stream of the Ishikari River. It is part of Ishikari Subprefecture. Roadways in the urban district are laid to make a grid plan. The western and southern parts of Sapporo are occupied by a number of mountains including Mount Teine, Maruyama, and Mount Moiwa, as well as many rivers including the Ishikari River, Toyohira River, and Sōsei River. Sapporo has an elevation of 29 m (95 ft 2 in)Sapporo has many parks, including Odori Park, which is located in the heart of the city and hosts a number of annual events and festivals throughout the year. Moerenuma Park is also one of the largest parks in Sapporo, and was constructed under the plan of Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American artist and landscape architect.
Neighbouring cities are Ishikari, Ebetsu, Kitahiroshima, Eniwa, Chitose, Otaru, Date, and adjoining towns are Tōbetsu, Kimobetsu, Kyōgoku.


=== Wards ===
Sapporo has ten wards (区, ku). The color shows the location of each ku in the map below.


=== Cityscape ===
Gallery
		
		
		


=== Climate ===
Sapporo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa), with a wide range of temperature between the summer and winter. Summers are generally warm, but not overly humid, and winters are cold and very snowy, with an average snowfall of 5.96 m (19 ft 7 in) per year. Sapporo is one of few metropolises in the world with such heavy snowfall, enabling it to hold events and festivals with snow statues. The heavy snowfall is due to the Siberian High developing over the Eurasian land mass and the Aleutian Low developing over the northern Pacific Ocean, resulting in a flow of cold air southeastward across Tsushima Current and to western Hokkaido. The city's annual average precipitation is around 1,100 mm (43.3 in), and the mean annual temperature is 8.5 °C (47.3 °F).


== Economy ==

The tertiary sector dominates Sapporo's industry. Major industries include information technology, retail, and tourism, as Sapporo is a destination for winter sports and events and summer activities due to its comparatively cool climate.The city is also the manufacturing centre of Hokkaido, manufacturing various goods such as food and related products, fabricated metal products, steel, machinery, beverages, and pulp and paper.Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. In April 2004, Air Nippon Network was headquartered in Higashi-ku. Other companies headquartered in Sapporo include Crypton Future Media, DB-Soft, Hokkaido Air System, and Royce'.
Greater Sapporo, Sapporo Metropolitan Employment Area (2.3 million people), had a total GDP of US$84.7 billion in 2010.In 2014 Sapporo's GDP per capita (PPP) was US$32,446.


== Culture and entertainment ==


=== Music ===
1934 – The International Contemporary Music Festival was held by Akira Ifukube, Fumio Hayasaka, Atsushi Miura, and Isamu Ifukube (30 September)
1936 – Russian composer Alexander Tcherepnin visited Sapporo
1960 – The Sapporo Symphony Orchestra founded
1962 – John Cage and David Tudor visited Sapporo
1966 – Berliner Philharmoniker with Herbert von Karajan performed Brahms's Symphony No. 2 at Sapporo Shimin Kaikan (April)
1974 – Maria Callas last public performance at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan (11 November)
1986 – The Sapporo Art Park include the Outdoor Stage and Art Hall (27 July)
1990 – The Pacific Music Festival (PMF) started
1997 – The Sapporo Concert Hall Kitara opened
2018 – The Sapporo Community Plaza is set to open in October

The Hongō Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture hosts a collection of over 1,800 works by the artist Hongō Shin.
The Sapporo Art Park contains Art museum featuring outdoor installations & a sculpture garden, and the old house of Takeo Arishima.

The Sunpiazza AquariumSapporo JR Tower adjacent to Sapporo Station.Sapporo Ramen Yokocho and Norubesa (a building with a Ferris wheel) are in Susukino district. The district also has the Tanuki Kōji Shopping Arcade, the oldest shopping mall in the city.
The district of Jōzankei in Minami-ku has many resort hotels with steam baths and onsen.
The Peace Pagoda, one of many such monuments across the world built by the Buddhist order Nipponzan Myohoji to promote and inspire world peace, has a stupa that was built in 1959, halfway up Mount Moiwa, to commemorate peace after World War II. It contains some of the ashes of the Buddha that were presented to the Emperor of Japan by Prime Minister Nehru in 1954. Another portion was presented to Mikhail Gorbachev by the Nipponzan-Myohoji monk, Junsei Terasawa.


=== Parks/gardens ===
The Odori Park
The Nakajima Park
The Maruyama Park is located next to the Hokkaido Shrine and houses the Maruyama Zoo.
The Moerenuma Park
The Nishioka Park is a location of rich nature which centers around a pond and consists of marshland and the forest of the Tsukisamu River and its upper river basin. This park also serves as one of the main habitats in Hokkaido for many types of wild birds.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park offers great views of the city.
The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens and The Chizaki Rose Garden
The Hitsujigaoka Observation Hill has a farm with sheep and attracts visitors with a statue of William S. Clark.


=== Events/festivals ===

February: the Sapporo Snow Festival The main site is at Odori Park, and other sites include Susukino (known as the Susukino Ice Festival) and Sapporo Satoland. Many of the snow and ice statues are built by members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force.May: the Sapporo Lilac Festival. Lilac was brought to Sapporo in 1889 by an American educator, Sarah Clara Smith. At the festival, people enjoy the flowers, wine and live music.
June: the Yosakoi Soran Festival. The sites of the festival are centered on Odori Park and the street leading to Susukino, and there are other festival sites. In the festival, many dance teams dance to music composed based on a Japanese traditional song, "Sōran Bushi". Members of the dancing teams wear special costumes and compete on the roads or stages constructed on the festival sites. In 2006, 350 teams were featured with around 45,000 dancers, and over 1,860,000 people visited the festival.the Sapporo Summer Festival. People enjoy drinking at the beer garden in Odori Park and on the streets of Susukino. This festival consists of a number of fairs such as Tanuki Festival and Susukino Festival.September: the Sapporo Autumn Festival
December: Christmas market in Odori Park, similar to German Christmas markets.
From November through January, many citizens enjoy the Sapporo White Illuminations.


=== Cuisine ===

The city is known home to Sapporo Brewery, and the white chocolate biscuits 'shiroi koibito' (白い恋人), also as the birthplace of miso ramen. The Kouraku Ramen Meitengai in Susukino district, an alley lined with many miso ramen restaurants since 1951. After its demolition due to plans for the Sapporo Olympics, the Ganso Sapporo Ramen Yokocho was established in the same place. It attracts many tourists throughout the year. From the year 1966, a food company named Sanyo Foods began to sell instant ramen under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban".
Haskap, a local variety of edible honeysuckle, similar to blueberries, is a specialty in Sapporo. Other specialty dishes of Sapporo are soup curry, a soupy curry made with vegetables and chicken or other meats, and jingisukan, a barbecued lamb dish, named for Genghis Khan. Sapporo Sweets is a confectionery using many ingredients from Hokkaido and the Sapporo Sweets Competition is held annually. Sapporo is also well known for fresh seafood including salmon, sea urchin and crab. Crab in particular is famed. Many types of crab are harvested and served seasonally in Sapporo like the Horsehair crab, Snow crab, King crab, and Hanasaki crab with numerous dishes revolving around them.


=== Sports ===

The Sapporo Dome was constructed in 2001 and currently is the host to the local soccer team, Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo, the baseball team Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters and the basketball team Levanga Hokkaido.
Sapporo was selected to be the host of the 5th Winter Olympics scheduled on February 3 to 12, 1940, but Japan had to give the Games back to the IOC, after the Second Sino-Japanese War broke out in 1937.
In 1972, Sapporo hosted the 11th Winter Olympics. Some structures built for Olympic events remain in use today, including the ski jumps at Miyanomori and Okurayama. After considering a bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Olympic representatives in Sapporo have said that the city is considering a bid for the 2030 Winter Olympics. The city predicts it may cost as much as 456.5 billion yen ($4.3 billion) to host the games and is planning to have 90 percent of the facilities within half an hour of the Olympic village, according to a report published 12 May 2016. The Alpen course would be in Niseko, the world's second-snowiest resort, while the village would be next to the Sapporo Dome, the report said. The plans were presented to the Japanese Olympic Committee on 8 November 2016. In 2002, Sapporo hosted three group matches of the FIFA World Cup at the Sapporo Dome. In 2006, Sapporo hosted some games of the 2006 Basketball World Championship and also for the 2006 Women's Volleyball World Championship. In 2007, Sapporo hosted the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships at the Sapporo Dome, Miyanomori ski jump, Okurayama ski jump, and the Shirahatayama cross country course. It has been host city of two Asian Winter Games and hosted the 2017 Asian Winter Games with Obihiro. Sapporo will also host some games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
Skiing remains a major sport in Sapporo with almost all children skiing as a part of the school curriculum. Okurayama Elementary School is unusual in having its own ski hill and ski jumping hill on the school grounds. Within the city are commercial ski hills including Moiwayama, Bankeiyama, KobaWorld, Sapporo Teine and Fu's.
Many sports stadiums and domes are located in Sapporo, and some of them have been designated as venues of sports competitions. The Sapporo Community Dome, also known by its nickname "Tsu-Dome", has hosted the Golden Market, a huge flea market event which is usually held twice a year, along with some sports events. The Makomanai Ice Arena, in Makomanai Park, was one of the venues of the Sapporo Olympics in 1972. It was renamed the Makomanai Sekisuiheim Ice Arena in 2007, when Sekisui Chemical Co., Ltd., acquired naming rights and renamed the arena after their real estate brand. Other large sports venues include the Makomanai Open Stadium, Tsukisamu Dome, Maruyama Baseball Stadium, and the Hokkaido Prefectural Sports Center.
Toyota Big Air is a major international snowboarding event held annually in Sapporo Dome. As one of the richest events of its kind in the world, it draws many of the world's best snowboarders.


==== Professional sport teams ====
J.League – Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo (J1 in 1998, 2001–2002, 2008, 2012, 2017–present; J2 in 1999–2000, 2003–2007, 2009–2011, 2013–2016) .
NPB – Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters in Pacific League


== Demographics ==
The city has an estimated population of 1,957,914 as of May 31, 2019 and a population density of 1,746 persons per km² (4,500 persons per mi²). The total area is 1,121.26 km2 (432.92 sq mi).


== Transportation ==

Sapporo has one streetcar line, three JR Hokkaido lines, three subway lines and JR Bus, Chuo Bus and other bus lines. Sapporo Subway trains have rubber-tyred wheels.


=== Rapid transit ===
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Sapporo Streetcar

=== Rail ===

Hakodate Line: (Zenibako) – Hoshimi – Hoshioki – Inaho – Teine – Inazumi Kōen – Hassamu – Hassamu Chūō – Kotoni – Sōen – Sapporo – Naebo – Shiroishi – Atsubetsu – Shinrinkōen – (Ōasa)
Chitose Line: Heiwa – Shin Sapporo – Kami Nopporo – (Kita-Hiroshima)
Sasshō Line (Gakuentoshi Line): Sōen – Hachiken – Shinkawa – Shinkotoni – Taihei – Yurigahara – Shinoro – Takuhoku – Ainosato Kyōikudai – Ainosato Kōen – (Ishikari Futomi)


=== Air ===
The Sapporo area is served by two airports: Okadama Airport, which offers regional flights within Hokkaido, and New Chitose Airport, a larger international airport located in the city of Chitose 30 miles (48 km) away connected by regular rapid trains taking around 40 minutes. The Sapporo-Tokyo route between New Chitose and Haneda is one of the busiest in the world.


=== Airport shuttle, tour and charter bus service ===
An airport shuttle bus servicing all hotels in Sapporo operates every day of the year. SkyExpress was founded in 2005 and also provides transport to and from various ski resorts throughout Hokkaido, including Niseko.

Worth seeing!!! The Sapporo Beer Museum is worth taking a look. My guess it would be better if you take their guided tour. Limited things to see on your own. We weren’t able to get the guided tour as it was closed at that time.
Museum will not take you long to go round but it is interesting. The beer tasting is good. 3 beers to taste, you buy your tasting ticket at the machine (the museum is free).

The #88 bus from Odori Park got us there. Free entry and the tasting for 3 midi beers was 800¥ ($11 AUD). Very nice beer too. A number of restaurants around the place is good. I recommend booking for the flash one as it was sold out. Taxi to the Sapporo Dome to watch the Rugby

Not an operating distillery, but the iconic beer brand speaks for itself. distance to the main sapporo station is at a walkable distance otherwise a short subway ride should get you there. There are nice food places in the area as well.
Grill sheep are recommended to eat with beer.Soft and good taste. There are buffet menu with reasonable price.

Take Bus 88, at the front of Tokyu Department Store and be taken directly to the Museum. The museum is very well staged and provides English translations of the history of Sapporo Beer. The surrounding gardens are beautiful. My partner especially enjoyed the Beer tasting.

There’s nothing worthy to see here. If you come here, it’s better to go to eat in the restaurant. The food, barbecue type meal, is really delicious. So you don’t have to waste your time to enter this musium.

This is a self tour museum especially for foreign visitors and it is FOC but u gotto pay 800 yen to experience tasting 3 different type of Sapporo beer ... my favourite? I must say is the Sapporo black label!

Well sign posted. Choice of tours with the self guided tour being for free. Every exhibit has a card in English. If you wish to try any of the beers there is a ticket vending machine at the end and you hand the ticket to the barman.

Hokkaido is the birthplace of beer in Japan. Learn about the history of beer in Japan & the process of beer making here. After viewing the exhibits, one can have beer tastings at a small fee. Easy Parking & Pleasant Grounds. Worth a visit!
Learnt a lot of interesting facts about the history for Sapporo beer. Great snacks and samples of beer to try. Put on your must go to list.

Maybe we just came on the wrong day. The free tour was not very impressive and the beer hall was closed. We had a beer in the Garden Grill which was nice.

I didn't think the visit was all that. This is Japan and everything should be in Japanese, so there really wasn't very much English to read or hear for that matter. The guided tours are all in Japanese as well as are most of the displays. The beer at the end was kind of cool.

You can visit, it's free and a shuttle bus is available from and to the Sapporo station. The guide viait is only in Japanese, but everything is translated in English for the free tour. After the visit you can enjoy different beers (fares apply).

The beer museum in January takes on a magical spirit by night lit with festive lighting through the surrounding gardens! Take in the museum and then book a table at the Beer Garden Restaurant next door!

The Sapporo Beer Museum is located in a very picturesque old brewery,, and looked beautiful in the fresh white snow and clear blue skies the day we visited. We did the free tour, wandering around and finding the information available about the history of the brewery and company

Good place to walk around and know about how Sapporo beer came about. At the end of the tour, you can get a taste of the beer at the little pub. The little village around is nice to walk around too

Beautiful building, great presentation on history of sapporo beer! It was snowing when we went and the atmosphere was ambient and lovely. Beer tasting was a nice experience for someone who drank beer for first time 👍 great photo opportunities

Free tour which you can walk around the museum yourself. After that you pay to taste the beer. There are few restaurants there for BBQ lamb. Free Parking
We went for the free self tour. It was a very short one but you get to understand a lot. Please try out the Sapporo Beer: Black label

Fun museum to learn 🍺 brewery. Also you can enjoy 3 types of beer for reasonable price. Tip for foreign travelers: take 88 bus from sapppro station. Google map says is enough fool to say 20 min to walk is only way to get here.

My husband and I went on a group tour here in 2002 inconjunction with the Sapporo Ice Festival. We did the tour and had a delicious meal that we grilled at our table. The beer was fresh and delicious. Highly recommend.

I did the Japanese only tour. The paid tour. It was still good. Plenty of written material and subtitles. Plus you get to try a beer only for this tour. Good stuff. Do the tour,
Japan's oldest brewery had kept the original photos and ads. I took the self guided tour. It start at the third floor and ends on the first floor. It took about 40 minutes. Gift shop at the end.
As title mentions too many people all the time. It’s difficult to take advantage from it. All Restaurants very noisy

Tourist Attraction that located at Sapporo. The Museum offer the story how Sapporo Beer invented. The place is near Higashi-Kuyakusho-Mae Station. However if you travel with 4 people, better to get a taxi to reach the museum

very well laid out self guiding tour covers the history of the brewery. I’d always wanted to see where one of my favorite beers is brewed. Easy to get to, pleasant surroundings and a good little shop. Great fun

The museum is quiet boring, nothing really interesting. Really loved trying the different Sapporo beers , this is definetely a must

Explains how Sapporo beer was started. Very enlightening experience as you gain an insight into how this was started in 1890. Very impressive. Pity that the tasting hall was closed when we visited, otherwise we could sample some of the beers.
Nice attraction. We did not take the tour. Tasting is a paid attraction. But its a nice diversion. Kirin tour in Sendai is a cut above if you're headed that way
There isn’t really much of a museum , just sone panels to read and then you head to the bar for some beer. Which was the best part.

Came here one afternoon. Did the free tour. Plenty in English to read so not to worry. Tasting room at the end offers 3 beer flight sample which was yummy. Easy access by bus. We walked there and bussed back to our hotel, which was also fine.
A must come and must eat place when you are in Sapporo. Nice building and environment. Do not miss it. Cheers. Adam Nic Singapore

Amazing beer museum. Very detail explained the history of sapporo and beer revolution in Japan! Great taste of sapporo beer from the early stage to the recent .

Worth a look to see the Beer history of Japan , you need to book your restaurant here as well the gardens are very pretty at night it looked like a white Christmas when I was here in March

Beer fan or not, this place is a must see! The old brick building is beautiful! Gives the history in multi-languages, without your needed. And there is beer tasting options at the end and juice too.

Lovely building nice place to visit, as we are there during winter the snow cover the whole place make it very beautiful. But the museum does not have much to offer, just a place to hang out if you a Sapporo beer fan.

A floor of museum depicting the history of Sapporo beer, and if you are into Sapporo beer jelly, you probably should get it from their shop cos I didn’t see them being sold elsewhere.

had dinner and beer at the beer garden and they served great food ! the king carb legs were so tasty and the beer was really very fresh ! highly recommended. When in Saporro, go here !

Jingshiskhan bbq meat is delicious, we took the All You Can eat buffet which includes king crab in the menu.

This museum talk about Beer History in Japan. Nice enough. The view is good... we play snow here . Easy to reach, just by bus.
Its a museum to tell you history of the beer. You pay for beer tasting. They do have buffet. We spent less than 30mins and left.

Interesting place to visit with a vibrant environment. A visit to the museum follow by drink and dine then complete the visit rounding the garden full of lighting with the kids give me the feeling of living in a mansion. The museum might be hard to navigate if you are not on

Sapporo is a world wide recognised beer, It is a beautiful old building and a must to take a guided tour of this brewery. Enjoy some beer!!!

Nice museum with great and tasty beer for your sampling .. Love the history of sapporo beer -makes me want to drink all the beers over the years...

Get to know the history of the beer and a little of Japan. You can see the first ads which are very interesting. But the best part is the dinner at Bier Garten afterwards!

The place is stunning especially when lighting. Grilled lamb and king crab ended with melon - Yummy !! Good service from staff.

mostly there are for dinner buffet which I didn't attend. museum was just a one floor with a few panel but it's free. and some beer tasting (200yen per glass). doesn't really understand how it's a museum.

its a self guided free museum (with a option to pay for a guided tour, but only in Japanese). in the end you can buy tickets for beer sampling. there are many restaurants on site.
not much to see, quite small display on offer, really the food options was better either fine dining or the beer garden for some Japanese bbq.

This place is about 30-35mins walk from Sapporo Station. Entrance is free unless you want to pay for a guided tour. Shows you some history of Sapporo Beer. First floor feature a gift shop as well as drinking place.

Visit the brewery and taste the freshly brewed beer! We did not take any guided tour since we have young kids with us. The exterior of this place are really nice photo spots too. Too bad, we were still full from our lunch, if not we would want to try the BBQ lamb and pork!
You enter in the history of a antique sugar factory transformed in a brewery and how contribute with the local economy.

A great place to go to know the history of Sapporo Beer - Sapporo City's own beer. There's a tasting room at the end of the museum wherein you can buy different kinds of beer for tasting.

really like taste 3 types of sapporo beer in one times. beer lover must come to visit this place, definitely will recommend to my friend who plan to go hokkaido :)

Visiting the Sapporo beer museum while in Sapporo is a must. The Sapporo beer garden offers nice lunch with local Hokkaido specialty and fresh draft beer. The museum is a good illustration of the famous Sapporo beer company.

Great to walk around the museum - very beautiful in the snow. The food was very average compared to everywhere else we'd eaten in Japan.

This was a great way to spend a late afternoon. The history of this infamous beer is displayed in a fun and interactive way. The tour is free. Afterward we ended the tour at the pub which is conveniently located at the end of the tour. The pub has a great atmosphere.

Easy to access, interesting to visit, nice food, albeit production lined, of necessity with the number of visitors and good beer.

great tour of how Sapporo beer came to be. The history and story were very informative and the pub to have beer tastings was a great way to end it.

It was a memorable trip for our family. Heard so much about it from friends and relatives who visited Sapporo. We got to know the history of Sapporo beer from the informative artifacts and write-ups. The beer at the end of the trip was a must-have.

This is an awesome place. It gives you the whole history and origin of Sapporo Beer and how it progressed through time. There is a place you can enjoy beer and buy souvenirs on the lower level too. Nice!

Traces the history of the famous Sapporo Beer. The history of Sapporo Beer mirrors the progress of Sapporo itself. The fun part is a the end of the tour, for a small fee, one gets to savour 3 types of Sapporo Beer. Must try Sapporo Classic - which is only available in Sapporo.
Went here and spent some time wandering around the grounds. Really interesting and worth a visit. Great restaurants on site too and a giant Xmas tree if you are there in Winter.

The museum is fairly difficult to get to as the only public transport there is by bus. Walking from the JR Sapporo Station is possible but will take you about 20 minutes, longer during winter. The Premier Tour is only available in Japanese. Foreigners would have to make do

We visited the place at night for the traditional Japanese BBQ where Sapporo beer was served. Meat and vege were served mainly. We had a pleasant dinner at the place.

Snowing heavily when we arrived? We had a tradional Japanese BBQ where used BBQ plates set into the table and cooked our own meat and veg, washed down with the local Sapporo Beer.very pleasant time had by all and food was good.checked out the museum, not big on museums and this

If you are a beer lover, this a place for you. Besides of the museum, there is a mongolian grill restaurant, with a great variety of beers.

When I went there, the main building was closed and I was a bit disappointed. However, I suggest to go there around meal time. There are very good Sapporo food restaurants.

A small and interesting beer museum. Tour took about 20 minutes. The high light was beer tasting at the end. Must visit for persons that love good beer. They had a garden, restaurants and shop next door.
Beer Museum is nice and educational. But take it as a short tour within Sapporo, not one to plan the trip around with

Great time with great mates-great prices too for lovely beer and an awesome range of it. Very informative history that leaves you wanting a taste even if you didn't start out as as so! Definitely recommend this to beer lovers all over! Do the all you can eat and drink too for

nice to see, very well done. worth the detour or the walk to. Did not try the restaurant, but tried the various beers.

Free admission, museum on the top floor, shop and restaurant at the ground floor, shopping mall nearby😬 what more can you ask for😄

when we came it almost close, just 10 minute to close so we didnt really come to the inside of the museum but we went to the cafe tried their beer and cheese and it was delicious. its a worth to try place

Yummy Draft beer (Sapporo Classic) and Lamb for dinner. You'll have to grill/cook it yourself. You'll smell like smoke after. But it was fun. They have beer halls like in Munich.

One of the place must visit for beer lovers. A place where it provides knowledge of beer and brewing. Its free admission but for beer tasting you need to purchase. There are three types of beer - black label , classic and Kaitakushi beer.

Learn about history of Sapporo beer. English guide is available at information counter. Also you can try their product downstairs.
Very convenient to take bus from Sapporo subway station. Although we are not really a beer lover, but worth to visit. Overall not bad at all

Good to visit if you would like to know a bit about Sapporo Beer history. Enjoy the beer which come with cheese! The surrounding was nice to walk about. Do some research about the tourist shuttle, it will be very useful to go around.
Sapporo Beer is one of my definite favorite beers and visiting the well put together museum and exhibits was really cool! Theres even a beer tasting area and a beer pouring demonstration.
A nice place but the information and history would only interest beer lovers. The visit also ends with beer in the nice cafe and shop.
Very well maintained museum tells the history of beer in the country replica of the old factory the museum has end tables and beer sales and souvenir shop

the museum is a bit confusing bcos we get down to sapporo beer mall instead of sapporo beer museum. the place is awesome and we learn a lot. we tried the 3 main local best beer in sapporo and we really enjoy it. the museum in near to sapporo train station.

Great old building with museum that was fun & informative. Able to do taste testing. Shops & food outlets.

A v. comprehensive museum about the history of Sapporo beer. With English subtitles. The beer tasting set is value for money.

Basically a place to eat. Lots of very busy, booked up restaurants in the old Sapporo factory. There's also a museum for beer if you're into that. No bars though, so if you want a Sapporo, you'll need to eat as well.

very interesting place. You can taste different types of beers. you can see how it all starts at Sapporo. big collections of cans Sapporo beer

This place is lots of fun. Museum itself is small but to the point. Beer tasting place downstairs is nice and very well organised. Each beer comes with either cheese or cracker.

This was really a great place to visit in Sapporo. If you're interested in Beer production and history, plus want to taste some cheap freshly brewed beer, definitely worth a visit! And its free to go! :)
Even though I have been to several beer museums, I was interested in Japanese beer history. I could understand the whole history, see the old factories and machines, and enjoy beer at last.
I been here in April.There were Sakura Blossom in front of the Museum. I tried all kind of Beer that they had. It was amazing. I can't believe that I spent time drinking beer here for 2 hours.

No:1 Beer must try and if not you had not come the Japan Hokkaido. Drink it as it is smooth to reach your Stomach.GOOOOD
Great place to meet with friends and have a Japanese BBQ with fresh beer. It shows some old tools and instruments used before for brewing beer.

One place you will never be bored with.Great place to gather facts about Sapporo beer from the horses mouth so to speak.Never for the faint-hearted if you get my drift.

Service is very good. We can know the history of beer industry in JP

Walk through the museum to glance through the history of Sapporo beer but because most things are in Japanese you might not get as much out of it unless there is an English tour. The highlight no doubt was at the end when you are directed to the shop and beer tasting area.

We arrived around 6:30pm, meaning we had missed the tours (apparently only in Japanese anyway). We payed 3800yen for all you can eat GenghisKhan and all you can drink beer for 100minutes. The atmosphere was awesome and we all had the best night. Go with friends and an empty

An interesting place to visit and can learned about beer making process. The best collection of beer advertisements. You can test three types of beer at the museum for reasonable price. No need of any advance reservation. Very little explanations are available in English.

Did a tour of the brewery museum after a brisk mile walk from my hotel. Lovely old brick building, and attractive tasting room and gift shop. Then got to experience Jingisukan cooking. Here on business and made a nice break.
We went here while in Sapporo for the snow festival. We had a fantastic lunch in the bier garden, and then toured the museum. The architecture and layout of the museum was stunning.

This is a beautiful building. very picturesque from the outside. The museum is free and very interesting with a lot of historical photographs and artifacts. No English, although they provide a brief overview of each section in a handout. You have a choice of tasting at the end

Great place to check out the history of Sapporo Beer and enjoy refreshing beers before leaving. Thoroughly enjoyed the layout of the museum and liked the tasting plate of beers which was a good price.

This museum tells the story of Sapporo Beer. Most information is in Japanese only, but there's an English guide that you can refer to. If you speak some Japanese, try and get in on one of the tours, as they were quite informative and enjoyable. My friend didn't speak any, but
Great way to spend a few hours. Not as much english translation as I would have liked. Nice beer sampling service and delicious restuarants.

I went here with a friend during the 66th Sapporo Snow Festival and had a great time. The only gripe I have is the lack of better ventilation in the main dining hall. You make your own food but the smoke was overwhelming at times. Would go again if I am back in Sapporo.

When we paid for the entrance fee, we were given some information sheets in English. The numbers on the paper correspond with the numbers next to the exhibits. The history of setting up the brewery and its operation through century was interesting to read. There is also a

As with any other museum, Sapporo Beer Museum is a place where Sapporo showcases the history of Sapporo Beer. It is located off the city fringe, so driving is recommended. There is ample parking, and there is a supermarket beside the location, so this makes a convenient

The building has 2 floors of photos, historical info, posters, adverts, etc. We were given information sheets in English. They provide Japanese speaking guided tours only. Sapporo beer is average. You can buy a tasting set of 3 glasses of beer for 500 yen.
Sapporo Beer Garden well worth a visit even if you don't drink beer the BBQ food is excellent, service A1 value for money
I think the title said it all. A must go for all the beer lovers. You can never question the service Japanese provides.

This was really the only thing we did in our short Sapporo stop and I am so glad we did. The tour starts with two floors of Sapporo beer history - photos, models, information, beer labels and advertisements. All in Japanese, but on entry we were given a brochure in English and a

If you're looking for more western influenced architecture among Japanese businesses, this factory has it all. You can spend a good amount of time walking around the old factory and museum but don't expect to learn much on the tour within the museum (if you are trying to catch
The space is not very big and the English translation is provided on a one page paper. There is free guided tour in japanese though. At the end of the tour, your can buy ice cream to try.

Nice little museum to visit in the middle of the blizzard in mid December 2014. Learn about the history of the brand. Cheap beer for purchase and tasting at the end of the tour. Somehow the beer tasted better here in the museum than when purchased elsewhere! Hic!
Noisy but very nice. The beer Garden is large and has a great feel to it. do it yourself cooking is a great way to fill in time while have a couple of Sapporo's' great beers

Its a great place for beer-lovers. It gives the first hand information on history of the best beer brewing method and the development of the best brewery in Japan. The collection items of historical and evolving beer Sapporo captures the mind and takes you for a tour through
Free entry and an enjoyable history of Japanese beer making, plus the opportunity to taste the various Sapporo beers for a small fee in the tasting room, with some beer snacks.

First, building and chimney catch your eyes. You can learn the history of Sapporo Beer, even if you are not curious for such a thing, maybe just walking around and taking picture are very interesting.

There is no entry fee to get inside the building and you work your way down from the 3rd floor to the ground floor passing through some historical facts of Sapporo beer's beginnings. You can sample the beers at a nominal fee and can also buy some souvenir items. The place is

The design of this building is amazing. However it is free and easy tour. No work in progress, just history. Unlike Kirin Beer Factory, this is just a museum. ¥500 for three types of Sapporo Beer, good price and good value. Nice and friendly staffs. However business time is from

Was a little bit far from the station but I liked it! Near was a mall and had a lot of options of food and souvenirs, you can eat in the museum but I didn't know, taste the special beer of the museum was delicious, taste it. They had traductor machine for tours

we walk from our hotel to the museum which is about 30 minutes from JR Sapporo station. the place is really nice with their history and all the old beers bottles and designs. the most interesting part is at the end of the visit where visitors are allow to try their beer for a

While hubby went for the trio beer where you could try the three types of beer produced there, I decided to try the beer ice cream which made for a refreshing snack for the afternoon. We did the self tour around the place which detailed the history of Sapporo beer and its

The Sapporo Beer Museum is located about a 30 minute walk from the JR Sapporo station. Not really worth taking a train here as the nearest station is a similar distance away. Attractions include a tour of the factory (only in Japanese though) and beer tasting. All the museum

Third time I've been to Sapporo and third time I've been back to the beer museum! You never get sick of the stories the exhibits tell. You definitely don't get sick of the 'tasting portions' of Sapporo beer, of which some are exclusive or difficult to find outside of Hokkaido.

Free to get in you are immediately directed onto a walking tour depicting the history and making of Sapporo beer. We found the museum lacking in substance and actually a bit boring other than the room of posters depicting advertising campaigns through the ages. Finally you come
No entrance fee, cheap (and really delicious) beer, and English provided. What more could you ask for? I definitely have new respect and appreciation for Sapporo beer.
Lovely place, did not charge for entrance. All you do is buy a ¥500 token from the machine and enjoy sampling the beer

The Museum is a don't miss and the like most of Japan, they know how to preserve their history and heritage. Beautiful buildings and grounds. Don't miss the Sapporo Bier Garden and the Ghengis Kahn dinner!

I visited this 'museum' on one of the last snowy days in early April and I must admit that our initial reason and motivation for going was to sample the beer. In fact, the old factory grounds and building have been well preserved and the small exhibition on the history of the

First up, we considered not going due to previous reviews mentioning no English tours. Confident in my Japanese ability, we went anyway. I needn't have worried. When we got there we were given English translations of each display. I found it much more pleasant to go at my
It was interesting, bug if you have been to a beer museum or factory previously, it's quite similar. The beer ice-cream though was a nice experience xP

Having read the previous reviews, I knew what to expect, but went anyway. I had to. Who, from America, goes to Sapporo and doesn't go on the beer tour? It was the only thing on my checklist for Sapporo after spending 2 weeks of snowboarding up in the mountains. It's

The museum tour is free and the main hall showcases the making of beer in a very cute way by using figurines. Unfortunately the explanation was all in Japanese and you need to refer to another document provided by the staff. You can taste their beer but they only have 3 types

Beer lovers should not miss this place. The place showcases the history and developments of Sapporo Beer, one of the leading beers in Japan. It is not a grand museum but you will enjoy it. I personally like those vintage posters at the grounds.

I went here as part of a group tour, but think it may be better to go on your own - apparently it isn't that hard to get to on the subway system. The tour guide we had was fantastic and explained everything with enthusiasm that was delightful to see. At the end of the tour you

So basically the japanese took the german brewing systems and copied them, making them more efficient. This created Sapporo Brewery! Its not very historical but its worth a visit none the less. The highlight would have to be the table bbq and all you can drink for 3 hours for a

The museum was a waste of time. There is nothing to see except some photos. Everything in Japanese. Beer garden next door worth a visit if you like BBQ. There is a Genghis Khan BBQ where you can have eat all you can lamb and drink all you can beer for 3700+¥. There is a mall
google: Good place for taking photos. Currently closed due to Covid-19. You should check on the website before you go

Excellent place to visit. Sapporo is not one of my favourite beers but after a visit to the distillery I may just start getting their black version which was good. After the visit to the museum we went to their lilac restaurant and ordered …

Love the all-you-can-eat menu.
Just remember to bring extra clothes for the smell will stick quite well in your clothes. The place is picturesque as well. Really recommended. The soft serve at the nearby shop is also good to try.

Sapporo beer is one of the oldest beer and most popular brand in the country. Brewing since 1877. The admission to the museum is free. At the end of the exhibit, beer tasting are available for a small fee. But if you want a guided tour they …

Very informative about the history of Sapporo Beer. The staff are really friendly and easy walking around the museum by ourselves without any charge.  Whilst all the display are information are in Japanese, there are useful English cards in …

Last orders for beer tasting is at 6.30pm so be sure to be there early. Made reservations on the spot for the Genghis beer hall, waited for around 30 mins to get a table. Really nice tasting meat, in particular the pork and chicken. Awesome …

The Sapporo Beer Museum is located in a very picturesque old brewery,, and looked beautiful in the fresh white snow and clear blue skies the day we visited. We did the free tour, wandering around and finding the information available about …

Museum itself was free. You only have to pay for the beer you want.  You have to take the elevator and stay on the 3rd floor and walk your way down through the museum. You have to go to a ticket machine to order your beer. Some of the informational stuff are in English. So that was nice.

The Sapporo beer factory. Enjoy a nice tour of the museum or do it for free. After getting through the museum they have a gift shop and a beer tasting section. Their beers are quite good and I happen to like their original brand which is …

Quite an informative tour( they have cards printed in English) about the history of Sapporo beer. The tour is free which is a bonus. If you wanted the 'premium tour' you pay 500¥ per person. There's an opportunity to do beer tasting- x3 …

Nice architecture and outdoor surroundings are good for pictures too. Entrance is free unless you decide to join the tour that includes 2 glasses of beer. We wanted to do so but later found out it was conducted in Japanese.

As a traditional museum leaves a lot to desire. But as an overall experience lovely. The premium tour is fine as an English person you just need to rent the audio guides (500 yen). Premium tour includes 2 drinks of the original recipe and the classic which you can't get outside of Hokkaido.

It’s a MUST, if you are in Sapporo even if you don’t drink. It’s a very iconic beer brand. The campus itself is quite big and they offer different restaurants at different locations (within the campus itself). The entrance to the museum is …

Great place to learn the history of the brand and taste some of the wares.  The guided tour is only in Japanese, but if you are planful you can download guide.  The sampling is a nice finish, but if you are headed to the Bier garden you could skip it.  The building is gorgeous and tasting how beer making has changed was interesting.
Please note that the Museum is temporarily closed to due a member of staff being infected with COVID-19.
The Beer Museum was the most fun I had in Sapporo! There's so much to learn and the beer is very tasty. If you're in the area Id highly recommend visiting the Museum

The museum provided great historical interpretation of the Sapporo beer factory and it's beer. I felt like they did a great job of connecting the production of beer with larger trends of globalization and modernization.

Not to be missed is …

Very cool place. If your into beer an your in Sapporo. This is a must visit place. You have a choice of free or paid tour. Free will take about 30 mins to walk around while the paid is a 50 min tour with a guide. At then of the tour, head …

Should try these fresh beers!
For me Sapporo Black was the best!

Classic had a bit light texture and Kaitakushi was less refreshed than black. But these threes were awesome! 
There is a complimentary snack for each bill. So it is simply …

Very good museum, had lots of information to browse and learn about, and highly well-maintained. Good visit! I would definitely recommend the tasting set, just because it was interesting to be able to try the three different kinds of beer. …
Nothing to add beyond what the others have already. The taster set is real nice and you can chill out at the tables for a while. Make sure to check out the store for their old school cup design
This place is lit. Amazing experience. Superb souvenirs. The private tour was not available today, but the free was good.

Interesting displays and stories about the beer and the brewery. There is an opportunity to taste some beers (and cheese if you like!) for a small fee - it was fairly quick for us but it looks like it can get very busy. Gift shops are fun and there are some more formal eating options.
Really fantastic place, a lot of history and a fantastic restaurant here. Must stop if you are in the area.

Great place to visit and have super delicios jingisukan - lamb yakiniku, four stars are because there’s a lot of  smoke in the restaurant, so they should invest in proper fans to filter the air inside the restaurant 
You can order all- you- …

Beautiful building, a good sense of the beer history of Sapporo and Japan.

Some great old as advertising posters from 1908 to today were on display, that was pretty cool, apparently geisha love beer. 

The beer hall with the BBQ was very smokey, a bit of ventilation improvement required.

This is the place to visit and enjoy if you love beer; and want to know more about Sapporo beers history. The museum is  clean and punctual, staff are friendly and helpful, and the beer tasting area is outstanding! I recommend the sampler platter, with the "premium cheese".  If you're in the area, make this place a must!

It's a must do thing on the list when visiting Sapporo. I did the free beer drinking event and also made some great fellow international friends on the tour. Then we went drinking afterwards!^^

I was during the week but I heard it can get crowded during weekends. Something to watch out for!

Wonderful place to see some historical beer artifacts. The tasting area is nice, and the cheese is awesome to get with a flight of Sapporo. Only nitpick is that there's not a cheaper place to enjoy Genghis Khan, which is the local dish.

The premium guided tour is completely in Japanese, although they do have an English audio guide (need to wear headphones).

You can also just wander around the museum by yourself but the "exhibits" are mostly just pictures and words. 

The bar downstairs is nice though. You can buy a taster set and compare the beers.
Last orders in the beer hall are 6:30pm, nice cheap beer tasting tray that comes with a packet of nuts. Free tour is good, lots to see. Fully recommend, but come before 6pm to enjoy it properly.

A traditional and historical  Place for Beer Lovers.The Museum is very interresting and The area around the factory too.The Entry is for free and you can Make a Beer tasting if you Like  and they have a small Museum Shop inside.The best for …

Beautiful old building. museum is appropriately brief, yet interesting with enough English to accommodate non-Japanese speakers. Note: last beer sale is 630PM, and the tasting room closes at 7PM, so "bottoms up!"

[Please "like" if you find this review helpful]

The beautiful Sapporo beer museum and grounds make for a delightful time. Try the premium yebisu dark stout while you're here. There are a number of restaurants and tasting areas in the vicinity, all associated with the museum. A Mongolian BBQ can be had at a couple. Well worth pairing with the dark stout
Nice museum with English explanation. Next to a big shopping mall too. The tasting set of 3 beers is a must try, comes with a free small pack of nuts.

Interesting place. You can visit this place for free and learn about Sapporo beer. The history of the advertisement used for the beer is also quite interesting. You can also taste three different kinds of beer here for 800 yen.
Went here to try the famous genghis khan BBQ lamb. It was almost full for lunch, great place for lamb lover

Beautiful factory with an interesting museum. There are English paper guides at each section as well as many other languages. They have a beer tasting at the end of you for you to try. 

There are also many nearby restaurants for you to try after your tour so plan on having dinner or lunch nearby!
Awesome place to chill with family and friends. BBQ need to reserve in advance, and Sapporo beers are light and tasty...in winter
Great trip walked from they centre of Sapporo to check this place out worth a visit!

Museum self guided tour is quick and quite lacking in English commentary or content. At the end there is an optional tasting and probably the best part to put the palate to the test. Would be a much better visit if some sort of audio guide was provided for English speakers/listeners.

Nice and beautiful place, there are many trees inside this area. The museum shows a lot of information about history of Sapporo beer. There’s a small place on the ground floor that sells sample beers for visitors (3 kinds of most famous …

It's a pretty, old building, and the information is rather neat. They have little English guides next to the displays that show the information. The free tour still gives you the opportunity to go down and buy some beer to try. It's nice considering the tour is free and the taste set is ¥800 for three different beers.

We did the "free" version of the tour because we were short on time. It took us about 15 minutes to go through the exhibits and then we had three sampler Sapporo Beers. We hope to return and do the guided tour next time. Highly recommended!

Nice beer museum at the site of Sapporo Beer factory. The factory had been built since Meiji period. There are several restaurants where you can have all you can drink Sapporo beer and fine grill lamb. Popular among visitors and local residents.

Honestly not impressive for tourists, the Sapporo Beer Museum was relatively small. 

Posters and bottles of different generations was the only attraction, but exhibits for brewing machinery were rather limited. No free trial unless you …

800 Yen for 3 (bigger than I thought) tasters of the three main beers produced by Sapporo, not bad. The museum had free admission and it had some interesting readings if you look at the English sheets that are located on the sides of each numbered stand. Took about 30 minutes to walk through the free admission area and read everything.

Nice place, the free visit is enough I guess, mostly signs to read about history of Sapporo beer, labels and bottles. The building itself worth the visit. You can have a taste of different beers at the end (~300¥ each, 800¥ for 3 different lagger, which weren't "that" different).

Not much to see, the guided tour is only conducted in Japanese so no use for foreigners.

But the fresh beer sampler at 800 yen for three drinks saves the day.

A small museum showing the history of Sapporo beer, the main selling point and what you should try are the 3 exclusive taster beers they offer that you can't find anywhere else. Those beers are some of the best I have ever tried.

Have a look around the rest of the museum as well.
Why not visit cause it's free! English translations are available. A beautiful site.

Good museum, beer, and food.

Museum was pretty quick without a tour guide (English speaker so lots of the exhibits I could only reason I a bit).

At the cafeteria you buy drinks from the ticket booth and bring it to the counter and they …
Don’t really got a chance to go to their museum yet cuz i came too late. But at least I got to try their beer flight before a flight back to reality after my long weekend.

A very interesting museum to learn more about Sapporo beer! You can reach the place with a public bus or even walk from downtown Sapporo (took us about 20+ minutes walking). You can choose to join a tour or go around the museum yourself. …
"There is a Beer Museum?! Let's go there!" - No regrets

Museum took 20 minutes including reading every word. 

Arrived at 18:15 since it closed at 20:00. 
Found out that Tasting bar at the end takes last orders at 18:30. Restaurants were 90 minute wait. 
No where you could buy a Sapporo after …
With English, mandarin and Korean translations. Pity the taste hall is closed today

Surprisingly deep free tour and delicious tastings - we didn't expect much but the free tour exhibits all have English translation cards next to them and teach you all about Hokkaido's development since the late 1800s.

The tastings at the …

text.wiki:
Moerenuma Park (モエレ沼公園, Moerenuma Kōen) is a municipal park in Sapporo, Japan. It has playground equipment, outdoor sports fields, and objects that are designed by Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese American artist. Visitors can enter the park and use the parking lot for free. Construction began in 1988; the park opened in 2005. It won a number of awards including the Good Design Award in 2002.


== History ==
Before the construction of Moerenuma Park, the place has been used as a garbage reclaimed ground since 1979. Under the Sapporo Circular Greenbelt Concept, a city planning project that aims at developing the urban areas of Sapporo with greenbelts and parks, construction began in 1982. Sapporo asked Isamu Noguchi to design the park.
Noguchi's first visit to Sapporo was in March 1988, when the place was still used as a reclaimed ground in part. Impressed with the landscape and the northern skyline, Noguchi contracted the offer from Sapporo government and made the master plan of the park, which includes the concept of "park that is considered to be one complete sculpture." On December 30 in the same year, however, right after making a miniature model of the planned park, Isamu Noguchi died of heart failure in New York City, and the park was constructed with his master plan from 1989.
In 1990, land reclamation of garbage was totally closed. It had 71.2 ha and 2,736,000 tons of garbage carried to the place until 1990.In 1997, Moerenuma Park made a park twinning agreement with the Bayfront Park in Miami, United States. The park won the Good Design Award in 2002, 11th Sapporo Urban Scenery Award in 2003, and Hokkaidō Red Brick Architectural Award in 2004. The park was partly open during construction, and on July 1, 2005, the entire construction was completed (although it was initially planned to be complete in 2004). The Sapporo international art festival was held in 2014 and 2017.


== Outline ==
The name "Moerenuma" (Moere marsh) is derived from the word "Moyre pet" in Ainu language, which means "a slowly flowing river." Moere marsh was in the place long before the park was constructed. The official name of the marsh is Shinoro New River. It is said that river was made because of perpetual flood in the past. It currently connects to the Kariki New River. The Moere marsh is surrounding the whole area of the park ground.
The entire area of the park is 1,888,000 m² including the Moere marsh, coming to a total cost of 27 billion yen. The park has 120 pieces of playground equipment, about 3,000 cherry trees, and the parking lots holds 1,500 vehicles. The construction is mainly supervised by Isamu Noguchi Foundation and George Sadao.
The biggest symbol of the park is a glass pyramid near the eastern entrance. The pyramid has the nickname "Hidamari", which means "sunny spot" in Japanese. The nickname was given in 2002 and selected from 2,340 applications. With a floor space of 5,328 m², the pyramid has three floors and a roof overlooking a large part of the park. The top floor houses the gallery of Isamu Noguchi and the miniature model of the park. A restaurant and museum shop are on the ground floor. The pyramid has an air conditioning system to cool down inside in summer, using snow stored in a neighbouring storage building during winter. Hidamari is also used for workshops and events including the Prestigious International Conference on Music and Perception with a concert by John Kaizen Neptune in 2008 in the rooms on the ground and second floors.
The Tetra Mound, an object with triangle stainless steels (one of the creations of Isamu Noguchi) is placed in the western side. Several events have been held in the square close by. The Mt. Moere occupies large part of the park. It is 62 metres high, which enables visitors to overlook the landscape of the park and northern part of the Sapporo city. More playground equipment is near the Forest of Cherry Trees and the Moere Beach, which is a shallow pond open during summer.
A 150-metre canal, the Aqua Plaza, is in the centre of the park, and the Sea Fountain is constructed near the canal. The fountain reaches 25 meters high when it jets out, and it is closed during winter. The monument called Music Shell is used as the musical venue. It is shaped to imitate two shells swelling up from the ground — as the name indicates.
The park contains sports grounds such as a tennis court, baseball field and athletic field. These are opened from April to November. Registration to use these facilities is required at the management office. Visitors can rent bicycles. In winter, as some facilities in closed; people can enjoy cross-country skiing in the park instead. Courses are set up, which enable visitors to view objects in the park whilst skiing. Cross-country skiing equipment is lent at the office in the glass pyramid.


== Nearby ==
Close to Moerenuma Park, there is the Sapporo Satoland — a theme park focusing on agriculture and one of the venues of the Sapporo Snow Festival. The Sapporo Community Dome, an indoor stadium which is often used as a venue for some sports events, and the Okadama Airport are close to the park.


== Access ==
Hokkaido Chuo Bus (Higashi69 or Higashi79): 25 minutes from Kanjō-Dōri-Higashi Station (Tōhō Line) to 'Moere Koen Higashiguchi' bus stop, then a 10-minute walk to the Glass Pyramid.


== Sources ==


== External links ==
official site
Moerenuma Park - Land + Living (in English)
Moerenuma Park - Images
text.quote: Innovative park designed by sculptor Isamu Noguchi, with a museum, wading pool & playgrounds.
trip: Visited with family Pros: 1) This park can be reached via train and bus. Ensure to read and understand the directions carefully because it can be confusing. 2) Best to visit with a full stomach and bring some drinks and snacks. My family and I visited right before lunch,

The park can be reached by riding a train from Sapporo Station and a bus. Travel time is less than an hour. The park is filled with man made features like Mount Moere a 62 meters tall and offers great views of the park and the surrounding area and a Louvre like pyramid

The spacious park includes art installents, hilld, many walking and cycling trails and and much more. Cycling is the best option. It offers great views of the city if you climb to the top of the hills.

Got here in the evening, so only managed to visit the pyramid, and walk around a little. The pyramid is beautiful, with lovely views from the top. The park is also lovely, with lots of sculptures, if only I had more time.

We went here by city bus and got lots of help from fellow passengers to find it. it is one of our most prominent memories of sapporo, and indeed of japan in general. do NOT miss the fountain show, preferably the one that occurs after dark.

This is a huge public park and we wanted to visit the different attractions like the fountain, the hill and the Glass Pyramid. We underestimated our time. We came to the park around 4pm and by the time we walked up to the top of the hill, it was sunset already. The walk up

This spot is far from the center of Sapporo city, it takes 50-minutes by the train and local bus. From the nearest bus stop 'Toyohata' it's a 15-minute walk to the center of the park. In this park, there are white birch trees, artificial hills and a pyramid of glass. You can
This park took my breath away. It was quiet when I visited the park and it was so calming to walk around. Viewpoints from some sculptures were breathtaking. I would go back here in a heartbeat!
Landscape park, the territory is pretty big, so it's a lot of walking or you can rent a bike on site. If you want to see it all - be ready to climb a lot of stairs.

This park is famous as great sculptures park designed by Isamu Noguchi. I love this park since when I was child. It has beautiful mountains, sculptures and playgrounds For children. Unbelievably the entrance fee is nothing. Just free! A little bit far away from Sapporo

This is a sculpture park designed by the American born artist of world renown; Isamu Noguchi. there are kids play areas, and fountain shows long and short (30 min and 15 min), there are also 30 tennis courts and a sports field. Built upon a landfill dump in a swamp, this is
Such a chill place, with beautiful scenic views. Had lots of fun cycling around!! The tranquility I’ve experienced is one that I can never forget.

My fiance and I went here for sightseeing. We wanted to see snow on this area, however, most of the snow has melted because we visited in the closing month for winter season. Nevertheless, the views are great and fresh air awaits. We had alovely time while walking around.

Wonderful, unique park dedicated to a talented artist. Went with my wife, sister, and mother who all enjoyed the experience for the landscape design and overall visit. We’ve been to the Noguchi studio museum in Long Island City, NY and love his aesthetic and work. This is even

The highlight of my trip to Sapporo. What a thoughtfully built park which engages all your senses! This is not to be missed even thought it is not easy to get to and not very clear to get instructions on either. I would recommend a taxi but given that Taxis are super
This park is okay for a bike ride or view from the top of the hill. The best part is the fountain, which sprays in various patterns.
This by far is one of my favorite places in Sapporo. It's a train, bus & a lot of walking away outside Sapporo but you're patience will be rewarded. Beautiful park!

The first impression of the park from the internet was a cool looking park designed by Isamu Noguchi. Once I enter the park, I was delighted to find out that you can rent a bike to ride in the park. This park was huge with a few architectures to see. But for me, as I was

We rented the inexpensive bikes at the park (200 yen for 2 hours) and took a self-guide tour through the park. Though we are average-sized, the bikes were too small. The birch forest to the west of the main entrance were breath-taking, the highlight of our visit

We rented a bike for ¥200/2hours and it worthed every pennies of it. The landscape, clean air, relaxing atmosphere we could just escape from all the routine in our life momentarily. The restaurant inside the pyramid was a perfect setting. Close to Sapporo Sato Land Farm Park
The place is nice, can ski very heavy snow. Like the environment, not far just need sit they city bus to reach. Many people come here for ski.

For 200yen you can hire a bike for two hours to ride around the park, which is highly recommended as it's such a huge park to cover by foot. Weather permitting, it's quite a relaxing half day in a very calm setting.

Free to enter. We rented bikes at very reasonable rate (200 yen for 2 hours) at the entrance and helped to move around, which saved our energy for walking up to various higher grounds for most charming views around. We enjoyed the 15 minutes fountain show. Check the schedule
The place is bigger than I expected, and so green! The Isamu Noguchi Glass Pyramid is a must see. Can trail up to grass hills/slopes, nice small hikes. Lovely in summer!

They have bike rentals for 200 yen and I learned how to bike here while admiring the architectural structures around the park! Great place for families to spend an afternoon in the park and to get a great view of Sapporo from the hills here.
