It’s an iconic tower. Good for picture taking but nothing special about it in particular. LOL. It’s very accessible from Sapporo Station. I personally think it looks lovelier during winter time because of the illumination and snow effect. LOL.
You must visit the observation deck of this tower if you want to get the iconic view of Odori Park. Plenty of things to do around the area as well especially with the snow festival going on.

This is a great place to start a trip to Sapporo. We went up today to see the Snow Festival site and the stunning views of the surrounding hills, including the Winter Olympic ski jump. The weather was clear. It would be a complete waste of time if snowing or foggy. What is

Nice view up the very top over odori park ,fun to climb a few storeys steps ,good exercise but from the 3rd or 4th floor there are lifts up and then you have to decide if you want to go to the very top , entrance fee it's not expensive ,a good view of Sapporo ,but not that

Like the ones in Nagoya and Tokyo, Sapporo tv tower offers a 360 view of the city with the view of odori park. In our visitz the platform was excessively heated that locals and foreigners alike day hatsui and we had to go down after a few minutes in the tower.
I would suggest to give this place a miss if it snows in Sapporo. It does give a 360 degree view of the city, but the snow flakes will obstruct the distant views as evident from my attached

Since it is located in the city centre, it makes a good focal point so you can get your bearings of what is around. There are restaurants and tourist information centre at the tower. I did not go up the viewing deck so not sure on the views from the top.

This iconic TV tower sits on the corner of Odori Park. We didn't take the elevator ride up to the top as the weather was not in our best interest. After taking the subway back to our hotel, we pulled back the curtains. And the tower was there, outside the murky, rain-washed

Nice view here too! Though is raining during my time of travel. If you are a person who enjoy City Night View the way liked I do, I would recommend this as well, go for this first before heading down to JTower 38. :) Price are the same for both. Estimated Duration: 20 mins to

The hard sell to buy unadulterated rubbish in the gift was pretty awful, but the view was amazing. Would highly suggest as a place to visit, but be ready to duck and bob the selling when you exit the elevator and try valiantly to find the exit through the gift shop.

As always with observatories, the quality of the visit is really determined by the weather, as if the view isn't up to much there's not that much else of the tower to detain your attention. But the views over the city are great if that's your thing.

The TV Tower is a veteran, it's been around since 1957. Visiting the NIppon TV Tower is as part of Sapporo as visiting the Empire State Building is part of New York. The Tower has a good all-round view, with good explanations of what you are seeing. The Tower seems to sway a
This is a landmark in the area and is on your way to the nijo market. Since you are in the area, you night as well go up and admire the view of the city. Apart from that it's nothing fancy

Sapporo TV tower was super fun! Taking the elevator up to the top and seeing Sapporo from above was fascinating. Odori park is beautiful in autumn colors! You will be able to take really great photos and I recommend this attraction for photography lovers!
Very well organised trip up to the observation deck in this tower. Staff very polite & helpful. Extremely busy tourist attraction.
Nice to have a pic at the end of Odori park. This is a centric place for restaurantes, metro, and other turistic places.
When you hear about a TV Tower you always imagine a tall building with great views. Well. This is not the case.

You will see the Sapporo TV Tower at the end of the park area and it makes for a good photo opportunity. You can take a ride to the top (for a fee) but it didn't seem worth it to me. If I was in the area from a week or more then maybe I would take the time, but not on a quick

This steel tower looks similar to the world renown Eiffel Tower in Paris, however it is much lower and it’s used as a television/communication tower and its name Sapporo TV Tower. It was built back in the 1950s in the center of the city, in the Obori town, and has an observation

This is a must visit . Even for just a photo . But visiting the observatory would be nicer. Getting a view of Odori park would be better. Their own identity to compare with the Tokyo Tv tower , Auckland sky tower or even the Eiffel Tower of Paris .
You will have to buy the tickets and then head to the elevator to go to the top. There are not many things to do at the top so this place is perfect to a short visit.
Reminds me of a small version of Eiffel tower. There are restaurants under the tower and on the mid floors. Lit up at night and a prominent landmark in Sapporo.

Must visit place in Sapporo. The Tower located along the Odori Park. It's a nice place to spend the day and relax while chit chat with friends or family. It's a walking distance place from Odori Park Station.
A must visit when you're in Sapporo. Nice tower especially if taken with beautiful flowers surrounding Odori Park in summer

My son and I went to the Sapporo TV Tower on July 15th and enjoyed the views from the observation deck. We went early and it wasn't crowded at all. The deck is a bit small, but the views from the deck are quite impressive. You can look directly up Odori Park and also look over
Called in for a beer late evening. Plenty of activity and interesting eating. Nice big glasses of cold beer.

Be warned, for those with a fear of balance or falling rather than "heights" the elevator is entirely glass walled! Had a minor panic attack going up so chose to stand dead centre and not look! Once at the top it was fine, great view of Odori Park and the city in general.
The Sapporo tower although it is not as majestic as the Paris tower but still can had a nice view from the top of the tower.

Right in the heart of Sapporo City. A must to visit. Go up and look around. Inexpensive ticket and takes 60 mins out of your schedule. Beautiful scenic and city views. Just a bit higher than the Statue of Liberty. We enjoyed our visit, especially the younger and older kids.
Actually Sapporo city is a very small city; my tour was in June so nothing much to see but shopping at Daimaru mall . weather was very nice.

Located at one end of the Odori Park in central Sapporo, this iconic tower is hard to miss. We were there on a beautiful late spring morning and it was just beautiful. The joyful atmosphere at the park made this a lively addition to the scene, even though it is a sturdy

We arrived just before sunset. Manage to get a good birds eye view of Sapporo before and after sunset. Great scenery. Recommended to photographers. The tower looks like the Eifel tower in Paris. Worth the cost of the tickets. There are souvenir shops at the viewing deck.
Hard to miss. A landmark that must visit when in Sapporo . Near to odori park and easily accessible by the underpass from the train station .
Viewed this tower in both day and night, which would provide you with different vibes. The tower viewed at night was spectacular!

One nice thing about Japan is that attractions like this are not very expensive. This one was (combi ticket with Clock tower) 800 Yen The elevator goes to the fourth floor where you have a 90 meter high view on Sapporo. The view was very clear so we could look very far. Great
Sapporo TV Tower looks like a quaint relic from another era. It is a handy landmark for navigational purposes when strolling around Sapporo.
A visit to a tower ensures on of a good view of the city ! It gives you a perspective of the whole city as it’s impossible in a short visit to see everything !

We went up to the observation deck mainly to get a view of Odori Park. It’s a small observation platform but there are small seating nooks where you can sit, relax, and enjoy the view. We enjoyed looking around Sapporo City and Odori Park but we didn’t stay too long as there
A symbol of pride for the community with historical value and a scenic view from the observation deck. We just settled at ground level because of the chilling Spring winds

Sapporo is a beautiful city, to see it from up there is just amazing. It was pretty cheap to go up, lots to see up there with 360degrees view and plenty of vending machines up there for a snack and drink. It's all about the view, was brilliant. Go up and see the city

After building a snow man at Odori park, we headed to the TV Tower to view what the park looked like from an elevated perspective. There was no rush, we could take our time to soak in the view. Where possible, when we visit a city for the 1st time, we would try to go to an
Really good view of Sapporo , you can feel the tower move in the wind , Good time to go is around Sunset , worth the money only 720 y

You must definitely visit this TV tower as it is one of the main landmark here in Sapporro. There is also lots of underground shopping you can do here as well as get up this tower to view the whole city.

We visited Sapporo TV tower at night. It is adjacent to Odori park and we enjoyed the night view from here. It was not so crowded, but you might be disappointed if you expect too much. There are some souvenir shops at the lower floor and you can select "famous" souvenirs.
It took a bit of walking to this tower from the JR Sapporo station. We only visit the floor where the souvenir shop is located. Just went there to warm up our body in a cold day.
The TV tower is ok but too expensive. I would recommend the ropecars for this as this is too costly. Do not shop here. This place is situated very near the sapporo station and the park.

Sapporo TV Tower is an iconic landmark in Sapporo, Hokkaido. Located at the Heart of Sapporo City, offering a 360 View of the city. The main view is Odori Park. The ticket price is affordable. They also do have a cafe and merchandise shop. Put this into your itinerary list while
SapporoTV tower consider is a iconic building at Sapporo. The Sapporo TV tower are located nearby Odori park.

It's a relatively small tower, and to get up the observation deck was somewhat costly. However, the TV tower has numerous photo spots, and its decoration lights was very beautiful in the evening. On the ground floor was a souvenir shop that sells chocolates and many other
Great view of the Sapporo Snow Festival at Odori Park at sunset and at night. The Festival is illuminated. You can also view Sapporo when you go around the Tower.

Recommended to go around 4.30-5pm to get day and night shots. Do expect a queue at the ticket booth. You can purchase tickets online to skip the queue. There is also a queue for the lift. Skip the queue by climbing up the stairs to go to level 3 to take the lift up the tower.

The scene from the TV Tower was beautiful, if you visit during the month of the snow festival I would recommend travelling up there to see the lights from a birds eye point! However the line up to the top is quite a bit of a wait, had to wait up to around 30 mins before I

Feels like floating when u r up there. View was fantastic, good experience. Snow festival season u could see the fantastic lights. I thought the tower would have been a bit more new. I like the tax free souvenir gift shops. Bought many stuff

Great scenery of Sapporo from the bird's eyes from observation deck floor.I went during the Snow Festival, so was great views of the snow festivsl at Odori park. Suggest you buy your ticket at a tourist information center (there are several in town and you'll save more than
Great place to see the city. Not a long wait and fairly priced at $6 a person. We went at night for a great view of the snow festival at odori park.

Great view of Sapporo from the top floor observation deck. We went during the Snow Festival, so the vista was particularly enchanting. Suggest you buy your ticket at a tourist information center (there are several in town and you'll save more than $1 per ticket). You'll find the
Nothing special but made for a nice photo in the night time when all lit up! We saw it in the day and weren’t fussed, but in the night it made a great background for a photo.

I went during the preparation of the Ice festival in Sapporo. Have a good scenic view 360 degrees of the city. Good place to get to know the city. There are some food stalls at the base during this time . A must to see Sapporo.
It is a great view from different location in the city and it is a great views from tower observation desk to see the city as well.
The TV tower is a good landmark to stop at through your walk of the Sapporo CBD, worth revisiting during the day and then at night to get a different aspect as the tower lights up.
One of the Sapporo landmarks is Sapporo TV Tower which is nice to visit there no matter day time of nice time with a panoramic of Sapporo City and Odori Park
Most people pay a visit at night but I would recommend visiting in the early hours as lesser tourists at this hour. Nice place for pictures...
Good view from any point in the city. Colorful during festive season. Showing the time led light is a good service buy it's off just after mid night.

I wasn’t sure if this was worth it, but it turned out to be a highlight. Great views of Sapporo and the surroundings. Some ways to really enjoy the tower: 1. Discounted tickets are available if you buy them from the tourist information centres. We got ours in the one enroute to

It’s a TV Tower in Odori Park if you are in the area you are gonna see it. I wouldn’t go outta your way for the tower specially but I would for Odori Park and since you are there already well.... why not take a look.

Its practically in the middle of the city of Sapporo. Build in the 1950’s. You can go to the 3rd floor to get a glimpse of what the view can offer. If you want to go to the observation desk you need to buy a ticket on the third floor. You get to see the beauty of Sapporo

Though I came here because of a tour, we came early and hence there was not much people around. Views were great and even in the elevator you could see the views as you ascent/descent. Entrance fee only applies if you want to go all the way to the top to take a look.
This tower usually arise in Gundam fighting movie😁..its has an iconic value..so we must take a photo here. You can get a good angel for this tower from inside the aqua city park.
This is one of few landmarks in Sapporo. Hence, it provides a good photo op to prove you have visited Sapporo. Otherwise, it is nothing to write home about. I did not pay to ascend the tower.
We didn't pay to enter - thought it was rather pricey. From level 3 (free), you can walk around the tower and have a panoramic view of odori park. It's connected directly via the subway.

Great landmark standing at the Odori Park. Connected to the subway underground shopping and provide 360 view of the Sapporo city. The lighted tower compliments the white illumination during winter also created a great atmosphere to the German Christmas streets.

Beautiful landmark of Sapporo. Sadly it’s winter season and it’s snowing very heavily early this December, views are obstructed. Nevertheless, a classic landmark, worth a photograph no matter what the weather is like.

While you may visit Sapporo TV Tower for free from the outside, making a paid entrance the to observatory 90 metres above ground is a must. Cost is ¥720 per adult and multiple price tiers for students. The view is completely different between day and night. If you cannot visit
The view from the top is awesome! You can see Odori Park and the surrounding buildings. It is best viewed at night.
We went there in the early morning, taking photos from Odori park. Relaxing. Night view could be nicer i guess.
I don't think it's worth to go up there. Not because of the USD 7 price. I'd recommend just check it out from the outside. Get an ice cream at the bottom of it.

A little overrated. Good place to take photos of Odori Park and the city. You can buy a two visit ticket for 1100yen so that you can come back in the night and not have to pay the 700yen entry twice. It's still worth visiting but you won't be there long as it's just a view.
This is a nice tower to take pictures of - especially as you walk down the park. I didn't have a chance to go up.

If you are at Odori Park, please make an effort to come up to the Observatory Deck at the TV Tower. A 60-second elevator will bring you up to the observatory deck 90 meters above ground. From here you will have a 360 degree panoramic view of Sapporo. Magnificent. The night view

This a landmark in Sapporo built in 1957 it is 147meters tall. It sits at one end of Odori park so you get a good view of it and the park both during the day and at night. The landscaping in Odori park near the tower is nice with flowers and sculptures. At night the tower is
If your walking the streets at night then I suggest you go see this. But don't plan a trip around it. Very average

The Sapporo TV tower is just beside the Odori park & is just beside Odori subway station. The observation deck (720 yen) provides a great view of the Odori park and its surrounding. A nice place to drop by and snap a few photos

We visited during night time while my short stay at Sapporo. It is like normal tower good to see from outside and have some photo shoot nearby. What we enjoyed here is cultural festival and dancing Japanese people with beautiful music.

The tower is interesting but so much more. It offers a great way to get oriented when exploring downtown Sapporo. You can always look up and find the tower to find your way to any subway stop or your hotel!

We choose to visit the tower at about 5pm in the spring so we get to see the day and night view within 1-2 hours. You do not need to cater a lot of time on the tower as you will want to spend more time in Odori park itself, but still a "must see" view for me.

We knew it would be touristy but we went ahead and headed over to the Sapporo TV tower. The kids were able to bungee jump off of the seventh floor of it which was fun. They're a great views from up above although the price to get in is a bit much.
Can see local picnic there. Selling a lot of street foods such as corn, ice cream and Sapporo beer. Very near to odori park.

Located in Odori Park itself we didn't walk to the tower but instead admiring it from a distance. It came to life during night time where the lights made it such a romantic sight to look at when you're walking in Odori Park.

Excellent views of Odori Park at night. During the summer, there is outdoor seating at the base of the tower with people enjoying grilled food. The smells are amazing. This tower offers a more scenic view of Odori Park compared to the more general city view from the JR station

Doesn't need to be // It is a small tower. You can see the entire Sapporo but, remember there are no skyscrapers in Sapporo so what do you wanna see? Perhaps it may be more beautiful at night but during the day, perhaps not so interesting unless you must have a snap view of

Loved the view. Took many beautiful pictures. There was no crowd when I visited, which made the whole experience pleasant. I could take my time getting my best shot. The view of the park was great! Instead of taking the lift, we walked down. The pictures and information
Love the 360 degree view and over head view of odori park. Spotted some other venues that we visited later.

We forgot the local tour after will come here again, so we went there at the first night, and again at day time on the fifth day. Don't compare it with Tokyo/Skytree tower please, but it could show you a great view for the Otori during day time. I will suggest you come at around
if you want to see from top beside mountain, this is another way, but let me remind you, there is nothing here.
Lovely gardens around d tower. Can do picnic or stop for a break with refreshments. Mini bungee jumping for kids & adults.

You can have an overall view of Sapporo city in the evening with light and traffic from the high tower. Enjoy taking photos here. Just a spot you should come when coming to this beautiful city to have nice memory with your family or friends.
Was ok and I thought it would be free but I would not pay to go up again. Same in every country an observation deck. If you've never been before then yeah sure but not really for me.

You will get a good view of the boulevard in which this tower sits. The view at sunsets is excellent on the west facing platform. The entry to the ticket platform is on the third floor where you will find restaurants and gift shops. The lift will take you further up to the top

It is well worth trekking to visit this site at night to see it nicely lit up. You can also climb to the observation deck to take in views of a very nice green belt running through the centre of the city. Take the time to visit while in the city.
The iconic structure in Sapporo best visited in the evening. Though we did not take take the lift to the top the overall surroundings are quite nice
A cool structure to stop for a picture, but it's merely a landmark. Nothing fantastic about it, in my humble opinion.

A must visit when you go to Sapporo especially when you're travelling with elders or kids. It's very accessible as it is smack in the middle of the town. Relax while you stare at the amazing view from up there. View is great on both summer and winter.
The Sapporo TV Tower,Located on the ground of Odori Park, in the northern city of Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan
Easy to find this place from the underground passage of Sapporo... At the top of the tower you can see almost all of Sapporo..

Price for going in is reasonable compare to lots more tower across the world. With 720yen to explore Sapporo night view is not a bad price. The lift is surprisingly slow to carry passenger to the top compare to any other tower's lift. There is also a small cafe in the area and
We always enjoy seeing the lights during the White Illumination period and festival of December. This in combination with the German Fest makes it a delightful (how beit cold) time to visit!
This is yet another landmark of Sapporo, easily spotted when just walking around the streets of Sapporo!
I came to see this tower after went to Otaru. decided to walk along the way from Sapporo station to my Hostel

Located in the city centre with props of Sapporo alphabets to have great pictures and fronted by the flower garden during spring / summer the place is great for memory pictures . In the nighttime with illuminations it adds to the charm of the place .
Sapporo TV Tower at the eastern end of Odori Park. The tower has extended hours (8:30 to 22:30) during the festival. Admission to the top observatory deck.
At a glance, it looks like a small Eiffel tower with clock, but it fits nicely with surrounding buildings and scenes. Best for the place for promise.
It's located at the East end of Odori Park. It's easy to access and a perfect place to view the city and the light display during X'mas or Snow Festival.

Sapporo TV tower is located at the end of Odori Park and it can also be reached by walking from Tanuki-koji Pedestrian street. If you take subway to Odori Station, take Exit No: 27. Built in 1957 and is a 147.2 metre high. An observation deck at a height of about 90 metres.

Entrance fees are reasonable, friendly staff and you can see good view of odori park and Sapporo from here. Quite a small tower, we spent less than an hour there. There are also shops selling souvenirs but nothing much.

I quite enjoy going up on all these TV towers when traveling in Japan. In general, Japanese are not pro skyscrapers, so normally you can have a great unblocking view to the entire city. You can even see the city of Sapporo surrounded by those mountains as the backdrop. Also a
As the subject mentioned, it lights up at night, which is nice and pretty. In the day, it's not that attractive.

The entry to the observation deck 90m above Odori Park is good value and the view is pretty good. I have marked it down a little as the trading kiosks on the observation deck have a couple of impacts on visitors. Firstly, the observation deck is not large so consuming important
Next to odori park in the middle of the city, sapporo tv tower is a modern Landmark, showing sapporo's status as hokkaido capital.
Worth the ride up to see the city. Great place to take some photos. The thing lights up like a Christmas tree at night.
we actually planned to be at odari park but we stranded here without regrets! we went up and paid a ticket for the entrance and witnessed sapporo from above. so beautiful!
The tower offers an excellent view of the city in all 4 directions. There are many restaurants besides a souvenir shop in the tower.Very close to JR. Taxi ride may only cost 500 yens

Ok, Sapporo is quite short on sights but this still shouldn't be high on the agenda. The whole interior feels dated and, more importantly, the view just isn't much to admire. Also, it's weird that a place like this is cash only. Watching it from outside is enough.

I've been in few "Towers" and my expectation level were too high. Tokyo Tower is definitely a WOW as well as few other regional "towers" in Japan but this wasn't in that level. It was more of Oodori deck type. I suppose the JR Tower near by this location gets more WOW and nice

Sapporo TV Tower has a Panasonic clock on it. There is an observatory but we did not get inside as we already got a very good city view at the Okurayama Ski Jump Stadium. This is located a block away from Odori Park in central Sapporo.

所用をかねて、さっぽろテレビ塔のある大通り公園で開催されている、ホワイトイルミネーションに行ってきました。記念写真やテイクアウトやリカーを販売するお店もあり、とても充実していました。（There were shops selling commemorative photos, take-outs and liquors.）大通公園やテレビ塔がライトアップされていてとても幻想的です。（Odori Park and the TV tower are lighted up and it is very
Frankly we are not keen on going to TV tower but shoot it's view outside always make us happy enough ^ ^ Isn't it a beautiful view from my shot : )
We visited the TV tower during a short stay in Sapporo. We only made it as far as the third floor and the dated surroundings put us off making the trip to the observation deck.
It's just like eiffel tower, there's an Panasonic signage on it, digital clock. No need to walk there, if you need to pass, It's ok to take some photos.
It is nothing magnificent compared to the other towers all over Japan. It seems like it was more for publicity than anything.
This tower is located on Odori Street. If you are lost, you can orient yourself by finding this tower. This tower is more beautiful at night since it is LEd-lit.

From a Sapporo Walk bus, the TV Tower gives guests breathtaking views not only of the city but the sights and must see events of the Snow Festival 2017. the TV Tower gives a 360 degree view of the City of Sapporo bathe in snow and the pulse of the Snow Festival with hundreds of

After strolling through the annual snow festival sights in Odori park, we decided to join the crowds of people heading to the Sapporo TV Tower observation deck. There was a line outside to buy tickets, then a shorter line to get on the elevator to the third floor. On the third
the information desk where we bought ticket was very helpful at the ground floor. we went upsatirs had a good view and decided to have dinner there on the thirdfloor. But the food was terrible

One of the best places to visit at night (winter) all the roads are covered with powdered snow. Ive never seen such beauty in my entire life. A must place to visit during night time because of the christmas lights wrapped around the trees.

Initially, we were at the level 3 (free for all). There's nothing much to see though. Then, we decided to see more. We paid about 700 yen per person. We were led to take a lift ride. Wow, we were taken aback delightfully: on the way up to the TOP, we were able to see the

I would give this 3.5 as a place to go. It gave great views of the city, and especially with the snow festival going on, you can get a bird's eye view of the whole strip. I wouldn't necessarily call this a tourist trap, but if you don't have a chance to go here, it's not a big
Nice views, but a bit pricey for the time you're likely to spend there. Still worth a look though. Good for kids.

It was snowing and cold so we just took a picture of it from the entrance of the subway. Because there is nothing happening there during November. Is a trademark you can skip if you are there during November.

This is a good place to see the entire city, but the place might not be high enough and there is a fee of 720 yen per adult. It would have been good if the rates are a bit lower since there is really not much in there. We went there in the afternoon, so maybe the view is much
Brought duo ticket for morning & night view. Night view is really nice with vibrant view. The fun & bright light really entertained.

Must pay to visit the top. Suggest to take a selfie outdoor and proceed to other nearby attractions. Many times it is use as a recognition for tourist to identify nearby attractions such as nijo market, odori park and shopping districts

The views from the Sapporo TV Tower were worthwhile for us and our 2 children. Prices were not too bad including student discounts for the kids. The viewing platform is completely enclosed but easy to take pictures through. It also helped us get oriented to the other major sites
Extremely pretty in the evening when the lights are up. Very photogenic especially surrounded with snow. Worth a quick stop for some photos.
Saw from Odori park I'm sure it's a lot more impressive at night but nothing special in the morning so would not recommend coming in the morning

This is a good place in winter at night to take photos. The place is scenic with the background of snow with the area lit up with Christmas lights. Some sort of Christmas festival with stalls set up selling food n such a few days before christmas.
This is a small version of so called looked alike Eiffer Towel. It is located at the Odori Park. Easy to find. Best viewed in the night with lights on. Worth to see.
The Sapporo TV Tower is one of the key icons here. With an entrance fee, you can actually ascend to the observatory platform for a 360 degree of the city. Souvenir shops are located at its base.

The tower is around 150m tall. It is located at the eastern end of the Odori park and also near Odori station. The view from the top is that spectacular though as the deck is not located so high. There is a beer garden and Mongolian style grilled in summer time.
Nothing spectacular but it does give you a great view of Sapporo and the sunsets can be quite amazing.
Located at the Odori Park, it is a landmark of Sapporo. Looks common during the daytime, but very beautiful at night. Viewing it from the ground up is enough. It is no need to go up the tower.
This place also in Odori Park, near the Sapporo station, several souvenir shops and food stalls open daily.
Visited the place during the Christmas lighting. The snow, cold temperature and the lighting added to the festivity.

Nothing much to see at day time. Bits beautiful when lights on but nothing to see. Compare to others in thing sapporo TV Tower is just a tower but it's much better than Kyoto Tower which shorter than Sapporo Tower.

The tower is located towards the end of odori park and one could enjoy both tourist attractions at the same time. Apparently it's iconic and One could purchase a ticket to go up to the tower if I'm not wrong. Nice place to sit around and enjoy the atmosphere.

during mid day, it was nothing than a tower clock, but one can absorb the atmosphere of sapporo city perfectly there. guess i have to come back in different season like christmas and see it at night :)
The view up there is not fantastic, not worth paying to go up. Can make do with taking a few pics around the park.

We walked and travelled on public transport a lot during our stay and the iconic TV Tower was a landmark that helped us navigate the city. It's beautifully lit up during the night and forms a bigger lighting display as part of Odori Park. We didn't go up the tower but thoroughly

I didn't go up the tower. I only took picture of the tower from odori park which is very nice to take picture with. If you're in Sapporo, I'd suggest to quckly visit this place. It's 3mins train ride from Sapporo Station or 15m walk from Sapporo Station.

Sapporo TV Tower (さっぽろテレビ塔 Sapporo Terebi-tō) - Located at Eastern end of the Odori Park. Tickets can be bought at level 3 (22.9m) . I did not get up the observation deck. It's beautiful. If you have extra time, try to see it both during day time and night time.
Sapporo TV Tower may not be the best place to see around Sapporo but if look from Odori park or around at night in winter its decorated very fantastic.

Obviously another well known structure in this town. You will no doubt walk past it or spot it from a distance when exploring Sapporo. Pros: Well known, looks cool - a must see for first time tourists to Sapporo. Nice park surrounding this area too. Cons: Not really much else

It is a tower in Japan where you can see Sapporo in each direction. Notting much to comment, just take out your camera and snap lots of photo. Day and night give you different feeling. So try to be there before sunset then you can enjoy both environment.

Didn't go up the Tower since I'd already done the higher tower where you can see this tower from above, namely the JR Tower just a 10-minute walk north of this tower; but nonetheless, I was impressed by this tall & imposing structure with the shape of the Eiffel Tower on the
Nice observatory located on the Sapporo TV Tower at the end of Odori park. You must visit it during the day & at night,
I and family visit Sapporo TV Tower on snow day. People play in the snow around Sapporo TV Tower. It's very funny.
Good place for photo session. It is located nearby Susukino, Odori and Nijo market. This place often flooded with tourist.
Lovely place with very good garden. You can enjoy view from the top of tower. You can relax and enjoy there!

We went up during the evening hours. The feeling is excellent, though we have to queue for a while. we can see the town at a higher level ,though not the whole town. The town was lit and very colorful. It is a good experience .

I just generally enjoyed the whole experience. The tower was quite busy but the orderly queues and pleasant staff made the short wait for the lift a pleasure. Once at the observation platform the views are impressive, both of the city and beyond. Don't miss the opportunity to

There's really nothing special about the design of this tower, however, it is a really good place to get an overall look of Sapporo and just chill with some people. They have a restaurant in the base of this tower and the surrounding view was just beautifully relaxing.

Went up in the evening during the Ice Festival in January. The views were great.... BUT CROWDED!!! People pushing to get closer to the glass to take pictures. Very annoying. Its worth a visit at night for the city lights. Tower is old.

The TV tower is located at one end of Odori Park close to where the Clock Tower is. From the top you get a bird's eye view of Sapporo city as also look along the length of Odori Park as it stretches across several blocks. In the distance you can see the hills that ring the city
Beautiful day and night. Similar to a smaller version of Tokyo tower. Good to visit for the view and shops. There were some pop up beer garden and restaurant while we were there.

We strolled down Odori Park then walked to the Sapporo TV Tower. The views are beautiful at night when the city lights lit up. The tower also gets lit up and looks beautiful at night. A photo worthy place in Sapporo
Tourist attraction in heart of sapporo. Gives you a good overview of the place. Don't expect to spend too much time. Possibility to rent a room at mid level. Heaps of gift to buy...
Nothing much except the LED lights at night. it's more happening if there's food stalls or other stalls that selling stuff.

The first thing that you want to do when you reach Sapporo City is walk down the beautiful Odori park . In spring you will see a lot of colourful flowers and awesome cherry blossom trees as you walk towards the iconic tower. Once inside there are some cool souvenir shops
Right next to Odori park. I didn't go up but enjoyed looking at it and is certainly a nice place to take some pictures. Next to it they had a beergarden.
I did not make it up to the tower cause but is a good place the grab some photo in the surrounding not far from the tower there is a garden where everyone like to chill out.
The view at the top was beautiful and it is linked underground as well to malls and other places, so easy to avoid the weather.
This is real exciting, we walked up using the staircases and it was very windy, but really fun! We got certificates and drinks, and supporters too! Very challenging. The view is really worth a climb.
My 1st Self-drive (F&E) tour. My 1st visit to Japan. Go round and round to catch the nice view of Sapporo. It is great to catch the night view of Sapporo. I will visit again if I return to Hokkaido.
Easy Access to the Tower and nice view of the City and surrarounding aera. Consider waiting the lift to access the entrance of the tower more than taking the stairs, they are really steep!
If you want a day and night view, go before sunset and have dinner at the beer garden at the base of the tower if weather is good.

Personally been to other places (outside Sapporo) with much better night views. While this is probably one of the only high places to view the night scenery, there's nothing special about this place - it's not particularly high, and can't really see clearly due to the bright

The TV tower can be seen from all over the city. It is fairly cheep to go up the tower to the observation deck and look around. Sapporo is a relatively new city and has been laid out on a grid with wide streets (which is just as well after a heavy snowfall). The view from the

Sapporo is a fairly new city of Japan where the CBD is situated just like checkerboard. Centre of that is TV tower. The city is divided and named North, South, East and West from there. If you are lost and don't have Internet connection for google map, look for TV tower and see
Situated near Susukino and and we walked past the tower daily during our visit. It's was really pretty at night when the lights lit up.

Like many of Japan's towers, going inside is kind of a ripoff. Much better to just take pictures from the outside. During the Snow Festival there are far more interesting things surrounding the tower in Odori Park.
Nice looking tower located in the middle of Odori Park. Colorful lights light up the skies at certain hours of the night. Really beautiful place to shoot a time lapse recording.

This landmark actually looks like a stunted Eiffel Tower, painted in red! One can actually venture up to the 3F without the need of admission fees, albeit only a restaurant, a souvernir shop and the ticketing office is sited on this level. There is no good view from here either.
We went there by foot through the underground shopping mall. Best place to exit is via the stair at Odori station.
Not bad lol for photo taking / sight seeing of buildings and structure :D.... ....... along Odori Park where u get to stroll along the park after the view on the tower
Situated at the end of odori Park. This structure is a good compass when looking for certain places. Different view in the morning and at night.

While staying in Sapporo I saw the tower many times so one morning I decided to go visit and as luck would have it it started raining just as I got there, from street level you take the elevator to level three at no cost. There you will find a shop , restaurant and lots of kids

We got two free tickets as part of a package with a few participating hotels in Sapporo. Otherwise, the price is 720 yen per adult per admission. If I was paying for this, it would still be okay considering the Tokyo Skytree (although a lot higher up is over 2,000 Yen with
I didn't go up the tower, but it looks nice during the day or night. You can just pass by it when you move around Sapporo city.

Night view of the city covered in snow, there's a small souvenir shop there too, but all the shop in the entire building pretty much sells almost the same thing..so if u missed out any up here. U can just get them at other floors.

Just go for the experience of riding up the historical elevator to the top to catch a bird's eye view of the city. You can get a professional picture by the photographer and you have the option to purchase your photo. Overall a small area with a souvenir shop and you can

While clearly not the tallest building in Sapporo any more there is much more to see from here than from the JR tower at the station. If there is no queue you can be up and down again in about 45 minutes after inspecting the park and surrounding city from the small observation

A must do when in Sapporo. The view of Odori park and Sapporo at the summit is one of the most iconic views in Hokkaido. So you gotta check it out. Went here twice actually. First during the afternoon. However, because of the heavy snowfall that day visibility was not that
I was here the day prior to snow festival - it was great to see the last preparation works for the festival. Just a small cafeteria was missing - one shall bring own drink upstairs

it is a bit pricey, but the view is absolutely fabulous. The street with all the parks as well as the skyline of Sapporo (which feels incomplete, because the TV tower is no longer part of it) can be well seen.

We recently visited the Sapporo Snow Festival, and the TV Tower was right in the middle of the festivities. Although there were many tourists, the queue did not take too long. The queue at the bottom of the tower is to buy a ticket - and then you catch an elevator to the
Great view of the snow festival at night. Pretty crowded though with long lines. Typical tourist type of thing where they take your photo like the Empire State Building.

There is not much to see in this tower. It was just a typical tower one can find in their own countries with the view of the city. However, during the ice festival in Odori Park, this complemented the picturesque surroundings with the ice carvings in display. It was beautiful to

This is a mini-Eiffel tower built right in the middle of town. It is higher than it looks and you get a great view. The price seemed about right to me. The lower levels are free but you have to pay to go to the top. Take the stairs or the lift as far as you can go and then you
Nice view of the light up on Odori Street during Christmas period. Easily accessible. There's a cafe in the tower.

The view is stunning but the deck is quite small. The perfect spot for photo shooting is the one located facing the Odori park where you'll find a lot of photographer with pricey camera that will just stand there forever. If you have a better plan and not a big fan of a view

The tower is located at Odori Park, above odori station. If you walk from sapporo station to Odori station, you will pass through underground Arora Town with lots of shops and restaurants along the way. Will prefer visitors to visit at night when the lights are turn on to admire

It's just a tower. Take some photos and move on. To be fair, we didn't go up the tower which offers a view of the city but time permitting, a trip to the Olympic Ski Jump Stadium would be a lot better.

As we'd never gone to the top of the TV Tower on previous trips, made a point of doing so this time. There were no crowds at all when we visited (7pm ish), so we had most of the tower to ourselves. Ride up in the elevator short, but fun. Kids enjoyed it. The view from the 360
Nothing interesting. Difficult to take photo as it's just a short stretch of walkway. And it's quiet especially after 9pm
Very nice and already cold with seldom light snow. Can come in december as the snow will start fully in 2nd week of december

This tower is a great landmark to visit especially you are trying to get a good aerial photo of Odori and the surrounding area. I just wished though that there were English narration, especially while ascending in the elevator.

This a Sapporo landmark located in Odori Park. The view is awesome and should not be missed. The fee is 720 yen for the elevator ride to the observation deck. Check your hotel lobby where all the tourist brochures are for a discount leaflet.

You can get discount coupon from some magazines at the hotel. You might get 1 if you're lucky. The attraction itself is average, typical viewing point from high ground. The window frames for viewing purpose are not big enough, thus it's not as awesome. Other than that, nothing
Went up to 3rd floor. Pretty good restaurant for a drink with a view. Nice selection of souvenirs. Would return at night to see the sights.

We went there because we had bought a "2 attraction + Mt Moiwa" pass and we didn't have the time to use it at more interesting place. The tower is extremely expensive and nothing interesting at all. It is very small so the view is so so. Just a tourist trap

So.. I've been to Paris's Effiel Tower a couple of times.. Been to the very top (when they weren't on strike), and absolutely fell in love with Paris and the girl I brought up there.. Well this TV tower in Sapporo didn't quite give me the same sentiments.. Well.. It does look

If you want some good exercise, walk up to the souvenir level and have some refreshment. Amazing array of sake from all over the country which you can buy. Head also to the basement of the tower for some good izakaya food.

Take the elevator to the top. It is worth the 700 yen. The view is pretty, but probably only if there is snow on the ground. It definitely doesn't have the same pizzazz as Tokyo Tower or many of the others, but it's definitely worth a look. Check it out and see all the beauty

One must be up there 70m higher to appreciate the grandeur of Odori Park at night. Unfortunately you can't really take good pictures up there because of the reflections on the protective glass screens.

Small German Christmas market and food vendors for the first 2/3 of December. Light illuminations run through Dec, Jan, and Feb I believe. The park is good any time. The Tower serves as a useful landmark. Snow festival is also held in front of it during February. Enjoyable

I was here in December and it was decorated like a Christmas tree with its many colorful lights. It was beautiful. I recommend seeing this tower from a distance since the view to the tower matches the green colored Odori park in front the tower well.

Sapporo's Television Tower is a beloved landmark in the city. It's been around for years, and perhaps has seen better days. But on a good day, one can really get a bird's eye view of the city, and the park below. There are plenty of kitschy souvenirs to buy, if one is into that

Good for a snapshot, and some souvenir shopping on the fourth (?) floor, but I see no reason to go up to the observatory if you've been to other NHK TV "tower" attractions in a Japanese city. The view of Sapporo at night from Mt. Moiwa (on a clear eve) or even that at the
Japanese simply loves TV towers. This tower can be seen from different part of Odori park. In the day, it is an icon at the part. At night, It lights up the dark sky.

I went there in winter after the Sapporo Snow Festival so the view wasn't as good as seen in others' photos. But nonetheless, it is a landmark in Sapporo. It is located at Odori Park and thus, easily accessible by the Sapporo Municipal Subway.

This TV Tower is probably a Sapporo landmark. You can access to the top of the TV Tower and it will gives a sweeping view of Sapporo City. We didn't go up this time, because we will be viewing the Sapporo city from Mt Moiwa :) It is tall enough for us to see the TV Tower's

This tower is tall enough to enable visitors to enjoy the magnificent views of the city with distant mountains clearly visible from the top. This is also due to a few taller buildings in Sapporo. The tower is located at one end of Odori Park which looks beautiful under sunlight.

Yes, it's a tourist trap. The TV tower is one of the famous buildings in Sapporo and as a tourist one simply has to visit it. Just like many other towers it is jam packed with gift shops and the proprietors try to squeeze every last penny out of the visitors. That said, the

The older, smaller cousin of Tokyo Tower offers excellent views of downtown Sapporo. The view is 360 degrees, and the cost is less than 1000 Yen. The time it would take to visit is under 30 minutes. There were no crowds or waiting times during our visit which was at a weekend.
We went in the afternoon and was greeted by the view of the whole stretch of Odori Park. With the blue sky as background, it was a picture prefect view.
A not so tall tv tower...lol It's easily access from odori park or nijo market. There is a clock on the tower and admission fees is needed to enter the observatory level.
Great photo place if u stand a bit further away as it is a landmark and easy to navigate using it as landmark.

Sapporo Tower is built in 1957, is a 147.2 metre high TV tower with the height of 90.38 metres. Around the Sapporo Tower is located in the Odori Park. While we went up the Sapporo Tower you will find many souvenir that we can buy and a very beautiful views to look at.
This tower located at the end of the Odori park is a nice example of steel structures. You can see it from a distance and it is a well known landmark of the city.
One can see this Landmark from far and it does not get any more impressive getting close. Shops, restaurants and observation deck –a mini Effel Tower. Average.
Nothing much but just for photography and nicer to take it from far too. Basically just another must visit in Sapporo.
We went to Sapporo on our Honeymoon, so TV tower gives off a little of the Romantic ambience of Paris. Great for couples.

If you want to see the Sapporo famous view , you should visit. Also in the summer time, there was Beer Garden in front of the tower. The meat was very good so you should try. But if you ever visited Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Sky Tree, this Sapporo TV tower is very normal.
I didn't go up to the observatory deck but it is quite relaxing to hang around the small park and have some food at the restaurant.
On of the most popular place for tourists. very nice view on Odori park. Nice all seasons. in winter time you can see snow sculptures.

The "low cost" eiffel tower is not that beautiful indeed. Nevertheless it turns charming at night with the illumination. You can enjoy the view point in the top of it (not free) by the sunset, worth going.

Here is another lame Japanese tower that is not worth your time or your money. Give this place a skip and do something better with your time. Seriously, have you ever heard anyone tell you how amazing the sky line or cityscape of Sapporo is? I didn't think so.

Built in 1957, this is a Sapporo icon. It's situated within Odori park. You can't miss it. Entrance is reasonable and you get a really good view of Sapporo from the observation deck. I went in the summer during the Lilac festival so the view was quite nice. On a good day you

We had just completed our ski trip to Niseko and we're looking forward to spending 4 nites in Sapporo to wind down. The Sapporo TV tower wasn't a top priority but since it's just there at Odori Park, it didn't make sense to skip it. On the day we walked to Odori park , we were
TV Tower Sapporo is a good landmark for visitors, public garden nearby is beautiful. There is smoking room for rhose who still can't quit smoking.

One of Sapporo landmark, located at the end of Odori park. The tower was built in 1957 and is 147 meter high. The elevator up to the observatory is on third floor. You could also climb up by using the stairs and earn the "certificate" for your hard-earned achievement. When I
Excellent location to see Sapporo from the top. on a clear day, you get to see all the famous attractions, the mountains, the park, the buildings.
best to visit at night with the lights on, it create a special night view. a good place for photo session
If you have time to spare during your visit to Sapporo, a visit to this tower for night view should be worth it. The city night view is beautiful.

I ended up going with a group of friends because they were keen to check it out, and I didn't mind going along. There is an extensive souvenir shop on the floor you line up for the elevator that takes you up to the top, so if you're in need of more Shiroi Koibito's, or just

Located in the center of towm ideal for panoramic views of city. Even better when the Snow Festival is on. Worth the trip up - tip - put your camera on movie and film through the glass side walls as you go up.

We just happened to walk by on our first day of exploring Sapporo and thought we should check it out. It was a common attraction I came across online while researching the city so it seemed like a good idea. We were at the TV tower for only around 10 minutes, it was a nice view
Definitely worth a visit wonderful views across Sapporo can be seen on a clear day, I think arriving early in the day is probably best
Definitely a tourist trap. Visited on first day of Snow Festival. Nice views, but the set-up for moving people through the tower made it feel like we were being rushed and herded.

The view of Sapporo city from the Sapporo TV Tower is beautiful. From the tower, you can have a nice view of Odori Park, mountains and ofcourse Sapporo city. I visited the tower at night and enjoyed the Sapporo city all lighted up. You can spend an hour plus taking photos or

The Tower is in the middle of Sapporo, a short walk from Sapporo Station. There's a souvenir shop and restaurant in the tower. Unfortunately all the commentary in the elevator was in Japanese. Worth a short visit for the view.

The Tower is in the middle of Sapporo, a short walk from Sapporo Station. It is at the far eastern end of Odori Park. It costs about 600 yen to go to the observatory and the night views are quite nice. There's a souvenir shop and restaurant in the tower, which is 147m tall. The

Had seen the great pictures of Odori Park taken from the tower so just had to go up there to get my own. The elevator has a fair bit of glass in it so you get a clear view out on the way up. Super outlook and well worth the trip. I note several TA comments on the cleanness of

We went to Sapporo last Dec to see the TV Tower by night at winter time. It was completely different when visit here in other time and you would enjoy the joyful atmosphere around despite of the cold weather at night. Highly recommend you to come here in time for the White
I was there for last years snow festival. Great view from the top because the city is covered with snow.
The tower stands majestically , among the fountain, statues and flowers in Odori Park. Can see the night view of Sapporo from the top of the tower, 720 yen. Open from 9 am until 10pm
Numerous buildings in the city now tower over the the old TV station buildings - an interesting part of History but no view to speak of now.

well, its a tower. we had rushed there to see it before closing time. dashed through odori park and the beer gardens were just closing. wanted to see the acclaimed night view from a top the Tv tower. It was good.. but well, just like looking off any tall building. went with my

Went up to the top of this just 3 days after going up in the Eiffel Tower. So it sort of suffers by comparison, but on the other hand: 1) No crowds, no waiting, no ordering tickets months in advance 2) Much cheaper I had just wandered over (was strolling through Odori Park

Compared to other "tower" type attractions in Japan, this one certainly isn't anything special. But, it is kind of fun to visit an older tower to see what was all the rage in the 1960's. Of course, there is a nice view of Odori park and the rest of Sapporo, but if you are

Looks so much like the Tokyo Tower. It is beautifully litted at night, and changes into various colour. Sapporo TV Tower is located in Odori Park, within a stone's throw from Sapporo's other famous tourist attractions.
Not so tall, but worth spending half an hour to see. As i've got, it's remarkably old (1957?), but looks like it's the reason of specific atmosphere there. Very nice.

Located on the eastern end of the Odori Koen park this is a 147m tower which I believe is trying to mimic the Eiffel tower, although somewhat poorly. I saw it briefly while visiting Odori park and found it fairly underwhelming. I wouldn't recommend people loose sleep if their

Definitely worth checking out, both in daytime and nighttime. Perhaps even more in nighttime, as the lit-up Odori Park and other streets looks really nice in the dark. Also a great place to the see the cherry blossoms or autumn colours if u are visiting during either of those

The Sapporo TV tower is at the east end of Odori Park. The observation deck gives a spectacular view of Sapporo's East., North, South and West sides. One can see Mt. Moiwa and the Ski Jump Station in the distance. The observation deck is a little crowded with so many souvenir
The Sapporo TV tower is watching what the city is doing, and in front of everything it's Odori Park. It's a pleasant stay having a look at the city. It's especially nice during the sunset.

A smaller version of the Eiffel Tower. You get a good view of Odori Park westwards with the Okura Ski Jump in the distance. But that's about it. The view from the JR Tower is better, in my opinion. If you intend to visit the Tower and Mt Moiwa for high level views of Sapporo,

We have got up the TV tower during the day, the weather was nice and sunny so we could see the city and the surroundings. The view of Odori park is nice, you can take pictures of the city, cars and people. From the tower we noticed the ferry wheel which we didn't know about

This TV Tower dates from the 1960's when every Japanese city of any merit was putting up towers. No better than most, a little expensive for just the view which can be enjoyed from one of the top floor restaurants or bars at one of the nearby hotels for free. Invest the price
The entrance fee was pretty steep and unfortunately all the commentary in the elevator was in Japanese. I went up during the Snow Festival. The view of Odori Park and Mt Moiwa was really pretty.

the tv tower isnt very high up, but given that it is located in the middle of odori park, it gives a very nice overall view of central sapporo. It had a great view of the sapporo white illumination in december and i can imagine the wonderful view it will have during the snow

It's another tower in another city. The excitement level can only get so high. You are able to see the lights of Odori Park from the air which is nice but otherwise, this is not the highest of towers. I would not repeat this again. I think the price should be less than half

It's pretty standard for the genre of attractions. Just a viewing platform with the gift shop taking up most of the viewing area. Still its nice, and the staff was nice and put the elevator commentary on in English. We went up at Night and the Ski Jump and other lights were

You can see the view of Odori park from here and also sapporo city view. They have TV family(Terebi kazoku) characters inside. so cute.You can also get the clock tower coin from the vending machine on the observatory deck.
Did not go up to the top level but from the bottom, it resembles any other tv tower in Japan. It would be better at nights with the lightings on the tower.

I travelled with my husband and 10 year old daughter. The view is quite amazing and we especially enjoyed the look over the Park as everything was getting ready for the Snow Festival. Staff here were very friendly and went out of their way after my daughter left her gloves on
It was drizzling when I visited the TV Tower. As such, the visibility was not great. However, still managed to get a great view of the Odori Park
It is a nice tower just next to Odori Park . Marvellous View of the tower from Odori Park at night.Especially in winter, the view is nicer.

text.wiki:
Sapporo (札幌市, Sapporo-shi) is the fifth largest city in Japan, and the largest city on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is the capital city of Hokkaido Prefecture and its Ishikari Subprefecture, and numbers among the nation's ordinance-designated city. Sapporo lies in the southwest of Hokkaido, within the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, which is a tributary stream of the Ishikari. Sapporo is considered the cultural, economical, and political center of Hokkaido.  
As with most of Hokkaido, the Sapporo area was settled by the indigenous Ainu people, beginning over 15,000 years ago. Starting in the late 19th century, Sapporo saw increasing settlement by Japanese migrants. Sapporo hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Olympics ever held in Asia, and the second Olympic games held in Japan after the 1964 Summer Olympics. The Sapporo Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup and two games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
The annual Sapporo Snow Festival draws more than 2 million tourists from abroad. Other notable sites include the Sapporo Beer Museum, which is the only beer museum in Japan, and the Sapporo TV Tower located in Odori Park. It is home to Hokkaido University, just north of Sapporo Station. The city is served by Okadama Airport, and New Chitose Airport in nearby Chitose. 


== Etymology ==
Sapporo's name was taken from Ainuic "sat poro pet" (サッ・ポロ・ペッ), which can be translated as the "dry, great river", a reference to the Toyohira River.


== History ==


=== Early history ===
Before its establishment, the area occupied by Sapporo (known as the Ishikari Plain) was home to a number of indigenous Ainu settlements. In 1866, at the end of the Edo period, construction began on a canal through the area, encouraging a number of early settlers to establish Sapporo village.In 1868, the officially recognized year celebrated as the "birth" of Sapporo, the new Meiji government concluded that the existing administrative center of Hokkaido, which at the time was the port of Hakodate, was in an unsuitable location for defense and further development of the island. As a result, it was determined that a new capital on the Ishikari Plain should be established. The plain itself provided an unusually large expanse of flat, well drained land which is relatively uncommon in the otherwise mountainous geography of Hokkaido.
During 1870–1871, Kuroda Kiyotaka, vice-chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi), approached the American government for assistance in developing the land. As a result, Horace Capron, Secretary of Agriculture under President Ulysses S. Grant, became an oyatoi gaikokujin and was appointed as a special advisor to the commission. Construction began around Odori Park, which still remains as a green ribbon of recreational land bisecting the central area of the city. The city closely followed a grid plan with streets at right-angles to form city blocks.
The continuing expansion of the Japanese into Hokkaido continued, mainly due to migration from the main island of Honshu immediately to the south, and the prosperity of Hokkaido and particularly its capital grew to the point that the Development Commission was deemed unnecessary and was abolished in 1882.
Edwin Dun came to Sapporo to establish sheep and cattle ranches in 1876. He also demonstrated pig raising and the making of butter, cheese, ham and sausage. He was married twice, to Japanese women. He once went back to the US in 1883 but returned to Japan as a secretary of government.
William S. Clark, who was the president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the University of Massachusetts Amherst), came to be the founding vice-president of the Sapporo Agricultural College (now Hokkaido University) for only eight months from 1876 to 1877. He taught academic subjects in science and lectured on the Bible as an "ethics" course, introducing Christian principles to the first entering class of the College.
In 1880, the entire area of Sapporo was renamed as "Sapporo-ku" (Sapporo Ward), and a railroad between Sapporo and Temiya, Otaru was laid. That year the Hōheikan, a hotel and reception facility for visiting officials and dignitaries, was erected adjacent to the Odori Park. It was later moved to Nakajima Park where it remains today. Two years later, with the abolition of the Kaitaku-shi, Hokkaidō was divided into three prefectures: Hakodate, Sapporo, and Nemuro. The name of the urban district in Sapporo remained Sapporo-ku, while the rest of the area in Sapporo-ku was changed to Sapporo-gun. The office building of Sapporo-ku was also located in the urban district.Sapporo, Hakodate, and Nemuro Prefectures were abolished in 1886, and Hokkaidō government office building, an American-neo-baroque-style structure with red bricks, constructed in 1888. The last squad of the Tondenhei, the soldiers pioneering Hokkaido, settled in the place where the area of Tonden in Kita-ku, Sapporo is currently located. Sapporo-ku administered surrounding Sapporo-gun until 1899, when the new district system was announced. After that year, Sapporo-ku was away from the control of Sapporo-gun. The "ku" (district) enforced from 1899 was an autonomy which was a little bigger than towns, and smaller than cities. In Hokkaido at that time, Hakodate-ku and Otaru-ku also existed.
Gallery
		
		


=== 20th century ===
In 1907, the Tohoku Imperial University was established in Sendai Miyagi Prefecture, and Sapporo Agricultural College was controlled by the University. Parts of neighbouring villages including Sapporo Village, Naebo Village, Kami Shiroishi Village, and districts where the Tonden-hei had settled, were integrated into Sapporo-ku in 1910.
The Sapporo Streetcar was opened in 1918, and Hokkaido Imperial University was established in Sapporo-ku, as the fifth Imperial University in Japan. Another railroad operated in Sapporo, the Jōzankei Railroad, which was ultimately abolished in 1969.
In 1922, the new city system was announced by the Tokyo government, and Sapporo-ku was officially changed to Sapporo City. The Sapporo Municipal Bus System was started in 1930. In 1937, Sapporo was chosen as the site of the 1940 Winter Olympics, but due to the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, this was cancelled the next year. Maruyama Town was integrated as a part of Chūō-ku in 1940, and the Okadama Airport was constructed in 1942.
The first Sapporo Snow Festival was held in 1950. In the same year, adjacent Shiroishi Village was integrated into Sapporo City, rendered as a part of Shiroishi-ku, and Atsubetsu-ku. In 1955, Kotoni Town, the entire Sapporo Village, and Shinoro Village were merged into Sapporo, becoming a part of the current Chūō-ku, Kita-ku, Higashi-ku, Nishi-ku, and Teine-ku. The expansion of Sapporo continued, with the merger of Toyohira Town in 1961, and Teine Town in 1967, each becoming a part of Toyohira-ku, Kiyota-ku, and Teine-ku.The ceremony commemorating the 100th anniversary of the foundation of Sapporo and Hokkaido was held in 1968. The Sapporo Municipal Subway system was inaugurated in 1971, which made Sapporo the fourth city in Japan to have a subway system. From February 3 to 13, 1972, the 1972 Winter Olympics were held, the first Winter Olympics held in Asia. On April 1 of the same year, Sapporo was designated as one of the cities designated by government ordinance, and seven wards were established. The last ever public performance by the opera singer, Maria Callas, was in Sapporo at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan on 11 November 1974. The Sapporo Municipal Subway was expanded when the Tōzai line started operation in 1976, and the Tōhō line was opened in 1988. In 1989, Atsubetsu-ku and Teine-ku were separated from Shiroishi-ku and Nishi-ku. Annual events in Sapporo were started, such as the Pacific Music Festival in 1990, and Yosakoi Sōran Festival in 1992. A professional football club, Consadole Sapporo, was established in 1996. In 1997, Kiyota-ku was separated from Toyohira-ku. In the same year, Hokkaidō Takushoku Bank, a Hokkaido-based bank with headquarters in Odori, went bankrupt.
Gallery
		
		
		


=== 21st century ===
In 2001 the construction of the Sapporo Dome was completed, and in 2002 the Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup; Germany vs Saudi Arabia, Argentina vs England and Italy vs Ecuador, all of which were in the first round. Fumio Ueda, was elected as Sapporo mayor for the first time in 2003. Sapporo became the home to a Nippon Professional Baseball team, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters, in 2004, which won the 2006 Japan Series, and the victory parade was held on Ekimae-Dōri (a street in front of Sapporo Station) in February 2007.
The 34th G8 summit took place in Tōyako in 2008, and a number of people including anti-globalisation activists marched in the heart of the city to protest. Police officers were gathered in Sapporo from all over Japan, and the news reported that four people were arrested in the demonstrations.The Hokkaidō Shinkansen line, which currently connects Honshu to Hakodate through the Seikan Tunnel, is planned to link to Sapporo by 2030.
Gallery
		


== Geography ==

Sapporo is a city located in the southwest part of Ishikari Plain and the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, a tributary stream of the Ishikari River. It is part of Ishikari Subprefecture. Roadways in the urban district are laid to make a grid plan. The western and southern parts of Sapporo are occupied by a number of mountains including Mount Teine, Maruyama, and Mount Moiwa, as well as many rivers including the Ishikari River, Toyohira River, and Sōsei River. Sapporo has an elevation of 29 m (95 ft 2 in)Sapporo has many parks, including Odori Park, which is located in the heart of the city and hosts a number of annual events and festivals throughout the year. Moerenuma Park is also one of the largest parks in Sapporo, and was constructed under the plan of Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American artist and landscape architect.
Neighbouring cities are Ishikari, Ebetsu, Kitahiroshima, Eniwa, Chitose, Otaru, Date, and adjoining towns are Tōbetsu, Kimobetsu, Kyōgoku.


=== Wards ===
Sapporo has ten wards (区, ku). The color shows the location of each ku in the map below.


=== Cityscape ===
Gallery
		
		
		


=== Climate ===
Sapporo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa), with a wide range of temperature between the summer and winter. Summers are generally warm, but not overly humid, and winters are cold and very snowy, with an average snowfall of 5.96 m (19 ft 7 in) per year. Sapporo is one of few metropolises in the world with such heavy snowfall, enabling it to hold events and festivals with snow statues. The heavy snowfall is due to the Siberian High developing over the Eurasian land mass and the Aleutian Low developing over the northern Pacific Ocean, resulting in a flow of cold air southeastward across Tsushima Current and to western Hokkaido. The city's annual average precipitation is around 1,100 mm (43.3 in), and the mean annual temperature is 8.5 °C (47.3 °F).


== Economy ==

The tertiary sector dominates Sapporo's industry. Major industries include information technology, retail, and tourism, as Sapporo is a destination for winter sports and events and summer activities due to its comparatively cool climate.The city is also the manufacturing centre of Hokkaido, manufacturing various goods such as food and related products, fabricated metal products, steel, machinery, beverages, and pulp and paper.Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. In April 2004, Air Nippon Network was headquartered in Higashi-ku. Other companies headquartered in Sapporo include Crypton Future Media, DB-Soft, Hokkaido Air System, and Royce'.
Greater Sapporo, Sapporo Metropolitan Employment Area (2.3 million people), had a total GDP of US$84.7 billion in 2010.In 2014 Sapporo's GDP per capita (PPP) was US$32,446.


== Culture and entertainment ==


=== Music ===
1934 – The International Contemporary Music Festival was held by Akira Ifukube, Fumio Hayasaka, Atsushi Miura, and Isamu Ifukube (30 September)
1936 – Russian composer Alexander Tcherepnin visited Sapporo
1960 – The Sapporo Symphony Orchestra founded
1962 – John Cage and David Tudor visited Sapporo
1966 – Berliner Philharmoniker with Herbert von Karajan performed Brahms's Symphony No. 2 at Sapporo Shimin Kaikan (April)
1974 – Maria Callas last public performance at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan (11 November)
1986 – The Sapporo Art Park include the Outdoor Stage and Art Hall (27 July)
1990 – The Pacific Music Festival (PMF) started
1997 – The Sapporo Concert Hall Kitara opened
2018 – The Sapporo Community Plaza is set to open in October


=== Art ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art represents Hokkaido artists like Eien Iwahashi, Kinjiro Kida, Nissho Kanda, Tamako Kataoka, and especially glass objects of Ecole de Paris
The Hongō Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture hosts a collection of over 1,800 works by the artist Hongō Shin.
The Sapporo Art Park contains Art museum featuring outdoor installations & a sculpture garden, and the old house of Takeo Arishima.
The Moerenuma Park including the Glass Pyramid, designed by Isamu Noguchi
The Migishi Kotaro Museum of Art
The Hongo Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture
The Miyanomori Art Museum
The Sapporo Odori 500-m Underground Walkway Gallery
Member of UNESCO Creative Cities Network as a Creative City of Media Arts since 2013
Sapporo International Art Festival (2014/2017)


=== Literature ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Literature
Takeo Arishima Residence in Sapporo Art Park
Junichi Watanabe Museum of Literature


=== Film ===
The Idiot (1951 film) by Akira Kurosawa
The Northern Museum of Visual Culture
Theater Kino
The Sapporo International Short Film Festival and Market


=== Points of interest ===

Registered Tangible Cultural Properties in Sapporo

The former Hokkaidō government office building
The Sapporo Clock Tower
The Hokkaidō Shrine
Hokkaido Museum
Historical Village of Hokkaido
Sapporo Buried Cultural Property Center
The Sapporo City Archive Museum　(Former Sapporo Court of Appeal)
The Edwin Dun Memorial Hall
The Hokkaido University & Hokkaido University Museum
The Sapporo Beer Museum & Sapporo Factory
The Sapporo TV Tower
The Sapporo Convention Center
The Sapporo Salmon Museum in Makomanai Park
The Sunpiazza AquariumSapporo JR Tower adjacent to Sapporo Station.Sapporo Ramen Yokocho and Norubesa (a building with a Ferris wheel) are in Susukino district. The district also has the Tanuki Kōji Shopping Arcade, the oldest shopping mall in the city.
The district of Jōzankei in Minami-ku has many resort hotels with steam baths and onsen.
The Peace Pagoda, one of many such monuments across the world built by the Buddhist order Nipponzan Myohoji to promote and inspire world peace, has a stupa that was built in 1959, halfway up Mount Moiwa, to commemorate peace after World War II. It contains some of the ashes of the Buddha that were presented to the Emperor of Japan by Prime Minister Nehru in 1954. Another portion was presented to Mikhail Gorbachev by the Nipponzan-Myohoji monk, Junsei Terasawa.


=== Parks/gardens ===
The Odori Park
The Nakajima Park
The Maruyama Park is located next to the Hokkaido Shrine and houses the Maruyama Zoo.
The Moerenuma Park
The Nishioka Park is a location of rich nature which centers around a pond and consists of marshland and the forest of the Tsukisamu River and its upper river basin. This park also serves as one of the main habitats in Hokkaido for many types of wild birds.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park offers great views of the city.
The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens and The Chizaki Rose Garden
The Hitsujigaoka Observation Hill has a farm with sheep and attracts visitors with a statue of William S. Clark.


=== Events/festivals ===

February: the Sapporo Snow Festival The main site is at Odori Park, and other sites include Susukino (known as the Susukino Ice Festival) and Sapporo Satoland. Many of the snow and ice statues are built by members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force.May: the Sapporo Lilac Festival. Lilac was brought to Sapporo in 1889 by an American educator, Sarah Clara Smith. At the festival, people enjoy the flowers, wine and live music.
June: the Yosakoi Soran Festival. The sites of the festival are centered on Odori Park and the street leading to Susukino, and there are other festival sites. In the festival, many dance teams dance to music composed based on a Japanese traditional song, "Sōran Bushi". Members of the dancing teams wear special costumes and compete on the roads or stages constructed on the festival sites. In 2006, 350 teams were featured with around 45,000 dancers, and over 1,860,000 people visited the festival.the Sapporo Summer Festival. People enjoy drinking at the beer garden in Odori Park and on the streets of Susukino. This festival consists of a number of fairs such as Tanuki Festival and Susukino Festival.September: the Sapporo Autumn Festival
December: Christmas market in Odori Park, similar to German Christmas markets.
From November through January, many citizens enjoy the Sapporo White Illuminations.


=== Cuisine ===

The city is known home to Sapporo Brewery, and the white chocolate biscuits 'shiroi koibito' (白い恋人), also as the birthplace of miso ramen. The Kouraku Ramen Meitengai in Susukino district, an alley lined with many miso ramen restaurants since 1951. After its demolition due to plans for the Sapporo Olympics, the Ganso Sapporo Ramen Yokocho was established in the same place. It attracts many tourists throughout the year. From the year 1966, a food company named Sanyo Foods began to sell instant ramen under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban".
Haskap, a local variety of edible honeysuckle, similar to blueberries, is a specialty in Sapporo. Other specialty dishes of Sapporo are soup curry, a soupy curry made with vegetables and chicken or other meats, and jingisukan, a barbecued lamb dish, named for Genghis Khan. Sapporo Sweets is a confectionery using many ingredients from Hokkaido and the Sapporo Sweets Competition is held annually. Sapporo is also well known for fresh seafood including salmon, sea urchin and crab. Crab in particular is famed. Many types of crab are harvested and served seasonally in Sapporo like the Horsehair crab, Snow crab, King crab, and Hanasaki crab with numerous dishes revolving around them.


=== Sports ===

The Sapporo Dome was constructed in 2001 and currently is the host to the local soccer team, Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo, the baseball team Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters and the basketball team Levanga Hokkaido.
Sapporo was selected to be the host of the 5th Winter Olympics scheduled on February 3 to 12, 1940, but Japan had to give the Games back to the IOC, after the Second Sino-Japanese War broke out in 1937.
In 1972, Sapporo hosted the 11th Winter Olympics. Some structures built for Olympic events remain in use today, including the ski jumps at Miyanomori and Okurayama. After considering a bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Olympic representatives in Sapporo have said that the city is considering a bid for the 2030 Winter Olympics.
