The city predicts it may cost as much as 456.5 billion yen ($4.3 billion) to host the games and is planning to have 90 percent of the facilities within half an hour of the Olympic village, according to a report published 12 May 2016. The Alpen course would be in Niseko, the world's second-snowiest resort, while the village would be next to the Sapporo Dome, the report said. The plans were presented to the Japanese Olympic Committee on 8 November 2016. In 2002, Sapporo hosted three group matches of the FIFA World Cup at the Sapporo Dome. In 2006, Sapporo hosted some games of the 2006 Basketball World Championship and also for the 2006 Women's Volleyball World Championship. In 2007, Sapporo hosted the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships at the Sapporo Dome, Miyanomori ski jump, Okurayama ski jump, and the Shirahatayama cross country course. It has been host city of two Asian Winter Games and hosted the 2017 Asian Winter Games with Obihiro. Sapporo will also host some games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
Skiing remains a major sport in Sapporo with almost all children skiing as a part of the school curriculum. Okurayama Elementary School is unusual in having its own ski hill and ski jumping hill on the school grounds. Within the city are commercial ski hills including Moiwayama, Bankeiyama, KobaWorld, Sapporo Teine and Fu's.
Many sports stadiums and domes are located in Sapporo, and some of them have been designated as venues of sports competitions. The Sapporo Community Dome, also known by its nickname "Tsu-Dome", has hosted the Golden Market, a huge flea market event which is usually held twice a year, along with some sports events. The Makomanai Ice Arena, in Makomanai Park, was one of the venues of the Sapporo Olympics in 1972. It was renamed the Makomanai Sekisuiheim Ice Arena in 2007, when Sekisui Chemical Co., Ltd., acquired naming rights and renamed the arena after their real estate brand. Other large sports venues include the Makomanai Open Stadium, Tsukisamu Dome, Maruyama Baseball Stadium, and the Hokkaido Prefectural Sports Center.
Toyota Big Air is a major international snowboarding event held annually in Sapporo Dome. As one of the richest events of its kind in the world, it draws many of the world's best snowboarders.


==== Professional sport teams ====
J.League – Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo (J1 in 1998, 2001–2002, 2008, 2012, 2017–present; J2 in 1999–2000, 2003–2007, 2009–2011, 2013–2016) .
NPB – Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters in Pacific League


== Demographics ==
The city has an estimated population of 1,957,914 as of May 31, 2019 and a population density of 1,746 persons per km² (4,500 persons per mi²). The total area is 1,121.26 km2 (432.92 sq mi).


== Transportation ==

Sapporo has one streetcar line, three JR Hokkaido lines, three subway lines and JR Bus, Chuo Bus and other bus lines. Sapporo Subway trains have rubber-tyred wheels.


=== Rapid transit ===
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Sapporo Streetcar
Mount Moiwa Ropeway
Teineyama Ropeway


=== Rail ===
JR Hokkaido Stations in Sapporo
Hakodate Line: (Zenibako) – Hoshimi – Hoshioki – Inaho – Teine – Inazumi Kōen – Hassamu – Hassamu Chūō – Kotoni – Sōen – Sapporo – Naebo – Shiroishi – Atsubetsu – Shinrinkōen – (Ōasa)
Chitose Line: Heiwa – Shin Sapporo – Kami Nopporo – (Kita-Hiroshima)
Sasshō Line (Gakuentoshi Line): Sōen – Hachiken – Shinkawa – Shinkotoni – Taihei – Yurigahara – Shinoro – Takuhoku – Ainosato Kyōikudai – Ainosato Kōen – (Ishikari Futomi)


=== Air ===
The Sapporo area is served by two airports: Okadama Airport, which offers regional flights within Hokkaido, and New Chitose Airport, a larger international airport located in the city of Chitose 30 miles (48 km) away connected by regular rapid trains taking around 40 minutes. The Sapporo-Tokyo route between New Chitose and Haneda is one of the busiest in the world.


=== Airport shuttle, tour and charter bus service ===
An airport shuttle bus servicing all hotels in Sapporo operates every day of the year. SkyExpress was founded in 2005 and also provides transport to and from various ski resorts throughout Hokkaido, including Niseko.


== Education ==


=== Universities ===


==== National ====
Hokkaido University
Hokkaido University of EducationSee Japanese national university


==== Public ====
Sapporo Medical University
Sapporo City University


==== Private ====
Sapporo University
Hokusei Gakuen University
Hokkai School of Commerce

Hokkaido College of Pharmacy
Sapporo University of Health Sciences
Japan Health Care College


=== Primary and secondary schools ===

Sapporo Odori High School provides Japanese-language classes to foreign and Japanese returnee students, and the school has special admissions quotas for these groups.The city has two private international schools:

Hokkaido International School
Hokkaido Korean Primary, Middle and High School (North Korean school)


== Twin towns – sister cities ==

Sapporo has twinning relationships with several cities worldwide.
 Portland, Oregon, United States, since 1959
 Munich, Bavaria, Germany, since 1972
 Shenyang, Liaoning, China, since 1980
 Novosibirsk, Russia, since 1990
 Daejeon, South Korea, since 2010
 Chiclayo, Peru

The gardens are quite pleasant for a stroll, but not overwhelmingly beautiful. Nice roses and other flowers.

There is so much more that just gardens here - there are also a few small museums with information on the history of the Ainu people, animals of region, and local history. If you like gardens, you'll probably go here anyway, but even if you don't, it is a lovely calm spot in the

Such a beautiful place!!! You can walk the inner trail or outer trail, or wonder as you please. The only thing not maintained is the rose garden. Everything else was great. They also have an assortment of green houses. We really enjoyed the 2 museums inside as well. It was only

Was a little disappointed with our visit, it isn't well maintained and most areas just looked over grown and messy. There were a few nice plants and its a nice place to stroll around but not really somewhere to pay for. Expect it is better at certain times of the year when

Fairly poorly maintained. Lacked much interest and of little design merit. Possibly of interest if you are a botanist with some unusual varieties of plant species. It is a nice place to take a stroll and have a chat but otherwise little going for it.

Who would think that there would be a small forest just a couple of blocks away from Odori Park? The transition from an urban setting to a shangri-la of forest cover was almost startling. We enjoyed some needed downtime as we strolled through wooded trails among endemic trees

Decided to take a walk to the Botanic Gardens in Sapporo. 420 yen per person per entry! Gardens not taken care of. Total shambles and in disarray. Waste of time and money. First time I have given such a Low rating for anything in japan. Quite unexpected. Save your money for
And they have a little poster showing what's in bloom and what section it's in. It's possible to walk around the whole garden and see everything. Don't miss the roses.

We spent a very pleasant warm autumn morning strolling in the botanic gardens. Some late blooming roses were in flower. The gardens have lots of interesting foliage, including a Canadian rock garden and a hot-house; the water lilies were flowering.. Do not expect a formal
We were very underwhelmed with our visit to the Botanical Gardens. There are so many beautiful parks and gardens in Japan an this just didn’t compare to others we’ve been to.

Pretty in May, although we missed most of the cherry blossoms (a few were still blooming). We visited all the small museums, too, which we liked. It's fun to see the schoolkids, old and young, and a few salarymen and artists - just locals hanging out for the afternoon. Low
Based on what we saw, the gardens must be beautiful in the summer months. Everything was bright green and the cherry blossoms were in full bloom.

Visited in early August and there were not a lot of flowers. There was a lot of green grass and big trees and many well marked paths to walk. If you like to walk this is great place to go. There was a nice rock garden and a couple of small museums that had interesting
These botanic gardens, which include an arboretum, natural woodland, and two small museums, are well worth a visit and make a pleasant morning or afternoon's walk.

Whenever we travel we love to see the local botanical gardens. This one was incredibly disappointing--it had nothing special. in fact, the nicest flowers were in a bed outside of the front gate. It cost a bit to get in for our large group and we were wishing we had walked
A very relaxing garden with beautiful trees surrounding the pond. I notice that there are some koi fishes swimming freely in the pond. Another season of beautiful blooms with vibrant colours.

We spent about two hours here in the morning, an easy walk from our hotel in Sapporo. It was relaxing and enjoyable, with labels on the trees and plants and with a museum that focused largely on animals and birds rather than plants. Some interesting old buildings. Not a great

There were not many flowers in the Botanic Garden of Hokkaido University when I visited on 23 May 2017, although the lilacs were supposed to be in season. However, the greenery still made for a pleasant stroll. I was also surprised and pleased to see a small Ainu museum within

This is a beautifully laid out garden with a small but very engaging museum of the Ainu and other northern peoples in the garden grounds. Even if it is accused of being off the track for visitors, it shouldn't be. Though small and less formal, this is one of best gardens we

If being away from the tourist trail appeals, then I could recommend this garden. Highlight was the small but informative Ainu museum, which showcased various well preserved artifacts of the northern indigenous Ainu people. The gardens are well kept and worth strolling around.
When we visited all the places was covered by snow and give us a sense o Christmas! Incredible. We meet a professor of the University that explain how to circulate in the space of University.
It was a nice walk from Sapporo station eve though it was cold and rainy. The park was closed so we didn't get to walk inside the park but viewed from outside. It was worth it.
its surroundings was part of my planned must visit places. pay to enter and walk in a peaceful park together with viewing the different plants and flowers in the greenhouses.

These gardens were not at their best in mid autumn but there was enough autumn colour to give a good idea that they would be even prettier at other times of year. They are relatively extensive however, and very pretty for a central city area. There are several museum/collection
Had some super super fresh and delicious sushi. Small stall in Nijo market. The owner meticulously prepare the sushi and we just chow it down in less than 5sec! Not to be missed!
garden has an interesting selection of plants and flowers.worth a visit if you are a garden person.near sapporo station.

I rarely give less than four rings but this doesn't deserve more than two. It was uncared for, unkempt and not representative of the high quality parks in Sapporo. I was tempted to start weeding the shrubbery first then the ethnobotanical area, both were in poor state. Flowering

I visited the gardens in mid/late June. I was interested in the little Ainu museum there, so seeing that and having a park to wander around in afterwards made it a great way to spend the morning. Park maps are available in English and Japanese; I can't remember if any other

It's a nice place to walk, rather quiet except for the birds. Can be a nice way to spend an hour or two. Entrance fee is JPY420 per person. Do bring mosquito repellents though. I guess it's a summer thing.
Walking through this garden is a real inspiring event. For one finds the number of unique plants, flowers and trees here as an inspiration for quiet meditation.

We had a whole day before leaving for the airport so we chose to spend the morning at this Botanical Garden at Hokkaido University. What a treat!!!! Loved seeing all the roses, lotus and water lily flowers, and the tropical foliage. Not only was it a Botanical garden, but

Of you're onterested in plants or just want to relax a bit from the city around, this garden is worth a visit. We visited on start of May, when not many flowers were visible yet. But there are some cherry trees, which were full of flowers at that time. Entrance fee is ca. 400

This is a lush and well laid out garden with nice trails and two museums, both rather small. One has a collection of Ainu artifacts. the other has a set of taxidermy animals and documentation of a historic trip to the arctic with sled dogs.

Wanted to go and wander around tha park but it was closed for the winter months, apparently it closes in November and opens the end of April and seems it is always closed on a Monday. We took the opportunity and walked around the fence line to see as much as possible, a lot of
The tropical garden house which was the only place opened during the winter months, was not maintained. Plants were dying. However,may be different during the summer months.

We visited the Botanic Gardens in Sapporo to waste some time just prior to leaving. But after visiting, we wonder why this wasn't more highly recommended to us. The gardens are a decent size and show off all the typical Hokkaido trees and shrubs marked with their various names

With a Y420 entry fee it would have been nice if it was a better park. On my visit the autumn colours were on display and the large trees made the ground quite relaxing. However, the whole park didn't quite seem to work well - possibly because it is a botanic garden/park and
This is a large and interesting garden which is typical of a city centre garden in Japan. It has a great deal of trees and walkways and worthwhile visiting but nothing special
The garden itself was lovely and the western style buildings dotted around were a nice addition to the scenery.
Amazing park! I prefer the inside the building flora. Good location, work not all days in year. have to visit!

3-1/2 stars We spent a leisurely hour in the gardens on a mid-summer's morning. The small Ainu exhibit (i.e. Northern Peoples Museum) was a worthwhile for its exposition (however limited) of native tools, clothing, and customs. The gardens themselves were pleasant but seemed

Our kayaking trip as canceled because of the weather so we went to the botanic gardens for a couple of hours, hoping that the rain would hold off that long. Compared to gardens of historical importance in Kyoto and elsewhere on Honshu, it is a bit disappointing. The rose garden

True to its nature, this botanic garden is more of a teaching garden than a show garden. No much done to make the place attractive; a good variety of trees and plants for interested visitors. Clear labels and tags for all plants everywhere, but in Japanese only except for the
A great little garden in the middle of the city. Interesting museum on the Ainu people and history on the local botanists of Sapporo. No wow factor, but worth a stroll around if you're visiting.

These gardens set in the centre of Sapporo are worth a visit. There are many sections to the gardens, a map is provided when you pay the entrance fee, which is minimal . There are many large trees and one we had not seen before was the Dove tree with its interesting flowers. The

This garden encompasses a city block, so the size is manageable. We spent about an hour walking the paths on a recent rainy day. The roses were still in bud, but many shrubs and flowers were in bloom. Plants are marked in Japanese and also with their Latin names. The Canadian

From the reviews on TA and elsewhere, I was expecting a beautiful garden, what I got what just average. It is lush and green, with many labeled plants, shrubs, trees, flowers, herbs, but much of it is under cared for, overgrown, under watered where it needed it. It was a

There is an interesting museum with some stuff local animals (wolves and bears), and an exhibit about some minority people. The gardens themselves were a bit run down, and to be honest, not that interesting. You have to buy your ticket from a machine, then give the ticket

Having been to many botanical gardens I have to say this one is pretty average. Maybe it is the time of the year, but I was definitely not impressed. For example, the 'Rock Garden' was literally piles of rubble with some shrubs. I expected something more manicured, reminiscent

I particularly enjoyed the rose garden, but it was lovely to simply ramble around the grounds and get lost. Everything was lush and green, and it wasn't overly crowded with tourists. Interesting historical museum and exhibit of local wildlife (wolves, owls, etc).

This was the one place visited which was poor as their was an entrance fee and the free gardens were better maintained.Most of the plants in the greenhouse were dead or dying ,flower beds overgrown with weeds.cannot recommen
The plants are remarkable and the setting makes one envy of those who are educated in this university!

Hokkaido University Botanic Garden is near Keio Plaza Hotel where we stayed. Once we decided to came there and did not regretted. There are many kinds of flora in limited space. We liked little museum that is in the garden territory. I recommend to come there in hot summer day.
We read about the wide variety of flora there during the non-winter months, was there at the wrong time. Within walking distance from Saporro JR station.
Well-kept botanical garden with museums etc. in an easily accessed part of the city
google: I believe not too much tourists will go there. But I recommend you to take a walk, even in winter times. It is still have its attractive side. For myself, I am looking forward to visit her agin in summer or autumn.

It looks like the amount of stars this place receives is dependent on the time of visit, and understandably so.  I visited this garden during the last week of October and the trees were just about to shed their leaves for fall.  The colors …
The Garden is well maintained, very clean, as expected in Japan. A variety of plants blossom over many months. One can spend a few relaxed hours there for a reasonable entrance fee.

fun to walk through in the winter. the big area wasn't open so only the greenhouse, but for sure worth going to if you're a fan of plants. the full experience will surely be better in non-winter months
Very beautiful garden, with a small Ainu musium and a greenhouse. We've spend a couple of hours wandering around. Absolutely worth the visit
Walking distant from Hokkaido University or from Former Hokkaidō Government Office. Nice quiet with different plant zones and a small beautiful rose garden.

A beautiful experience among trees, flowers, fountains and peaceful silence.
Here you can find a beautiful museum of Japanese animal species too, including the Ezo Okami (Canis Lupos Hattai Kishida), the extinct endemic Japanese wolf.
If you are looking for nature, history, silence and meditation, this is the right place!!!
It has not been managed well. I think it is enough for free.

It’s got 2 really interesting museums, on Ainu and one on animals and live in Hokkaido 100 years ago. The ethno section of plants is also I retesting. The greenhouse is small but cute and the overall park pleasant to walk through. Garden and plants could be kept up better
Two small greenhouses with many plants and cute succulents, available in winter.

Cool place for nature lovers. The museum looked small but the exhibit is large enough to appreciate the wildlife. The park is big but the summer blossoms are too little. I have seen enough real Christmas trees but I am looking for more colorful flowers, such as roses and tulips.
Really nice, relaxing place with some very pretty flowers.
A nice park for a stroll and not too expensive.
A nice peaceful walk, and a few interesting things to see. Could probably be skipped if you have a tight itinerary.
So, so, so stupid to close a botanical garden on a Sunday!

Lovely garden in the center of Sapporo. There is also a small museum for Ainu culture there.
420 yen entrance fee per adult. Garden is very well maintained and there is a lot to see. Special highlights are the alpine garden, rose garden and carnivorous plants.

I came during the summer so there were interesting plants and flowers available to see. Touring the entire place would take about an hour and a half, so llan your trip wisely. 

What I didn't like about this place though was there was minor English translations for the plants as well as the exhibits in the museums.

The botanical gatden was not as lovely as it should be during our mid Agust 2019 visit. Isolated blooms were left at the Rose Garden. It was nice place  but it would have been beautiful if the flowers were in bloom.
Very beautiful and peaceful place, pretty flowers. Also the Ainu museum was very interesting.
Really peaceful garden area. Nicely curated and tended collection of plant species. Big trees, with lots of shade in the summer.

Beautiful park with an incredible array of old trees. The history of Hokkaido's benefactors can be felt here. A nice stop in the morning from 9:00 am before catching your flight home. Museums on site need some sprucing up with a few more …

Beautiful and well kept. There's an alpine garden, canadian rock garden, tropical house, shrubbery garden, rose garden, herbs garden and much more. I easily spend two hours here and enjoy watching the crows taking a bath in the small rivers and ponds.
It's a great garden and there are muzeum inside the park. Amazing autumn scenery

Quiet but interesting garden to visit right in the heart of the city. Small exhibits of the Ainu culture and taxidermy specimens of the local birds and animals made it a lovely experience.
It's a nice place for family and student to learn or just have fun at forest in the middle of city.

Doesn't seem to be artificially maintained, yet it might be better - so beautiful flowers are blooming!
Nice view especially in the Autumn, don’t forget to visit at early November if you visit Sapporo.
Worth the money, very pretty place, weren't many people around when I went. Very good place to casually walk around

Closed due to the earthquake last year. It will be set in open after repair.

Stunning grounds with beautiful trees and flowers, really underrated, uncrowded and genuinely beautiful place.

text.quote: Family spot featuring samples & exhibits of chocolate & cookies, plus a train ride & garden area.
trip: It's a magical winter paradise especially during winter or Christmas period. We went during early November, we still managed to admire the beautiful landscape around the park. We took a tour inside the chocolate factory. It's like a dream come true. Almost feel like we were

This is definitely a must-see for everyone - tourists and locals! Visited the park with family. Pros: 1) Its a mini wonderland of sweets, pocket gardens, and amazing afternoon show for kids. 2) The short walk from the train station to the park was cool and relaxing,

Went here in February. Unfortunately, we got there in the evening so it was closed but we enjoyed walking around the park area. The lights are beautiful. The music is magical. And it started to snow, light fluffy snow. We couldn't resist getting some Hokkaido soft serve from the
My tip is for you to go here at night when they turn on the lights. It is like their mini theme park for kids.

Only activities there are DIY (for pay). Kids walked around, looked thru the glass, looked at some art and that's it. Best part was outside for photo ops. I've included a photo of the factory so you can save your money...

The chocolate factory was a winter fantasy land. Great place to take pictures, lots of excitement around, kids having a great time. It was particularly beautiful at night. For some, the best part was the outdoor gardens with Christmas lights all aglow. For others, the

While the primary objective of visit for most visitors is to buy the range of merchandise available, the company has installed a lot of park decorations and activities to keep the old, young and adults occupied. It redefines the shopping experience, and we got to view their

The public area is free entry, the staff were consistently courteous and the environment was beautiful. visitors can bring back a stamped image and the staff were attentive and topped up the papers for stamping when it ran out. we reached there at 6pm and most of the

Visited the famous Shiroi Koibito Park (also known as White Lovers Theme Park) as our families love chocolates. We knew it's a tourist trap and weren't expecting much but were pleasantly surprised it turned out to be quite enjoyable. The whole place was decorated like a

What;s the fun of paying 600¥ to see from outside the cleanroom of a biscuit factory? Kids can also making biscuit by their own but you need to pay more for that. The outside area is free but not very exciting either. Not a fan.

A "magical" place with lots of photo opportunities and free too (unless you want to take the guided tour of the factory). Loved the hourly show at the park. The customised box with either a picture taken on the spot or pre-taken is a nice momento.

if you're going to sapporo with kids, this is one of the must go places. easily accessible via train ride. just need google maps to navigate train station exit to chocolate factory. the walk from the station to factory is around 10minutes, recommended if there is nice

Love the biscuit love the park. Nice little place for you to spend your morning or afternoon in. Many photo taking opportunities and it is great footer kids. Dont forget to try and make your own cookies.

Shiroi Koibito is a famous cookie brand from Hokkaido. I believe most people know it. The park is a very good combination of cookie factory and site seeing. The park itself is very Euro-style. It also includes some interesting things such as old toy exhibition. I strongly

Beautiful place! As if we are in a fairytale world, 600 yen admission, but you could pay 500 if you have discount booklet from car rental company. Free parking available. Was there around 9:15am and it started to get crowded by 10am.

Shiroi Koibito Park is a theme park by Ishiya, a local chocolate company. The company's flagship product is the Shiroi Koibito cookie, these are made with delicious white chocolate sandwiched in between two delicately soft butter cookies. These cookies are the best souvenirs

We were at the park on Christmas eve morning 2016. The Shiroi Koibito Park was an established attraction so expect a crowd and the typical tourist activities here... starting from a group photo at the Aurora fountain; print-outs could be purchased as a momento. Some picture

Beautiful place, enjoy walking at their garden. Free basement parking. Lots of cookies, cakes, chocolates, puddings and candy. There is a toy collection room, souvenir shops, cafe and restaurant. Easily can spend 2 hours.

Must go for the tour as its quite magical to see how the Japanese ensures that only perfect cookies made it out of the factory~ In-between the tour there is a photo-taking queue with the indoor fountain (do not need to queue as nothing special, just continue with the tour).

I have visited this park twice in two years because I came with different family groups. We drove here -- very easy: Parking lot has wide stalls and attendants everywhere to make sure you go to the right place. However, I advise you to get to the park as soon as it opens

Park is beautiful for photo shooting. i went there during summer, it was raining that day. The place was full of people. We didn't take factory tour as too many people queuing up for buying tickets. Worth to visit especially if you bring kids. There were plenty of car parks

I feel it's more for family place. As a couple, we registered for the making of Shiro koibito biscuits.U only get to flatten the dough with a machine,each standing at opposite side,pushing it towards each other for about 5 times.We had to wait 10mins by the bench,and flip the

The shiroi koibito biscuits are one of my all time favourites - hence visiting this park felt abit like a pilgrimage of sorts 😄 I was there during winter and the decor both outside and inside exuded a real winter and Christmas wonderland feel, which also made eating ice cream

Park is beautifully decorated with flowers for snapping photos. Factory tour is educational to watch how the tasty white biscuits are made. Even inside the factory, there are picture perfect places and items. Definitely worth a visit!
Beautiful place inside and outside. Worth the visit. Love their white chocolate biscuits. Can the factory is super clean

This is the place you can see, buy and try the shioi koibito cookies, this is like a museum, can spend a few hours there. You can also sign up (additional fee) to join the cookie making class, this is a very good activity for the family to bake and bring the cookie back home.

It is located together with the chocolate factory. It is a small garden like park with lots of summer flowers. It is a cute like getaway with lots of opportunities for picture taking. Hourly there was mechanical show which adds a class to the park

This place is good for both families as well as individual. There is a garden full of flowers and structures for taking photos. Inside the building you will need to pay 600yen to enter the factory and how they made the biscuits. It's quite hands on as well as visual part for you
Worth a visit if you have time. There is a rose garden which is really pretty in photos. But guess the scenery will be different in hokkaido's long winter

Shiroi Koibito is famous for its produce, white chocolate. Many visitors would bring home boxes of this goodie. I personally find it a bit too sweet but it is excellent as gifts. Each white chocolate is individually wrapped up. This "park" is big and interesting to walk around,

Before visiting this park, I went online to make reservations for the cookie making workshop, which includes the walking tour of the cookie factory. There are several workshop options to choose from and the English version of the site was useful. The website lists that you can
A must see for families with young children. It's almost like Willy wonka's chocolate factory meets a private European botanical garden.

The title "park" is a bit misleading, since this is a small complex of attractions, centred around the main drag, which is the Ishiya cake factory. If you, like me, are not Japanese this brand of cakes/biscuits is probably unknown to you, but they seem to be famous throughout
Beautiful garden with the roses in full bloom! Love it! Lots of delicious chocolates and candy to buy .

It wasn't a too far travel from Sapporo JR station. The free bits of the park included a really beautiful garden and a very European style building with a toy museum and candy making demonstration inside. Not half bad since it's free! My family got icecreams and sat at the
Nice place to visit, beautiful flowers. The whole place is full of life and activities. Good dessert available.

Educational and enjoyable visit! They have performances every hour and the park is magical. The chocolate factory is a must visit. You'll appreciate your chocolate cookie so much more by looking at how it's produced. We've also had a tea break at the cafe and it was delightful.

It's take about 5 minutes walk from Miyanosawa station. The flower garden here is really stunning and all decorations are so cute. What I like most is an ice cream. It's really tasty!! For the museum, I think it's just average nothing that special. Overall, I have a good time

I am not a person so much into chocolate, so I didn't find this place much impressive. The place tells you how they make their signature Shiroi Koibito chocolate. It was not boring but not that enjoyable for me. Anyway, you'd love it if you are chocolate lovers. In summer, there
must come use train takes time to reach here, but it will be forgotten when you reach here, they have side attraction and photo iconic inside their garden. they have famous snaks sell here, must come

This is throughly enjoyable and has something for everyone! From the kids train that circumnavigated it to the 60s memoribelia in the museums you can not get bored here. The gardens alone are worth the visit. Do not miss the candy making demonstrations.
Easily accessible by train... Beautiful garden... Fan of Shiroi Koibito should visit this place.. Many limited edition chocolates to buy... Not on sale at other parts of Hokkaido

I was happy for being there. A lot of shows, foods especially chocolate and flowers there. The decoration made it so beautiful to see and visit. The location is near the station and beside the Shiroi Koibito Park. Its a must for go there! ☺️☺️
Shiroi koibito is actually a chocolate factory turned museum with a really really nice park! The park is filled with flowers and ornaments, really beautiful!

I took a bus # 5 from sapporo station and got off a few blocks away from the park. Or you could take Tozai line from Odori subway station to Miyanosawa station (the end of the line) and walk from there (further walking distance). Inside they have a museum of tea set porcelains

It is an easily accessible destination on the subway. After exiting the station, there are signboards directing you to the Park. You have to actually cut through a Leraning Ctr and once on the street, you can actually smell the cookies.. really! We paid for the tickets to do

The factory walk tour was interesting...our 2nd time in Hokkaido...first was during Winter. This time the kids spent most of the time in a hands on workshop...where they put icing on a cookie shaped like the island of Hokkaido. Really nice...it lasts 7 days...so we ate one in
We went during Christmas. The lighting was pretty. We also went to the factory tour and get a free cookie. Must visit the cafe inside the factory. The dessert was good !

Visited the Shiroi Koibito Park in Sapporo recently. It is one of the oldest and most famous Chocolate Factory in Hokkaido. The exterior of the park is a beautifully landscaped garden, with many scenic spots for photo-taking. As you enter the main building, there are gallery /

The admission fee for the factory tour is 600 yen and you get a free Shiroi Koibito cookie. If you download the Sapporo Info app, you can also redeem a small gift (Shiroi Koibito post-its). The admission fee allows you to view a water fountain, some small galleries, factory, DIY

Very popular with large tourist groups but a must do for family holidays. The Gullivers land is fun and so is the train ride. The park around the factory with wafting chocolate smell takes you to a fairy tale land ..

This is Ishiya, where they make the famous 白色恋人 cookie. Love this place with the beautiful lush roses and magnificent exterior with intricate details. We paid to walk through the production line but my kids did not want to make a cookie, so no comment on that. Many pictures
It was like one of the attractions in Sapporo but you can buy Shiroi Koibito cookies anywhere in Japan (especially at the airport shops).

If you love cookies with chocolate, then this is definitely a must visit place for you! Shiroi Koibito park also is the location of the Ishiya Chocolate Factory, one of the oldest and most famous Chocolate Factory in Hokkaido and also Japan, and known for their famous cookies

The exterior of the park is like a fantasy place, with beautiful architectures and many scenic spots, great for photo-taking! Inside the park, there is a large shop selling the famous 白い恋人 chocolates, cookies, candies and souvenirs. Also they have scheduled candy-making sessions

This is the place where thousands of thousands of the famous 白色恋人 biscuits are made, having originated here in Hokkaido. This place can be easily access via Tōzai Line (Miyanosawa Station) about 7 stations from Odori Station. Upon arrival at Miyanosawa Station, just follow the

The name "chocolate factory" lured us here - it sounds amazing. However, this name really isn't true. More like biscuit factory (specifically, 2 cat tongue biscuits with a piece of white chocolate in-between factory). Even then, it is only a small part of this place. The rest of

Fun to all through of the buildings. If you are interested in the tour, go to the base of the clock tower and get your tickets at 700Yen per pax if I remember correctly. U get to see all sort of memorabilia from cups and containers related to drinking chocolate over the last few

Whenever I hear the words "Chocolate Factory" the first thing that pops in my mind is "Tourist Trap" where the factory ends up being a small shop with salespeople shoving all kinds of chocolates up your mouth LOL. However, I gave this place a chance because I heard a lot about

Came with low expectations but surprisingly it wasn't as bad as we thought. The exterior was great for photos with many nice decor for photo spots. We tried the cookies decor and the kids enjoyed it. I think this place is great for kids and dating couples including

Thumbs up for me because my kida enjoyed. So good place to visit for kids. Favorite cookie langue de chat. And popping candy chocolate kids love it. Although the place is small. Just visit the place if its along the way to your destination.

It's a famous Japanese chocolate brand. The facility is in a sort of industry surrounding. So you come specifically for this, nothing else. It's good for kids. Not recommended for adults only tour. Not giving you lots of free sample to try if this is your expectation.
The hotel staff said there is Royce chocolate available. Nope! Nice view of the mountains. Went at night and lighting made photos nice.

"Chocolate Theme Park" Experience: I think it is interesting to visit here apart for touristy reasons just because of the pure presence and endorsement of Shiroi Koibito branding in everything big and small, especially in Hokkaido (and also well heard of worldwide) - When I

What a way to appreciate the most delicious snack produced in Hokkaido??! We bought our entrance tickets for an affordable fee and went on a quick walk through of how they manufactured and produced this biscuit which has gotten so famous! There are numerous other activities
Can see how the famous Shiroi Koibito and some other Candy are made. Not particularly an attraction for adults who are looking for some cultural experience. Food was good though.

We went to this park while snowing heavily. My children enjoyed playing in the snowy park, making snow balls and throwing it to each other. The short tour inside the building was interesting and informative. Shopping was simple and you can get tax free service if you shop up to

We spent the morning there. Our little girl was more engrossed in playing at the outdoor area than going indoors. The snow park outside was fun for kids and the hourly bubbles and musical show was enthralling. Place was really crowded with bus loads of Chinese tourists! Sadly

This is a cute place to take photos of your kids in the garden. You can watch people make cookies at the factory or pay to join a cookie decorating class. All in all it is mainly a shop for you to buy shiroi sweets and icecream. Not worth the travel through rain and snow unless

A pleasant enough way to spend an hour or so but the tour is very short. The highlight is seeing the chocolate being made, but there isn't enough to warrant more than an hour or so of trundling around. English info available and helpful staff. You can design your own cookies

Production factory inside European style Castle!!! tonnes of chocolate and milk and ice cream to eat!!! Tell you the history and transformation evolve through the years till today. Children will like the place very very much. The interior and exterior decorated in style, lots of

A short rail trip from downtown, this place is a mini museum, park, demo chocolate factory and has a small cooking class. Entry is 600 yen and includes a bonus shiroi koibito biscuit. Pretty good! The architecture is nice in that somewhat overdone way, while looking at the

When we arrived there.. There was some TV show over there inside near the shop area. I think that was some baseball player interview but not so sure either. The scenery outside was awesome! There were a lot of mini houses, santa clause cart and deer, the light decorations OMG I
This place is very good, but crowd with tourist. The dessert is very good there, white thing one is good, not too sweet and worth for fatty. Outdoor park is adorable.

It is good for very young children and not for adult. It displays like a theme park and quite childish. We joined cookie making class there, really appreciate Japanese sense of hygiene, all participate need to clean their hand thoroughly, wear their standard apron. One time

Not reasonably a great place felt more like a tourist trap. Chocolates are limited in variety compared to departmental stores around train station. The cafeteria was good though. Try parfait & cheesecakes.

We went there because every tourist on tour seemed to be taken there, hence, out of curiosity we went to check out. We spent quite a bit by taxi to get there. The place was filled with shoppers. Queue to visit the factory was very long and we had to pay. Again out of curiosity

Shiroi Koibito park is part chocolate museum, part playground, with a nice little cafe which serves beautiful little parfaits and nice strong coffee. The cafe has a magnificent view so try to get a window seat.

This is a small (cookie? Chocolate?) factory which most of the tour buses stop at. You can watch the workers making the cookies but it is a short self guided tour and very crowded! You can sign up to decorate your own cookie, which is nice. The view is fabulous! One and done.

great place to spend 2 to 3 hours. directions to the factory is clearly marked after you exit from Miyanosawa station. you pay a small fee to enter and receive their speciality biscuit as a souvenir. take time to read about the history of the place plus the cups used over the

We referred to this place as the chocolate factory. It is a tourist trap, selling expensive and not particularly tasty cookies and cakes, way over priced. you can get much better stuff in the Sapporo underground shopping mall. The exterior is fashioned as a Chrsitmas Ginger
Great place to visit especially when its snowing! Its a chocolate factory which produces the famous chocolate blanc lang ue de chat.
The most memorable part of visiting for me is the smell of freshly baked cookies - almost worth the admission price alone! Otherwise it's all very sweet, pretty and predictable.

Kids had fun decorating the cookies, the finished products were packaged like giant versions of the original White Lovers' chocolates biscuits, cute! Look out for a white robot positioned near the entrance, it's super intelligent and can 'communicate' with visitors by replying

The factory visit is a little overrated and overpriced. 600yen for such a short visit is not exactly worth it. Taking pictures of the exterior is more interesting than the self tour of the factory. Souvenir prices are not factory prices as well. Same as what you pay outside.

Almost everyone who visits Hokkaido will return with a box of these cookies. So this is a visit to the factory that produces the cookies. Typically it is all very cute. The part where you can see the actual cookie production is short and compact. There are lots of other

Free parking at Shiroi Koibito factory, covered carpark leads to level 2 area. No need to pay for anything at Shiroi Koibito unless you want to take the cookie making tour/view their cookie making line. Every hour, the clock will chime and there'll be a mini performance in the
super nice place for kids. Candy's paradise. there is a tiny museum + candy production showcase. again kids will love it

This museum/ chocolate factory is full of a collection of interesting if not a little bit random artefacts. We saw cups and saucers, retro chocolate advertising, a fountain and a large collection of retro toys (which were very interesting) and also learnt the process of making

the ratings were good from tripadvisor. Went there based on those ratings. Only found it average and did not find anything special.. most items can be found in most departmental store anyway. the place is swarmed with tourist. extremely crowded when i was there. Entrance

Our family visited this chocolate factory in Sapporo and we loved it. It's like a mini theme park more than a factory that produced one of the more iconic snack here in Sapporo. At one part of the factory walk, we could actually see the actual production of the biscuits and that

If you're a foreigner, you can buy your cookies and other sweets tax free from the big shop on the first floor of the Tudor building. You have to spend at least 5000 yen though, so make sure to look at the tax free prices when shopping and adding up your total cost. There's a

We ended up here by chance but it was quiet cool for gift shopping. They have all kinds of sweets and chocolate, and really nice ice cream. Reasonably easy access on the Tozai line. Good place for people who love sweets

Going here: we took the Tozai subway line then exited at Miyanosawa station. After the exit, there are sign directions led us to the park which took us around 10mins walk Winter season made the park more beautiful because of the snow..it's like winter wonderland with shops
Kids enjoyed the parked outside playing snow and hide and seek. We also saw how the biscuits were made.

In case you don't know, there's a popular cookie in Japan branded 白色恋人. You will find it all across Japan and in many other countries. This is the factory for the cookie. If you are in the Sapporo area, it's worth a visit as it's only 30 minutes from downtown. Enjoy the free

It shows the production of cookies which is very interesting. The cookies are very delicious. You can feel that it melts in your mouth. The place was so crowded with tourist. Its a very touristic place, but worth a visit. The have garden which was decorated for the christmas

It is worth it simply for the many photo opportunities in the outside garden and throughout the house. We came late in the evening (just before 5 pm) and were through with the whole indoor self guided tour in under an hour. You get samples when you buy your ticket and there

Should you want to buy famous Hokkaido 白色 恋人 biscuits, it is best and worth to visit the factory though you could buy it everywhere in Sapporo. They have many choices for you to choose. Famous for its tourism. Have a beautiful garden outside the factory. The factory does not

We drove and reached the park at around 3pm, complimentary parking up to 7pm was provided. During the day, the place and especially the store was very crowded with bus loads of Asian tourists. We stayed till night fall when the crowds thinned down and the lights up made the
Kids had a lot of fun decorating cookies made at the factory and we tried the dessert at the 4th floor, it was sooooo good, one of the best we had so far. Gotta try ice cream when visiting Hokkaido!

As it was winter, along the way, we had a good time taking pictures of the snowy paths. Take exit 2 from subway. It's the nearest to the park. No need to buy ticket unless u r interested to see the factory. There were xmas decor so we took pics of both day n night. N of course

Finally, saw the 'chocolate factory' of the famous 白色恋人! Brought our kids aged 5, 7 and 12. They found it very fun! Played at the park (resembles a 'village', with many miniature-size houses, which are big enough for young kids to go in). Learnt about and saw the production

Came here as part of my Sapporo Trip, very excellent chocolate factory, flavour is uniquely Japanese fusioned with all the Flavours from Europe and US, great eye opening to the power behind the famous White Chocolate from Japan! Scenery: 5/5 Ambience: 5/5 Cleanliness: 5/5

It was not too difficult to get to the Shiroi Koibito factory, about 20 mins from Odori Park Subway station to Miyanosawa Station on the Tozai Subway Line. Just follow the blue signages as you exit from the fare gate. On reaching the main gate, it was awesome, the park was

This is a small park that houses the Shiroi Koibito factory. You can walk around the building, and see how the famous biscuits are made, and the history of chocolate. Upstairs, you can stop by the cafe, or take a class to make your own cookies. Everything here is quite cute,

My wife was very enthusiastic about visiting this park. She was going on about the cookie-making class and the chocolate & cookie factory tour. And she was right. 1. Beautiful landscaping The park ha/ Christmas decorations all over. Mini-houses, Christmas trees, reindeer and

We took a bus from JR Station, platform 5 bus number 55 or 57 is free of charge if you have JR Pass, Chuo bus also but you must pay about 600 Yen one ride. Stop at the Memorial Hospital and walk about 5 minutes to the gate. The entrance for tickets on the right next to the

The last attraction to visit for this day on the way back to Sapporo is the Shiroi chocolate park. This chocolate/ cookie factory now doubles as a tourist attraction. The building’s exterior is fairy tale like. Once, you enter the Tudor house, you will see a grand staircase with
Easy tourist place to visit on your own. Short away from subway station with clear direction signs along the way. Will be great for photo taking if snowing....

The service is very bad. The staff totally forgotten our order, when we asked about our order they were not really apologetic. We ordered a hot chocolate with orange liquor, the staff did not bother to place down the orange liquor until we request it. TOTALLY DISAPPOINTED WITH

This Park is stunningly beautiful - particularly if you swing by during the night when the place is illuminated in lights. The Park is currently decorated in Christmas ornaments and lights. Think reindeer and snowmen in Santa hats Must try the soft serve ice cream Biscuits

One subway ride from Sapporo to Miyanosawa on the Tozai line; and a short walk from the subway station got us here. The subway station staff had a map that directed us to this place. As we approached the cookie store, we could smell the sweetness of the goodies prepared here.

A must come if you are travelling with children. They have many things cateted for children here, like cookies decorating and the show ast the clock tower. Don't miss out the cafe. We enjoyed our tea there.

A unique and not to be missed experience if you are in Sapporo. The most extensive Toy Museum I've ever seen. The most delicious Hot Chocolate Ever!!! And the best soft serve ice cream I've ever tasted. And, yes don't forget to buy their chocolate biscuit sandwich.

Nice place for kids to run about. Miniature houses for taking photos! Train ride through the tunnel with my boys was so exciting. The paid tour was worth it. So different from the other factory tour in many other countries. Do drop by the cafe (cant remember 3rd or 4th

We were supposed to bypass this place, thinking it won't have much to see compared to winter which was astounding like a winter fairyland. But we were taken aback by the astounding beauty of autumn foliage and decoration. It is indeed like a fairyland too. I believe each

I'm happy just stuffing my face with the famous and super delectable chocolate biscuits which is the namesake of this theme park. But for those into theme parks, this is the usual trip into a fantasy world where milk chocolate flows in rivers and biscuits hang from trees. On the
Their most famous white lovers chocolate. A must visit and a must buy item in Sapporo. Every hour on the hour the clock puts on a spectacular display for the young and young at heart.
We have visited a Chocolate Factory with my teenage son in cold winter. Both have had fun in decorating a cookie, followed by an awesome drink.
Lots of fun activities and yummy food. Suitable for families with young kids Do not lose the parking coupon they give you in the way in, or there will be hell to pay on your way out.

This park is so awesome, just like a fairyland. I should say it is not only a wonderland to kids, but to all visitors. Love to immerse myself there. As you enter inside the building to see the famous cookies and chocolate making process and tour its museum, is another surprise!

Shiroi koibito is a famous chocolate cookie brand from Hokkaido. You can enjoy the gardens for free, but a tour in the factory and museum will cost you. The museum was nice, bot sure it is worth the price though. Good for children.

Immerse yourself in everything sweet at this good-sized theme park, home of the famous langue de chat Shiroi Koibito cookies. We didn't get to try cookie-making but we did do everything else at the park, including riding the small train that goes around the property. The whole

More suitable for kids. A mini wonderland to them. Entrance fee is needed to see the famous cookies making process. Another entrance fee if you wish to let your child to join the cookies making class.

get immersed in a wonderland feel at this park. a minimal entrance fee is required. best visited during winter! there are cafes inside the park as well! recommend to drink the hot chocolate! we ate ice cream in the open area covered in snow! definitely buy some goodies back!

I visited this factory with my family as part of a package tour. It is definitely a fun place to visit, especially for the kids. There is a cookie making studio where you can sign up for courses to make your own personalised cookie. There is a animatron performance every

We enjoyed the tour around the chocolate factory. We got to see how the chocolates and biscuits were made in the factory. We saw lots of interesting displays from old chocolate packaging and boxes, and toys. There is a nice cafe with delicious desserts on the top floor. We

Delightful place packed with humor n surprises. I specially loved the miniature wooden cottages complete with miniature furniture. Loved the european/danish architecture of the main building. Perfect place to snap lotsa pics and feel like a kiddo all over again! =D

it does not only have food but also nice mini theme park and museum inside. lots of old stuff and vintage collectibles. very worth touring around~ as to the sweet stuff, you can buy here lots of varieties of desserts good for souvenirs. better to buy here because its cheaper

If you like to take photos and in love with dessert, this is a place that you must visit in Sapporo. You will have experience like watching the 4D movie because you can also smell the sweetness since arrive. You can easily walk within 10 minutes from the Exit 2 of Miyanosawa

Great to visit especially if you love cookies and chocolate. It's worth doing the factory tour. They have museum that features demitasse cups and chocolate packaging. You also get to see the production line and see how chocolate is produced. You could also decorate your own

If you are a fan of the famous cookies, this place is a must go! Even if you aren't, skip the tour and go straight to the cafe for great desserts you don't usually get outside the place! Milk and hot chocolate are some of the must try!!!!

The chocolate factory itself is not so interesting but the garden is very beautiful and the decoration is very attractive. It is more to European style. Worth a visit for a sunny, free and easy evening.

The park is very big and offer you lots of experience. You can see the factory, make your own cookies, go for a coffee or just to play around in the park. There is a museum inside which displays lots of cool stuff for example a football shirt with Pele signature and other rare

You just need to pay for a one time entrance parking fee. Visit to this themed park is free except for the gamma phone museum. The moment you exited your car from the multi story carpark, the nice aroma of their famous biscuit brings you to wonderland, where you feel you have
Quite a random place with some weird and random stuff. Of course this is a good place to buy shiroi koibito products and at the same time try some of the soft cream and drinks from the cafe.

I love their chocolate cafe with yummy cakes coolers. Their confectionery biscuits are really good. The best time to be here is during summer when the English garden is in full bloom. Kids can learn to make confectionery biscuits.

Hands down the best place to hang out with family/friends in Sapporo! The design of this place is just remarkable. Reminded us how several beautiful cities in Europe were like. Not only the park was beautifully designed, they also had their specialty cookie and chocolates, which

The place packs a number of activities within its premises even though its not that big. Key activities include cookie making classes, photo opportunities with the miniature houses and rose garden as well as a small railway ride (lasts about 10mins) that runs every 20minutes

Famous place for making chocolates, sweets as well as cookies. After all, its a chocolate factory. The Rose garden is beautiful and covers a wide variety of flowers. The crowd mainly families and kids just love walking and enjoying the scenery while eating soft ice-cream. Do pay

This was part of my guided tour in Hokkaido and was probably one of the must-visits when in Hokkaido. The whole place decked out in fairytale style makes for very good backdrops everywhere, and an absolute delight to take as many pics as possible. But the herds of tourists

A great place for everyone but especially kids as the factory is housed in a beautiful old building and besides providing a view of the production process through large windows on the upper floors also houses a chocolate museum that educates you on the chocolate making process.

I visited this factory during winter and it was so magical. Especially when night falls, the lights of the park will light up the entire place. The entrance fee is 600 yen for adults and 200 yen for children. You will be given a small 'passport' to travel around the factory and

Whole area is not very big , just nicely decorated Probably only the kids enjoy this place , plenty of cute props around for them to play. Most adults are just resting at some table snacking or napping in the aircon areas waiting for tour time to end. We didn't spend too long

It is definitely for children.... but if you like me who loves chocolate and candy, this is your place to visit. The overall experience was great and picked up lots of candies and chocolate.. Good price overall and it is worth a visit.

I paid 600 yen for entry but couldn't find anything worth that money. Instead, if you have any child ride the small train near parking lot. My child loke that train much more than the museum. It cost me just 300 yen.

It was like a dream come true as you enter the Shiroi Koibito Park, really beautiful like fairytale castles! But I would definitely not recommend to go unless you are travelling with kids or you are a Shiroi Koibito fanatic. It's definitely overpriced for an adult ticket
This place has several things you can enjoy. There are park zone, preriod doll section, shopping zone and some you have to charge to access such as shiroi koibito production process.
A winter wonderland . With a tour of how the white chocolate lovers cookies made in the factory. A personal collection from the owner of vintage toys and nice vintage of hot chocolate cups.
Great place to visit and enhance your knowledge in the famous shiroi koibito chocolate factory. The park inside also has lots of beautiful flowers.

You can see chocolate being made on a production line and learn a small amount of how it is made. I've seen better chocolate museums elsewhere in the world (e.g. Germany). The rest of the park is an odd mix of a children's park, technology exhibition and a few other things.

We did the cookies making course (heart shaped cookies with own decoration). It was overall a good experience for first timers. It would have been nice if we could make the dough ourselves. The staff did the baking and cooling so it was a bit too much sitting and waiting for our

My family was traveling as a group (10), so we rented a guide for the day who took us to this little fairy tale of a factory. I know I missed so much of the gardens because we went straight to cookie making and then wandered the gardens afterwards. They were incredible though,

Feels like 'Alice in Wonderland'. I especially love the garden with assorted and beautiful flowers. Family members with children will definitely enjoyed this place. Do try the ice cream & confectioneries.

text.wiki:
Asahiyama Memorial Park (旭山記念公園, Asahiyama Kinen Kōen) is a park located in Chūō-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaidō, Japan. The park’s peak, at 137.5 metres (451 ft) above sea level, offers a great panoramic view of Sapporo, and the Sea of Japan beyond.


== History ==
Prior to the construction of Maruyama Park, the area was the site of a farm, and later Sapporo Onsen. In 1946 ownership of the property was donated to Sapporo city. Twenty years later, in 1966, the park was taking form, when over 5,500 trees were planted. The park was finally opened in 1970 to commemorate Sapporo’s 100th anniversary.
Since 2004 the park was closed for redevelopment; the entire fountain and the square around it, were built in those years; it was reopened on April 29, 2009.


== Overview ==

Located in the western extremity of Sapporo, the park’s lookout, located 137.5 mt above sea level, is surrounded by sculpted gardens with a large lawn, fountain, a terraced Italian flowerbed, French geometric garden and Chinese arbor. Surrounding these are the Learning Forest, which offers hiking paths, with the background of Ezo alder, Ezo spruce, magnolia and false acacia trees.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park also contains a rest house, food and drink stands, a hanging bridge, playground, and space for kids. At night the illuminated fountain and lights of the buildings in central Sapporo beyond, create a popular spot for couples to enjoy the night views of Sapporo.
The park is also the venue of the Sapporo Asahiyama Music Festival held every year in July, with the background of the Toyohira Hanabi.


== Access ==
JR Bus (Nishi13): 15 minutes from Maruyama-Kōen Station (Tōzai Line) to Asahiyama Koen-mae Bus stop, plus 5 minutes walk.


== External links ==
Official website

Great view of Sapporo. We gladly paid to use the ropeway and the rail car to go to the top of the mountain. The star projection in the little movie theater at the top of the mountain is not really interesting for people who don't understand Japanese.

With a big family in tow, it was quite a struggle to go up to Mt. Moiwa. There were several transfers before reaching the place but it was worth it! It might not be as high up as the mountains we went up to in Switzerland with cable cars, but Mt. Moiwa has its own charm. Before

The place offers you an amazing view of Sapporo city and Ishikari bay. I visited the place in January with my family .you can enjoy the perfect view in the evening time . Situated in the heart of the city , it is very convenient place to visit with family ( small kids). You can

Last December 18 my family went to Mt Moiwa, it was an awesome experience, the view was so beautiful, the trip on the way itself was a beautiful experience. We rode the tramp for the first time, The driver was so polite and kind to us. After the tramp we took the free shuttle

We visited on Dec 26th, taking a taxi from Okurayama Ski Jump. It was a short 6km ride costing approximately 1500yen for 4 of us. We left OSJ around 4.30pm, timing it such that we would get to Mt.Moiwa when it was dark. We read that the night views, because of the city lights

The views from the top was fantastic. Worth going up for the views. Taking the cable car up the top was a great ride. The usher bow to u when U are getting out of your cable car. That's the respect you get .. the feeling was great. Will go back again..
It is a nice spot to enjoy Sapporo citylights. Just be aware that during winter, the view are often blocked by blizzard. JPY 1700 for roundtrip cable car ride.
I personally like the ropeway and the view at the summit. It was breathtakingly beautiful and we were playing with a lot of snow at the summit. Great fun overall!
Windy and cold during winter. It also depends on luck. Sometimes there are snow or fog blocking. See the photo attached to have a idea. Download vouchers to get some discount.

Learn from my bad experience going to Mt Moiwa in the cold Dec month at night. Paid ¥1700 all the way to the top only to witness spots of lights among the vast darkness in sub zero temperature and strong wind blowing in your face. Would rather do something else more meaningful

Free shuttle bus from the streetbus (tram) station Ropeway Iriguchi. Also a good opportunity to try other local restaurants in the neighborhood away from the usual tourist areas like Sapporo train station, Odori or Susukino. Mount Moiwa is a very popular tourist spot, even

We visited Mt Moiwa on our first night in Sapporo. We decided to go there at night so we could view the bright city lights. We visited on an autumn night and it was pretty chilly so if you're doing the same thing,be sure to dress warmly. We took as many photos as we can, rang

Mount Moiwa offers great views of the Sapporo city. Went during the winter and the weather was so cold compare to other places. Only take half day/quarter day trip here.I went around 6pm and back around 9pm.The ride up and down on the ropeway was also enjoyable. Free shuttle bus

There is free shuttle bus near tram station to ropeway entrance. In the tram, there are leaflets stand which provides tram map and roapway discount coupons which will save your roapway fee 200 yen per person.

Mt. Moiwa boasts the best spot to view the city of Sapporo, and it did draw lots of people even on a rainy, humid August night. As you might have already learned, you need to take two different gondolas to get to the top. As the gondola sent us upward, the nightly cityscape

Mt Moiwa can be reached by a cable car. It is one of highest mountains in the Sapporo area.The peak has a bell, which lovers can ring to ensure eternal love, and also attach a padlock to the railing. The view from Mt Moiwa is gratifying. The peak is over 500 metres (1640 feet)

Don't really know what the fuss is about...to get there u need to get into a street tram, then get on a shuttle bus, then pay to get on a ropeway (which is basically a cable car) to the middle level, then a transfer to a smaller cable car to get to the summit. You do get a nice
Charming night scenery of sapppro. it looks like sea of 🌟. Also they have free shuttle bus. 1st thing should do in sapppro at 🌃!

Cloudy day on visit nearing sunset. The view was nothing wow, ticket to the top was not worth the experience. City view was so-so, everything is so tiny. Might as well skip this and Google sapporo City view instead. Lover's Sanctuary is kinda gimmicky. These are one of the

Easy way to get there is to take the tram (streetcar). There’s only one tram line and it makes a loop through the city. The Ropeway Iriguchi tram stop where you want to get off is about half way around the loop if you get on where most tourists do: on the street above the

We hiked up this mountain, using directions provided from an internet search. The hike up took us slightly more than an hour on a well-marked and we'll-travelled trail, past many Buddhist statues and local residents also hiking. The trail was slightly muddy due to recent rain.

So you can take the cable car if you want to, but I went with a group of people hiking up the trail. The trail is super well maintained and should be doable for all ages as long as you're physically fit enough to hike uphill. The top is a very beautiful view. I went in the
View from top is not that good. It is partially obscured by forest on the mountain. I would prefer mount Hakodate instead.

Went here on a weekday afternoon and the place was PACKED! The cable car ride up wasn't too pleasant as we had to squeeze with many other tourists, although they run frequent enough that we could have waited for the next one (but who knows if it would be the same). Great views

I did a hike up to the summit (great view of the city!) There are 5 routes to the summit (google it for more information) but I went up via the route from the Jodoshukanon Temple (starting from Kanonji Parking lot on google map) It is quite a short hike, took about 2 hours round

I brought my two sons and my daughter-in-law to Sapporo for a few days in July and we planned on going to Mt. Moiwa on July 14th. However, the rainy weather forced us to cancel those plans because the cloud cover was very bad on that day and the weather forced us to go

MT. Moiwa makes it possible to appreciate the extent and beauty of Sapporo City area. It is best accessed by car and then the Gondula. There is food and gift shop with wrapping service but best of all is ringing the bell to celebrate your arrival or any thing else you wish to

I'm glad we took this little side adventure. Mount Moiwa offers great views of the entire city. It was windy and cold on our visit to the top, but that probably kept the crowd sizes down. Actually, there weren't many people there at all. There's a little café area at the
Use the circular city tram to get there. If you are romantic couple buy the padlock at midway station (or bring your own) to put on the roof thingy shown in the picture.
Very simple attraction with very friendly staff. You get a nice view of the city and there is a restaurant to dine at if you want. Do it if you are bored.

We visited the place on a foggy day. It wast difficult to find and there is a free shuttle bus service from the bus stop to the cable car stn (return trip too). The person selling the ropeway tickets advised us abt the poor visibility but we still bought the tickets. At the peak

I didn't know night view of Mt. Moiwa is top three night scenic view in Japan. You can see 360 degrees from the peak. 1.9 milion people living city light is shining beautifully. Top of the montain is windy. You need to bring a jacket even the temperature is over 20 degrees.

To avoid too many people we went to the top before sun set. Unfortunately, the weather was not with us and it was windy and raining. The shuttle bus from the tram station is relatively small so it will not be able to cope with large input of guests. The day view from the

We drove and took the mini cable car up to the mt moiwa. Need to pay for parking (toll) and also for the mini cable car. We went in the afternoon, it was quite windy. Nice view of Sapporo. We rang the bell of happiness for good blessings. Should have brought a padlock to place
need to take two times of cable car to reach the hill top. good panoramic view of Sapporo city. was told it"s beautiful at night.
Well worth a visit - Mt Moiwa is easy accessible via streetcar then courtesy shuttle bus to the lower Ropeway (Cablecar) station. Spectacular views over Sapporo.

Me & my friends went there on January arround 8pm, we took the tram & free shuttle. When we finally on the top, the weather was soooooooooooo cold & snowy. We only there for like 5mins to saw the view and took picture, then we went back inside. Beautiful view... but not
Sunset worthy spot, but however, after sunset hours, the cable car to go down will take 1-2 hours. There is a total of 2 cabins and limited pax going up and down. Be prepared to wait.
Very easy to find this place, take sapporo tram street car, stop at Iriguci rope way stop,free shuttle bus waits you and take to the front gate of Ropeway station.
Took a trip here at night and was able to see the whole of Sapporo spread out in front of us. Amazing sight.

The reason why you should go to the top of Mt. Moiwa is that there is not really any reason why you should not. Not every city has a ropeway up a hill from which you can get a great view, but Sapporo does. So why not go up there and enjoy the view? It is very convenient to get
Although it was hazy the view was stunning and well worth the trip to the top. Of course had to ring the bell for many many years of love!

We were attracted by the advertisement for the beautiful night scenery from the peak (the one with the bell). The bell looks beautiful particularly at night, but we just cannot manage to take any photos with the same angle as the advertisement. What we can capture in the photo

I am not sure if it's worth the 5 minute view to have to spend a good two hours round trip for that. the lines -when the weather is decent and there is actually something to see- are CRAZY. you spend 5 minutes at the top because it's amazingly cold ( I visited in May) and you
Great experience ascending/descending the mountain using the cable car, beautiful view from the top, must go places when you are in Sapporo.
If your time schedule allows, do not miss this tourist attraction. You can get there by tram and a free shuttle bus. Overlooking the city of Sapporo, by day or night is spectacular. Don't miss it!

I always wanted to visit Sapporo, Hokkaido for their cute food and beer even though I dont drink. Some people say that they have good parks. So I prepared for parks itinerary while in Sapporo. But when I touched down Sapporo last week, I read review that Mt. Moiwa is one of best

It's a must write for me on the early part of the Mt. Moiwa trip. We slighted at the station of Ropeway Iriguchi to take the free shuttle bus to the ropeway. The attendant there is more than fantastic. 10mins of waiting time he was polite and courteous and friendly. To every

Wasnt that easy to find the route up considering its one of the main tourist attractions. There were no signage of directions from the nearest streetcar stop (Denshajigyosho-Mae). However, once you've braved the 15 minutes trek to the ropeway building, it's a nice ride up to

We visited here at night right after the sunset (I wish we could have seen the sunset). It was an incredible experience. Riding the ski lift to the top of the mountain, you could see all of Sapporo with all the buildings and lights. There is so much life in Sapporo! The first
Good view of the City. We got special discounted rates by buying from tourist center office in Tanukikoji. =)
Highley recomeneded, I suggest going up about 30 minutes prior to sunset. The day/night view are both spectacular.

We chose this ski resort because it was close enough to our hotel in Sapporo to get a taxi there and back in a day, and because we have novice skiers with us, so we didn’t need a more up market resort. The beginners slope is not as well arranged for learners as other ski fields

I heard of this place through here and I just had to check it out. I went close to 9 pm this past Wednesday night, hoping there would be a smaller crowd. We made it before the last free shuttle and we were rewarded with spectacular views! I recommend a good jacket for this time

One of the rated night view of Japan was indeed beautiful, it snow heavily when I turn dark so I couldn’t take much photos. Crowded with tourist, so be more careful when you are at top.

Mt.Moiwa can access by street car (tram) and when arrive iruguchi station and continue with the free shutter bus to the cable car centre. On top the Mt.Moiwa we can see the whole Sapporo city view especially the night view are amazing. On top the Mountain the snow scence are

Unfortunately I didn't manage to go up to this attraction. That is because I went in the middle of Febuary with the initial thought of going to see the snow festival with a few add on things. But if you do wish to go up here as I heard the view is fantastic, then please check

The night view from Mt. Moiwa near Sapporo, so beautiful that it has been listed as one of the “three best night views of Hokkaido.Place for lovers.It only takes about 30 minutes from Sapporo station, and is a very important sightseeing spot.
Visited here toward the end of the day and watch the sun go down. Its gorgeous to watch the lights come on over the city as the place turned dark. Seemed like Christmas in February!

One of the best place to try for foreigners & locals alike. If you happen to be in sapporo city, Don't forget to include this tourist spot on your schedule. You will love the breathtaking view of the whole sapporo city from the top of this mountain. Very accessible from sapporo

We visited this mountain on a cold February evening. The view was spectacular and well worth the trip, but very, very cold. You couldn't stay out long but ringing the bell gave a nice photo opportunity . Cable car was cramped ,but if you were by the window you had a good view.

We took the cable car and rope car to the top of Mt Moiwa. Lots of snow but the views are incredible. Watched the 3D movie which was interesting although it was Japanese which was to be expected of course but still got the gist of it. Had an ice-cream which seems to be the norm
Worth to visit while in Sapporo Nice view of Sapporo from the top of the mountain A bit cold in the evening
