text.quote: Grand red-brick former government building from the 1880s, with exhibits on Hokkaido history.
trip: Iconic historical building that formed the seat of government for a period of time. I typically visit the grounds every time I am in Sapporo. It is right downtown, adjacent to upscale shopping and dining venues and within a few minutes' walk from from the south side exits of

Whereas in other seasons the building may be framed by a sea of different hues, visiting in January, the colourful building stands out against a monochromatic background of a grey sky and a blanket of fresh snow. The Former Hokkaido Government Office Building is nicknamed
Our Japanese friend wanted to go there, or we would not have gone. We went after getting warmed up in the underground walkway, so we were ready to be outside a bit longer.

The Hokkaido Government Buidling is built in Western style. When Hokkado was being colonised in the late 19th century, it reprsented the fact that Hokkaido was a new State, and part of Japan. As Japan's northern-most island, Hokkaido gets very cold in winter. It's a good place

Built in 1888 and has done several restorations including the current design of its iconic Green octagonal dome and its enduring red bricks famous for photographers, locals and tourists alike on every season but specially during Winter where the snow added more charm and life to
The building stands out in the middle of the office blocks. Looks grand with its red exterior and European style. The grounds were beautiful in winter with perfect white and soft snow all around.

As usual, typical people who comes to this place. But yess its very beatiful. No wonder everyone wants to be here. After visiting this place, we know that Hokkaido is a state and Sapporo is like their district/province
Nice park to walk around. I think there is a museum but its currently closed? So I was only able to wander around outside. I would go back again when the museum is reopened.

You must visit here if you come to sapporo, in order to understand the history of the place. It's free of charge and has a nice garden around it. Walking distance from both Sapporo station and Odori park.

This is a Baroque style red brick building. It is a museum but currently closed due to renovation. The garden and landscape in front of the building is very scenic. It is a good place for a stroll and snap some photos.
MUST visit! We were there and witness snowfall. It was like falling in love all over again. So beautiful.

Another very beautiful place to be in - Autumn. The red brick building may be historic, but the pond even viewing from the entrance & sidewalks were superb, serene & forms very pretty surroundings. Do which ever post & yet it was picture perfect. The multi hue & the
Nice old building with history. Tend to be crowded with tourist and there is few booth open after the main gate. good to spend up to 45 mins looking around and taking picture
I found this building by accident and thought it most beautiful. I just had to go in and find out what it was. I then saw the ponds and trees in Autumn leaves. I was entranced.
Get in your steps walking around the government building enjoy the sights and photography opportunities.

This is a landmark that I couldn't miss on my first visit to Sapporo. We took the underground to Sapporo Station to visit this Former Hokkaido Government Office (Red Brick Office) building close to the station. The grand red American neo-Baroque style building built in 1888 that
Just a nice sight to see. They have a little reflective pond in front which is beautiful. It’s a nice detour if you’re walking around town. Not a destination spot.
Lots of photo opportunities outside around the gardens. Absolutely beautifully kept. The actual museum is closed for the next 4 years. Still a great place to drop in to see.
This is a nicely preserved landmark. Really impressed with the way the building and landscaping are maintained. Construction was in progress to be finalized in Spring 2020.
This is a nice, well maintained building with very pleasant grounds. It is worth a walk through for the lovely gardens.
Attractive build set in pleasant grounds. Free entry and a low key museum inside. Easy access from the JR & Odori stations.
Interesting free museum with info & artifacts from the northern territories of Japan. The surrounding gardens & pond were very pretty.
You can definitely spot this unique red building from far away. The entrance fee was free of charge. It was fun to get to know the history of Hikkaido.

It’s free of charge. Exhibition is available for you to understand more about how the ex directors of Hokkaido works, as well as the history behind. Bilingual panels are available so it’s foreigner friendly. A recommended place to go and it’s near O-dori Park and Sapporo
A nice walk through a historical provincial Hokkaido government building. The outside is more interesting than inside and our kids found the visit less interesting. Good for a 15 minute visit.
Nice historic government building. Beautiful park surrounding the building. Documents museum. Nearest subway exit is Akrenga Mall. 👍
The impressive red brick government building holds lots of information and displays for those interested in Hokkaido's history.
Good place to sit and rest. Peaceful pond and garden. Come in mid to late May to see tulip. Early May has Sakura too. Have some Sakura on May 19.

The building looks beautiful, and is well preserved both outside and inside. The place is used mainly as a museum for Hokkaidō history. There does not however appear to be a main theme for the exhibits, and it is especially difficult for non-Japanese visitors to follow as most

Located at the city, easily can reached. Have a park outside the building. Visit on April, the building under construction but still can visit inside. Information mainly is Japanese language. There have a small shop inside the building.
Went to visit the old givernment building. The US style of red bricks looks so nice. People can go in & see some arts. They also have a souvenir shop second floor.

I wouldn’t say it is a MUST do whilst you’re in Hokkaido, unless you’re really into history and what not. It’s a good place if you just want to stroll around as there’s park nearby. You’re able to go into the building, to the upper floors and into certain rooms, however still

Not sure this should be high on your priority list. The doorway was covered with sheeting. Not sure if this was for the cold weather or if building is closed. The grounds are snow covered and huge mounds of snow are everywhere. I am sure it will be different if you visit in

You are only able to get into the grounds at present as the doorway is closed for visitors. I do not know when they will be letting people around. There are explanatory signs around in the garden about the building . At present the gardens are snow bound.

Was happy we stopped here. There were staff on the ground volunteering to take our photos. They were offering free mailing services too with free postcards. There was a hot milk bar beside it. We went inside the building to find a museum. Though most were in Japanese, there were
Disappointing, attractive historical building with great Japanese Hokkaido significance . However most of the exhibits are in Japanese. Still Free attraction . Quick 40 mins out of the cold !
A must to visit as this building located by walking distance from Sapporo Station. The place is beautiful and worth to visit and for instagram!

Glorious old dame... am sure it is the great pride of Japan. Unfortunately for non-Japanese visitors, it's tough to truly soak into the history and appreciate it fully. Most texts in Japanese, so makes it hard for us to understand many things... Still worth a visit though...
It's sad that such a beautiful building is not well maintained. The glory is choked under the shade of surrounding tall buildings.
A landmark great for photo taking both during the day and at night. An iconic place that one will pass by if you’re getting to and fro the Sapporo main station.
Very charming and picturesque at night. Worth a photo stop if you are staying nearby or passing through.
...and the miny park around it is a nice walk too, if you're ion the area. For us it was just one stop amongst a few , on a walk around town.

The building is just so beautiful to look at both from ourside and inside. Very grand and it stands out from the rest of it’s surrounding. It’s now a museum, tourist information centre and small gift shop. I visited it during summer and there was a pop-up stalls around the

I was walking from Susukino towards the JR Sapporo station this morning 08 Nov 2018 and chance upon this gem at around 10.10 am in the morning. After reading the banner outside , then I realized that it’s a UNESCO heritage building ! Colours of the autumn leaves makes the whole
As part of the tour, visited this place, nothing much actually. Can skip it if you do not have time.
Boring just a red brick building Lot of other more fun things to do ! Go to the beer museum!! Unless u really love history. Give it a miss !

A magnificent, red-brick building in the centre of Sapporo near the clock tower and station. A free - entry museum, (with an ink-stamp for collectors of stamps!) is surrounded by beautiful gardens, was built to American design and reflects this heavily, although a number of

This looks just like something you might expect to see in the West, this former governmental building is interesting enough for a foreign visitor, although some of the exhits and information in the building is only in Japanese, many have English translations. The building and
Take a nice walk from Sapporo station to get here.... It's a nice building full of history and tradition It has a museum but unfortunately most of the explanations are in japanese

The building itself is impressive and there is a beautiful garden and mini lake to walk around. Great location for those who love photography. You can get really great shots of nature with the reflection of the sky and surrounding buildings from the water. Very nice and
I didn’t enter, but it’s a nice building to take a photography. It’s also near the other turístico places in Sapporo.
It is located near the Hokkaido University. It has an Old European style building. We can enter the building by free, however please watch out about the closing time. There is souvenir shop inside.

We just stroll around the place . The tour guide explained the history behind the place. Nice gardens , courtyard , and of course , the building itself . We didn’t get the chance to enter by the way .

They show you at this place how the Japanese were influeneced by the west after the war and it is very interesting. It is a very big place and there are no taxis outside the building to go back so you can ask the reception to call a taxi for you.

Visit historical Former Goverment Building Saporo in Spring and one would see the beautiful archictecture of this Building. The scene is complimented with the beautiful flowers in bloom. Feast one eyes with the beautifully landscaped courtyard.

It was a great place to spend some time and have a stroll. Sapporo is a place with flowers and lots of green. Didn't get to go inside though, not sure whether can. I went around 5 pm. The door was shut.

Well worth a visit - the gardens are immaculate and beautiful. The building is interesting and important in Hokkaido's history. Inside there are some displays, including one explaining the tussle between Japan and Russia over the islands off Hokkaido. Enough in English to make

The architecture on the outside is nice and photo worthy... the exhibits inside however can be better. Exhibits have limited English translation so unless u are really familiar with Japan's history, it can be difficult to follow.

An old building surrounded by colorful flowers in the gardens. Just simply beautiful! We did take the opportunity to go inside for the free museum but did not spend much time in there. The colorful tulips really made this place alive when we were there in late spring. A good
Well maintained and with a beautiful pond and garden. The building is old but looks magnificent! Must see when in Sapporo.

Nice stroll, good place for photos. A couple was taking bridal photos while I was there. Seems popular with tour groups.

As we are not a family of history buffs, the history of this building did not really beckon us to explore. We did however explored the outside patches of gardens to take pictures of the beautiful cherry blossoms, tulips, and shaped trees. We did venture inside as entrance is
This is a must visit tourist attraction in Sapporo. Now with cherry blossom and beautiful tulips, a scenic place for photo taking.
A beautiful area surrounding a lake. Nice variety of local flora (and the occassional small, friendly birds) including blossoms. Loads of photo opportunities and a great place to chill out

You should not miss this attraction. The building is lovely and it tells some interesting history stories about Hokkaido. The park is just lovely to stroll around. Entrance is free It is closed on weekends.

This was recommended as an attraction for visitors and coaches of tourists flooded this site even in a cold day. I am probably too old to find this an attraction anymore after been to so many grand buildings.

Very interesting event to see during the same time as the Sapporo Snow and Ice Festival. Located on the grounds of the Former Hokkaido Government Building. This 30 minute presentation is done with laser lights projected onto the building. It is accompanied with music and

Had a very interesting museum inside with multiple exhibits and easy to understand, most was in Japanese but there was a lot of English available and the night-time light show is very interesting lasting for approximately 15 minutes but is well worth it.

Visited in June 2017. Interesting place to learn about Hokkaido history and appreciate the vintage architecture. The grounds were simply beautiful, with flowers everywhere. It was also peaceful to walk by the pond.
Free entrance and I got a free gift from filled up the questionnaire provided by the tourist association as they are doing a research. :)
old building free visit. night light show is good. brilliant red in the snow. close to downtown area with a lot of good restaurants nearby..
This is historical Hokkaido government office. Massive red brick building. So pretty during the winter. I just came to look at this beautiful architectural structures.

Went for a look round the building during the day time and there was quite a lot to look at and read although not everything has English translations. In the evening there was a light show on, in conjunction with the city's snow festival, which consisted to projections onto the
It was snowing and the entire place was white. Go around 9am to avoid the crowd and get good shots. Expect to spend around 15 mins there. Worth the walk.

I went here last January when I had a little free time from my business trip. The building is worth the view and also you can do several activities here. I was shocked even there was a couple did their pre-wed photos here!
Worth making a quick detour to check out this building at dusk and all lit up. It was a 10-15 minute walk from the snow festival.
Very nice place to see with a free museum. They put a lots of lights and they have a light show in the evening. Unfortunately we were there during the day but the park is nice.
We saw very beautiful autumn foliage in this park. There is a big pond with ducks. Nice place to take photos and enjoy the scenery.

Beautiful office building located at the center of Sapporo. Easy to access and have a beautiful park. Foliage at the first week of November is extraordinary beautiful and have a great stuff of Hokkaido and Sapporo history. Don't worry this museum have phone application for
Very beautiful.. 10-15(or lesser) mins walk maybe from Sapporo station.. definitely a tourist attraction many were taking photos..
has so many pictures here as i felt i was in one of the english castles. building was so nice and it had a large pond and a park also.

If English is also included in the pictures of yesteryears, we could have understand better. Depended on google translator to know what was written. Not sure though if there’s guided tour to this building as we were on our own. Note that not all the rooms are accessible to the

Though this is a site of historic value, there are other exhibitions from other museums (when I visited) and plenty of artefacts and even the preserved setting of the old government office. A recommended site while visiting Hokkaido!
Visited at night. Great with snows and lighting. Less people when I visited. It was quite cold night. But very romantic and nice.
Inside this former Hakkaido Goverment Office building, has a room introducing it past history and another room sell sourvenir. And you could get a stamp of the building at the centre of entrance.

When we visited the place, it was snowing, which makes it more beautiful. Inside the building there were some showing rooms, but not interesting to us. But I really like the red brick architecture though. Very nice place.

The Former Hokkaido Government Office Building is a very beautiful and old style building in the city. There is a beautiful garden around it. The building itself has a attractive red shape which make it very attractive. The inside of the building is separated into several rooms.

Stopped by for a brief visit when walking from my hotel (near JR station) to Susukino. The building is really pretty to look at, but only moderately lit up on the outside when it gets dark. Inside though, it is properly lit. It seemed to contain a few museums (wih entry fee) -

It stand majestic on the preserved ground. Very beautiful on a bright winter morning. The surroundings must be lovely in summer with lakes and trees. Downside is there is no English board to explain the significance of the building.

The scenery is great especially at night with lighting all around and if you happen to be there when there is a light snow fall, it makes the whole scene perfectly unreal! You get lots of historical info with a short visit to the old Hokkaido Government Office Building.

This historical building doesn't need much review beyond what has already been said. But it should be noted that it's particularly beautiful on a winter evening, when the surrounding trees are lit up with classical white lights.
No trip to sapporo is complete without a visit to this beautiful building. It houses a lot of history that it would make no sense to skip it.
Nice scenery of garden and office I got there on night such a beautiful garden lamp on trees and garden

Dropped by here. There were some stalls selling fresh produce, ice creams, and bread! Lovely flowers planted all over. Free wifi! Stepped in and you're transported back through time. Walk up the red carpeted stairs to view the office as it was used during previous times. It's a

A famous and outstanding building in the city centre near Odori Park and Sapporo Station. There is a brief history shown in the museum. A good place for photo taking. I love the small garden near the building.

The Gardens surrounding this building are well maintained with an eclectic collection of trees, bridges and architectural features and several ponds filled with massive and colourful Koi. On weekends the site is often filled with cultural events like the annual Hokkaido Kabocha
Good selection of Japanese food stalls and local produce for shopping, tea break, lunch and snack. Picked oysters and scallops which tasted yummy.
Not really worth a detour to visit but if you are in the area, the gardens are a nice place to visit especially in Autumn. Pretty place for a stroll
Another "icon" of Sapporo. Pleasant place to visit and take a stroll as well as get a glimpse of Sapporo's past. Very pretty during the day as well as night.
This was a nice building to walk around after sunset to get nice pictures. It's lit up very well with large lights.

This museum is free to get in and is average at best. The building is nice looking and an example of late European influenced style. There was very little English language signage making some of the exhibits a puzzle. The park grounds around the lakes are very Japanese with

A very common Western style historical building that is not well maintained. The wall paper was peeling off with water damage. There is very little English information to read about the building either. Free entrance.
To me I would of thought it was a few hundred years old. But built in 1888, beautiful spot to just sit and look at flowers and chat as well. I enjoyed it

Nothing exciting, just a historical building. It was not very well presented and certainly not a place for foreigners as not English sign posted at all. Staff was not helpful and spoke very minimal English

Good to look at to see the architecture around sapporo. You dont have to specially walk to visit this place. Its quite close to sapporo station, nearby places are good for dining and taking nice pictures.

The building has some interesting history and very lovely gardens. Inside the building is like a museum with good displays and a few rooms were the displays are changed regularly. Worth a couple of hours to visit when staying at Sapporo.

This is the gorgeous building and the grounds around it are very beautiful. We used it to cut through to get to the train station but it was definitely one of the nicer spots in Sapporo and worth heading over to.
Not much to tell here, we just visited the outside park and lake, and took some selfies with the cherry blossom trees.

Feeling great being here. I bet the winter make this place lively. Great biilding great view. It a must to have a picture with this building which mark that you are in sapporo. Dont miss a chance to selfie with a cute ready made snowman there.

This building is well-known for its western-style architectural structures, once burned down and restored. Facilities available including a museum, library, reference room and souvenir shop. A large collection of historical materials and records of Hokkaido and numerous
A must visit place after odori park, can see how the former government building looks like. Entrance is free

There is a very interesting museum, which is very informative about the historical political relationships between Japan and Russia. However, as a tourist, I would not spend money to visit Sapporo. The city does not look like a Japanese city. Hokkaido should be visited only by
Beautiful architecture, and worth a visit when in downtown Sapporo. Easy to combine with the old clocktower. Great exhibits, and worth seeing.

No entrance fee to enter this building. Nice to take photos of this landmark and its pond and gardens. Walking distance from the Sapporo Station. Was not able to visit the second floor though, just the book shop and the small exhibit on the first floor.
Took my family for a bit of history and really enjoyed this building. While there they had a food truck vendor market right in front of the building. Loved the turn of the century style of buildings.
No elevators so elderly could only visit limited first floor exhibits. The better displays are upstairs.

Maybe I'm just not that interested in this history, but the things on display weren't interesting at all. Not much English text so I couldn't understand most of what I was seeing. You could probably just go to the park surrounding the building for a nice walk- which is honestly
Visited the building during winter and managed to capture some really amazing photos. There are some historical info and display in the building, good for educational visit.
Another good place to know more about Japan apart from taking great photos with this gorgeous architecture.
Go early to avoid tourist buses. A small but nice pond with lotuses. Very close to odori park worth a quick photo while passing by.
In this region of Japan this is a very old building. We enjoyed wandering through the exhibits showing the history of the area.
Nice grand building which used to be the seat of power in sapporo. Today, it is a nice museum with well preserved building and garden. Admission is free.

This is my first visit to Sapporo. Took a walk about the city this morning and found myself in the centre of the 26th Yosakoi Soran Festival. So, making Detour I headed for this building. It is set in manicured parks land as you'd expect from the Japanese. The verdant display

Love this place. ESP the garden in front of the building. Cannot imagine how it looks like at winter snow time or Spring blossom time. The trees , flowers and the huge sky. It is a great place for a walk anytime during the day . The old building itself tells u iits history.
Lovely old trees, 2 large ponds, flowers and an old building. A great place to rest after walking around Sapporo. Recommend a break here
Located at the end of Odori Park, this building will attract you with western architecture and of course the colour. For history and architecture buffs, this place is for you.

I can recommend this location for a beautiful park-like setting and sakura viewing, even in mid-May. We hoped to see the cherry blossoms this late in Hokkaido since it was still relatively cool, but found them hard to find until we stumbled onto this property. The sakura was

Built in 1888, the former Hokkaido Government Office Building is one of Hokkaido's most famous buildings at the heart of Sapporo. With its red brick walls, it stands out among Sapporo's more modern buildings.
It is a must go place where you can see a very clean and well maintained old building... The landscape outside is beautiful...

It's a must see if you're nearby and want to sit for a while and just catch your breath. Great pond with colorful Japanese koi carps, so be sure to step away from the front of the building after taking your pics and explore the gardens around you.

One of the reasons we visited Hokkaido early May is to catch the last of the Cherry Blossoms season in Japan. However, most of the places we visited have just a few of the blooms left, including Hokkaido Shrine ( more details in my other review of this place... We decided to

We encountered this building on our walk through the grid of Sapporo. It was early March 2017 so there was much snow on the ground. The building was a nice red brick building and the snow made it even nicer. The ponds surrounding were frozen over and there was a lot of snow
Short walk from JR Sapporo station. Free admission. 2 lines of cherry blossom trees right after main entrance. Small park but enough colors to lift up your mood.
The other name of this building is Red Bricks buildings and have nice garden around the building. Today is a museum about Sapporo government history.

I stopped by here while moving from Sapporo station to hotel nearby Odori park. This place has beautiful old building and some cherry blossom tree. I think you need to visit here when cherry blossom tree has flower. Anyhow it is worth visiting here for a moment.

This edifice standing fgor over a century can be easily visited while walking to Odori Park from Sapporo station . It is quite a grand structure and as you enter on the ledt you can have good photo opportunity with sakura trees and Japanese style small garden . A nice place
It has a beautiful pond with flowers and ducks. As it is free for entrance, you can enjoy Sapporo history displayed inside of the building. Worthy to spend your time.
Nice gardens to stroll around. A few displays in the government building it self. All free of charge.
As compared to Malaysia, their appreciation for history and culture is well demonstrated, hence giving much credibility to why foreigners love to visit this place despite the cold.
It is a place with lake birds and ducks and pleasant gardens and bench to meditation. Is a invite to life reflection.

The Botanical Gardens (closed Nov until end Apt), the Old Government Building and the Clocktower are an easy walk from Sapporo station. The architecture of the building is interesting and is surrounded by lovely gardens.

nice garden outside the building... I can't say there are many things to see inside but it was enough for us... it was good that there were benches for us to take a rest as it took us a while to walk to there under hot weather.
Well maintained government building with nice park to stroll around in the afternoon. Worth the visit for less than 1hour. Its free entry.

The outside of this building is neat, and it's interesting to see this kind of architecture in Japan. We didn't understand many of the exhibits because everything was in Japanese and I didn't find any English, or other language, translations.

The grounds and building are interesting and provided an enjoyable visit. The highlight for me was the room given over to an explanation of the issues between Japan and Russia over the northern islands of the east coast of Hokkaido. If you have half an hour to an hour free in

Uses to be a government building, akarenga is turned into tourist spot and a museum. I visited during winter so the place is very romantic, covered with snow and ice. The inside is a museum about Sapporo government history. A nice building influenced by European style.

Only walking distance from Nakamuraya ryokan. It's located in front of the road 5min walk from the Ryokan. We took pic and enter the office for free and got stamp. Historical red bricks buildings with the snowy park, ensure morning and night pic taken.

The Former Government Building is a good place to get history tidbits about Hokkaido and Sapporo. At the 2nd floor we found displays about territorial dispute against Russia (which is now resolved) and info on their former provincial governors.

The building's architecture is a pleasant change from the modernity of the majority of Sapporo's buildings, and is accessible by the nearby underground passage, connected to the major buildings and shopping malls in the city's centre.

I wandered around this place while walking about in Sapporo. Just though I would check it out. The structure is nice solid construction. The real beauty is in the surrounding landscape. Beautiful ponds surrounded by interesting trees. Worth walking around.
The garden there is beautiful in winter time. The trees are big. Building is beautiful but full with tourist all the time.
We couldn't get in as it was weekend but from outside is just amazing blanketed with snow. it's beautiful in winter and worth a visit.
Classic red bricks building, free admission to learn a piece of history of Sapporo. Even in winter, the building look stunning cover with snow! Good for photography and time passing...
Beautiful building. Lit well at night/evening. Free entrance to enter the building to view some sort of antique furniture and historical stuff
We went there both in Sakura season and summer. Great place for dine photo shoot along the walking trail from Odori Park to Sapporo Station.

If you like history & museums of some sort, this is a place for you. If not, you will probably find this place boring. Admittance is free. The red brick building is classic and holds a historic meaning. There is one particular room that explains all that in details. For

Great exhibits and information about the area. Historical building and very informative. If you like history and knowing more about the area you are traveling in, definitely recommend. Lots of stairs to climb, can't remember if there was an elevator though. Beautiful when it's
Basically a government office where it shows office furnitures and some issues Hokkaido face. Free entry. Visit only if you have time as there is nothing really interesting.
this old & historical building is really clean and the environment is really nice. i love the lake in front of this building. English style building.
went there in winter. The whole place is blanked in white snow. truly beautiful and scenic. great photo opportunity. Walking distance (abt 15 mins) from sapporo station
Very scenic area outside the building especially in winter when the park is all white with snow while the building stands out with its red brick building.
Beautiful historical building. It looks incredible during the winter night when we were there. So magnificent.
Wasn't fantastic, there isn't much to see or do in the building itself though the building looks amazing in pictures!

Nice to take pictures during winter. The view of this building with snow everywhere even the walkway make it beautifully and lovely. The visit to the government house is free of charge. Those who are interested of it's history is worth the visit.
We walked past this place and it was a good spot to take some pretty pictures. You can enter the building for free and walk around. There's a museum although everything is in Japanese.
The place looks beautiful when it is clad in snow. Very nice for photo taking. Easily accessible from JR Sapporo station. After that you can walk to Hokkaido University campus to have a look around.

Previously when we were at Sapporo, we did not managed to visit this place and thus, we made sure that this time round, we will definitely visit this place due to its historical value. Never regret as the building itself is magnificent. The surroundings felt more like a park

This former building is more of a photo opportunity stop for tourists. There are lovely trees and colorful flowers all around this Massachusetts architecture - inspired building. There are 2 floors of museum in the former office building. A quick run through to the various
Beautiful red building with some historical exhibition inside, should visit once if come to Sapporo!

We have visited this place twice in two years and the two lakes on either side of the building are divine. One year the entire place was covered in snow and was a stunning winter wonderland perfect for photos & snow fights. This time it didn't snow but the lakes were frozen and
It was a lovely place to visit. The park at the side was really beautiful. Entrance to the museum is free. Can easily spend an hour or two here
A free attraction where you can learn a lot about the history of the city of Sapporo. It also has a lovely garden.
I visited during the autumn colours and it's beautiful. I didn't go inside, but certainly it's one of the famous landmark in Sapporo. 5 minutes walk from Sapporo Station.
You wont miss it if you walking above on the streets, worth to passby for a view, whiles it was in my planned must view places together with its surrounding places

We were intrigued because the view from our hotel room window was straight down the street to this building. The juxtaposition of such beautiful traditional architecture with a sea of modernist high rise is always striking. The building is just as striking viewed from up close
A visit to Hokkaido will not be complete without a visit to this majestic sight. People are a plenty and it's a photographer's paradise.
Now aday this building was museum there display very thing about Hokkaido and Sapporo. Recommenced place .They also call "Akarenga" same as the redbrick in Yokohama.
We reached there during a raining morning. However, I still managed to walk around the building, though it is an aged building but it looks magnificent, Serene environment.

It's in the center of downtown near the rail station and its shopping centers, and also near the Botanical Garden, so is a good link on a stroll. The building could easily be Old Main at an old state teacher's college in the US. I arrived late, so didn't visit the historic

It seems to be a must see place in Sapporo. So we went there to see for ourselves. The building was nice enough from outside. But we enjoyed the autumn colours of the trees and the small gardens on the right and left and the plants along the path leading up to the building more.

It is a small former administrative building used for displaying the past of the city. There is also a hall for visitors to sign a petition the Japanese government is raising on land dispute. The outside of the building is more impressive than the inside, IMHO. The pond outside
Nice autumn leaves and beautiful park. Very picturesque. An artist haven. Saw many young and old enjoying leisure time.
We came to this beautiful structure as part of our city tour. Surrounded by beautuful garden and lots of bonsai tree(miniature tree) Although we did not enter the building but the sight was great.

This red-bricked two-storied building from a bygone era with a green dome on top (not a very big dome) and spherical-shaped shrubs (with flowers) on the front grounds is a place you could stop by quickly on your way to or from the big Sapporo Station just about a two-minute walk

we went here during winter, hence, the small body of water on it sides are frozen. you can feel that the entire building is old, rich in history but no doubt it's well maintained. so many artifacts inside, statues and mangas. definitely worth visiting when its your first time in
The building is good.. Iconic for sapporo. Nice view surrond the building.. You can find some attraction if you are lucky. You can also buy fresh fruit there..
It consists of rooms to display some arts collections and some history of the country. At the security guard booth, each visitor can register to get a small brochure on free wifi for 14 days.

The red bricks is made from the soil that was part of the volcano eruption decades ago. Entrance to the building via Hokkaido University gave an "impression of Kensington Palace view". There were some food stalls within the gardens so it was a good opportunity to take a bite
Red bricks wall were nicely build. Good place for sightseeing and phototaking. However, it is always crowded with local or tourists.

The archive section provided quite interesting artefacts about Hokkaido and is free to the public. The garden was big but surprising to see a few run down parts. The building itself has gone through some transformations (spend more time in the archive).

an unique outstanding western building amidst the modern multi story buildings. The building was for visitors to understand the historical part. Unfortunately, there is no English description inside. However , can still appreciate the architectual of the building.

We were surprised that you can just walk into this historic building and having climbed the screening wooden stairs on the first floor a number of exhibits located in various rooms. There was little or no English to explain the displays other than do not touch or stand on the

I personally think that this building possesses a touch of historical design to it. We took quite some picture trying to find the best angle and they all turned out to be really artistic, thanks to the motif of this building. Sadly, the information and historical background of

A centrally located attraction in a nice setting that has a nice old western styled building with which served as the former Government office. Close to Odori Park and the Hokkaido University Botanic Gardens.
Went on a brief tour and visit of the building. Was told about how difficult a time they had recreating the western style brick. Lovely grounds to take a stroll and some photos.

Located half way between Sapporo and Odori station, it is the most iconic building in the city as it was Western style building. The building is quite beautiful. There is small flower field in front. Several events often take place here. You can get in for free. There is nothing

Stop by for a quick photo taking. Building architecture was beautiful, with the flowers blooming in front, making great pictures. The trees and landscape were nice too. Good to spend more time if had a leisure afternoon.
The best photo spot is in front of the flower bed east of the building. You may have to be a little patient until you get your turn.
This is an old government office building with a small garden outside. Good place for taking photos. Free for entrance. Worth for a short visit, say half an hour.

Elegant building now a museum. European style. Free entry. Peaceful grounds with a small lake. Exhibits providing information on Hokkaido but mostly in Japanese. To attract more international visitors, information relating to the exhibits need to be translated into English.

A short distance walk from my hotel stay Mitsui Garden hotel, I enjoy sitting in this small park of former Hokkaido government office which open to general public to enjoy the quite and peaceful surrounding. You can enjoy various type of flowers according to its calendar.
Impressive at the front door with brown classic building with colorful flower which are suitable for taking photos. Inside building there are several important history information in Hokkaido
This red brick office is a famous Hokkaido landmark. We didn't go inside. It is good enough to pop by to take a few photos. It is a short walk from JR Sapporo Station.
It was an interesting walk outside and inside the building. Most of the written display are in Japanese.
It's a pretty building with a pretty outside and inside. I enjoyed the Ainu component inside, and learning how short the history of Japanese occupation of Hokkaido is. It's close to Odori park.

The Former Hokkaido Government Office Building is within walking distance from JR Sapporo station which makes it very accessible. The Garden there is beautiful. There are people, local Japanese and tourists, non-stop coming to visit this place, especially the garden. Not so

We walked across this place and are attracted by the red building. Is a beautiful old building with beautiful flowers. Though old but well maintained. Entrance is free and is a good place to learn of the history

Building looks better from outside than inside. All in all a good place to learn about Sapporo (Hokkaido) if you know how to read japanese. All displays and posters are in Japanese so not exactly very beneficial for me.
Very beautiful building with serene park and pond. Can take a nice stroll in evening. Good greenery photo shot.

We came across this by accident, the red brick building looked out of place. There are some good permanent exhibitions on display. We especially liked the one on the history of the ownership of the four disputed islands to the north of Hokkaido.

Definitely a building worth visiting in Sapporo. There is a beautiful garden on the way in, so it does make for lovely photos. Entrance into the building is free, and you can pick up a leaflet in English on the way in. You will learn a bit about the history of the building and
It's another historical building in Sapporo. A good walking location with beautiful garden and landscaping.
Nice location for taking pictures. Liked the red brick building surrounded by a beautiful park. They have an exhibition inside, but unfortunately the most is only in Japanese.
This government office architecture was based on the State House in Boston, Mass. It is one of many building in Sapporo that bears the influence of the Eastern US.

We visited the building and enjoyed taking photos with the building in the backdrop. The flowers were nicely decorated but what caught / distracted us were the ducks on the pond. They went about their business oblivious to the tourists taking photos. We did not get a chance to
Love this red brick building :) it's a nice place to take photos. There are a few rooms inside where you can see some historical paintings and exhibits. I spent about 20-30 mins there.

Again we have visited the Former Government Building during our short stay in Sapporo early in June this year. We visited the internal part of buildings and took a few photos outside prior to our leaving for the other sites.

Actually this place is not far from Sapporo station but we went there by taxi from Sapporo station because it will be close in 6pm. In this building no need fee for entrace and we can take about 30 minutes for tour in the building.
I think this kind of red brick building only can be found in Hokkaido area. This place is quite nice when snowing. It is a good place for taking a picture too.

We find many blooming sakura tree there. Not have much time to explore more, only take a picture in the alley

Visited this place in end-May 2016 simply because it is just across Sapporo Grand Hotel where we were staying. Open to public and has a park/garden and a small lake. Very pleasant place to spend your time (picnic perhaps) and to take a rest or via away the time. Flowers were in

Nice place for a stop over for a pic or two. Its along the road leading to the street malls and near to Odori park. Its open to public and there is a beautiful pond in the area, good for a rest or taking pictures.
Nicknamed Akarenga or red bricks, it was completed in 1888. It is surrounded by a beautiful park with a small lake complete with colorful ducks.
This building is quite near to the clock tower. It has quite a big park beside it and have cherry blossoms if you go at the right time. Good for a picture take.
A relaxing walk and beautiful garden outside the building is great for taking pictures. Other than that, nothing much here, just a landmark of Sapporo to visit.
Nothing quite interesting unless you love to tour all kind of museums. There has small souvenir shop downstair, restroom provided and no admission fee.

A small historic red brick building telling a little of Hokkaido's history. Thats my impression. By itself against an imaginary forest, this akarenga looks great! Alas, human development brought about all the skyscrapers, making this building stands out like a sore thumb.

We were lost after visiting the clock tower but managed to get on to this building with the help of the mobile GPS. Nothing special.

Without the “Welcome to Hokkaido” sign in front of it this pretty building would be worth only a 2-minute look from the sidewalk. The sign makes a good selfie spot though so queue up with the other tourists to take your new profile picture.

I walk there from Sapporo JR, it's a bit far but worthed, very beautiful at dark (6pm already dark), free to enter. Recommended

Nice building but we didn't make it in time to visit the inside. Would have given a better rating. They have a projection show during New Year period.

I come here every now and then whenever I am in Sapporo, just because it is very close to the JR Sapporo, to the city and simply the building is beautiful in any season. Not much to see in the inside though, and because I do not know much about the history of Hokkaido it does

The building is interesting and the free admission is very nice. Most of the exhibits inside are lacking in English, so I really didn't know what I was looking at.

+ nice place to take some beautiful outdoor photos + exhibition and museum entry is free, most exhibits in Japanese though

Beautiful building and great to take picture with, especially with snowy background. This building is actually in the city center and very near to the hotel we stayed. Easy access and free admission to the building. I think worth spending a little time here.

It is a nice historical building, we were in the winter. The building looks fantastic with the snow. Definitely is a nice place to shoot if you are a photography enthusiasts. However there was nothing interesting inside the building.
Not much info of the place was in English It would be helpful if there's organized tour guides in English

One of the places that a visitor to Sapporo should stop and see. The surrounding grounds and ponds are very nice and building itself is historic. There is no fee to take a self tour inside the building and there's a gift shop inside.
Even it is a short walk passing during snowing, it is very nice place to visit and take memory pictures. Western style building during Meiji period.

Right next to our Sapporo Grand Hotel so we took a quick stroll inside. It's a nice building but not worth spending too much time here as there was nothing tinder except some pictures of past history. Would only recommend coming here if staying close by and definitely not a

Nice garden but very little to see inside as a Museum although the entrance is free. Only encourage to visit if you have extra times and interested to know the history of Sapporo.

Walked from Susukimo, Odori Park on our way to Sapporo station. Saw this regal looking building with great English structure. As it's nearing Christmas, there are many Christmas décor dotting the façade. It was a great place for photo-taking.

Frankly although the outside may be unusual for Japanese it is quite standard and ordinary for Europeans. Inside there is little to fascinate or entertain.

This red brick building stands majestically against the beautiful surroundings of colorful trees and lakes. The building has become a museum piece with archives of Hokkaido displaying paintings, pictures and exhibit items. For history lovers, this is a worthwhile place to visit.

I've spent some time there, because it was just around the corner when it started raining. It didn't find it special. However, there were some nice exhibitions in there. Some paintings, some photography, all from local artists. In my opinion, not really worth to specially plan

Beautiful red brick.building with lots.of history. Easy to access by subway. But i biked to visit the building at night... it.was.closed very late

Nice free museum in Sapporo with very attractive gardens. Some very interesting history of the city can be taken in here and much of it is in English. Worth a hour to two to visit and is close to many other things

If you love taking picture. Come before dark. Take picture before and after dark. It is totally different.if you want to see sapporo history . They closed at 6 pm

Another must go place in Sapporo and one is able to grab nice pictures too. The place is spacious and clean and not crowded too.
nearby Sapporo JR station. It's called Akarenga "Red Brick". There is a museum inside. You can see a history of Hokkaido. Also a garden in front of the building is beautiful.

The park was flowerished in july and really very beautiful. The visit of the building is less intresting for foreign visitors. The place is near the railway station in a calm area. Very relaxing

It tells u d history of Sapporo n Hokkaido ..... worth visitIng n had very nice garden with lots of flower

this is one of the place that was included in the itinerary. Already the building is maintained now as a Museum. being summer time the flowering is really beautiful especially Lavender bloom.

if you like to read and understand the history of the Sapporo and japan must place to visit lot of heritage valued iterms , with beautiful well kept garden outside and very near the city center and subways with lot of eatery and shopping near by

About 15 minutes walk from JR Sapporo Station. Several European buildings with water ponds and landscaped areas around. Nice to take a few pictures for memory when travelling in Sapporo.

It's just on our way from JR station to the hotel. Pretty good scenery with snow. Free entrance;)

Unique red brick building which we caught a glimpse of while looking for the more famous Sapporo clock tower. Looks nice. Go there take some photos, stroll around the place.Not quite sure what else you can do there.
a typical colonial building, located near Odori Park so can pass by and take some photos... nothing much to see but as a famous attractions known in Sapporo, you won't miss it.

The building is neat looking, but is really nice is it surrounded by a beautiful park. We really enjoyed walking through its park.

text.wiki:
Sapporo (札幌市, Sapporo-shi) is the fifth largest city in Japan, and the largest city on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is the capital city of Hokkaido Prefecture and its Ishikari Subprefecture, and numbers among the nation's ordinance-designated city. Sapporo lies in the southwest of Hokkaido, within the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, which is a tributary stream of the Ishikari. Sapporo is considered the cultural, economical, and political center of Hokkaido.  
As with most of Hokkaido, the Sapporo area was settled by the indigenous Ainu people, beginning over 15,000 years ago. Starting in the late 19th century, Sapporo saw increasing settlement by Japanese migrants. Sapporo hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Olympics ever held in Asia, and the second Olympic games held in Japan after the 1964 Summer Olympics. The Sapporo Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup and two games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
The annual Sapporo Snow Festival draws more than 2 million tourists from abroad. Other notable sites include the Sapporo Beer Museum, which is the only beer museum in Japan, and the Sapporo TV Tower located in Odori Park. It is home to Hokkaido University, just north of Sapporo Station. The city is served by Okadama Airport, and New Chitose Airport in nearby Chitose. 


== Etymology ==
Sapporo's name was taken from Ainuic "sat poro pet" (サッ・ポロ・ペッ), which can be translated as the "dry, great river", a reference to the Toyohira River.


== History ==


=== Early history ===
Before its establishment, the area occupied by Sapporo (known as the Ishikari Plain) was home to a number of indigenous Ainu settlements. In 1866, at the end of the Edo period, construction began on a canal through the area, encouraging a number of early settlers to establish Sapporo village.In 1868, the officially recognized year celebrated as the "birth" of Sapporo, the new Meiji government concluded that the existing administrative center of Hokkaido, which at the time was the port of Hakodate, was in an unsuitable location for defense and further development of the island. As a result, it was determined that a new capital on the Ishikari Plain should be established. The plain itself provided an unusually large expanse of flat, well drained land which is relatively uncommon in the otherwise mountainous geography of Hokkaido.
During 1870–1871, Kuroda Kiyotaka, vice-chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi), approached the American government for assistance in developing the land. As a result, Horace Capron, Secretary of Agriculture under President Ulysses S. Grant, became an oyatoi gaikokujin and was appointed as a special advisor to the commission. Construction began around Odori Park, which still remains as a green ribbon of recreational land bisecting the central area of the city. The city closely followed a grid plan with streets at right-angles to form city blocks.
The continuing expansion of the Japanese into Hokkaido continued, mainly due to migration from the main island of Honshu immediately to the south, and the prosperity of Hokkaido and particularly its capital grew to the point that the Development Commission was deemed unnecessary and was abolished in 1882.
Edwin Dun came to Sapporo to establish sheep and cattle ranches in 1876. He also demonstrated pig raising and the making of butter, cheese, ham and sausage. He was married twice, to Japanese women. He once went back to the US in 1883 but returned to Japan as a secretary of government.
William S. Clark, who was the president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the University of Massachusetts Amherst), came to be the founding vice-president of the Sapporo Agricultural College (now Hokkaido University) for only eight months from 1876 to 1877. He taught academic subjects in science and lectured on the Bible as an "ethics" course, introducing Christian principles to the first entering class of the College.
In 1880, the entire area of Sapporo was renamed as "Sapporo-ku" (Sapporo Ward), and a railroad between Sapporo and Temiya, Otaru was laid. That year the Hōheikan, a hotel and reception facility for visiting officials and dignitaries, was erected adjacent to the Odori Park. It was later moved to Nakajima Park where it remains today. Two years later, with the abolition of the Kaitaku-shi, Hokkaidō was divided into three prefectures: Hakodate, Sapporo, and Nemuro. The name of the urban district in Sapporo remained Sapporo-ku, while the rest of the area in Sapporo-ku was changed to Sapporo-gun. The office building of Sapporo-ku was also located in the urban district.Sapporo, Hakodate, and Nemuro Prefectures were abolished in 1886, and Hokkaidō government office building, an American-neo-baroque-style structure with red bricks, constructed in 1888. The last squad of the Tondenhei, the soldiers pioneering Hokkaido, settled in the place where the area of Tonden in Kita-ku, Sapporo is currently located. Sapporo-ku administered surrounding Sapporo-gun until 1899, when the new district system was announced. After that year, Sapporo-ku was away from the control of Sapporo-gun. The "ku" (district) enforced from 1899 was an autonomy which was a little bigger than towns, and smaller than cities. In Hokkaido at that time, Hakodate-ku and Otaru-ku also existed.
Gallery
		
		


=== 20th century ===
In 1907, the Tohoku Imperial University was established in Sendai Miyagi Prefecture, and Sapporo Agricultural College was controlled by the University. Parts of neighbouring villages including Sapporo Village, Naebo Village, Kami Shiroishi Village, and districts where the Tonden-hei had settled, were integrated into Sapporo-ku in 1910.
The Sapporo Streetcar was opened in 1918, and Hokkaido Imperial University was established in Sapporo-ku, as the fifth Imperial University in Japan. Another railroad operated in Sapporo, the Jōzankei Railroad, which was ultimately abolished in 1969.
In 1922, the new city system was announced by the Tokyo government, and Sapporo-ku was officially changed to Sapporo City. The Sapporo Municipal Bus System was started in 1930. In 1937, Sapporo was chosen as the site of the 1940 Winter Olympics, but due to the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, this was cancelled the next year. Maruyama Town was integrated as a part of Chūō-ku in 1940, and the Okadama Airport was constructed in 1942.
The first Sapporo Snow Festival was held in 1950. In the same year, adjacent Shiroishi Village was integrated into Sapporo City, rendered as a part of Shiroishi-ku, and Atsubetsu-ku. In 1955, Kotoni Town, the entire Sapporo Village, and Shinoro Village were merged into Sapporo, becoming a part of the current Chūō-ku, Kita-ku, Higashi-ku, Nishi-ku, and Teine-ku. The expansion of Sapporo continued, with the merger of Toyohira Town in 1961, and Teine Town in 1967, each becoming a part of Toyohira-ku, Kiyota-ku, and Teine-ku.The ceremony commemorating the 100th anniversary of the foundation of Sapporo and Hokkaido was held in 1968. The Sapporo Municipal Subway system was inaugurated in 1971, which made Sapporo the fourth city in Japan to have a subway system. From February 3 to 13, 1972, the 1972 Winter Olympics were held, the first Winter Olympics held in Asia. On April 1 of the same year, Sapporo was designated as one of the cities designated by government ordinance, and seven wards were established. The last ever public performance by the opera singer, Maria Callas, was in Sapporo at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan on 11 November 1974. The Sapporo Municipal Subway was expanded when the Tōzai line started operation in 1976, and the Tōhō line was opened in 1988. In 1989, Atsubetsu-ku and Teine-ku were separated from Shiroishi-ku and Nishi-ku. Annual events in Sapporo were started, such as the Pacific Music Festival in 1990, and Yosakoi Sōran Festival in 1992. A professional football club, Consadole Sapporo, was established in 1996. In 1997, Kiyota-ku was separated from Toyohira-ku. In the same year, Hokkaidō Takushoku Bank, a Hokkaido-based bank with headquarters in Odori, went bankrupt.
Gallery
		
		
		


=== 21st century ===
In 2001 the construction of the Sapporo Dome was completed, and in 2002 the Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup; Germany vs Saudi Arabia, Argentina vs England and Italy vs Ecuador, all of which were in the first round. Fumio Ueda, was elected as Sapporo mayor for the first time in 2003. Sapporo became the home to a Nippon Professional Baseball team, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters, in 2004, which won the 2006 Japan Series, and the victory parade was held on Ekimae-Dōri (a street in front of Sapporo Station) in February 2007.
The 34th G8 summit took place in Tōyako in 2008, and a number of people including anti-globalisation activists marched in the heart of the city to protest. Police officers were gathered in Sapporo from all over Japan, and the news reported that four people were arrested in the demonstrations.The Hokkaidō Shinkansen line, which currently connects Honshu to Hakodate through the Seikan Tunnel, is planned to link to Sapporo by 2030.
Gallery
		


== Geography ==

Sapporo is a city located in the southwest part of Ishikari Plain and the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, a tributary stream of the Ishikari River. It is part of Ishikari Subprefecture. Roadways in the urban district are laid to make a grid plan. The western and southern parts of Sapporo are occupied by a number of mountains including Mount Teine, Maruyama, and Mount Moiwa, as well as many rivers including the Ishikari River, Toyohira River, and Sōsei River. Sapporo has an elevation of 29 m (95 ft 2 in)Sapporo has many parks, including Odori Park, which is located in the heart of the city and hosts a number of annual events and festivals throughout the year. Moerenuma Park is also one of the largest parks in Sapporo, and was constructed under the plan of Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American artist and landscape architect.
Neighbouring cities are Ishikari, Ebetsu, Kitahiroshima, Eniwa, Chitose, Otaru, Date, and adjoining towns are Tōbetsu, Kimobetsu, Kyōgoku.


=== Wards ===
Sapporo has ten wards (区, ku). The color shows the location of each ku in the map below.


=== Cityscape ===
Gallery
		
		
		


=== Climate ===
Sapporo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa), with a wide range of temperature between the summer and winter. Summers are generally warm, but not overly humid, and winters are cold and very snowy, with an average snowfall of 5.96 m (19 ft 7 in) per year. Sapporo is one of few metropolises in the world with such heavy snowfall, enabling it to hold events and festivals with snow statues. The heavy snowfall is due to the Siberian High developing over the Eurasian land mass and the Aleutian Low developing over the northern Pacific Ocean, resulting in a flow of cold air southeastward across Tsushima Current and to western Hokkaido. The city's annual average precipitation is around 1,100 mm (43.3 in), and the mean annual temperature is 8.5 °C (47.3 °F).


== Economy ==

The tertiary sector dominates Sapporo's industry. Major industries include information technology, retail, and tourism, as Sapporo is a destination for winter sports and events and summer activities due to its comparatively cool climate.The city is also the manufacturing centre of Hokkaido, manufacturing various goods such as food and related products, fabricated metal products, steel, machinery, beverages, and pulp and paper.Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. In April 2004, Air Nippon Network was headquartered in Higashi-ku. Other companies headquartered in Sapporo include Crypton Future Media, DB-Soft, Hokkaido Air System, and Royce'.
Greater Sapporo, Sapporo Metropolitan Employment Area (2.3 million people), had a total GDP of US$84.7 billion in 2010.In 2014 Sapporo's GDP per capita (PPP) was US$32,446.


== Culture and entertainment ==


=== Music ===
1934 – The International Contemporary Music Festival was held by Akira Ifukube, Fumio Hayasaka, Atsushi Miura, and Isamu Ifukube (30 September)
1936 – Russian composer Alexander Tcherepnin visited Sapporo
1960 – The Sapporo Symphony Orchestra founded
1962 – John Cage and David Tudor visited Sapporo
1966 – Berliner Philharmoniker with Herbert von Karajan performed Brahms's Symphony No. 2 at Sapporo Shimin Kaikan (April)
1974 – Maria Callas last public performance at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan (11 November)
1986 – The Sapporo Art Park include the Outdoor Stage and Art Hall (27 July)
1990 – The Pacific Music Festival (PMF) started
1997 – The Sapporo Concert Hall Kitara opened
2018 – The Sapporo Community Plaza is set to open in October


=== Art ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art represents Hokkaido artists like Eien Iwahashi, Kinjiro Kida, Nissho Kanda, Tamako Kataoka, and especially glass objects of Ecole de Paris
The Hongō Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture hosts a collection of over 1,800 works by the artist Hongō Shin.
The Sapporo Art Park contains Art museum featuring outdoor installations & a sculpture garden, and the old house of Takeo Arishima.
The Moerenuma Park including the Glass Pyramid, designed by Isamu Noguchi
The Migishi Kotaro Museum of Art
The Hongo Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture
The Miyanomori Art Museum
The Sapporo Odori 500-m Underground Walkway Gallery
Member of UNESCO Creative Cities Network as a Creative City of Media Arts since 2013
Sapporo International Art Festival (2014/2017)


=== Literature ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Literature
Takeo Arishima Residence in Sapporo Art Park
Junichi Watanabe Museum of Literature


=== Film ===
The Idiot (1951 film) by Akira Kurosawa
The Northern Museum of Visual Culture
Theater Kino
The Sapporo International Short Film Festival and Market


=== Points of interest ===

Registered Tangible Cultural Properties in Sapporo

The former Hokkaidō government office building

The Sunpiazza AquariumSapporo JR Tower adjacent to Sapporo Station.Sapporo Ramen Yokocho and Norubesa (a building with a Ferris wheel) are in Susukino district. The district also has the Tanuki Kōji Shopping Arcade, the oldest shopping mall in the city.
The district of Jōzankei in Minami-ku has many resort hotels with steam baths and onsen.
The Peace Pagoda, one of many such monuments across the world built by the Buddhist order Nipponzan Myohoji to promote and inspire world peace, has a stupa that was built in 1959, halfway up Mount Moiwa, to commemorate peace after World War II. It contains some of the ashes of the Buddha that were presented to the Emperor of Japan by Prime Minister Nehru in 1954. Another portion was presented to Mikhail Gorbachev by the Nipponzan-Myohoji monk, Junsei Terasawa.


=== Parks/gardens ===
The Odori Park
The Nakajima Park
The Maruyama Park is located next to the Hokkaido Shrine and houses the Maruyama Zoo.
The Moerenuma Park
The Nishioka Park is a location of rich nature which centers around a pond and consists of marshland and the forest of the Tsukisamu River and its upper river basin. This park also serves as one of the main habitats in Hokkaido for many types of wild birds.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park offers great views of the city.
The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens and The Chizaki Rose Garden
The Hitsujigaoka Observation Hill has a farm with sheep and attracts visitors with a statue of William S. Clark.


=== Events/festivals ===

February: the Sapporo Snow Festival The main site is at Odori Park, and other sites include Susukino (known as the Susukino Ice Festival) and Sapporo Satoland. Many of the snow and ice statues are built by members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force.May: the Sapporo Lilac Festival. Lilac was brought to Sapporo in 1889 by an American educator, Sarah Clara Smith. At the festival, people enjoy the flowers, wine and live music.
June: the Yosakoi Soran Festival. The sites of the festival are centered on Odori Park and the street leading to Susukino, and there are other festival sites. In the festival, many dance teams dance to music composed based on a Japanese traditional song, "Sōran Bushi". Members of the dancing teams wear special costumes and compete on the roads or stages constructed on the festival sites. In 2006, 350 teams were featured with around 45,000 dancers, and over 1,860,000 people visited the festival.the Sapporo Summer Festival. People enjoy drinking at the beer garden in Odori Park and on the streets of Susukino. This festival consists of a number of fairs such as Tanuki Festival and Susukino Festival.September: the Sapporo Autumn Festival
December: Christmas market in Odori Park, similar to German Christmas markets.
From November through January, many citizens enjoy the Sapporo White Illuminations.


=== Cuisine ===

The city is known home to Sapporo Brewery, and the white chocolate biscuits 'shiroi koibito' (白い恋人), also as the birthplace of miso ramen. The Kouraku Ramen Meitengai in Susukino district, an alley lined with many miso ramen restaurants since 1951. After its demolition due to plans for the Sapporo Olympics, the Ganso Sapporo Ramen Yokocho was established in the same place. It attracts many tourists throughout the year. From the year 1966, a food company named Sanyo Foods began to sell instant ramen under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban".
Haskap, a local variety of edible honeysuckle, similar to blueberries, is a specialty in Sapporo. Other specialty dishes of Sapporo are soup curry, a soupy curry made with vegetables and chicken or other meats, and jingisukan, a barbecued lamb dish, named for Genghis Khan. Sapporo Sweets is a confectionery using many ingredients from Hokkaido and the Sapporo Sweets Competition is held annually. Sapporo is also well known for fresh seafood including salmon, sea urchin and crab. Crab in particular is famed. Many types of crab are harvested and served seasonally in Sapporo like the Horsehair crab, Snow crab, King crab, and Hanasaki crab with numerous dishes revolving around them.


=== Sports ===

The Sapporo Dome was constructed in 2001 and currently is the host to the local soccer team, Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo, the baseball team Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters and the basketball team Levanga Hokkaido.
Sapporo was selected to be the host of the 5th Winter Olympics scheduled on February 3 to 12, 1940, but Japan had to give the Games back to the IOC, after the Second Sino-Japanese War broke out in 1937.
In 1972, Sapporo hosted the 11th Winter Olympics. Some structures built for Olympic events remain in use today, including the ski jumps at Miyanomori and Okurayama. After considering a bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Olympic representatives in Sapporo have said that the city is considering a bid for the 2030 Winter Olympics. The city predicts it may cost as much as 456.5 billion yen ($4.3 billion) to host the games and is planning to have 90 percent of the facilities within half an hour of the Olympic village, according to a report published 12 May 2016. The Alpen course would be in Niseko, the world's second-snowiest resort, while the village would be next to the Sapporo Dome, the report said. The plans were presented to the Japanese Olympic Committee on 8 November 2016. In 2002, Sapporo hosted three group matches of the FIFA World Cup at the Sapporo Dome. In 2006, Sapporo hosted some games of the 2006 Basketball World Championship and also for the 2006 Women's Volleyball World Championship. In 2007, Sapporo hosted the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships at the Sapporo Dome, Miyanomori ski jump, Okurayama ski jump, and the Shirahatayama cross country course. It has been host city of two Asian Winter Games and hosted the 2017 Asian Winter Games with Obihiro. Sapporo will also host some games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
Skiing remains a major sport in Sapporo with almost all children skiing as a part of the school curriculum. Okurayama Elementary School is unusual in having its own ski hill and ski jumping hill on the school grounds. Within the city are commercial ski hills including Moiwayama, Bankeiyama, KobaWorld, Sapporo Teine and Fu's.
Many sports stadiums and domes are located in Sapporo, and some of them have been designated as venues of sports competitions. The Sapporo Community Dome, also known by its nickname "Tsu-Dome", has hosted the Golden Market, a huge flea market event which is usually held twice a year, along with some sports events. The Makomanai Ice Arena, in Makomanai Park, was one of the venues of the Sapporo Olympics in 1972. It was renamed the Makomanai Sekisuiheim Ice Arena in 2007, when Sekisui Chemical Co., Ltd., acquired naming rights and renamed the arena after their real estate brand. Other large sports venues include the Makomanai Open Stadium, Tsukisamu Dome, Maruyama Baseball Stadium, and the Hokkaido Prefectural Sports Center.
Toyota Big Air is a major international snowboarding event held annually in Sapporo Dome. As one of the richest events of its kind in the world, it draws many of the world's best snowboarders.


==== Professional sport teams ====
J.League – Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo (J1 in 1998, 2001–2002, 2008, 2012, 2017–present; J2 in 1999–2000, 2003–2007, 2009–2011, 2013–2016) .
NPB – Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters in Pacific League


== Demographics ==
The city has an estimated population of 1,957,914 as of May 31, 2019 and a population density of 1,746 persons per km² (4,500 persons per mi²). The total area is 1,121.26 km2 (432.92 sq mi).


== Transportation ==

Sapporo has one streetcar line, three JR Hokkaido lines, three subway lines and JR Bus, Chuo Bus and other bus lines. Sapporo Subway trains have rubber-tyred wheels.


=== Rapid transit ===
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Sapporo Streetcar
Mount Moiwa Ropeway
Teineyama Ropeway


=== Rail ===
JR Hokkaido Stations in Sapporo
Hakodate Line: (Zenibako) – Hoshimi – Hoshioki – Inaho – Teine – Inazumi Kōen – Hassamu – Hassamu Chūō – Kotoni – Sōen – Sapporo – Naebo – Shiroishi – Atsubetsu – Shinrinkōen – (Ōasa)
Chitose Line: Heiwa – Shin Sapporo – Kami Nopporo – (Kita-Hiroshima)
Sasshō Line (Gakuentoshi Line): Sōen – Hachiken – Shinkawa – Shinkotoni – Taihei – Yurigahara – Shinoro – Takuhoku – Ainosato Kyōikudai – Ainosato Kōen – (Ishikari Futomi)


=== Air ===
The Sapporo area is served by two airports: Okadama Airport, which offers regional flights within Hokkaido, and New Chitose Airport, a larger international airport located in the city of Chitose 30 miles (48 km) away connected by regular rapid trains taking around 40 minutes. The Sapporo-Tokyo route between New Chitose and Haneda is one of the busiest in the world.


=== Airport shuttle, tour and charter bus service ===
An airport shuttle bus servicing all hotels in Sapporo operates every day of the year. SkyExpress was founded in 2005 and also provides transport to and from various ski resorts throughout Hokkaido, including Niseko.

=== Universities ===

=== Primary and secondary schools ===

Sapporo Odori High School provides Japanese-language classes to foreign and Japanese returnee students, and the school has special admissions quotas for these groups.The city has two private international schools:

Hokkaido International School
Hokkaido Korean Primary, Middle and High School (North Korean school)


== Twin towns – sister cities ==

Sapporo has twinning relationships with several cities worldwide.
 Portland, Oregon, United States, since 1959
 Munich, Bavaria, Germany, since 1972
 Shenyang, Liaoning, China, since 1980
 Novosibirsk, Russia, since 1990
 Daejeon, South Korea, since 2010
 Chiclayo, Peru

text.wiki:
Chūō-ku (中央区, Chūō-ku) is one of the ten wards in Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. Chūō-ku means "central ward" in Japanese. City administration and entertainment facilities are centred in this ward.


== History ==
During Meiji Period, Sousei river, precursor of Susukino district, Sapporo Beer company and the drill hall of the former Sapporo Agricultural College were built in the area where Chūō-ku is currently located. After Sapporo was divided into wards (ku, 区), Sapporo Agricultural College, currently Hokkaido University, was moved to what would become Kita-ku, and was replaced by the Sapporo wards administration building.In 1922, Sapporo was chartered as a city. The 1st Sapporo Snow Festival was held during the Showa period, and Sapporo City Hall was erected in 1971.
Chūō-ku was officially established in 1972, when the Sapporo Olympics was held and Sapporo was accredited as one of the city designated by government ordinance. During the Olympics, Chūō-ku hosted the normal hill ski jumping event and the ski jumping portion of the Nordic combined event. The other 6 wards (Higashi-ku, Kita-ku, Minami-ku, Nishi-ku, Shiroishi-ku and Toyohira-ku) were also established in the same year. The ski jump would be a venue when the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships would be held at Sapporo in 2007.


== Overview ==

The ward is located in the center of Sapporo. As a downtown district of the city, there are a lot of governmental offices and buildings of companies. The City Hall of Sapporo, the office building of the government of Hokkaido and the headquarters of Hokkaidō Police office are located.
Chūō-ku is also the centre for sightseeing, and many of historical and entertainment facilities of Sapporo are located. Odori Park lies on the centre of the ward, and Sapporo TV Tower is placed on the eastern end of the park. The Sapporo Snow Festival is also held annually in Odori Park. The largest shinto shrine in Hokkaidō prefecture, Hokkaido Shrine (Hokkaidō jingu) is located in Miyanomori area, and draws a number of people on the island during Oshougatsu (the New Year's Day). Maruyama Zoo, Mt. Okura Ski Jump Stadium, and Miyanomori middle hill jump stadium are near the shrine.
Susukino area has many bars and pubs. The street car runs from there to Odori Park going around the ward. A beautiful panorama view is enjoyable on the top of Mt. Moiwa, which has a ropeway. Memorial guest hall, Hōhei Kan, is in Nakajima Park, which houses a music hall Sapporo Concert Hall "Kitara". The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens is also in this ward.


== Economy ==

Hokkaido Railway Company has its headquarters in the ward. Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. Yomiuri Shimbun has a branch office in the ward.Japan Airlines at one time operated a ticketing facility on the second floor of the Imon Sapporo Building in Chūō-ku. On March 31, 2009 the facility closed.


== Statistics ==

As of April 1, 2008, statistics of Chūō-ku, Sapporo is listed below.

Area: 46.42 square km
Population: 211,233
Households: 115,362
Chūō-ku Ward Office: Minami 3 Jo Nishi 11 Chome, Chūō-ku, Sapporo-shi (city)
Zipcode: 060-8612
Phone: +81 11 231-2400


== Education ==


=== University ===


==== Public ====
Sapporo Medical University
Sapporo City University, Soen Campus and Satellite Campus


==== Private ====
Hokkai Gakuen University, Yamahana Campus


=== High schools ===


==== Public ====

Hokkaido Sapporo Nishi High School
Hokkaido Sapporo Minami High School
Hokkaido Sapporo Asahigaoka High School
Sapporo Odori High School


==== Private ====
Sapporo Seishu High School
Sapporo Ryukoku Gakuen High School
Sapporo Sacred Heart School High School
Hokusei Gakuen Girls' High School


=== Other ===
The South Korean government maintains the Korea Education Institution (Korean: 삿포로한국교육원; Japanese: 札幌韓国教育院) in Chuo-ku.


== Transportation ==


=== Rail ===
JR Hokkaido
Hakodate Main Line, Sasshō Line: Sōen Station, Naebo Station
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Namboku Line: Sapporo - Ōdōri - Susukino - Nakajima-Kōen - Horohira-Bashi
Tōzai Line: Nishi-Nijūhatchōme - Maruyama-Kōen - Nishi-Jūhatchōme - Nishi-Jūitchōme - Ōdōri - Bus Center-Mae
Tōhō Line: Sapporo - Ōdōri - Hōsui-Susukino
Sapporo Streetcar
Ichijō Line
Yamahana Line
Yamahana-Nishi Line


=== Road ===
Route 5
Route 12
Route 36


== Points of interest ==

Sapporo Clock Tower
