text.quote: Long, covered shopping street stretching for 656 ft. & dating back to 1868, with around 200 outlets.
trip: Lots of shops here, so you can buy all your souvenirs from here. It was quite busy but orderly. Mat restaurants as well. Many tax free shops for tourists too.
Tanukikoji shopping street is packed with people, lots of food, drinks, souvenirs and the list just go on! I was even surprised that there was a pet shop too!

Stop, look, buy and go! Plenty of shops to see and explore. From food, drinks, souvenirs, clothing, pharmacies, and much more, you will almost get what you need from this shopping street. Come at night as it it brightly lit up. A long stretch of walkway to feast your eyes on.
Many shops and stalls selling all kinds of Japanese products such as dolls, tea, clothes, shoes, hats....and the list go on😊. Many cafes and restaurants too. Loved the ramen place here!
Loads of things to see, eat and do. There is karaoke here, along with claw machines outlets and ransom tasty street food. Worth a visit!
Came here for 24 hours Mega Don Quijote. Good quality second hand branded stuff at 2nd street. A lot of drugstores.

A very lively brightly lit happening shopping entertainment foodie area.Lotsa souvenir shops and drugstores with discounts.We got our Royce chocs and magnet here.I wish I could have gotten a nicer magnet design but all the shops sold the same things.Walkable from Sapporo station
Lots of shops for a relaxing stroll after dinner time. Has a good mixed of restaurants and shops. You can find all your touristy shop here and some

Sapporo has no lack of underground shopping malls and shopping streets but the famous Tanukikoji shopping streets, which are made up of 7 blocks of individual shops with the last block being the wet market, is a must-visit. It's all sheltered so you don't have to brave the

Go to this area is a must try. Some shops open till late and Don Quijote open 24hrs. There's a lot of tax free shop. You can find anything in this area. We visited this shopping area few times as our hotel just nearby and too tiring to do in a day!

Although it doubles as shop for snacks and confectionaries and suchlike, Calbee Plus really scores with its line-up of Poterico and soft ice cream. With the Poterico Salad, there’s no reinvented wheel here, but everything’s exactly as it should be: the chips have an exceptional,

This is a sheltered open air pedestrian walking street. It is about 7 blocks long with shops and restaurants on both sides of the street. The shops looked rather plain and simple. Many of them seemed to be selling the same things. I didn’t feel any excitement or liveness

If you have been to other parts of Japan, this shopping street is just the same as others. If you are into shopping, maybe you can spend more time here. One can use the underground walkway to reach here from Sapporo station.

We found the best things for the best prices pn this street. Easy to spend the whole day just on this street alone...theres much to see & snoop around. No lacking in the variety of foods and restaurants too.
We shop in there a lot of time when we stayed at Sapporo because it's near to our hotel. We buy many souvenirs and we love there.

Really nothing much. Most shops repeat themselves, game arcade booths and shops that sell Japanese tidbits and souvenirs. There was a pet shop with sale of puppies and kittens that was more interesting. A long street with 6-7 sections. The underground pole town separates it into

Well sheltered stretch of shopping areas. You will find lots of stuff here, from food to souvenirs. Good to walk, regardless of the weather, there are seats for you to rest during your breaks. You will definitely be spoiled with choices. Most items are at good buys. Truly, shop

Comprising more than 200 shops, large & small - one could easily buy souvenirs, fruits, upmarket products, medicine or even 100 Yen specialise shop. We would recommend that you make your purchases via shoplets that provide already a discount for tourist instead of collecting the

Such streets are or look quite typical of Japanese shopping street. This one spans a few roads, and is covered, except when you have to cross the roads. We came here a couple of times, just for the clothes/bags/shoes bargain and also the big Mega Don Quixote store, which opens
Tourist spot, happening area. Food and souvenirs area. Repeating shops. Good to walk around especially after meal.

Tons of sightseeing use google maps for walking around and everything else. You need more then three days. I put 15 miles on my feet in one day. Taxi friendly, close to trains, bicycle parking everywhere. Safe place.

We chanced to walk into this shopping arcade after a visit to Nijo market. Nothing but the same shops one arcade after another. Can't believe there are 7! We gave up after 4 thinking the next one would be different. Lots of drug stores, clothes and some restaurants in between.

Love this place!!! The best shop for gifts are the Mega Dons. There’s 2 across from each other. Tho shopping area has cool clothes, dining, fruit, etc. We got takoyaki at High Ball. There’s also a McDonald’s at the very end. A must for tourists.

This location is filled to bursting with hotels, ramen shops, souvenir shops, and duty free options. It’s a good location for one stop gift shopping but I found it very underwhelming. I was hoping for local stores not bulk generic items.
Similar to Osakas Namba / Shinsaibashi area, there are lots of restaurants and clothes shops in the area

Loved this shopping arcade. From the restaurants (where I had delicious pig liver and chives in a Korean place, and pasta in another) to the ice cream and many stores. Be sure to look for the used clothing stores for great bargains, especially the one where you go down narrow
Nothing stood out for me and it is just like every other shopping street in Japanese cities. It is average cos you can get food, snacks and souvenirs so it may still be a convenient location.

If you don't like the sea of faces passing you at a "speed of light" then this is the place for you. It is very similar to Dohtonburi in Osaka, less the crowd. Shops are well placed and a number of restaurants are evenly situated. The whole stretched is covered. It is walking

Even with pouring rains, Tanukikoji Shopping Street is comfortable place to stroll as it is covered with arcade. Many chemists and souvenir shops open late so you never miss purchasing things you might want to get.
As the other reviewers have said, it's a dated mall full of cheap shops and not much else. Don't bother. Better off looking for other places to go. Walk around the food markets and find a food court.

If you want to do shopping, this is the best place to be because almost everything I think of is available here. It's a straight long street full of shops. The price I think is reasonable. They have benches in the middle of the street in case you need to rest or have a bite of

Great place to shop your souvenir.. lots of variety..from fridge magnet to green tea. We did found one Muslim friendly convenient shop that sells food from neighboring asia such as Thailand and Malaysia.

I love to shop at Tanukikoji street because it has got many retail shops selling popular Japanese brands of skincare and cosmetic (from mass market brands to counter brands like DHC，ZA, Fancyl, Kose, Kanebo, SKII to Shiseido and more). The promoters there are well-trained in

Kinda touristy but on our first night, we got into our hotel a little later than expected so having this shopping arcade near our hotel made it easy to find many eating choices. I wish I got the name of this Irori grill. We had a great dinner. They had the 980 yen all you can

There have many shops that we can do our shopping. As for eatery, there is Pork Free Restaurant and other Restaurant as well. There is few hotel also. All in one roof. Nice to walk around. You may want to spend few hours here.
Half a day there...your luggage would be full already :) Just opp Niko Fish Market where u can get all the fresh seafood too.

It was not as fanciful as those found in the mega cities like Osaka and Tokyo. The shops seen here are usually restaurants or drug and cosmetics stores and apart from that, there really isn't anything special about this shopping street.
It's a long shopping street in Sapporo. There are lots of stores and restaurants in the area. Don Quijote is also in here. The ramen in this area are also good. Definitely a must try!

When compared to shopping streets seen in other Japanese cities, Tanukikoji is not very impressive. There is a good selection of restaurants and “souvenir” type shops, but the street lacks in real shopping or street food, which we found to be the highlights in other cities.

Sure, see it. It's in the area. But this is nothing to write home about if you have been to a few shopping arcades during your travels within Japan or put of Japan. Some food joints, souvenir shops, clothes shops etc. Kyoto, Osaka and Tokyo do these arcades way better!
This shopping street can make you shop & eat all you can. At the end of Pavilion 5 you can also find Fish Market where fresh sashimi, sushi & all seafood you can enjoy !

Located between Odori Park and Susukino, this above ground but covered shopping street is a number of blocks long. There is a supermarket located here as well as numberous restaurants, bars, and an over abundance of beauty stores and drug stores. Great for protection from the

there is a sapporo underground pedestrian which full of store but feels like ordinary shopping malls. tanukikoji feels different because is more like a sinsaibashi in osaka, but a little bit smaller. you can find many store here selling merchandise and souvenir and there also

This was once a wonderful shopping arcade. Sadly (or happily) the shopping has moved underground to the stores and arcades there where it's warm and bright year round What's left at Tanukikoji is a mostly deserted shell of what was once a thriving shopping area.
In the afternoon on a winters day this is not such an attractive spot. It’s undercover but cold with tacky shops.
Was quite disappointed with this streets shopping, 90% are selling cosmetic. Unless you are here for group purchases of cosmetic, other than that I don't see ironic case to come to this street.

Local comes here to eat as well so I suppose it's not bad ,interesting streets to walk around ,I think it just continues for 5 streets in 1 straight line under cover so u dont have to worry if it snows or rains ,I notice it's absolutely pack in the weekends , it's easy to get

We had lunch at Susukino at decided to walk over to Tanukikoji Street to do some shopping It is a typical Japanese shopping street (which they call a Shopping Arcade) It’s basically a plastic roof over 2 parallel buildings and lots of shops and restaurants The Wife managed

Stopped by Tanukikoji Shopping Street to buy wrapped food and biscuit gifts for friends. The shop gives 10% off and they help to pack the food into big boxes to bring home. This is the longest covered shopping street in a Sapporo. Many hotels, restaurants and drug stores here

Tanukikoji might be the most lively spot in Sapporo. It's roofed shopping street spans for a few blocks from west to east. It hosts duty free stores, pharmacies (which open until 10pm), budget hotels, and izakayas. Nice place to enjoy night in Sapporo.

Shopping street lined with souvenir shops, tax free shops, restaurants and cafes. Great for late night shopping - the duty free shop closes at 1 am and is always buzzing with lots of people including locals.
Went to this place twice, i found that there s lots of drug stores (beauty products and health products). Besides that there s a video arcade and some gift shops. Also its very near to Nijo Market

It has a long stretch of shops. Something like those in Osaka. The shops sells everything and the prices are inexpensive. Good place to go if you are sick of the malls. But do not go after 8pm as all the shops are closed.

Went to the Tanukikoji shopping arcade and it have many interesting shop such as Calbee and KIt Kat, also souvenir shops that you can buy local goodies , Buscuits and chocolates lavender , horse oil soap , handcream and so on . There is a total of 7 streets , took me abt 2 hours

This place has many stalls selling cheaper and outdated stuff. If you are looking at higher end goods or clothings, better to head off to the Malls around Sapporo station. The fashion there are closer to the latest fashion in Tokyo but not this place though.

Tanukikoji Shopping Street has everything and anything you would need! Shops, restaurants, bars, tourist information desk points, regional souvenirs, arts and craft shops, 100 yen shop, pharmacies, hotels, hostels, cafe’s and more! Easy walk through from block 1 to block 7.

This is one of the famous shopping area in Sapporo where you can purchase the famous white chocolate biscuit and other local delicacies at discounted price. It is also a place where there are shops across a few streets, be prepared to spend a few hours if you plan to walk every

Cool place to wander around in. A covered shopping arcade with everything you could imagine, want, or need. When I started feeling like I was in the same shop as I was 5 minutes ago, I know it was time to button it up. It can get very repetitive.

A busy undercover shopping strip with residents and drugstores, as well as a Don Quijote which sells delicious baked sweet potato for 108yen. The beauty is that this step connects to the underground Pole Town shopping strip, which connects to multiple other shopping strips. Very

If you have never visited any Japanese shopping streets, then it might worth to visit. But i have ever visited shopping streets in Kyoto and not impressed for this. Take namhuk line and get off at suzukino street. (or you can get off in front of street from the tram.) Not

It’s a long stretch of restaurants and shops. And it’s usually crowded with tourists. The street is also covered, so it’s a great option to spend your time there if it’s raining. Also a really good place to buy souvenirs as well as beauty products at their drug stores.

Tanukikoji is one linear kilometer ( three-quarters of a mile) of non-stop shops. The shops are in an enormous variety, but it's not like the Ginza in Tokyo or Dotonbori in Osaka, the shops tend to be a tad downmarket. This will not prevent the dedicated shopper from spending at

Right across from nijo market.... It's a long street of shops...plenty of cosmetics and pharmacies but the shopping streets of Osaka and Tokyo are better. This one is supposed to be the oldest shopping street in Sapporo...

The weather was perfect 65 degrees outside. This is several blocks long in One Direction. There's a special KitKat shop with different types of candy by that manufacturer. Several drug stores are also on the way. it was a great 90 minutes shopping and walking for the visiting
Popular shopping arcade near Nijo market. Shops and restaurants of all kinds stretch 1 kilometre designed for pedestrians only. Very covenient, safe and clean. Must visit in Sapporo.

Beautiful shaded stretch of restaurants and shops . Gimmicks abound. Talented street performers line up several areas. Bars , convenience shops , supermarket, budget and souvenir stores . Get your preferred Japanese cuisine , ramen , everything. Others close late night. A

Be prepared to wear a pair of good shopping shoes as it's a length of 7 arcades long in Tanukikoji. There are lots of duty free shops, souvenirs and Hokkaido delicacies to be found here. You can also get more information on travelling around Hokkaido from the tourist information

lots os small cafés and restaurants not to mention so many shops selling all kinds of things I don’t want to buy. There was a shower so it was fun to stroll inside and watch the hustle-bustle of the locals doing their thing

Did some shopping at Tanukikoji Shopping Street during my recent trip to Sapporo. There are a variety of shops (and it is easily more than 100 shops if you want to count) which you can shop in. And if you feel hungry, do drop by in any one of the restaurant for a meal. There is

My family and I hit the Tanukikoji Shopping Street on July 15th, the only rainy day on our Sapporo Trip. We had a great time walking the seven blocks of the shopping area, looking at the shops, restaurants and even a hotel or two. We hit the Donki Store and spent some time in

Tanukikoji is interesting place to stay or visit. Because is connected to several hotels like Karaksa , Sunroute hotel and others, it is very convenience for traveler to wonder around. In addition, it is roofed, so you wont get a single drop of rain. Many shops, pharmacy,

Like any other shopping street in Japan, I will say this street is simple and can't remember there is how many blocks in total but the last block is mainly food. Lots of clothes, cosmetics and medication shops, I think the ladies will enjoy it very much.

I would really just concentrate efforts on the 5th and 6th streets as pretty much every other street sells the same things; pharmacy and souvenirs. The drug stores in particular are good for shopping and staff are also well equipped language wise to deal with tourists. 5th
It is a nice shopping area to shop if u are buying cosmetic or medication as there are a lot of shops selling.

Plenty of food and shopping here. The HUG food court is good and cheap. The underground Pole City is located under the building, which is another additional place for shopping. The morning market is also located nearby.
Mini version of the Osaka Dotonbori and Namba covered shopping street. Many restaurants too. Nice to shop here when raining.
Above the pedestrian underground is this pedestrian Shopping Street . Our friends went to but stuff from Don Quixote outlet while we had Coffee nearby. Nice Area to spend free time.
Not as vibrant as the shopping street in Osaka, it nevertheless is worthy a visit for its large no of restaurants, shops and hotels.

I went there with family with the seniors. We enjoyed the shopping street very much. This place is all in one service ranging from eating like local in a small izakaya to the proper dinner. For shopping , the underground shopping street is fabulous. For the souvenirs, there

This is a nice complement to the underground pedestrian walk between Susukino and Sapporo Station. They also intersect. Even though it's not climate controlled inside this covered arcade line of shops, the "roof" makes all the difference. I don't know how cold it is in here
A must visit place in the middle of the city. It is a very long walking/shopping street with lots of shops, restaurants, game shops, and a few hotels.

This is a landmark in Sapporo and is an enjoyable undercover street running 7 city blocks in central Sapporo. There a few hotels located right on this drag and dozens of shops though mainly huge pharmacy supermarkets, restaurants, convenient store and good smattering of bars.

Nice shopping district with many shops , walk till you drop . Shopping district sheltered . A lot of eateries . This place can be access from underground walkway , walk towards pole town , up escalators and arrive .
Wide range of souvenir & drug stores. Price are slightly cheaper than underground shops. Plenty of restaurants to choose & price quite reasonable.

This is a long covered shopping street that stretches for about three blocks with shops selling daily merchandise mainly for locals. The prices of these shops are very good. I almost bought a brand new kimono jacket made with fine materials and they were just asking for Y2000.

Good shopping for duty free products. They have a speciality shop for Calbee and kitkat products in various flavors. Little shopping for fashion / clothes - if you are shopping for clothes, this place is not for u.
This street is one of the longest i’ve been to. Tons of shopping and food. Definitely recommended to visit.

There are many shops along the covered walkway. Don quijote or aka Don Don Donki is located at Tanukikoji street which is opened 24 hours! There are a few arcades, shops selling toiletries, a pet shop, restaurants etc. A nice long walk after dinner. Most shops closes at 9pm.
Advantage of this shopping street is that it has a roof. For the rest lots of shops for Japanese people, for tourists there’s not that much to see/buy. Nice for a rainy afternoon.

The shopping arcade is all weather with selections of stores mostly specialty and plenty of pre loved stores for the brand fanatics. Be ready for a long walk with very few benches to relax the tired feet. A great place to do your shopping .

I love the way parts of Japan have these shopping districts. They have taken a street that goes on for many blocks and enclosed it and made for foot traffic only. Full of shops and restaurants. A very fun a safe way to shop and walk or just walk safely to other parts of town.
this is a place for you to buy skincare, supplements, local snacks, supplements. Do compare the prices.
I like strolling around this area because it has a long and clean street and easy to navigate,, It has 5 or 6 rows in a line, and you can find a lot of restaurant and cosmetics stuff in here,,
Extremely good shopping area! Spent a lot of time at the multi-storey Daiso and Don Quijote. A small Ramen restaurant can be found at the end of the alley. Yummy and inexpensive!

This is for all of you who loves shopping..there are endless of restaurants and shops here to spoil you. Do also visit the pet shop if you can for you will be able to see lots of cute pups and kittens for sale. There is also a big daiso nearby.

The shops along both sides of this precinct are basically cosmetic outlets that catered for Chinese tourists or clothing/shoes stores for bargain hunters. However there is a very well kept pet shop and a specialty knife store. These two are the little gems that can escape

This long stretch of sheltered shopping street starts/ends opposite the Nijo Market and is conveniently connected to the underground shopping malls, Aurora and Pole Town, as well as the Susukino, Odori and Sapporo train stations. There are escalators leading down to the

There was plenty of shops to offer what do you like to purchase. My main purpose of visit to this street was to buy some good Japanese knives. There is a great shop, can’t pronounce the name, very specialized in making Japanese knife. They do write a name in the knife to be very

Sapporo's oldest shopping mall is actually a covered street that goes for several blocks, and provides every type of shop and restaurant, as well as hotel entrances that locals and tourists alike could possibly need. It is certainly brightly lit, but it also conveniently joins
Was checking out the winter festival and came across this Street. Something for everyone on a budget. Even a fresh fruit stand (in February)? Easy to walk, but cold in the winter.

Shopping for cosmetic things as many drug stores located in here. There is 7 street in total if I’m not mistaken xD. I walk from the first until the end so couldn’t remember it. There not much shop in the end, a lot of clothing shop had been closed down.

If you’re into drugstore products, this entire long shopping street is worth your time! Just go straight to Don Quijote and buy your goods. Cheaper compared to other drugstores! Many restaurants around this area as well. And if u visit in the morning, can go over to Nijo Market
Tanukikoji street located at the centre of Susukino area. This place can consider a drug store street. Beside drug store also have few shoe store and restaurant.

Some shops were open till late. But most of the shops are targeted at tourists. Countless gift shops and drug stores available. Many restaurants and arcade as well. Even though most shops sell almost the same items, you may be able to find something unique if you look hard

I wouldn't consider this shopping street is an attraction, but if your itinerary is affected by a rainy day, then take a leisure walk along this covered shopping street might be a way to kill your time or look for the bargains. The entire shopping strip is separated in a few

In snow-bound places like Sapporo covered shopping tunnels are needed built features. This place is dead during the day and is not a farmers market/fish market, but it gets really lively at night. Shopping tunnel features (2) Donkihote, hotels, restaurants, drugstores, and
I guess for a local its fine but as a tourist i found few shops worth stopping in. A nice place to get something to eat but little more than that. Preferred the street stores over the shops here.
There are lots of drug stores. Also, some of them operates for 24hrs. Come by here and enjoy your sightseeing! But be careful, there’re many people..:(

Lots of drug stores, a large 24hr general store called Don Quixote which was o k. I saw a puppy store and a speciality Japanese knives store. It will be my first - and last - visiting this shopping arcade.
The prominent taste of commercialism is everywhere. We didn't stay long, for everything we saw was cheap souvenirs taylor-made for dummy tourists. Nothing delicate or able to represent the city.

An excellent alternative tot he department stores and even the underground shopping arcade. Lots of shops ranging from restaurants, food stores, minimarts, second-hand stores and even a great pet store. My favorite is the pet shop and the secondhand shop next to it.

If you're looking for a vast variety of shops offering everything from A to Z, this is probably not going to be that exciting. I would recommend the interlinking underground shopping from JR Station to all the other shopping centers. I would say this is only good for some

The entire shopping street is one of the oldest in Sapporo and seems to stretch more than a kilometers. There is a tourist information at this location where you can book local tours to some attractions.
This Sapporo walk involves few km of walking with shopping bar and restaurants. Plenty of things for sale. Ideal for a very cold day. Lot of crowd.

Generally common shopping area like most Japan city. However one of the spot we find in here is the tourist center and we managed to get some information or advise on what to do and the dates available for some events like snow village etc.

Another must visit that has been overrated. Yes, we got many souvenirs from this spot but if you ask me...good drugstores anywhere also have souvenirs offer. The best thing about this place is deco having duty free offering at many stores. So it’s convenient for tourists.
Is a different type of experience. shopping in the cold weather. too cold just go in one of the shop to grab some snacks or drinks.

Here's a rough breakdown of the 7 sections: 1-2: shops that do sell shoes/bags (Anello bags can be found at 1) 3-5: more shops that are open and more interesting 6-7: Most are food places that open late evening There was little variety and things I expected to find (such as

Tanukikoji Shopping Street is the largest and most famous shopping street in Sapporo. It is good for buying Sourvenir. Besides, tourists can also buy appliances and cosmetics here. It's a all in one street concept for shoppers.

Great place to shop under shelter but still cold for the winter season. Many tax-free shops but will require an expenditure of 5400 yen to be tax-free so consolidate your purchases to enjoy the tax-free. Merchandise are priced same as airport tax free, if there is sufficient

Obviously, every city has her own shopping havens. Sapporo is no exception. Just keep walking from one end to the next. Shop, walk, eat, rest, toilet and repeat the process above. Make sure you bring enough dough. Pharmaceutical and cosmetic companies took the girls to seventh
This place is great for escaping the snow. It's completely roofed over, and has multiple entrances to the subway below. Can both shop and eat here.

Total six districts along Tanukikoji Shopping Arcade, you will find many different shops from restaurant to cafe to Don Quixote to ABC Mart and many many drugs stores. Most, if not all, of the drugs have Chinese speaking staffs to cater to the China and Taiwan tourism

An outdoor roofed shopping street with 7 sections long, section 1 is right next to the famous seafood market called Nijo (another must go spot for fresh cook crab !). Souvenirs, drugstores, restaurants, duty free shops, anything you can think of Sapporo as a tourist, a shopper

Was recommended by a Korean pretty girl during day tour at Marukoma Hot Spring that Don Quijote is a MUST for any souvenirs and food which you can see at all the tourist spots in Sapporo. We decided to give it a try and found out that the store was so amazingly convenient and we

This is a great place to visit if you want to buy some souvenirs from Sapporo. Tanukikoji is about a kilometer long with over 200 shops. You can find everything from pet stores to well established knife shops as well as restaurants. It is great for rainy days when other

Well to be honest the one thing I liked about strolling down this place was to find drugstores with discounted price of japanese cosmetics. The gifts were also cheap. You could find ramen street here.
If you've been to many other Japanese cities, I would not recommend this pedestrian mall. It's somehow similar yet not that distinctive.

A very famous shopping street in Sapporo. I found a lot of game centres here. There is one tourist information centre here where you could get information about Sapporo and also some discount vouchers.

The Tanukikoji Shopping Arcade is a covered arcade that runs through seven streets from east to west (Tanukikoji 1 to Tanukikoji 7 chome). It contains about 200 shops selling various products and services. There are drugstores like Matsumoto Kiyoshi, big retailers like Don

來北海道札幌焉可不來狸小路商店街朝聖血拚購物一番。琳琅滿目五花八門的東西應有盡有只怕你鈔票沒帶夠。信用卡當然收，還有折扣優惠和免税（要護照）。 If you enjoy shopping, you should come here to shop around. All kinds of foods, cosmetics, souvenirs in hundreds of stores. Credit card, cash all ok plus coupon and duty free offers (with passport). Have
Visited the shopping arcade many times during my stay. It's always busy! All types of shops and eating establishments. Because it's covered it's also a good place to get away from the weather.

Expected a lot more from this place so, I felt it was a bit of a "overrated". However, the Don Quixote shop at 3-Chome is worth going to for bargain goods and even luggage (if you don't mind queuing at least 30 minutes for tax refunds)

The streets are very clean and wide which is very easy for shopping and walking at night time. The famous fishing market,Nijo Market, is located at the end of the street. Enjoy rice fish bowl for breakfast at the market is great.

I really enjoyed Tanukikoji Shopping Arcade, with its many restaurants i tried ramen, sushi, German cuisine, takoyaki and icecream here) and lots of shops. Specially recommend the organic grocery store there, the honeydew melons they sell are super yummy, and the staff there

It's a souvenir street that sells the same thing at every block. The difference between each shop is so minute... sometimes you're looking at 50yen differences between shops. Some shops are tax free buy only if you spend over 1000 yen. On the other hand, you can get to the

The Japanese have figured out a way to entice shoppers in congregating onto a main shopping belt : a) make it a pedestrian-only street; b) cover the overhead so it blots out the heat from sun, and wet caused by the rain; c) put interesting F+B outlets cheek by jowl with

Not as vibrant as the ones in Osaka. Most stores are cosmetics/drugstores. Highlight is the 24 hour Don Quijote outlet. Most stores offer tax free if you reach the required minimum spending. Other major shopping stores like Uniqlo, GU, etc are just nearby.
Long shopping arcade in Sapporo with lots of restaurants and pharmacies which some opens 24 hours. That would be great for those who still wanna shop till dawn without any crowd.

Several blocks of street are roofed over to provide a mall-like environment. This gets you out of the snow and rain while you shop or hunt for a likely restaurant. You can just use these streets to get from one place to another any time of day. During the day it is more of a

What I heard from my aunt about this street - most of it repeated drug shops. We walk pass to have a look, some drug shops aim tourist to selling high price. Not much people during our evening visit, nothing to see others than many many drug shops selling the similar products.
Quirky pubs and cafes. Fresh fruit. Gigantic shops and tourist restaurants. This is a great place to explore day or night.
in here you can see lots of shopping mall, they not in one blocks but going straight in small shops getting together.. they have ramen zero here which is delicious. try them..

I think this shopping arcade/street is perfect especially at night -- and here's why: During the day, most of us are touring or driving places. Then, at night -- at least in the early and late summer months, it's the perfect time to go walking around. Susukino's Tanukikoji

Please remember which gate you enter the arcade. Drug store is everywhere. You can find lots of local cosmetic product here especially skII. You can ride a streetcar from here too. It also connected to undeground shopping arcade.

This shopping arcade is covered, you can stroll, eat and shop even on raining days without getting wet. Tanukikoji flourished as a bar district in Sapporo's early days. Today local delicacy restaurants, eateries and folk handicraft shops stand side by side.

A typical shopping street. Lots of similar shops selling same things. Typical tourist shopping area for duty free items like cosmetics, phamaceutical stuff and local food souvenirs. Compare to Osaka shopping street this is just average.

There were lots of shopping in the alley and interesting shops selling various stuff. Restaurants are plenty too. Drop by the Tourist Information center for some really useful tips and discounts. Very colorful place indeed
this place has almost everything that you can want and some shops close really late. it's a long street as well dotted with cafes etc...so you can easily take a break from that shopping spree.

Warning // If you have visited a long stretch shopping arcades then you would think, "all similar and nothing special". But this place could be good ,,, read further down. What's there // Shops, souvenir shops, eating places all under a long long stretch of roofs and six
This is for tourist, not much to see except shopping. it has lots of stores selling cosmetics. The opening time is quite late except one of the stores open 24hours.

Definitely no shortage of shopping here. Way more than I needed, but probably what most people want. Lots of choices, seems like endless shops, busy excitement and other things that can make for a fun shopping experience. Convenient to get to by can it walking from area hotels.

This is the typical shopping street like other parts of Japan. Lots of stores that sells cosmetics, shoes, clothings, food and restaurants. There is a Don Quixote along the street here. If saporro is the last stop, you can get stuff over here and tax free if you buy more than
Main shopping street! Go Don Quixote! Really pack and squeezy but has really cheaper stuff. Many drug stores here too. Big and small. Some stores have staff that speaks mandarin.
Can get almost everything you want here. Worth a visit, but very touristy and not that much to see. Would not spend much time here.

This is a long row of shops where you can buy souvenirs for your trip to Sapporo. The Don Quixote and Sapporo Tourist Information Center is located here as well. There are many type of shops from game arcades to pets stores, restaurants, 7-eleven and McDonalds. If you're
You probably can take a walk down this to have a look see, but the shops were mainly restaurants, drug stores and touristy places to buy souvenirs.
From Ramen, Don Quijote, Arcades, Grocers, Antique shops to trinkets. Without discipline and self control, one will probably stuffed themselves silly with food or spend too much with shopping. ;p

I don't understand why this place is even listed as an 'attraction'. Its a covered area of few streets and some shops and restaurants. Nothing special to see here !! I crossed this place because it was near my hotel.

It's like 5-8 mins walk from Odori station, or 10-15 mins walk from JR Sapporo. Lots of shops, incl restaurants, and lots of pharmacies for your to shop Jap drugs, incl a 24 hour one. The ice cream shop located in the entrance of one shop, called Creamia, is a must try. There

The shops were all pretty much similar, and personally, was more boring that I had thought it would be. Even the underground shopping streets of Taipei are more exciting! However, pharmacies and tax-free shops were aplenty! There was this pet shop that had super cute cats and

Touristy but nice Long stretch to browse and buy souvenirs and food stuffs . That is about it. Need time to slowly browse and venture into the little lanes. I suspect prices are all similar across the stores..

The milk ice cream we got here was better than all the other places we had. This is from sampling at least a dozen ice cream shops all over Sapporo. The street is busy and lively. This is a good place for a stroll to find food.
If you need anything at all you will probably find it in this several block long tunnel. I can not say it was nice but it was worth walking through once.

After visits to few major shopping areas here, you realised that they are about the same. Even the covered roof design & street shops walkways are similar in few of these malls. And to top it all, a number of "chains" shops are found in every of these malls. Good to just have

I personally found Tanukikoji boring as it had mostly pharmacies and shops selling cosmetics /skincare plus some restaurants . Nothing like the shopping streets in Osaka or Kyoto. The underground pedestrian walk shopping and food options are a lot more interesting . However if

The shopping street has many types of shops. Japan people are so kind, so when I went shopping, I was excited!! It also near with stations such as Susukino and Odori station. For moms who loves shopping, it is better to go here first to buy some gifts. The prize specially is not

Tanukikoji street has 6 sections and a wide variety of shops. There's restaurants , drug stores , clothing stores , electronics etc..most of the shops open at 10am and the place is usually crowded with tourists. There's a big book off and daiso near to section 3 of the street.
Not much to see, just the usual pharmacies. Not interesting Japanese standard. I would say the seafood wholesale market is much more interesting and you actually get to eat decent food.

This place has a lot of food and shopping and drug stores. It houses the Don Quijote, which is 24 hrs, which has a lot of things, from drug stores, beauty, mobile accessories, to random toys. You will need a lot if time when shopping at the Tanukikoji.
This is truly for shopaholics with endless shopping. Suggest you start from one end and make your way leisurely to the other end. I hope to come back here again.

This "arcade" is not hard to find, just keep walking away from the Sapporo Train Station (south) and you'll find it. It's about 20 minute walk. The sheer size gets you first. The array of shopping offered is amazing, literally "one of everything". This is a must for the seasoned
similar to other covered shopping street in Japan, this one is ok but not as big as the others in kyoto or osaka.

there are tanukikoji streets 1 to 7! full of bars, food shops, game arcades, pet shop, animal cafe, drugstores and everything! its like a one stop area for all shopping needs and for entertainment. one could probably kill lots of time here by just walking around and going in and
basically you can get anything you want from this place. There's a lot of different shops here and also great food.

a 7-block semi-covered pedestrian mall lined on both sides with shops, restaurants & bars. Most establishments open at 10am & close at 9 except the restaurants & bars & Don Q which is open 24 hours. A nice cutlery store with a large selection of knives for the food service

If you're buying gifts to take home this is a good stop because there are a range of tax free stores. You can find Royce chocolates, liquor, Hokkaido food items, and souvenir knick knacks. The Don Quixote store is in this arcade and there are steps down to another shopping area,
The best shopping experience in Sapporo. 5 blocks of covered streets and not located under the earth. We loved it.

You can find almost everything in this nice shopping location that is very large and easily accessed. The central area is covered over allowing access in all weather conditions. You will have access to many restaurants and both local and international brands of clothing shoes

Shop till you drop in all weather. This is a covered pedestrian walkway stretching about 1 km long across 7-chome (streets). Prices here at generally cheaper than the bigger department stores near-by. The products, ranging from snacks, cookies, chocolates, health, facial

This area is very touristy. Many of the shops sell souvenirs. Highlights: Store selling decent range of Kit Kats. I found 5 varieties. Tanukikoji 5 or 6. Don Quixote. Store selling all kinds of random crap. Amusing and cheap. Ramen. Never had ebi broth ramen before. Very
A long covered arcade of shops and food outlets. Very much medium to low end and mostly pharmacies! Shops were repetitious. Probably caters for coach loads of tourists
It's less crowded than the streets you'd find in Tokyo and Osaka, but there's a good variety of shops for shopping.

There are in total 7 stretch of road along this street... And since I stay in the hot along this area, we managed to explore all the streets to see what was on offer. You can buy almost everything here actually - souvenirs, pharmacy, fruits, fashion, etc...

Tanukikoji Shopping Arcade is a street split into sections 1 to 7. The shops are mostly drugstores, clothes shops, and eateries. There is also a stone statue which you can touch in various combinations to get luck. Using Sapporo Subway Station as the starting and ending point,
Pedestrian streets that are covered. With many small shops and restaurants. Some good ramen restaurants are location here. Very busy especially on weekend evenings.

Best place shopping for souvenirs. Spending up to 5,000Yen just show your passport and get discounts. If you're a pre-loved clothes/bags/shoes collector, this is the place ! "Bundle heaven" In case if you're staying at a hostel with a kitchen, FamilyMart for groceries shopping.
The least interesting shopping area in Sapporo. It seems to be popular with some foreign tourists for duty free drugs & cosmetics. Not a place for interesting local shopping or restaurants.

The name says it all. This is a long stretch of shopping street in covered walkway, with souvenir shops, drug stores, restaurants, cafes and some pachinko game arcades. It also links to the underground shopping malls, Pole Town and Aurora Town, which leads to Odori and Sapporo

This is a near 1km long shopping Arcade. Unfortunately, I find it nothing really about shopping except souvenirs shop. There are so many souvenirs shop (mostly tax-free svc for min. spending). Other than that, eatery and convenience store. That's really about it. A 7-story high

If you've been to Dotonburi in Osaka you'll find this place less exciting. Didn't find any shops which was particularly attractive except for a gaming shop which had groups decked out in similar outfits.

This is a huge shopping area that is clearly catered to tourists with all the tax free signs. So come here to get your cosmetics, gifts for friends and family and snacks! Also, you can come here to take sticker pictures and visit an animal cafe where you can have animal

Many of shops and great place to shopping, convinient stores, drugs stores, restaurants, cafe,souvenir stores, etc. We shopping for whole day, from one store to another store, many things you can see and buy.

One of my favorite place in Sapporo. Huge establishments reminiscent of the shops in Tokyo. In terms of the prices, I'm not sure if there are price differences but fairly reasonable. Same goes with restaurants located here.

The place has changed a lot since I first visited in 2000. It was a real shopping area for locals and tourists, selling cheap and weird goods. Now it's catered towards the bus loads of PRC tourist that descend in the area.

Plenty of shops and great place to visit in winter when everywhere else is covered in snow. From British pubs to restaurants and hooby shop and groceries and convenience stores. Try the one YEN pachinko parlours (Japanese ball bearing machines) and slot machines for fun &
They have sections in Tanukikoji mainly consist of cafes, restaurants, phramacies and the tourist information center.

This is a covered Pedestrian shopping street which is divided into a number of sections. The strech of street until Nijo fish market on the other end. Many shopping outlet, like Donki Quijote Section 3; foods outlets and restaurants. Section 4, have elevators to go down to

A lot of food and shopping available here. My kids love the pet shop that has all the cute puppies and kittens on display. They have all kinds of drug stores with beauty products here too. Definitely one of the most iconic shopping area in Sapporo.
If you had done shopping arcades in other Japanese cities, this one is not that different though. Shops, restaurants, cafes, etc. you can think of.

You can spend long time there eating and shopping. We had all you can eat grill there. Restaurants there are not expensive. Some offers promotional offers as well! You can find different types of restaurants and shops there.
The best thing in this shopping location is that it has a covered roof. You can shop and shop without being wet if it is raining. Lots of shops and restaurants and easily accessible.

Interesting shops we came across: pet shop with live dogs as their window display in a natural setting, a game centre with live owl as their window display in a natural setting, a Singapore coffee shop which literally stopped us in our tracks for a photo stop, Don Quijote for
Lots of food and duty free shopping. Good to spend 1/2 day to stroll around. If it rains, there's underground shopping (Pole Town) which leads to the Susukino station.

'A great place for Shopping Haul' Experience: If you have been to Japan before, think the equivalent of Osaka's Shinsaibashi, Kyoto's Shinkyogoku Shopping Street - this is pretty much the Hokkaido's version which is located near Susukino, divided into 7 segments or 'chomes'.
from food to fashion, you can almost find everything here. what I like the most was that there are many game stations and they open (am not sure/maybe) till late at night!
Shopping Street is under roof is good if the weather is bad some shop is 24 h open like Don quijote or conviniece store many restaurant are here with many choice of food a fast food like Subway
There are many blocks along the street and at night is very crowded. Many stalls and restaurant at around. When heavy snow we entered a small ramen resto side road, nice to get warm and enjoy ramen.

This place is a street shopping that is famous all over Japan which opens till late night. It is near to Odori park and walking distance from the Panasonic Sky Tower with is arches across the road 1 to 7. The mall has lots of restaurant, Pharmacy, souvenir shop, coffee shop
Offers protection from the from weather. If it get too cold go underground to Pole Town, a shopping mall that connects three train lines a Odori station.
Great people watching ... Smaller local shops, no big brands but a good way to walk around under cover and experience the local shopping scene.

Not a lot of "unique" stores along the street. Many pharmacies, tax free shops, 7-11 though. There is a knife store that seems to specialise in sushi knifes and such but was not open when we were there in the evening. Else, it could have been nice to buy a traditional knife

My sole purpose was to buy some knives at the famous Miyabun shop - and I was NOT disappointed. The range of knives, scissors and virtually anything else with a blade was breathtaking. As a very amatuer sushi cook I was most impressed with the service and patient advice from
Many good place for dining : ) Of course it's a good place for shopping too.... low to moderate price clothing and daily use product is easy to find there.
I enjoyed walking down this open yet covered street mall. Lots of places to eat and drink many stores. It wasn't raining but if it were this wound be a perfect place to go shopping.

Very long street for shopping. Many drug stores line this shopping street, don't need to go elsewhere to shop. Covered roof walkway is exceptionally good for me during the winter month. There's a ramen shop that's very good here, a must try..don't know the name in eng, but it's

A nice break from the slippery wet icy streets and yet able to shop. Personally I preferred this open air but covered shopping area than the underground ones. I found those underground places too hot. Lots of shopping, food and amusement arcade to enjoy ourselves.
Good for local bargains and souvenirs, it runs the length of the shopping district and bisects Pole Town the underground shopping area that runs between the train stations
You can enjoy shopping for clothes or even souvenirs. They have pet shop here. There are also a few hotels located in this area. Highly recommend for tourist to stay in this area.

Big selection of places to eat or grab a beer. Souvenir stores were rip offs full of bus groups. Many of the places to eat were very reasonable prices, but I was too full to try any of them. Saw a number of people eating ice cream while the temperatures were below 32F--0C.
This street span about 4 blocks, have lots of good restaurant but we wine to the one in the little alley way. It have covers so even in winter it is not cold.

The strip mall-ish concept really helped us take shelter from the harsh winds. There are a lot of small mom & pop type shops with a few chain coffee stores and of course DonKi where duty free shopping is open 24/7. It's nice to visit and grab a bite to eat while strolling.
A well planned shopping arcade giving tourist and local community so much of wonder shopping experience.

This is a must for my wife when in Sapporo and something I have learnt to accept. My wife loves all the cosmetic stores (all do tax free) and we can spend hours here. Many other types of shops though, souvenirs, Don Quixote department store (sells just about everything), many

Nothing outstanding, you not going to miss a things, just like you typical outdoor shopping mall. Lot of drugstores, cosmetics, souvenirs and tax free shops. Many restaurants and cafes. Unless you are looking for something particular, the shops in the underground mall at Pole

This is one long street several blocks long popular amongst tourist especially for cosmetic and medication plus anything else you want to buy st Hyper Media which opens 24 hours even expensive watches, bags and liquor. So if you can't sleep or running out of time to shop this is
Shopping place! Its like shinsaibashi of osaka its has a variety of stores to choose from, don quijote one my favorite store to go is located there. A must visit place.

Shopping area that closes ranging from 9 pm to 1am. Alot of duty free and souvenir shops catered to tourist. Good to visit if you run out of shopping places to visit or if you need to shop late at night. In winter most of the shops in the other shopping area closes at 8pm.
Open concept shopping street. Flooded with drugstores. Some restaurants. That's it. Remember to bring your passport for tax refund at the drug store.

From Odori station, we walk via under ground passenger walkway to go here. There is halal restaurant Jyoti located. About 10-15 minute walk from station. But you would not felt boring because a lot of shop at u/g shopping street. One of the shop is selling the halal local food
Have many pharmacy and souvenir shops for you to buy. Dormy inn is located inside. Ippudo ramen also located nearby. Nijo market is located near tanukikoji 1. Also many many good eateries near here.

Most of the shops in this place sells mostly Japanese sweets and confectioneries that are mostly offered to tourist. I do not find anything interesting in these shops as most of the Japanese sweets and confectioneries can be found everywhere, or may be I was at the wrong side of
I don't think Tankikoji Shopping Street is as good as Aroma or Pole there isn't as much shopping selection or restaurants

Street of restaurants , souvenirs and convenient stores grouped with respect to their areas. If you want to buy souvenirs or sweets and biscuits in bulk , they will pack for you nicely in box to be brought home .

The street here is divided into 7 sections. 狸小路1 to 狸小路7. Most of the shops are selling souvenirs, pharmacies or restaurants. Compared with Tenjinbashi in Osaka, this street pales in comparison. The Kit Kat shop is a unique one though. It has unique flavours not found else where
Went there november. Huge area of shopping streets.. plus underground somemore. Bought the 白い恋人 chocolate in one of the shops. Following a group and was given handsome discount :)

This is a rather long stretch of ground level street with shelter that can provide temporary protection from the cold wind outside. It is also connected to the underground shopping mall. Good place to explore!
Popular with tourists There were locals shopping. But not that many. Variety of shops and products. If not into shopping it's good day to walk and browse

Along this kilometer long street, you can find very unique old and new shops and eateries of all kinds around this area. It is covered, so it's "weather-proof". It is the very authentic shops existing for many decades that are interesting!
The street is full of tax free cosmetic/toiletries/drug stores. Nothing much other than that. Can be covered in about 1-2hrs if you do not patronise every other store.

Interesting place to visit. Spans over about 6 street sections. Has pharmacies, shoe shops, souvenir shops, cafes/eateries, grocery stall, fruit stalls, game shops, clothes shops, a pet shop. After a while, it's the same thing in the next section. Go there for the experience.
You can shop till late at this place. The shopping arcade is covered; at night the wind can make the place ver cold.

I have always liked shopping streets. The street is pretty long, filled with souvenir shops. You will meet many tourists who arrive in bus loads. Some souvenir shops enjoy brisk business. The tourists buy in cartons. This will be the place to get toiletries and cosmetics

A shopping street, with a cute name, "Little road of raccoon dog". Very long, from 1丁目 to 7丁目, across 7 blocks, over 1 Kilometer. Just a shopping street. If you have limited time in Sapporo, skip this. But, it is very popular with tourists. Everyone go there,…..
The famous street that all tour group will bring you there to buy back tidbits and pack in cartons. There are many drug stores there too.

We arrive late on a Saturday evening, and quite a few of the shops have closed. You can tell that this is one of the places that people visits. There are stores selling food, souvenirs, clothing, nice used clothings, tax-free store, among others. One of the bigger tax-free

This place used to be the old shopping street of sapporo. There are alot of things that can be purchased walking along this street, from fruits to souvenirs to medicines. There are alot of eateries scattered around the street as well.

Tanukikoji is similar to the typical covered shopping that can be found in other Japanese cities. The shopping area is spread over 7 partitions. Standing out is Don Quixote which is a 24 shopping store which sells virtually everything. It has about 5 floors for shopping. The
This is a shopping heaven. Pedestrial walk with lots of shopping outlets. You can find cheap shoes,boots, winter hat, medicine and so on. This area near to Nijo Market.

went there last year. a good palce to buy all Sapporo's specialties and snacks, handcrafted souvenirs, etc. it's a one long street full with shops. prepare your wallet, or you may use horse's glasses if you dont want to buy anything..which is so difficult for me...:)

I have visited this place before and it's always a welcome escape from the cold wintery weather. We arrived later this time and most shops were closed except for some quaint little food joints (including some international offerings, steaks, Mexican and of course ramen),

Been to Osaka Dotobori and was quite disappointed with Tanukikoji... we were there on weekday and the alley was very quiet. It's an open area and so get prepared for cold winter weather when shopping there in winter. However, there was still plenty of places for food. Not really

There are many shops here selling souvenirs that you can bring back as gifts. Get the Ishiya chocolates and the Royce chocolates here. The prices is less than at the factory itself. Also , look for tax free shops. Show your passports and get the tax refund on the spot instead of

Whatever we need to buy back home or even for food, we can get it here very conveniently be it rain, sunshine or snowing as it has covered roof and when it is too cold, we can shop in the Underground Shopping Street. Generally the shops close at 8pm but Don Quijote is 24 hours

Second time around to the famous street, lots of shops selling biscuits/chocolates and other food gifts. Pharmacies galore if you are looking for Japanese products, lots of them around each corner. Can't say we walked the whole street since its a long one, great for a visit
Shopping time this street very famous in name of shopping and layout. Very very easy to walk around they've 7 sections each section has difference stuff and open till late night.

This street reminds me of Shinsaibashi in Osaka but a much quieter version, maybe because we were there during weekdays. There are shops, cafes, restaurants, even casinos at the 2 sides of the street.
Many shops selling fashion wear clothing and restaurants. They have 1st to 7th sections (last section). Many people in this area including tourists. Prices are reasonable. Services are good.

This is a street shopping that is famous all over Japan which opens till late night. The mall has restaurant, Pharmacy, souvenir shop, coffee shop and all kings of Japanese store. Advice is to canvass the stores before buying as shopping should be. Also remember the duty free
Great shopping place. There are seven streets. All under one roof. Instant tax refund. Eat, play, shop at one go.

If shopping for local products, plus your usual shoes and clothing stores, is your thing, then this is the right place for you. As is common in shopping streets in major cities in Japan, this is a covered shopping street and makes for quite an interesting visit, even if you

Got to a long-arched glass-roofed shopping street like this one in every city of Japan that I got to except Hiroshima, but this one in Sapporo was the "best one" with a wider walkway and bigger stores (some are really pretty big "fun arcades" for video games & gambling & such);

interesting smaller stores here with ability to Segway out to other alleys and streets. lots of places for food n I bought from a well known knife maker an excellent kitchen knife . small supermarkets there as well with good prices

This place is near to Susukino, Sapporo Station but it is just a perfect place for tourist. You don't get the messy red light district like in Susukino, you don't get expensive shops like in Sapporo Station. It's a "must visit" if you are running short of time for shopping in

Every big city needs a shopping street with a sheltered thoroughfare for pedestrians only and this is it in Sapporo city! A large variety of shops await - there are a few souvenir shops along the stretch retailing packaged food (which are simply irresistibly delicious!) and

Tanukikoji have 7 sections, you can either walk from 1 to 7 or only selected if you know where is the shop location. This place is good for shopping. There are many drug stores whereby donki is operating 24 hrs. Good place to shop even it is raining.
Huge drug and discount stores concentrated within the length of arcade. Eatery outlets with some pubs. Benches to rest spaced throughout. Connected to Auroro Town and Pole Town shops.
It is a shopping area filled with shops. It has even a very cute pet shop. It's worth your time to drop by.
This is nothing special, very similar to other shopping streets around the Japanese cities. Sovereign, beauty, pharmacy shops and restaurants. Okay to walk through when raining!

This street is lined with various shops and restaurants. There is a shop that sells fresh fruit - must try the strawberries when in season. So fresh! There is a 24 hour Don Quijote store here where that sells anything from designer goods, make-up, kitkat and even fresh corn!

This shopping street is no big difference with those in other parts of Japan like Osaka. If you need to buy daily necessities, medicine, skin care, etc.. then it is the right place. However, the price seems higher than in Osaka. By the way, there is a Daiso near to section 2

An excellent place for last minute shopping. There would be a couple that's open 24 hours such as Don Quixote Plaza. Overall, best buys in this area although not all shops may give further discount. However, if you need very specific quality goods such as horse oil - the very
During a raining day, you can walk in this area. It's a commercial area without particular things to do. There are some nice restaurants on the road

This is a long shopping street under a roof. It is located a few blocks north of Susukino station. There are always foreigner tourists here. The most popular shops on the street is probably Don Quijote or Donki Houte.

A good long stretch of shopping for tourists indeed. You can get your food souvenirs here, and plenty of Jap skincare / medicines all around, abit like Watsons of sorts. Spotted some arcade / jackpot machines too I think? Most shops close at 8pm though, save for a huge 24hour

Great place to get souvenirs, you could spend whole afternoon or day if walk from the beginning to end stretch. We only did from street 3 to 7 though. Particularly liked the decoration above at street 6. However, it was too crowded and raining when we were here.

We enjoyed walking around the shops in Tanukikoji Shopping Street. There is a wide variety of shops and restaurants. You can get souvenirs, beauty products, Japanese snacks and food and so on in this street. A good place to walk and shop!
Took a walk here after dinner. Mostly drug stores and souvenir shops , a couple of fruit shops and some eateries . Nothing outstanding

A long stretch. covered shopping street. You can find everything here from souvenir, restaurant, pachinko (slots machines) & lots of shops sellings clothes, shoes, bags, etc. Super love their drug store that sells almost everything at very affordable price such as snacks,
This is a nice covered shopping street with a Don Quijote, which is always fun. Having been to Osakas Dontonburi is a spoiler. This is one straight street but nice to browse.

This shopping street is a great place to go, inbetween Susukino and Odori Park. It was a rainy day and we were walking along and happened to walk into it. It spans several blocks, full of shops with all kinds of shopping and also food stores, stalls, restaurants.

If you are looking for massive shopping, this street is the perfect place to go. Its in between Odori Park station and Susukino station. So you can walk to this place from these 2 stations. Lots of shops and restaurants. There is a tourist information center in the middle of the
You can walk in this place to see and buy. There are many shops, restaurants and cafes. You should wear canvas shoes not high heels to make you walk all day :)
The long street is filled with shops and connected to the sapporo underground pedestrian shops. It's a good place to visit if you want to shop.

If you are only able to come to Sapporo and wanted to go to Tokyo, the only place with Tokyo-Like things is basically in Tanukukoji. It's more crowded, has all the shops lined up together, has department stores, and just off the street there's also a building with Animate,
Plenty of shops and restaurant in the same area. You can walk from morning through the Nijo market and enjoy shopping till night. The street cover with the roof so no problem during rainy day.

The street traverses so many streets. It is not a place to go window shopping. Better bring a Japanese guide or ask your hotel's concierge for directions on which area to go to if you know what you want to purchase. Otherwise you will have a long walk.
enjoyed shopping here,wish there was more shops and restaurants and supermarkets in lake Toya Village.

As in any other cities in Japan, Sapporo has a coveted shopping place that include food shops, pharmacies and other shops to bring japanese souvenirs. It's a nice place to visit while you are in Sapporo.

It was an interesting walk to see the shops and restaurants locals can frequent. However it is turning into more of a touristy place. We see so many drug stores now that it seems a bit ridiculous. I would recommend a walk there but don't put it as your top priority.
Not worth the visit unless you wanna stock up on souvenirs. Long street. Tried the ramen and snacks along the way and below average.

The average Japanese Shotengai - although the first block is unique and full of character and great shops (Gelato, Singaporean bar, etc), the remainder is the standard Japanese Shotengai; only less interesting. Mostly shops catering to tourists from Mainland China and an owl

This is the oldest roofed shopping street at about 135 years old. It’s a great idea for the shopping enthusiasts, so they can shop regardless of the weather conditions. The street has around 200 stores; there are clothing, shoes, dry seafood, souvenir shops, and bars. You name

6 blocks of covered shopping & restaurant street, great for rainy days. connecting to underground shopping (Susukino, Odori, Sapporo Station). walking towards 1 Chome, you'll end up at Nijo Market, upon crossing the street.

The Japanese like their covered streets and this is similar to many you may have seen. It doesn't have the higher class shops you get for example in Hiroshima but is fun to walk through. We found a decent Italian restaurant for dinner and there were others that looked good too.

many shops from Area 1 to 7 in Tanuki Koji abound. Many eats too from McDonalds to ramen shops and fine dining and mid-level restaurants. There are many pharmacies, dog shop, souvenir shops and pachinko shops. There is even a 24 hour Donki shop where practically everything is on

There is a small number of hotels and inns on this street. Walking from one end to the other provides you with a small insight into how small shops are the majority of places the Japanese prefer. Nearly every shop on this street, except for the restaurants, is a mom & pop

A convenient 7 areas of roofed pedestrian ways from west to east, 5 blocks south of Odori Station. Connects some of the bargain and big tax-free dept stores, eg Don-Quixote and famous food spots, eg Zero Ramen. Ends to the east just at the face of Nijo seafood Market. Worth

7 blocks of shops filled up shopping street, though only block 1-6 seems to be actively in business. It can be accessed from Pole Town too, just follow the directions and take the escalator up to Tanukikoji shopping street. You can follow find restaurants, beauty salons, shops

Lots of shops and foods. And even a little tanukikoji shrine. Definitely worth coming to have a look. Go to the 5 storey Daiso nearby and try the kinotoya bake cheesetart and Kinotoya Hokkaido icecream in the underground shopping area

There are quite a few sections to this place. The ends have more eclectic stuff, the middle is more touristy. One end abuts the Nijo Fish Market, and the other has interesting restaurants at the end. Interesting spots: Singaporean restaurants at one end Charcoal grill Knife
Not bad.. Lots of Pharma stuff and shoes shops. Would recommend for any last minute quick buy. Stuff are priced same throughout. So no need to compare prices between shops.

A nice place to browse as the walkway is covered. Lots of tax free pharmacies and restaurants. Do note that tax free is applicable to minimum purchase of 1500 yen in a single receipt. It's good that there's some benches for tired shoppers or just some elderly people who needed

We have visited this shopping street in early June during our short stay in Sapporo. Lots of visitors came here to buy their souvenirs because there were varieties of tax-free shops here. This shopping street still survived well under the current economic downturn. Hope that
have everything in this street eg. shopping,slot,games,food,beer and no mafia convincing u to go to sex club like other places
Leave your last minute shopping to this place - there are lots of Tax-Free shops and they all sell a wide range of products from local produce to skin care.

Basically, everyone will come here to buy souvenirs, a lot of cheap shops here, from Don Quijote, you can find almost anything here, some little convenience stores that sell cheap KITKAT, yes KITKAT, the most hunted chocolate here. There're also a lot of game arcade here, you
You can get practically all the Japanese good stuff here and the prices are good too. Chocolates, wine, creams, make up. Spend a day here before you fly off .....

If you have the time, you can spend days shopping here and hotels are available. The happening place in Sapporo. The underground shopping is huge and you can lost your sense of direction. This place is near to Odori park and walking distance from the Panasonic Sky Tower with

I had a great time staying at this place during my visit to Sapporo. I find that this street with many section (1-6) have everything I need in Sapporo. There are lots of restaurants, retail shops, gaming centre, hotels, drugs store and even pet shop. Must go in Sapporo city.
At least it is a nice place to get out of the rain. Lots of clothes and goods to satisfy the mobs of tourists.

Truly a shoppers paradise. There's so much to see and all the shops are so well assigned beside both parts of the walk way.you just walk in a straight line from shopping station number 1 no till the end.Endless shopping and you can get almost anything you'de want there if you
