It is obvious how the shops and restaurants along this covered and brightly lit arcade have adapted to lure foreign tourists. So many have advertised their use of english/chinese/ korean, the tax free purchases, halal products avalability, etc. Probably foreign tourists out

This shopping street has 7 blocks. But most tourists make their shopping tour around 3 to 6; with various hotels, shops and restaurants. No wonder it is full of people. However, when you have time to explore a bit, blocks 7 is also worth of visiting, It is the least visit of all
Retail therapy haven and foodie destination for food lovers. Just be thorough when making your choice on which outlet to shop or eat. Prices differ drastically from one outlet to the other. Be smart!

You can find almost everything here. The whole street comprises of countless drug stores (cosmetic shop), Donki at the corner of the street (Don Quijote) where you can find all stuffs that you can imagine of ranging from snack to cosplay. When your purchase is more than 5,000

Sapporo must not be missed is a good place to go shopping for Tanukikoji! Free exercise no pressure of time, and let us not even a two-day visit,we had a good time. Saw a small family shop at the exit of JR station are selling yaki, a 100 yen is not expensive to buy a cream

A nice shopping alley segmented into 7 areas where you can definitely buy stuffs for souvenirs as well as find nice restaurants to satisfy your hunger. The alley is NOT a night market and most stores close by 9PM. In such case, you may head to Don Quixote (in Katakana

Even though it was cold out, many of the shops were open. Unfortunately, the variety of shops were limited. Too many of them catered to tourists from the mainland. Further to the disappointment, some of the restaurants were still not smoke-free.

This place of roofed shopping stalls reminds us of Shinkyogoku in Kyoto, Shinsaibashi in Osaka and Sun Plaza in Kichijoji, Tokyo. So many different kinds of shops and restos to explore in this place, almost everyone in our group felt 2 and a half hours here was NOT enough.

Pro: Located at city area. Easy to navigate. Whole range of souvenir we may choose from.shopped until we drop.:) Cons: there are a lot of tourist groups do their shopping here. You might find it is quite hard to shop in crowded store if you crash with their shopping time.

A long walking street that crosses over many intersection. A lot of shop line up along the walkway and also a lot of small restaurant to. Those who love shopping will love this place. Bring along a lot of money.
Bring a lot of cash because there's a lot to do here. Shopping, eating. Heck, they even have small bars. Great place to chill at after a day of wandering.

An entire alley of food and shops, this is a perfect one-stop place to fill your stomach and fulfill your inner shopping desires. There are altogether about 7-8 alleys that you can walk from one end to the other. Look out the for the glass display of owls along alley 1 or 2.

A long row of shops that spans 6 streets. You can get all your cosmetic stuff along this street. There are many shops selling the items so you can compare the prices to get the best deals. You can spend a whole day here or all your money depending on which is faster :)

I believe there were 6 covered blocks of stores in an arcade setting. It was snowing hard when we were there so the overhead protection. There are several nice souvenir shops with a variety of products to take home. I must have seen at least 20 restaurants, most of them

The shopping street spans about 6-7 blocks in a covered pedestrian only walkway. It's similar to the Shinsaibashi shopping area in Osaka, but many stores here are tax-exempt (bring passport) catering to the many Chinese, Taiwanese and Korean tour groups for uniquely Hokkaido

If you are living in Japan then this is your any shopping street, but good thing its covered, so good for rainy or snowy days. And if you are an oversea tourists, this is an intersting street to spend couple of hours to half day to wander around. Lots of restaurants also to eat

The mall is not less than 2 km long, and right in the heart of Susukino. There are lots of shops selling everything and restaurants to choose from. There is even a hotel there. The mall is connected to the subway and the entire underground shopping mall, including Pole Town.
Lots of shops line the shopping street and you can get most of your shopping done here. Restaurants, cosmetic shops and drugstores are located here.

If you're looking for typical Japan souviners, you'll find lots of souviner shops here. Theres also a pet shop that has a few japanese souviner dog toys (I had to get a squeaky Mt Fuji to takehome for my dog)... they sell exercise drinks for dogs/cats etc (worth a look just for
Around six blocks of small hotels, eateries, bars for foreigners, traditional japanese bars, souvenirs, chemists and even a pet shop.

Before visiting Sapporo, I was told that 狸小路 was a area I must visit during the trip, and there would be so many things to be discovered here. However, when I visited there, unfortunately I didn't see many things really interesting and didn't have a lot of fun. The shops in

The shopping street is located just above the pole town. The street have lots of shops and restaurant all along the way. But restaurant there is a bit expensive compare to underground restaurant with the same food. No English menu is given. But there are still lots of tax free

Lovely shopping street with varieties of souvenir, drug, cosmetic, clothing and food to buy. There is also quite a few restaurant around the area. The whole shopping street is easily access via the underground Aurora town and near the Susukino Station so it is very convenient as
It's like hong kong streets. U walk in the middle and there's shops on the sides. Mostly pharmacies and souvenir shops. Good to shop for hokkaido local food confectionery pdts.

We frequent this shopping area since the hotel we stayed in is connected to it. It is definitely a great place to shop for souvenirs and also other duty free items. Specialty shops selling knives, traditional clothing, and even electronics can be found here. Only drawback is
Shopping is ok here for souvenirs, pharmacy and beauty products. a couple of restaurants. i saw two hotels right here, one was dormy inn. quite a long strip.

Varities shop about 200 on the famous shopping street at Susukino area.It is not far from Odori park.You can walk from Nijo fish market to Tanukikoji Shopping street by 5 minutes only. Travelling by subway Namboku line to Susukino station exit 1 and straight on 2 block.

This is a fairly long connected pedestrian walkway crossing 5 perpendicular roads with some large fashion retailers , restaurants, drug stores and amusement centers along the walkway. It sure beats walking along busy roads inhaling more vehicle fumes. In terms of selection of
This arcade has many shops and many excellent restaurants. Almost anything you need can found here. The stores range from high end to moderately priced goods.

Like any other shopping streets around Japan, lots of shops, restaurants, and crowded with locals and tourists. If you're a shopaholic, this is the place to visit. Though I reckon the prices might not be the cheapest you might get.

Quite varied in choice of shops. Most striking are the number of shoe and drug stores in the precinct. Good when it snows as you're under a roof and the street is connected to the subway. You'll see many tour groups gathering here as it's one of those must visits.
Great variety of things to buy at mid range prices and duty free . Saw some small hotel, will stays in them next time when in town
The shops do not open very early. They open at different timing. It will be good to visit it around mid afternoon so that you can get to see more shops.
Shops are not very interesting. The restaurants are of wide variety but quite expensive. Going for dinner would be fine. Shopping... Na...

The Shopping Street has total 8 sections and it took me about 30 min to complete the whole street. Quite disappointed because there are very few varieties offered. Shops are mainly farmacy, shoes, cloths, grocery and Japanese restaurants.

It was winter when I went there. The outside was covered with snow and it was comfortable that I could avoid the snow in this street with the roof. The street is running from East to West, and the Eastern area was more enjoyable for tourists and the Western area was more for the

Just skip this if it's too cold walking through the streets. Too many pharmacies selling the same stuff. There were some restaurants which looked real interesting but we didn't get to try any as we were not hungry.
We didn't really find much things to do here except strolling from one end to the other. Filled with shops and eating places.

It's an interesting interconnected shopping street, crossing the underground shopping mall near the arterial road that has the city trams. One highlight of this street is the availability of Kimono on rental for taking some quick photographs in the local costumes. While there

Just rows of shops that sell pretty much the same stuff. It's true that you might find Shiroi Koibito cookies at a slightly cheaper price. Other than that, there's nothing very much. It's not quite as interesting and colourful as Osaka's Dotonbori in terms of sight and sound

Just a row of shops located on each side. Probably catches your eye or it does not. I did get my Japanese groceries list done here (curry, tea, rice crackers etc). If you can't sleep there is a 24 hour shop that is a few floors high that sells you all kind of stuff (groceries,

This is a series of inter-connected shopping streets in Sapporo. It is not far away from Susukino Subway Station. Lots of foods, souvenirs and things to look for in here if you are not a big fan of department stores etc.

Everyone told us to visit this shopping street for excellent Japanese gifts and souvenirs. I was expecting an old-fashion alley way with unique traditional Japanese shops, and i was disappointed to see a large long modern shopping mall filled with cosmetic/drug stores offering

I've visited Tanukikoji Shopping Street in the evening when it was raining. Going there in the evening was great, because it has a good atmosphere with all the lights. Going there while it was raining was great, because you are kind of outside, but still protected. It's good for
Lots of shops & eating places under covered walkway in city centre. Great place to wander for gifts etc

This place used to have different type of stores and a great place for shopping but it seems nowadays mainly you will see drug store and souvenir shop. Many mainland chinese and Taiwanese like to buy cosmetic and souvenirs that's why there is am increase in this type of stores.
causal local shopping street with many interesting shops. good for a nice long slow stroll. bets before or after dinner.
A great place to bargain and especially for cosmetics and drugs. This place seems to be very popular for Taiwanese as Mandarin is widely spoken here so it is easy to buy stuff if you speak it.

Many tax free shops for tourists! Cosmetics, shoes, souvenirs, snacks etc. However, price for cosmetics are different from shop to shop. Some items differ 100 yen! Thus, make sure you walk around to get the cheapest price since the whole shopping street is not a long distance.
Less expensive items, 2nd hand items and look out for deals and sales. Plenty of walking around 6 diff. street to walk(1km). restaurants, convenience store, shoes, bags & clothes

This is a popular tourist shopping belt (狸小路), numbering 1 to 7. It is parallel to Odori park and cuts across several lanes. Also a covered pedestrian walkway without any cars, hence you can leisurely browse both sides of the shops along the lanes. There are many shops selling
This shopping street is quite quiet and has nothing much to offer when compared to those in the major cities like Osaka etc.
This an interesting shopping street but fairly typical of what you find in Japan. It is covered and has every type of cheap shop you might hi=ope to find and some better ones as well..
Love this place as just near to susukino. A place for good duty free shopping and food choices. There are a few of this street to shop too.

Tanukikoji is great for buying tax free items. Donki at Tanukikoji is literally a place where you can shop till you drop. Dont expect to buy international brands here though. This place is more of a street shop kind.For more information on shopping in Sapporo, visit

A shopping mall that spans a few blocks. There is lots of shops selling all kinds of stuff. This is a shopping mall for the locals as well so you will not see inflated prices for tourist. However, you will not find any "special shops". We went here on the final day of our trip,

The hotel that I stayed very time I visited Sapporo is in there! This shopping street is never sleep! Lots of good food, shopping, and even Donkey store is on this street too. Love the vibes of this street so much!!

lots and lots of shop. Some are local shop some are cosmetic tax free shop. Not everyshop offer tax free. Things I like the most from here is local shop. Highly recommend to go on Saturday evening. All the local shop will have a massive discount. Most of them let you play game
Nice just to walk there and see a lot of goods on both sides. There are food, wear, footwear, pet supplies. sales.
Spend half day in there. A lot of Tax free items. The restaurants there are generally good. I tried one ramen shop and a Japanese restaurant in the basement.
Depends what you want from here. Duty free shop, shoe shop, food, hotels, second hand clothing and knife shop. Plenty to buy here but nothing really in the high end.
7 blocks shopping streets near the susukino subway station. Many shops and restaurants. Japanese brand cosmetics are really cheap here. Many tax free retails, can get tax refund from the shop.

This is a fun fully covered arcade to walk along in the north of Susukino district. It stretches some one kilometer from the east to the west for six or seven blocks, but the fun area is limited to the first five or six blocks. They say there are about two hundred shops and
Nothing much to see, eat or buy. Touristy place, whole street quite empty when we were there. Sapporo underground is way much better then coming here. Do not waste your time finding this place.
just a normal long shopping arcade. it is covered and offer variety of shops. Just normal daily thing sold here. prefer to spend time else where. I went for a walk half way and went back to hotel.
This is a long, long street that is divided into several sections (each section separated by a road). Mainly for shopping (tax-free) and dining.

Plenty of eateries and tax-free shops. Eateries mostly open after 5pm. Those open early only have limited seats. Over all speaking, nothing special.

Obviously not everybody enjoys such a long, covered shopping/eating area. I first sent my hubby back to our nearby hotel to do the gym/check work emails etc, while I enjoyed the pleasure of finding a lot of skin care, cosmetic products at only a third of the prices you would
There are plenty of cheap good bistro, cosme shops and souvenir stores. Dormy Inn Hotel is located on the main street. Pretty convenient!

The pet shop had really cute puppies, mostly toy breeds. At the corner was Don Quito, a large shop selling everything! It had 4-5 floors and surprisingly, my son found an anime figurine that he was looking for at a very good price. Plenty of restaurants and pachinko outlets.

This shopping street stretches from W1 to W7 on South 3. Although this street is quite long but the variety of shops are limited. However, visitor should still be able to find something for souvenir purpose.

Tanukikoji is a very long covered shopping street with loads of shops and restaurants much like those you can pretty much find anywhere else in Sapporo. However, there are 3 shops for me that stood out and is worth a visit for us foreign tourists. 1. There is a Kimono shop in
Overall this place is seriously catered to tourists. But we discovered two shops that offers duty free and the prices are lower than what is offered at the airport or other pharmacies.

It's a very long shopping street with lots of shops but the products are not good quality and mostly overpriced for tourists. Don't make a special trip but if you are in the general area, feel free to check it out.

Its good to shop and eat here if it is raining outside. There is a lot of resturants and acrade around but less shopping. Towards the end is mostly resturant and bars as there are lesser people there. If you like arcade, properly that's the place to go.

some tourists guess it is because longer winter here in hokkaido, but i have seen all similar shopping areas in osaka and tokyo. I guess japan generally just try their best to offer the best shopping comforts for visitors, sapporo too. From sapporo JR sta. walk down south

Really liked this place. Many things to see, many stores to shop, many items to buy and LOTs of food! I really love japanese food so this is haven for me. From eateries, pubs to restaurants and street stalls. Every sort of food possible from western sandwiches, burgers to
This shopping street supposedly has a history dating back 120+ years. Interesting mixture of stores and restaurants. Very worthwhile strolling through the arcade.

Tanukikoji is a busy shopping street with everything you can find from pharmacy, restaurants, fruits and shoes. I was particularly attracted by their pet shop more than the shopping. The pet shop has dogs and cats that are so KAWAII! I know this will probably anger the animal

It's a nice sheltered shopping street but seriously nothing to shout about. Having said that, the fruit stalls are worth a visit - great selection of fresh fruits at affordable prices. Their melon is a must try, and you can request the stall holder to cut into slices for you,

It's a shopping avenue where restaurants, convenient stores and gift shops are packed together. We went there to buy more Royce white chocolate as gifts for our friends and relatives. The shops are almost selling the same thing. Nothing of fancy.

I spent countless of hours here during my recent trip to Sapporo. Tanukikoji Shopping Street stretches several blocks and there are plenty to see, buy and eat. There are many restaurants, souvenir shops, konbini, etc. There's also a Donki halfway in the middle. You can literally

my motif to go there is to dine at Ippudo Ramen shop, to me its the best Ramen tasted so far. We discovered Ippudo since 2008 at Arcade 6, if u pass arcade 5 before u cross the street to no 6. U can see it on the left side at no 6.

Perfect place to buy Hokkaido famous souvenirs. The streets are covered with a transparent roof to protect pedestrians from rain, it was mentioned that the roof opens up on a sunny day. Didn't not manage to experience that, as I was there in the evening. Most of the shops offcer

We were brought here to buy chocolates and biscuits that are much, much cheaper than in the normal outlets. Green tea kit kats was only 350yen and the Shiroi Koibito biscuits were so much cheaper too. Also cheap are some Glico food stuff. Just walk around and check out the
many shops here. Restaurant closed at around 9pm. U can get tax free goodies if you purchase over about 10k yen Nearby there is daiso and branded shop like LV....
It's not many variety of shops here. Most of them that come here are tourists. You may skip here if time is limited.

It's hard to skip, because it's right there in central Sapporo, we walked past it a few times, but eventually decided to give it a chance. Most of it is boring, but I did find one nice souvenir shop, where I got most of my gifts for friends and family, so this street was worth

When I read about Tanukikoji, I wanted to visit this because it said it offered a unique shopping place which was in an indoor covered pedestrian street offering local souvenirs and interesting stuff. But I was disappointed. If you have limited time maybe, it will be nice to

a typical shopping street for tourist, consist of pachinko shops, souvenirs etc but recommend the last portion of this street where the Izakaya concentrated, it provide a variety of Izakaya for tourist to try out, it's quite pricey since it's considered a tourist area but will

We visited this shopping area after reading reviews that said it was a popular shopping area. There did not seem to be much shopping apart from souvenir shops. Most of the other shops were restaurants (that seemed a bit overpriced when we compare to similar restaurants outside

Shop till you drop!! Although the majorities are drug stores and souvenirs stores. It’s a covered pedestrian walkway. 7-chome in totally so it’s a long walk if you check out every store. Generally speaking, the product and food these shops offered are cheaper than in the big

An excellent covered shopping arcade.
Easy east-west navigation covering several hundred meters.
Includes 2 large popular souvenir shops, restaurants, and most other types of shopping.
There’s also a large but remarkable outlet of the famous discount Don Qiote discount department store chain.

A nice and lively shopping street, but not enough to impress me. There are food trucks, shops and stores and convenience stores, pachinko casinos(?) also but all seemed repeating and not that interesting when I came in. Maybe because except …
7th street was the best! More local and genuine vibes
A nice and lively shopping street, but not enough to impressed me. Not one shop seemed inter

A lot of shops duty free shops good for cosmetics, there is a very nice knife shop if you want buy a good Japanese  knife.
There is not many places to eat on the actual street, more underground or nearby streets. The center of the shopping …

A bright and vibrant place in Sapporo . A must go to experience the good vibe . Beware of restaurants that offer a “English menu “ these are mostly tourist traps . They are very expensive and not so great . Beware
at least not really cold while walking in here i was here in winter woah it's super cold for someone who is from Indonesia tropical-hot-always summer country

I love it. This area has 2 long street crossing in central city of Sapporo. First  from west to east Arcade Shopping street . Second is located under ground from North ( around clock tower) to south ( Susukino Station.) Excellent
Pretty good place to shop. There are a few 2 nd shop that are worth visiting.

We spent a day exploring this long, long street full of shopping and dining finds. Loved the bargains, from
clothes to beauty products to Sapporo souvenirs. We came on a Sunday and discovered a picnic at the end with food stalls and made sure to sample them. The food trucks along the street are also a delight!
Famous shopping and foods street in sapporo, alot of choices and some shop can provide immediate tax refund for foreigner

There's a lot to shop there, from souvenirs to snacks to medicine and groceries.

Along the big street there's not a lot to eat but it's the smaller streets that you can find lots of restaurants.

I would say it's not extremely crowded, and …

I went during summer festival so it was very busy. There were some live performances too. Tables were set up for people to drink beer and eat some snacks. Also, at the end of the streets, there's beer garden.

This shopping street has all you need (restaurants, cafe, beauty shops, pet shops, shoes, ...etc)
It's good place to go shopping. The location is strategic. So crowded but fun to take a walk
Place for souvenirs and snacks. There are many drug stores and mega donquijote. Be prepare to worm your way through packs of tourists. And be mindful of your belongings

Very nice street to find great restaurants or activities in Sapporo. You can just wander there for a while if you have nothing to do or go there during night time to find great izakaya/bars to enjoy your time

This is a great place to go shopping, eat and have fun.

Lots of intresting things to buy.

Worth a visit day or night.

It's convenient and located in town. Many restaurants and also a good place to shop for locals and tourist. There are a fe hotels located alongside the shops and access to underground pole town for more shopping.
A place where you can find anything you prefer, including a nice cup of boba milk tea.
Popular shopping street in Sapporo. A lot of gift claw stations and drug stores, amongst a number of restaurants and souvenir shops. Good for a leisure walk. The walkway is mostly sheltered.
Take Osaka's Shinsaibashi and scale down a bit and you have this shopping street. Lots of tax free shopping and good eats in and around the area. A must see if you're in Hokkaido.
Alot of shops that sell almost the same things and also eateries.  Very happening and fun to just walk around
Nice place to do some shopping. There are hotels too. For tourists, there are tax free shops too.
A good tourist destination as I manage to get bubble tea, titbits, ice cream, cheese tarts and sweet potatoes.....all are so yummy!!
Very Japanese style shopping street woth a variety of shops found. From time to time there will be decoration or even activities celebrating different festivals or events.

Great place to stay in the shade in summer or out of the snow & rain in winter.

Primarily retail locations & things I personally find to be boring but, plenty of neat food & beverage establishments tucked away to be discovered as well. Definitely worth checking out even if shopping isn't your thing.
Quite a variety of shops, good way to spend you time there and things are cheaper there compared to other places
A good place for shopping especially for foreigners who want to buy functional food.

Place with a lot of positive vibes..  When thinking of converted rates, it would feel the rates are high.    A good place to shop and people know little English, anyway gestures are enough for the communication and the people are so much helping...... Almost all shops has toilet facilities ....

Many shops but pretty similar (souvenirs and drugstores) I highly recommend Kobushiya along lane 4 if you are buying souvenirs. They are so pro in packing. They provide box for check in and proper packaging with handles for easy handling.
Worth buying and great place for cruising. Shopping area that attracts crowd. Central of culture in Sapporo
Nice spot to spend time shopping with a large variety of shops.
A lot of places here, I went to game center, some clothe shops, and drug stores for shopping. There are many restaurants here. Ippudo ramen is the best!! There is toilet in thr restaurant.
Popular shopping street in Sapporo. Filled with drugstores, convenience stores, shops and restaurants. There are a few cosy izakaya shops to enjoy some local food and sake.
Classic japanease covered shipping street with a number of tourist tap shops . Nice walk but I preferred the meals  we had in other places.
Loads of tourists, but the prices here are competitive for souvenirs and stuff from the various pharmacies. They're usually tax-free if you spend more than 5,000 yen on a single receipt.
Excellent place for getting your tourist fix
Super nice shopping street. Full of cosmetic stores and delicious restaurants.
Is really a long stretch of shopping streets selling mainly discounted items such as cosmetics, Japanese snacks...good place for tourists to get their souvenirs. There are hotels and restaurants too.
Nice place to hang out in Sapporo, so many tax free shops here. Suitable for tourist and traveller.
Very nice place to shopping, the people is polite and helpful although language is a problem, they try the best to help you always.

It's definitely a nice place to shop and eat.My minor complaint is that a lot of of the stores are very similar (mainly drug stores).Other than that prices are reasonable and the service is nice.(My favourite lane will definitely be lane 4 since one of the drug store provides boxes and the employees were especially nice)
Of the numerous covered shotengai in Sapporo, this is one of the livelier ones. Lots of stores here but many are pharmacies catering to the Mainland Chinese tourists. Lots of restaurants as well.
Cheap and delicious food everywhere. There's even a souvenir shop that's super cheap! Recommended.
Lots of snacks and restaurants. Not much shopping. Very catered towards tourists mostly. Found this drug store (in the picture) that sold skin care products cheaper than other places! :)
Long covered and very Popular shopping street. Prices are cheaper here. Good for gift buying.

Shopping Arcade with glass ceiling roof top along the street with different sections separated by traffic lights for road traffic. Drug stores, souvenir shops, restaurants, boutiques and many other shops for a good shopping experience. …
Its the best place in sapporo to hunting all you need for life haha
Kit Kat and Calbee snacks specialist store. All the favourites. 👍
I love Japan. Even price is price but the environment and culture made me cool to stay there. Tanukikoji is one of places can buying sourviner and food. There is lot of shop and items can purchase.
Toguchi Ramen at reasonable price, tastier than Ichigen and Ichiran ramen.

Biggest shopping arcades in Hokkaido for sure. Like many shopping areas in mostly big cities in Japan, they offer variety of things, plus restaurants, cafes, hotels, also with bars in their vicinity. It consists of many blocks, and is …

Long but in fact not much shops and restaurants. Most of the shops are very similar such as drugs stores, tax free stores.. 
Very hard to find a restaurant at dinner time mostly are full and need reservation, end up we  bought from family mart and eat inside our hotel room. 
Not our favor place at all.
Great place to find affordable stuff that you cant find in SG. Mega store (Don Quisote), capsule store and pet shop were my favourite attractions.
Good shopping street but I'm only interested with their drugs store which I can purchase cheap beauty items.
Should be able to get whatever you normally have in mind; same as all the big cities on earth. Price is standard. With a little more exploration, can get some other things not normally found at home.
Vibrant places selling affordable goods and daily uses. Several restaurants with good variety. Fast food and local cuisine.
Very looooooong street with too many shopping stores..very nice for walk and shopping and to find a good restaurant.
Pharmacies, food outlets and snack stores line these rows of shops. It is an interesting place, however a lot of repeated shops
Many shops selling souvenirs and food. Some shops also organised some fun lucky draws in conjunction of Christmas celebration.

Nice shopping center with don quijote, various restaurants, and food stands
 Reminds me of Osaka

text.wiki:
Takino Suzuran Hillside National Government Park (国営滝野すずらん丘陵公園, Kokuei Takino Suzuran Kyūryō Kōen) is a Japanese national government park located in Sapporo, Hokkaido.  It is the only national government park in the northern island of Hokkaido.  The park area spreads over 395.7 hectares of hilly country and ranges in altitude between 160 and 320 m above sea level.  Currently, 192.3 is accessible to the public.  The park grounds are separated into six zones: the Mountain Stream Zone, Central Zone, Lodging Zone, Forest Experience Zone (planned to be open in 2009), Nature Observation Zone (planned to be open in 2010), and Preservation Zone (not open to the public).  During the winter season, the park operates as the “Takino Snow World”, providing visitors with a wide variety of winter outdoor activities.


== History ==
In 1975, the Hokkaido Regional Development Bureau set up a committee to select a possible location for a national government park in Hokkaido.  In 1976, the committee chose the current site, and the construction of the park was officially decided in 1977.  In 1983, the park, with approximately 30 hectares of the planned 395.7 hectare area opened to the public, begins its operation as the fifth national government.


== Access ==


=== By train ===
From Sapporo, take the Sapporo Municipal Subway Nanboku Line to Makomanai Station and transfer to the Chuō Bus Takino Line; get off either at Suzuran Kōen Higashi-guchi Stop or Atsubetsu no Taki Stop.


=== By car ===
Drive on the Central Hokkaido Expressway and exist at the Sapporo South Interchange; head for Makomanai/Takino and follow the road signs.


== References ==


== External links ==
http://www.takinopark.com/11_FOREIGN/index_e.html English Official park website
http://www.takinopark.com/ Official park website

text.wiki:
Sapporo Teine (サッポロテイネ) is a recreational center in Teine-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. It comprises many facilities, such as the ski resort (with other facilities, besides ski), the Teineyama Ropeway, and the Sapporo Teine Golf Club fields.
The ski resort has a summit elevation of 1,023 metres (3,356 ft), located on Mt. Teine, in western Sapporo. Currently skiing and snowboarding can be performed here. In 1972, Mt. Teine was the site of the first Winter Olympic Games in Asia and hosted the giant slalom and slalom events in alpine skiing.


== Facilities ==
Sapporo Teine ski resort is separated into the Highland Zone, and the Olympia Zone. Also, connecting the 2 zones is the Rainbow Course, a super long course with a maximum run length of 5.4 km (3.4 mi) from the summit. Other facilities at the ski resort are Highland Ski Center (with lift ticket sales, rental gear, shop, restaurant, coin lockers, nursery, etc.), Olympia House and North Maple (restaurants), Hot Café 1024 (cafeteria), the General Information Booth, and Pandaruman (kid's winter park; snow play, skiing, etc.).
The Highland Zone comprises various kinds of courses for all levels of skiers. Here is also the place to enjoy a great view over the city and the sea of Japan on sunny days.
The Olympia Zone, includes both intermediate and advanced levels courses. At this zone is located the Olympic flame-holder, exactly as it did during the games.
Both zones are open to the public (for skiing and snowboarding practice), between early December and late March, every year.


== 1972 Winter Olympics ==
The 1972 Winter Olympics were held 48 years ago in Sapporo, and Mount Teine hosted the alpine skiing (giant slalom and slalom only), bobsleigh, and luge events (Note: The bobsleigh and luge tracks used for these Winter Olympics were separate tracks.).


=== Alpine skiing ===
The first skiing courses were constructed between 1968 and the end of 1970. The slalom courses had an elevation difference of 300 metres (980 ft) while the elevation differences for the men's and women's giant slalom were 400 and 300 metres (1,310 and 980 ft), respectively. Requiring additional vertical drop, the downhill events were run on Mount Eniwa.
After the Olympics, Teine has held many important ski events such as; Winter Universiade, Asian Winter Games, and other FIS official competition (the International Miyasama Ski Games), as well as being one of the main facilities for regional and national ski competitions.


=== Bobsleigh and luge tracks ===
The tracks were constructed between October 1969 and January 1972. Costing ¥ 433 million to complete, the bobsleigh track was constructed of reinforced concrete, which took 60 ice workers twenty days to create ice that was 13.5 cm (5.3 in) thick. A total of 127 lamps were used to highlight the course for night runs. Costing ¥ 277 million to complete, the luge track was constructed of reinforced concrete and took 1000 man-days to create ice.
No turn names were given for the tracks.
After Nagano was awarded the 1998 Winter Olympics in 1991, the tracks were dismantled.


== Access ==
JR Bus: 20 minutes from Teine Station (JR Hokkaido) to Teine Olympia mae Bus stop.


== External links ==
Official website (in Japanese)


== References ==

text.wiki:
Sapporo (札幌市, Sapporo-shi) is the fifth largest city in Japan, and the largest city on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is the capital city of Hokkaido Prefecture and its Ishikari Subprefecture, and numbers among the nation's ordinance-designated city. Sapporo lies in the southwest of Hokkaido, within the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, which is a tributary stream of the Ishikari. Sapporo is considered the cultural, economical, and political center of Hokkaido.  
As with most of Hokkaido, the Sapporo area was settled by the indigenous Ainu people, beginning over 15,000 years ago. Starting in the late 19th century, Sapporo saw increasing settlement by Japanese migrants. Sapporo hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Olympics ever held in Asia, and the second Olympic games held in Japan after the 1964 Summer Olympics. The Sapporo Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup and two games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
The annual Sapporo Snow Festival draws more than 2 million tourists from abroad. Other notable sites include the Sapporo Beer Museum, which is the only beer museum in Japan, and the Sapporo TV Tower located in Odori Park. It is home to Hokkaido University, just north of Sapporo Station. The city is served by Okadama Airport, and New Chitose Airport in nearby Chitose. 


== Etymology ==
Sapporo's name was taken from Ainuic "sat poro pet" (サッ・ポロ・ペッ), which can be translated as the "dry, great river", a reference to the Toyohira River.


== History ==


=== Early history ===
Before its establishment, the area occupied by Sapporo (known as the Ishikari Plain) was home to a number of indigenous Ainu settlements. In 1866, at the end of the Edo period, construction began on a canal through the area, encouraging a number of early settlers to establish Sapporo village.In 1868, the officially recognized year celebrated as the "birth" of Sapporo, the new Meiji government concluded that the existing administrative center of Hokkaido, which at the time was the port of Hakodate, was in an unsuitable location for defense and further development of the island. As a result, it was determined that a new capital on the Ishikari Plain should be established. The plain itself provided an unusually large expanse of flat, well drained land which is relatively uncommon in the otherwise mountainous geography of Hokkaido.
During 1870–1871, Kuroda Kiyotaka, vice-chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi), approached the American government for assistance in developing the land. As a result, Horace Capron, Secretary of Agriculture under President Ulysses S. Grant, became an oyatoi gaikokujin and was appointed as a special advisor to the commission. Construction began around Odori Park, which still remains as a green ribbon of recreational land bisecting the central area of the city. The city closely followed a grid plan with streets at right-angles to form city blocks.
The continuing expansion of the Japanese into Hokkaido continued, mainly due to migration from the main island of Honshu immediately to the south, and the prosperity of Hokkaido and particularly its capital grew to the point that the Development Commission was deemed unnecessary and was abolished in 1882.
Edwin Dun came to Sapporo to establish sheep and cattle ranches in 1876. He also demonstrated pig raising and the making of butter, cheese, ham and sausage. He was married twice, to Japanese women. He once went back to the US in 1883 but returned to Japan as a secretary of government.
William S. Clark, who was the president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the University of Massachusetts Amherst), came to be the founding vice-president of the Sapporo Agricultural College (now Hokkaido University) for only eight months from 1876 to 1877. He taught academic subjects in science and lectured on the Bible as an "ethics" course, introducing Christian principles to the first entering class of the College.
In 1880, the entire area of Sapporo was renamed as "Sapporo-ku" (Sapporo Ward), and a railroad between Sapporo and Temiya, Otaru was laid. That year the Hōheikan, a hotel and reception facility for visiting officials and dignitaries, was erected adjacent to the Odori Park. It was later moved to Nakajima Park where it remains today. Two years later, with the abolition of the Kaitaku-shi, Hokkaidō was divided into three prefectures: Hakodate, Sapporo, and Nemuro. The name of the urban district in Sapporo remained Sapporo-ku, while the rest of the area in Sapporo-ku was changed to Sapporo-gun. The office building of Sapporo-ku was also located in the urban district.Sapporo, Hakodate, and Nemuro Prefectures were abolished in 1886, and Hokkaidō government office building, an American-neo-baroque-style structure with red bricks, constructed in 1888. The last squad of the Tondenhei, the soldiers pioneering Hokkaido, settled in the place where the area of Tonden in Kita-ku, Sapporo is currently located. Sapporo-ku administered surrounding Sapporo-gun until 1899, when the new district system was announced. After that year, Sapporo-ku was away from the control of Sapporo-gun. The "ku" (district) enforced from 1899 was an autonomy which was a little bigger than towns, and smaller than cities. In Hokkaido at that time, Hakodate-ku and Otaru-ku also existed.
Gallery
		
		


=== 20th century ===
In 1907, the Tohoku Imperial University was established in Sendai Miyagi Prefecture, and Sapporo Agricultural College was controlled by the University. Parts of neighbouring villages including Sapporo Village, Naebo Village, Kami Shiroishi Village, and districts where the Tonden-hei had settled, were integrated into Sapporo-ku in 1910.
The Sapporo Streetcar was opened in 1918, and Hokkaido Imperial University was established in Sapporo-ku, as the fifth Imperial University in Japan. Another railroad operated in Sapporo, the Jōzankei Railroad, which was ultimately abolished in 1969.
In 1922, the new city system was announced by the Tokyo government, and Sapporo-ku was officially changed to Sapporo City. The Sapporo Municipal Bus System was started in 1930. In 1937, Sapporo was chosen as the site of the 1940 Winter Olympics, but due to the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, this was cancelled the next year. Maruyama Town was integrated as a part of Chūō-ku in 1940, and the Okadama Airport was constructed in 1942.
The first Sapporo Snow Festival was held in 1950. In the same year, adjacent Shiroishi Village was integrated into Sapporo City, rendered as a part of Shiroishi-ku, and Atsubetsu-ku. In 1955, Kotoni Town, the entire Sapporo Village, and Shinoro Village were merged into Sapporo, becoming a part of the current Chūō-ku, Kita-ku, Higashi-ku, Nishi-ku, and Teine-ku. The expansion of Sapporo continued, with the merger of Toyohira Town in 1961, and Teine Town in 1967, each becoming a part of Toyohira-ku, Kiyota-ku, and Teine-ku.The ceremony commemorating the 100th anniversary of the foundation of Sapporo and Hokkaido was held in 1968. The Sapporo Municipal Subway system was inaugurated in 1971, which made Sapporo the fourth city in Japan to have a subway system. From February 3 to 13, 1972, the 1972 Winter Olympics were held, the first Winter Olympics held in Asia. On April 1 of the same year, Sapporo was designated as one of the cities designated by government ordinance, and seven wards were established. The last ever public performance by the opera singer, Maria Callas, was in Sapporo at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan on 11 November 1974. The Sapporo Municipal Subway was expanded when the Tōzai line started operation in 1976, and the Tōhō line was opened in 1988. In 1989, Atsubetsu-ku and Teine-ku were separated from Shiroishi-ku and Nishi-ku. Annual events in Sapporo were started, such as the Pacific Music Festival in 1990, and Yosakoi Sōran Festival in 1992. A professional football club, Consadole Sapporo, was established in 1996. In 1997, Kiyota-ku was separated from Toyohira-ku. In the same year, Hokkaidō Takushoku Bank, a Hokkaido-based bank with headquarters in Odori, went bankrupt.
Gallery
		
		
		


=== 21st century ===
In 2001 the construction of the Sapporo Dome was completed, and in 2002 the Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup; Germany vs Saudi Arabia, Argentina vs England and Italy vs Ecuador, all of which were in the first round. Fumio Ueda, was elected as Sapporo mayor for the first time in 2003. Sapporo became the home to a Nippon Professional Baseball team, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters, in 2004, which won the 2006 Japan Series, and the victory parade was held on Ekimae-Dōri (a street in front of Sapporo Station) in February 2007.
The 34th G8 summit took place in Tōyako in 2008, and a number of people including anti-globalisation activists marched in the heart of the city to protest. Police officers were gathered in Sapporo from all over Japan, and the news reported that four people were arrested in the demonstrations.The Hokkaidō Shinkansen line, which currently connects Honshu to Hakodate through the Seikan Tunnel, is planned to link to Sapporo by 2030.
Gallery
		


== Geography ==

Sapporo is a city located in the southwest part of Ishikari Plain and the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, a tributary stream of the Ishikari River. It is part of Ishikari Subprefecture. Roadways in the urban district are laid to make a grid plan. The western and southern parts of Sapporo are occupied by a number of mountains including Mount Teine, Maruyama, and Mount Moiwa, as well as many rivers including the Ishikari River, Toyohira River, and Sōsei River. Sapporo has an elevation of 29 m (95 ft 2 in)Sapporo has many parks, including Odori Park, which is located in the heart of the city and hosts a number of annual events and festivals throughout the year. Moerenuma Park is also one of the largest parks in Sapporo, and was constructed under the plan of Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American artist and landscape architect.
Neighbouring cities are Ishikari, Ebetsu, Kitahiroshima, Eniwa, Chitose, Otaru, Date, and adjoining towns are Tōbetsu, Kimobetsu, Kyōgoku.


=== Wards ===
Sapporo has ten wards (区, ku). The color shows the location of each ku in the map below.


=== Cityscape ===
Gallery
		
		
		


=== Climate ===
Sapporo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa), with a wide range of temperature between the summer and winter. Summers are generally warm, but not overly humid, and winters are cold and very snowy, with an average snowfall of 5.96 m (19 ft 7 in) per year. Sapporo is one of few metropolises in the world with such heavy snowfall, enabling it to hold events and festivals with snow statues. The heavy snowfall is due to the Siberian High developing over the Eurasian land mass and the Aleutian Low developing over the northern Pacific Ocean, resulting in a flow of cold air southeastward across Tsushima Current and to western Hokkaido. The city's annual average precipitation is around 1,100 mm (43.3 in), and the mean annual temperature is 8.5 °C (47.3 °F).


== Economy ==

The tertiary sector dominates Sapporo's industry. Major industries include information technology, retail, and tourism, as Sapporo is a destination for winter sports and events and summer activities due to its comparatively cool climate.The city is also the manufacturing centre of Hokkaido, manufacturing various goods such as food and related products, fabricated metal products, steel, machinery, beverages, and pulp and paper.Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. In April 2004, Air Nippon Network was headquartered in Higashi-ku. Other companies headquartered in Sapporo include Crypton Future Media, DB-Soft, Hokkaido Air System, and Royce'.
Greater Sapporo, Sapporo Metropolitan Employment Area (2.3 million people), had a total GDP of US$84.7 billion in 2010.In 2014 Sapporo's GDP per capita (PPP) was US$32,446.


== Culture and entertainment ==


=== Music ===
1934 – The International Contemporary Music Festival was held by Akira Ifukube, Fumio Hayasaka, Atsushi Miura, and Isamu Ifukube (30 September)
1936 – Russian composer Alexander Tcherepnin visited Sapporo
1960 – The Sapporo Symphony Orchestra founded
1962 – John Cage and David Tudor visited Sapporo
1966 – Berliner Philharmoniker with Herbert von Karajan performed Brahms's Symphony No. 2 at Sapporo Shimin Kaikan (April)
1974 – Maria Callas last public performance at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan (11 November)
1986 – The Sapporo Art Park include the Outdoor Stage and Art Hall (27 July)
1990 – The Pacific Music Festival (PMF) started
1997 – The Sapporo Concert Hall Kitara opened
2018 – The Sapporo Community Plaza is set to open in October


=== Art ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art represents Hokkaido artists like Eien Iwahashi, Kinjiro Kida, Nissho Kanda, Tamako Kataoka, and especially glass objects of Ecole de Paris
The Hongō Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture hosts a collection of over 1,800 works by the artist Hongō Shin.
The Sapporo Art Park contains Art museum featuring outdoor installations & a sculpture garden, and the old house of Takeo Arishima.
The Moerenuma Park including the Glass Pyramid, designed by Isamu Noguchi

The Sunpiazza AquariumSapporo JR Tower adjacent to Sapporo Station.Sapporo Ramen Yokocho and Norubesa (a building with a Ferris wheel) are in Susukino district. The district also has the Tanuki Kōji Shopping Arcade, the oldest shopping mall in the city.
The district of Jōzankei in Minami-ku has many resort hotels with steam baths and onsen.
The Peace Pagoda, one of many such monuments across the world built by the Buddhist order Nipponzan Myohoji to promote and inspire world peace, has a stupa that was built in 1959, halfway up Mount Moiwa, to commemorate peace after World War II. It contains some of the ashes of the Buddha that were presented to the Emperor of Japan by Prime Minister Nehru in 1954. Another portion was presented to Mikhail Gorbachev by the Nipponzan-Myohoji monk, Junsei Terasawa.


=== Parks/gardens ===
The Odori Park
The Nakajima Park
The Maruyama Park is located next to the Hokkaido Shrine and houses the Maruyama Zoo.
The Moerenuma Park
The Nishioka Park is a location of rich nature which centers around a pond and consists of marshland and the forest of the Tsukisamu River and its upper river basin. This park also serves as one of the main habitats in Hokkaido for many types of wild birds.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park offers great views of the city.
The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens and The Chizaki Rose Garden
The Hitsujigaoka Observation Hill has a farm with sheep and attracts visitors with a statue of William S. Clark.


=== Events/festivals ===

February: the Sapporo Snow Festival The main site is at Odori Park, and other sites include Susukino (known as the Susukino Ice Festival) and Sapporo Satoland. Many of the snow and ice statues are built by members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force.May: the Sapporo Lilac Festival. Lilac was brought to Sapporo in 1889 by an American educator, Sarah Clara Smith. At the festival, people enjoy the flowers, wine and live music.
June: the Yosakoi Soran Festival. The sites of the festival are centered on Odori Park and the street leading to Susukino, and there are other festival sites. In the festival, many dance teams dance to music composed based on a Japanese traditional song, "Sōran Bushi". Members of the dancing teams wear special costumes and compete on the roads or stages constructed on the festival sites. In 2006, 350 teams were featured with around 45,000 dancers, and over 1,860,000 people visited the festival.the Sapporo Summer Festival. People enjoy drinking at the beer garden in Odori Park and on the streets of Susukino. This festival consists of a number of fairs such as Tanuki Festival and Susukino Festival.September: the Sapporo Autumn Festival
December: Christmas market in Odori Park, similar to German Christmas markets.
From November through January, many citizens enjoy the Sapporo White Illuminations.


=== Cuisine ===

The city is known home to Sapporo Brewery, and the white chocolate biscuits 'shiroi koibito' (白い恋人), also as the birthplace of miso ramen. The Kouraku Ramen Meitengai in Susukino district, an alley lined with many miso ramen restaurants since 1951. After its demolition due to plans for the Sapporo Olympics, the Ganso Sapporo Ramen Yokocho was established in the same place. It attracts many tourists throughout the year. From the year 1966, a food company named Sanyo Foods began to sell instant ramen under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban".
Haskap, a local variety of edible honeysuckle, similar to blueberries, is a specialty in Sapporo. Other specialty dishes of Sapporo are soup curry, a soupy curry made with vegetables and chicken or other meats, and jingisukan, a barbecued lamb dish, named for Genghis Khan. Sapporo Sweets is a confectionery using many ingredients from Hokkaido and the Sapporo Sweets Competition is held annually. Sapporo is also well known for fresh seafood including salmon, sea urchin and crab. Crab in particular is famed. Many types of crab are harvested and served seasonally in Sapporo like the Horsehair crab, Snow crab, King crab, and Hanasaki crab with numerous dishes revolving around them.


=== Sports ===

The Sapporo Dome was constructed in 2001 and currently is the host to the local soccer team, Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo, the baseball team Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters and the basketball team Levanga Hokkaido.
Sapporo was selected to be the host of the 5th Winter Olympics scheduled on February 3 to 12, 1940, but Japan had to give the Games back to the IOC, after the Second Sino-Japanese War broke out in 1937.
In 1972, Sapporo hosted the 11th Winter Olympics. Some structures built for Olympic events remain in use today, including the ski jumps at Miyanomori and Okurayama. After considering a bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Olympic representatives in Sapporo have said that the city is considering a bid for the 2030 Winter Olympics. The city predicts it may cost as much as 456.5 billion yen ($4.3 billion) to host the games and is planning to have 90 percent of the facilities within half an hour of the Olympic village, according to a report published 12 May 2016. The Alpen course would be in Niseko, the world's second-snowiest resort, while the village would be next to the Sapporo Dome, the report said. The plans were presented to the Japanese Olympic Committee on 8 November 2016. In 2002, Sapporo hosted three group matches of the FIFA World Cup at the Sapporo Dome. In 2006, Sapporo hosted some games of the 2006 Basketball World Championship and also for the 2006 Women's Volleyball World Championship. In 2007, Sapporo hosted the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships at the Sapporo Dome, Miyanomori ski jump, Okurayama ski jump, and the Shirahatayama cross country course. It has been host city of two Asian Winter Games and hosted the 2017 Asian Winter Games with Obihiro. Sapporo will also host some games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
Skiing remains a major sport in Sapporo with almost all children skiing as a part of the school curriculum. Okurayama Elementary School is unusual in having its own ski hill and ski jumping hill on the school grounds. Within the city are commercial ski hills including Moiwayama, Bankeiyama, KobaWorld, Sapporo Teine and Fu's.
Many sports stadiums and domes are located in Sapporo, and some of them have been designated as venues of sports competitions. The Sapporo Community Dome, also known by its nickname "Tsu-Dome", has hosted the Golden Market, a huge flea market event which is usually held twice a year, along with some sports events. The Makomanai Ice Arena, in Makomanai Park, was one of the venues of the Sapporo Olympics in 1972. It was renamed the Makomanai Sekisuiheim Ice Arena in 2007, when Sekisui Chemical Co., Ltd., acquired naming rights and renamed the arena after their real estate brand. Other large sports venues include the Makomanai Open Stadium, Tsukisamu Dome, Maruyama Baseball Stadium, and the Hokkaido Prefectural Sports Center.
Toyota Big Air is a major international snowboarding event held annually in Sapporo Dome. As one of the richest events of its kind in the world, it draws many of the world's best snowboarders.


==== Professional sport teams ====
J.League – Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo (J1 in 1998, 2001–2002, 2008, 2012, 2017–present; J2 in 1999–2000, 2003–2007, 2009–2011, 2013–2016) .
NPB – Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters in Pacific League


== Demographics ==
The city has an estimated population of 1,957,914 as of May 31, 2019 and a population density of 1,746 persons per km² (4,500 persons per mi²). The total area is 1,121.26 km2 (432.92 sq mi).


== Transportation ==

Sapporo has one streetcar line, three JR Hokkaido lines, three subway lines and JR Bus, Chuo Bus and other bus lines. Sapporo Subway trains have rubber-tyred wheels.


=== Rapid transit ===
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Sapporo Streetcar
Mount Moiwa Ropeway
Teineyama Ropeway


=== Rail ===
JR Hokkaido Stations in Sapporo
Hakodate Line: (Zenibako) – Hoshimi – Hoshioki – Inaho – Teine – Inazumi Kōen – Hassamu – Hassamu Chūō – Kotoni – Sōen – Sapporo – Naebo – Shiroishi – Atsubetsu – Shinrinkōen – (Ōasa)
Chitose Line: Heiwa – Shin Sapporo – Kami Nopporo – (Kita-Hiroshima)
Sasshō Line (Gakuentoshi Line): Sōen – Hachiken – Shinkawa – Shinkotoni – Taihei – Yurigahara – Shinoro – Takuhoku – Ainosato Kyōikudai – Ainosato Kōen – (Ishikari Futomi)


=== Air ===
The Sapporo area is served by two airports: Okadama Airport, which offers regional flights within Hokkaido, and New Chitose Airport, a larger international airport located in the city of Chitose 30 miles (48 km) away connected by regular rapid trains taking around 40 minutes. The Sapporo-Tokyo route between New Chitose and Haneda is one of the busiest in the world.


=== Airport shuttle, tour and charter bus service ===
An airport shuttle bus servicing all hotels in Sapporo operates every day of the year. SkyExpress was founded in 2005 and also provides transport to and from various ski resorts throughout Hokkaido, including Niseko.


== Education ==


=== Universities ===

Hokkaido University
Hokkaido University of EducationSee Japanese national university

=== Primary and secondary schools ===

Sapporo Odori High School provides Japanese-language classes to foreign and Japanese returnee students, and the school has special admissions quotas for these groups.The city has two private international schools:

Hokkaido International School
Hokkaido Korean Primary, Middle and High School (North Korean school)


== Twin towns – sister cities ==

Sapporo has twinning relationships with several cities worldwide.
 Portland, Oregon, United States, since 1959
 Munich, Bavaria, Germany, since 1972
 Shenyang, Liaoning, China, since 1980
 Novosibirsk, Russia, since 1990
 Daejeon, South Korea, since 2010
 Chiclayo, Peru

text.wiki:
Maruyama Park (円山公園, Maruyama Kōen) is a park in Chūō-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. The park was modeled after the park with the same name sited in Kyoto.
The park is home of a number of attractions such as, the Hokkaidō Shrine, the Maruyama Zoo, the Maruyama Baseball Stadium and the Maruyama Athletics Stadium.


== History ==
Prior to the construction of Maruyama Park, in 1875, 150 trees were planted on the road to the Hokkaidō Shrine as part of a city planning project. Many years later, after the opening of Sapporo Maruyama Zoo in 1951, the park was taking form, and in 1957 it was officially opened.


== Overview ==
Located in the western suburbs of Sapporo under the Maruyama mountain, in the north part of the Maruyama Forest. The park contains virgin forest with Oak, Katsura (Japanese Judas tree), Magnolia, Maple and other varieties of trees, and is a designated natural monument. On the hillside of the park, there are giant Elm and Cypress trees where different bird species gather. With over 1,500 sakura trees the park is the most popular hanami place in the city of Sapporo.
The Hokkaidō Shrine located at the north end of the park, opened on 1869, is the most important Shinto shrine of the City.
The park contains the Maruyama Baseball Stadium, opened on 1934, it was the main baseball park of the city, before the opening of the Sapporo Dome (2001). In front of baseball stadium is the Maruyama Athletics Stadium, also opened the same year, is utilized for track and field competitions, at local and national level.
Sapporo Maruyama Zoo, opened on 1951, covers an area of 22.5 ha.
The park also contains some sports grounds (tennis courts). Also in the park is the theme park, Maruyama Kids' Land.


== Access ==
Tōzai Line: 3 minutes walking distance from Maruyama-Kōen Station


== External links ==
Sapporo Parks' website (in Japanese)

A big Park that is connected to Hokkaido Shrine and Maruyama Zoo... There's a spot filled with Cherry Blossoms and a nice place for picnics...
From Maruyama Koen subway station by walk is about 10 minutes (cuz we quite not familiar the place). Can take beautiful pictures and enjoy mini snow sliding. Have a walk to the Shrine.

We saw cherry blossoms blooming all around here on May 6, during the golden week. It was a beautiful sight! Very nice park, scenic and tranquil. A lot of people were doing picnics. There were stalls selling street foods near the Hokkaido shrine area. The weather was very

This small and cute sakura park is in the area of Hokkaido shrine. Very nice path with several kind of Sakura flowers. This park marks the end of the Sakura season of all Japan. Sayonara Sakura ceremony held here with respect. Due to the last season this park can be tricky with
Was there on 4th May when it was supposed to be the cherry blossom peak season in Hokkaido... but really cannot compare with Kyoto or Tokyo. Simple because the sakura tree type is different.

On a holiday this place is thronged by locals with their families in toe with kids enjoying the place . The places oozes of local culture many people having a picnic at the spot even as few are iup on the way by steps to the mountain top.

We went to the park around 9.30am and had hoped to enjoy a quiet walk and a hike to the summit. But, no such luck. It was Golden Week, and the place was insanely crowded by 10am. The hike to the summit took about 1-2 hours (with limited places to rest in between), and there are
Lose most of the tourists by hiking up to the top. It only takes about half an hour, but the views are great, and you don't have to share with a million other tourists!

Stroll along this Maruyama Koen during winter was truly an unforgettable experience. The snow was very thick that we hardly walk through it. And yet my children were so happy to play on the snow, sit and sleep on the fluffy snow. Making pictures was so fun as well as playing

One of the places that you may experience Hanami during spring.. there will be stalls selling local street foods such as okonomiyaki, yakisoba, grilled calamari, takoyaki, dorayaki.... and draft beers! It was a unique experience for my group of friends and i to savour the street

We went to the park on our way to the shrine on a Sunday. Lovely place that isn't too crowded and you get lovely view of the snowy landscape. There were people jogging, taking their dogs for a walk and children playing in the snow. It's about a 10 minute walk from the Maruyama
I like the greenery and forest-like park. Very refreshing but I was chased by lots of mosquitos. Mood spoiled.

my most memorable time in sapporo was in the maruyama park . Being spring time it was surreal to walk in the woods with cherry blossoms blooming all around. The path to the park and the exit has some beautiful houses and some of them had great views of the park. It was start of

Sadly, it was raining when we went on June afternoon. Our main aim was to visit the Hokkaido Shrine located within the park and since it was raining, we did not exactly stop and enjoy its scenery. It is a popular park among locals too as we saw numerous Japanese kids playing

My 1st Self-drive (F&E) tour. My 1st visit to Japan. We went to Maruyama Park for a morning walk. You can choose to cut through this park where you are visiting Maruyama Zoo and Hokkaido Shine. This is a nice park during this season. We saw lots of little children dancing in

We walk through this park on route to Hokkaido Shrine. It is well established park with lots of interesting objects scattered around. Maruyama Zoo also lacated in one end of this park. I really enjoy the walk.

We went twice to the park in our 3 day visit. It was peaceful and so green. We went almost during the end of Sakura season and hence there were only some trees that we could spot. But there were beautiful tulips of many colors. On Sunday afternoons, you could see locals playing

Expect to walk in this place with nice ozone, quiet and peaceful. Unfortunately, there was many people come to picnic.. They grilled meats, drinks, loud chat and it was smell smoky around. During way to shrine, there also have many street foods both side of walkway. It look so
The park is so welcoming and relaxing.There is a shrine inside and also sakura trees.You can find stall selling local street food here too.Just be careful of the crows.They do snatch food.

It is an old-growth forest, not terribly big makes it easy for a hiking day trip. Fresh air,various vegetation and wonderful view on top of Maruyama Park. The difficulty of hiking in this path is somewhere between easy and moderate. At one of its entrance lies the Sapporo zoo.
Be at one with nature at this well maintained park where rindless and cute wild animals are free to roam. Definitely will visit this park again.
This is a big park and beautiful in winter. I am sure it is equally beautiful in summer. While I did not visit the Zoo, I visited the Hokkaido Shrine which visitors should not miss.

This is a fantastic little park with a stream running through a typical japanese forest. You wouldnt make a special trip to visit the park but you would enjoy it as a side trip from the zoo (which is next door).

Lovely in spring where you can see cherry blossom in bloom all over the place! I recommned going there in early May! There are a few statues around and a food carnival going towards the temple. Lovely place.

We wanted to visit the Hokkaido shrine, and ended up taking a stroll through the snow covered paths in the park. It was serene, peaceful, except for the hungry crows. Please do not eat while walking because the crows will snatch your food away. Apart from that, we love this park!

This might not be a specific attraction you would add into the itinerary but is surely an en route passage to the Hokkaido Shrine that should not be missed. I was there just last week and there was snow everywhere. My daughter and I were enchanted by its tranqulity and
You can enjoy summer and winter at this zoo. There are a lot of animals in this zoo a lion, a tiger, a giraffe, a flamingo and a lesser panda.

Maruyama Park is particularly popular in November for some beautiful autumn leaves sights. It is located within five minutes by subway from downtown Sapporo. Despite its convenient location, the park is very serene and peaceful. 円山公園內的風光: 這邊的秋天紅黃綠漸層交錯的景色超美的。
Very nice place, so close to the nature, nice to just walk there with friend or along. Best park in Sapporo
Take subway Tozai Line exit Maruyama Koen ¥200 10 minutes walking. There are a lot of beautiful Tulip. Cherry blossom not much. Free admission.

Visited here in the winter, and it was simply beautiful after dark. There is a somewhat ethereal quality in it, viewing the darkened shrines in either the lamplights or moonlight. We loved our walk through the park, as well as our romping in the snow. Utterly delightful. There
It's very close to center of Sapporo, however, there are lots of trees and flowers in the park and you can relax. Also park has a little lovely tea house, Rokkatei. You can have some tea and sweets.

I loved walking through this park! It was easy to get to from subway station T-06 and there were lots of locals using it. I loved that there was an intense game of baseball going on at 11 am on a weekday, so that made that area of the park a bit more lively.
A beautiful park next to the Hokkaido Shrine. When visit the Shrine, remember to try the free red bean pastry. Free and great taste

Maruyama is a small heap of 225 meters above sea level. It is wrapped up to cityscape of Sapporo. You walk to the mountain top of Maruyama for around 30 minutes. You can climb with a feeling of taking a walk. You can come across 88 Kannon and wild small animals in the middle
google: Just took a walk in the park. The zoo was closed. As the government told us to avoid crowded place. It was late Feb 2020. Situation in Japan started to get worse.  Hope all of you stay health. I will visit again. Nice place, nice people.

Beautiful place, close to the city and full of real nature. It is close to the Hokkaido Shrine, but it is surrounded by forests and beautiful trails to walk around and enjoy. It is one of the best places to appreciate the four seasons and their effects. Check it out on autumn and spring, you won’t be disappointed.

A nice walk between the shrines to the temple. Relaxing walk through the primeval forest to the Zoo. A small but enjoyable walk round the zoo. There is a view of sapporo from the polar bear enclosure. Glad we went. A walk from Sapporo city but got to see more than if we used a taxi

text.wiki:
Sapporo Station (札幌駅, Sapporo-eki) is a railway station in Chūō-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. It is served by Hakodate Main Line and other lines of Hokkaido Railway Company (JR Hokkaido), and is also connected to the Subway Sapporo Station.
Sapporo Station is the starting point and terminus for most limited express services operated by JR Hokkaido. It also has the tallest building (JR Tower) in Hokkaido. Sapporo station is developing into a commercial center as large as Ōdōri Park and Susukino.


== Lines and trains ==
The following JR Hokkaido lines and trains pass through or terminate at Sapporo Station:

■■ Hakodate Main Line
Okhotsk limited express (Sapporo – Abashiri)
Sōya limited express (Sapporo – Wakkanai)
Kamui limited express (Sapporo – Asahikawa)
Lilac limited express (Sapporo – Asahikawa)
Ishikari Liner semi-rapid (Otaru – Sapporo – Takikawa)
Niseko Liner rapid (Rankoshi, Kutchan – Sapporo)
■ Chitose Line
Hokuto limited express (Hakodate – Sapporo)
Ōzora limited express (Sapporo – Kushiro)
Super Tokachi limited express (Sapporo – Obihiro)
Suzuran limited express (Muroran – Sapporo)
Airport rapid (New Chitose Airport – Sapporo – Otaru)
■ Sasshō Line (Gakuen Toshi Line)


== Layout ==
Sapporo Station consists of five platforms that are raised above street level. These raised platforms serve 10 tracks which run in an east-west direction. Two concourses run north-south below the platforms. It has a commercial facility called Paseo under the ground and JR Tower on the south side of the station. The station is also planned to become a terminal station of the Hokkaido Shinkansen that is scheduled to open in 2031.


=== Platforms ===


== Adjacent stations ==


== History ==

Sapporo Station opened on 28 November 1880 as a terminus of the Horonai Railway. A new station building was built in 1881 and it was enlarged as Sapporo developed. In 1908, the station building was rebuilt because of a fire in 1907. The restored building can be found in the Historical Village of Hokkaido in Nopporo Forest Park.The third reconstruction was finished in 1951 and the Sapporo Subway was opened in 1971. An underground shopping center was started in 1972 and a commercial building was opened on the east side of the station in 1978.With the privatization of JNR on 1 April 1987, the station came under the control of JR Hokkaido.The current building was built in 2003.Overnight sleeping car trains Cassiopeia, Hokutosei, and Hamanasu served the station prior to their discontinuation.

text.quote: Opened in 2003, the 173-m high skyscraper houses a shopping mall, office complex & observation deck.
trip: This is another part of the underground walkway, where there are lots of shops and restaurants. It is also conveniently connected to the JR Sapporo and underground trains.

One of the many shopping areas and department stores, Paseo is connected to JR Sapporo station as well as being conveniently accessible thru the underground passageway. Plenty of shopping and restaurants available. Remember where you came in because you are sure to get lost.
It's two sides of a shopping area at JR Sapporo train station. It's got lots of shops and eateries..and prices are more reasonable than day daimaru

This one is underground and near the train station. Lots of nice shops but the mall is used for walking between two other malls and very busy. I didn’t like this, my girlfriend had only eye for the shops, it didn’t bother her ;)
For people who are on the go who are on the way to Subways. Grab a bite or shop whilst you are there for meetings. Plenty of resting places for food

There is an amazing network of underground shopping mall with a wide array of eateries and shops. Things sold there are of good quality. You can get yourself lost down there, but that is part of the fun!
Conveniently located near JR Sapporo Station and went there almost everyday when I came back to Sapporo from my one day trip.

Sapporo is very unique in that one can walk underground from this location all the way down to suskino , clock tower, Sapporo park, etc. and beyond. JR tower is a bit more high end but lots of stores, restaurants, etc. we wen in summer just beginning part so was not hot and we

Underground shopping located at JR Sapporo Station. It is connected to other big-scale shopping malls such as Esta and Daimaru. Numerous shops selling affordable clothing when we were there in summer and we really enjoyed shopping here.

The Paseo centre was one of my favorite shopping areas connected to the underground network near the JR Sapporo station. There are 2 levels of restaurants to the West and they have some cool and fun shops to the East, including a few stores dedicated to popular japanese cartoon

One of the few shopping center or department stores linked to JR Sapporo Station. Worth a visit for some shopping or meal if you have the time to spare.

We spent our short stay visiting this complex for three consecutive days to shop mostly for food although we did a little shopping too. This underground mall is a haven for ardent shoppers. It is easily accessible to other malls and hotels nearby through the passageway.

Here, everything is just fit them together and anything you want could find anywhere from here. As well, more well organised thing is the biggest railway station is inside.

This is part of the whole JR Tower complex comprising of four "shopping centers" - Apia, Esta, Stellar Place, and Paseo. What I wanted to share was the 1000 yen in welcome coupons available upon presentation of your passport at the information desk! The coupons are in 100 yen

Big mall for being underground. Lots of different "walks" to check out and plenty of places to eat. Great signage to help you get from the street level, to the shopping to the train station part of this underground maze.
google: Nice place if you want a special wiew on the city

A cool and trendy place for shopping and visiting for foreign travellers ~ The tower is gigantic - so large in space and many of floors, which then divided into different zones named Stellar Place, Paseo, Apia, Esta. All filled with fashion …

Glad to witness the last sunset of 2019 fromJR Tower Observatory T38. The view are so superb even from their washroom. Btw, Happy New Year 2020 to all! 😇🙏🏻🎉🎉🎉
Nice view of downtown Sapporo. We bought shoe cleats in the visitor center on the first floor. Those really came in handy.

A great place  for a panoramic view of Sapporo City .
The observation deck offers a great view of the city as far as the eye can see.
 Up there ,you can find very clean toilet facilities,snack bar and souvenir shop and of course some …

I suggest to coney here if you want to looks for a good shopping mall with a big supermarket and not just a convenience store
Great lookout on top floor.  Lots of nice shops.
It's very good place for change your busy mind   😊
this place also provide prayer room for muslim..near to bic camera mall
For a cheap best view of downtown Sapporo. Such an amazing city.
The best shopping plaza in Sapporo city, you will enjoy shopping here as well as dining and movie going
Great location. Next to JR Sapporo station (train) and Bic Camera the famous electronics stores. Great room view as well.

Go to level 6 by a side elevator.

Ōdōri Station (大通駅, Ōdōri Eki) is a subway station in Chūō-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan, operated by Sapporo Municipal Subway. The station opened on December 16, 1971 as part of the first phase of the Namboku Line.


== Lines ==

text.quote: This fish market is known for its huge range of freshly caught raw produce & its dining stalls.

Loads of fresh seafood that you can eat on the spot. We had oysters the size of our face and clams that were palm size. Super great food

The sushi is fresh at Nijo market, however the price is expensive by local standard properly because it is a tourist attraction spot. You can get better priced sushi in other restaurants in Sapporo. Chitose Airport (domestic terminal after immigration) standing sushi bar is
This fish market was quite disappointing, as it is very small when compared to other fish markets in Japan like in Tokyo and Kyoto. Not really worth a visit, unless you just want to buy some seafood.
