text.wiki:
Sapporo (札幌市, Sapporo-shi) is the fifth largest city in Japan, and the largest city on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It is the capital city of Hokkaido Prefecture and its Ishikari Subprefecture, and numbers among the nation's ordinance-designated city. Sapporo lies in the southwest of Hokkaido, within the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, which is a tributary stream of the Ishikari. Sapporo is considered the cultural, economical, and political center of Hokkaido.  
As with most of Hokkaido, the Sapporo area was settled by the indigenous Ainu people, beginning over 15,000 years ago. Starting in the late 19th century, Sapporo saw increasing settlement by Japanese migrants. Sapporo hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics, the first Winter Olympics ever held in Asia, and the second Olympic games held in Japan after the 1964 Summer Olympics. The Sapporo Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup and two games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
The annual Sapporo Snow Festival draws more than 2 million tourists from abroad. Other notable sites include the Sapporo Beer Museum, which is the only beer museum in Japan, and the Sapporo TV Tower located in Odori Park. It is home to Hokkaido University, just north of Sapporo Station. The city is served by Okadama Airport, and New Chitose Airport in nearby Chitose. 


== Etymology ==
Sapporo's name was taken from Ainuic "sat poro pet" (サッ・ポロ・ペッ), which can be translated as the "dry, great river", a reference to the Toyohira River.


== History ==


=== Early history ===
Before its establishment, the area occupied by Sapporo (known as the Ishikari Plain) was home to a number of indigenous Ainu settlements. In 1866, at the end of the Edo period, construction began on a canal through the area, encouraging a number of early settlers to establish Sapporo village.In 1868, the officially recognized year celebrated as the "birth" of Sapporo, the new Meiji government concluded that the existing administrative center of Hokkaido, which at the time was the port of Hakodate, was in an unsuitable location for defense and further development of the island. As a result, it was determined that a new capital on the Ishikari Plain should be established. The plain itself provided an unusually large expanse of flat, well drained land which is relatively uncommon in the otherwise mountainous geography of Hokkaido.
During 1870–1871, Kuroda Kiyotaka, vice-chairman of the Hokkaido Development Commission (Kaitaku-shi), approached the American government for assistance in developing the land. As a result, Horace Capron, Secretary of Agriculture under President Ulysses S. Grant, became an oyatoi gaikokujin and was appointed as a special advisor to the commission. Construction began around Odori Park, which still remains as a green ribbon of recreational land bisecting the central area of the city. The city closely followed a grid plan with streets at right-angles to form city blocks.
The continuing expansion of the Japanese into Hokkaido continued, mainly due to migration from the main island of Honshu immediately to the south, and the prosperity of Hokkaido and particularly its capital grew to the point that the Development Commission was deemed unnecessary and was abolished in 1882.
Edwin Dun came to Sapporo to establish sheep and cattle ranches in 1876. He also demonstrated pig raising and the making of butter, cheese, ham and sausage. He was married twice, to Japanese women. He once went back to the US in 1883 but returned to Japan as a secretary of government.
William S. Clark, who was the president of the Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the University of Massachusetts Amherst), came to be the founding vice-president of the Sapporo Agricultural College (now Hokkaido University) for only eight months from 1876 to 1877. He taught academic subjects in science and lectured on the Bible as an "ethics" course, introducing Christian principles to the first entering class of the College.
In 1880, the entire area of Sapporo was renamed as "Sapporo-ku" (Sapporo Ward), and a railroad between Sapporo and Temiya, Otaru was laid. That year the Hōheikan, a hotel and reception facility for visiting officials and dignitaries, was erected adjacent to the Odori Park. It was later moved to Nakajima Park where it remains today. Two years later, with the abolition of the Kaitaku-shi, Hokkaidō was divided into three prefectures: Hakodate, Sapporo, and Nemuro. The name of the urban district in Sapporo remained Sapporo-ku, while the rest of the area in Sapporo-ku was changed to Sapporo-gun. The office building of Sapporo-ku was also located in the urban district.Sapporo, Hakodate, and Nemuro Prefectures were abolished in 1886, and Hokkaidō government office building, an American-neo-baroque-style structure with red bricks, constructed in 1888. The last squad of the Tondenhei, the soldiers pioneering Hokkaido, settled in the place where the area of Tonden in Kita-ku, Sapporo is currently located. Sapporo-ku administered surrounding Sapporo-gun until 1899, when the new district system was announced. After that year, Sapporo-ku was away from the control of Sapporo-gun. The "ku" (district) enforced from 1899 was an autonomy which was a little bigger than towns, and smaller than cities. In Hokkaido at that time, Hakodate-ku and Otaru-ku also existed.
Gallery
		
		


=== 20th century ===
In 1907, the Tohoku Imperial University was established in Sendai Miyagi Prefecture, and Sapporo Agricultural College was controlled by the University. Parts of neighbouring villages including Sapporo Village, Naebo Village, Kami Shiroishi Village, and districts where the Tonden-hei had settled, were integrated into Sapporo-ku in 1910.
The Sapporo Streetcar was opened in 1918, and Hokkaido Imperial University was established in Sapporo-ku, as the fifth Imperial University in Japan. Another railroad operated in Sapporo, the Jōzankei Railroad, which was ultimately abolished in 1969.
In 1922, the new city system was announced by the Tokyo government, and Sapporo-ku was officially changed to Sapporo City. The Sapporo Municipal Bus System was started in 1930. In 1937, Sapporo was chosen as the site of the 1940 Winter Olympics, but due to the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, this was cancelled the next year. Maruyama Town was integrated as a part of Chūō-ku in 1940, and the Okadama Airport was constructed in 1942.
The first Sapporo Snow Festival was held in 1950. In the same year, adjacent Shiroishi Village was integrated into Sapporo City, rendered as a part of Shiroishi-ku, and Atsubetsu-ku. In 1955, Kotoni Town, the entire Sapporo Village, and Shinoro Village were merged into Sapporo, becoming a part of the current Chūō-ku, Kita-ku, Higashi-ku, Nishi-ku, and Teine-ku. The expansion of Sapporo continued, with the merger of Toyohira Town in 1961, and Teine Town in 1967, each becoming a part of Toyohira-ku, Kiyota-ku, and Teine-ku.The ceremony commemorating the 100th anniversary of the foundation of Sapporo and Hokkaido was held in 1968. The Sapporo Municipal Subway system was inaugurated in 1971, which made Sapporo the fourth city in Japan to have a subway system. From February 3 to 13, 1972, the 1972 Winter Olympics were held, the first Winter Olympics held in Asia. On April 1 of the same year, Sapporo was designated as one of the cities designated by government ordinance, and seven wards were established. The last ever public performance by the opera singer, Maria Callas, was in Sapporo at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan on 11 November 1974. The Sapporo Municipal Subway was expanded when the Tōzai line started operation in 1976, and the Tōhō line was opened in 1988. In 1989, Atsubetsu-ku and Teine-ku were separated from Shiroishi-ku and Nishi-ku. Annual events in Sapporo were started, such as the Pacific Music Festival in 1990, and Yosakoi Sōran Festival in 1992. A professional football club, Consadole Sapporo, was established in 1996. In 1997, Kiyota-ku was separated from Toyohira-ku. In the same year, Hokkaidō Takushoku Bank, a Hokkaido-based bank with headquarters in Odori, went bankrupt.
Gallery
		
		
		


=== 21st century ===
In 2001 the construction of the Sapporo Dome was completed, and in 2002 the Dome hosted three games during the 2002 FIFA World Cup; Germany vs Saudi Arabia, Argentina vs England and Italy vs Ecuador, all of which were in the first round. Fumio Ueda, was elected as Sapporo mayor for the first time in 2003. Sapporo became the home to a Nippon Professional Baseball team, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters, in 2004, which won the 2006 Japan Series, and the victory parade was held on Ekimae-Dōri (a street in front of Sapporo Station) in February 2007.
The 34th G8 summit took place in Tōyako in 2008, and a number of people including anti-globalisation activists marched in the heart of the city to protest. Police officers were gathered in Sapporo from all over Japan, and the news reported that four people were arrested in the demonstrations.The Hokkaidō Shinkansen line, which currently connects Honshu to Hakodate through the Seikan Tunnel, is planned to link to Sapporo by 2030.
Gallery
		


== Geography ==

Sapporo is a city located in the southwest part of Ishikari Plain and the alluvial fan of the Toyohira River, a tributary stream of the Ishikari River. It is part of Ishikari Subprefecture. Roadways in the urban district are laid to make a grid plan. The western and southern parts of Sapporo are occupied by a number of mountains including Mount Teine, Maruyama, and Mount Moiwa, as well as many rivers including the Ishikari River, Toyohira River, and Sōsei River. Sapporo has an elevation of 29 m (95 ft 2 in)Sapporo has many parks, including Odori Park, which is located in the heart of the city and hosts a number of annual events and festivals throughout the year. Moerenuma Park is also one of the largest parks in Sapporo, and was constructed under the plan of Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American artist and landscape architect.
Neighbouring cities are Ishikari, Ebetsu, Kitahiroshima, Eniwa, Chitose, Otaru, Date, and adjoining towns are Tōbetsu, Kimobetsu, Kyōgoku.


=== Wards ===
Sapporo has ten wards (区, ku). The color shows the location of each ku in the map below.


=== Cityscape ===
Gallery
		
		
		


=== Climate ===
Sapporo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa), with a wide range of temperature between the summer and winter. Summers are generally warm, but not overly humid, and winters are cold and very snowy, with an average snowfall of 5.96 m (19 ft 7 in) per year. Sapporo is one of few metropolises in the world with such heavy snowfall, enabling it to hold events and festivals with snow statues. The heavy snowfall is due to the Siberian High developing over the Eurasian land mass and the Aleutian Low developing over the northern Pacific Ocean, resulting in a flow of cold air southeastward across Tsushima Current and to western Hokkaido. The city's annual average precipitation is around 1,100 mm (43.3 in), and the mean annual temperature is 8.5 °C (47.3 °F).


== Economy ==

The tertiary sector dominates Sapporo's industry. Major industries include information technology, retail, and tourism, as Sapporo is a destination for winter sports and events and summer activities due to its comparatively cool climate.The city is also the manufacturing centre of Hokkaido, manufacturing various goods such as food and related products, fabricated metal products, steel, machinery, beverages, and pulp and paper.Hokkaido International Airlines (Air Do) is headquartered in Chūō-ku. In April 2004, Air Nippon Network was headquartered in Higashi-ku. Other companies headquartered in Sapporo include Crypton Future Media, DB-Soft, Hokkaido Air System, and Royce'.
Greater Sapporo, Sapporo Metropolitan Employment Area (2.3 million people), had a total GDP of US$84.7 billion in 2010.In 2014 Sapporo's GDP per capita (PPP) was US$32,446.


== Culture and entertainment ==


=== Music ===
1934 – The International Contemporary Music Festival was held by Akira Ifukube, Fumio Hayasaka, Atsushi Miura, and Isamu Ifukube (30 September)
1936 – Russian composer Alexander Tcherepnin visited Sapporo
1960 – The Sapporo Symphony Orchestra founded
1962 – John Cage and David Tudor visited Sapporo
1966 – Berliner Philharmoniker with Herbert von Karajan performed Brahms's Symphony No. 2 at Sapporo Shimin Kaikan (April)
1974 – Maria Callas last public performance at the Hokkaido Koseinenkin Kaikan (11 November)
1986 – The Sapporo Art Park include the Outdoor Stage and Art Hall (27 July)
1990 – The Pacific Music Festival (PMF) started
1997 – The Sapporo Concert Hall Kitara opened
2018 – The Sapporo Community Plaza is set to open in October


=== Art ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Modern Art represents Hokkaido artists like Eien Iwahashi, Kinjiro Kida, Nissho Kanda, Tamako Kataoka, and especially glass objects of Ecole de Paris
The Hongō Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture hosts a collection of over 1,800 works by the artist Hongō Shin.
The Sapporo Art Park contains Art museum featuring outdoor installations & a sculpture garden, and the old house of Takeo Arishima.
The Moerenuma Park including the Glass Pyramid, designed by Isamu Noguchi
The Migishi Kotaro Museum of Art
The Hongo Shin Memorial Museum of Sculpture
The Miyanomori Art Museum
The Sapporo Odori 500-m Underground Walkway Gallery
Member of UNESCO Creative Cities Network as a Creative City of Media Arts since 2013
Sapporo International Art Festival (2014/2017)


=== Literature ===
The Hokkaido Museum of Literature
Takeo Arishima Residence in Sapporo Art Park
Junichi Watanabe Museum of Literature


=== Film ===
The Idiot (1951 film) by Akira Kurosawa
The Northern Museum of Visual Culture
Theater Kino
The Sapporo International Short Film Festival and Market


=== Points of interest ===

Registered Tangible Cultural Properties in Sapporo

The former Hokkaidō government office building
The Sapporo Clock Tower
The Hokkaidō Shrine
Hokkaido Museum
Historical Village of Hokkaido
Sapporo Buried Cultural Property Center
The Sapporo City Archive Museum　(Former Sapporo Court of Appeal)
The Edwin Dun Memorial Hall
The Hokkaido University & Hokkaido University Museum
The Sapporo Beer Museum & Sapporo Factory
The Sapporo TV Tower
The Sapporo Convention Center
The Sapporo Salmon Museum in Makomanai Park
The Sunpiazza AquariumSapporo JR Tower adjacent to Sapporo Station.Sapporo Ramen Yokocho and Norubesa (a building with a Ferris wheel) are in Susukino district. The district also has the Tanuki Kōji Shopping Arcade, the oldest shopping mall in the city.
The district of Jōzankei in Minami-ku has many resort hotels with steam baths and onsen.
The Peace Pagoda, one of many such monuments across the world built by the Buddhist order Nipponzan Myohoji to promote and inspire world peace, has a stupa that was built in 1959, halfway up Mount Moiwa, to commemorate peace after World War II. It contains some of the ashes of the Buddha that were presented to the Emperor of Japan by Prime Minister Nehru in 1954. Another portion was presented to Mikhail Gorbachev by the Nipponzan-Myohoji monk, Junsei Terasawa.


=== Parks/gardens ===
The Odori Park
The Nakajima Park
The Maruyama Park is located next to the Hokkaido Shrine and houses the Maruyama Zoo.
The Moerenuma Park
The Nishioka Park is a location of rich nature which centers around a pond and consists of marshland and the forest of the Tsukisamu River and its upper river basin. This park also serves as one of the main habitats in Hokkaido for many types of wild birds.
The Asahiyama Memorial Park offers great views of the city.
The Hokkaido University Botanical Gardens and The Chizaki Rose Garden
The Hitsujigaoka Observation Hill has a farm with sheep and attracts visitors with a statue of William S. Clark.


=== Events/festivals ===

February: the Sapporo Snow Festival The main site is at Odori Park, and other sites include Susukino (known as the Susukino Ice Festival) and Sapporo Satoland. Many of the snow and ice statues are built by members of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force.May: the Sapporo Lilac Festival. Lilac was brought to Sapporo in 1889 by an American educator, Sarah Clara Smith. At the festival, people enjoy the flowers, wine and live music.
June: the Yosakoi Soran Festival. The sites of the festival are centered on Odori Park and the street leading to Susukino, and there are other festival sites. In the festival, many dance teams dance to music composed based on a Japanese traditional song, "Sōran Bushi". Members of the dancing teams wear special costumes and compete on the roads or stages constructed on the festival sites. In 2006, 350 teams were featured with around 45,000 dancers, and over 1,860,000 people visited the festival.the Sapporo Summer Festival. People enjoy drinking at the beer garden in Odori Park and on the streets of Susukino. This festival consists of a number of fairs such as Tanuki Festival and Susukino Festival.September: the Sapporo Autumn Festival
December: Christmas market in Odori Park, similar to German Christmas markets.
From November through January, many citizens enjoy the Sapporo White Illuminations.


=== Cuisine ===

The city is known home to Sapporo Brewery, and the white chocolate biscuits 'shiroi koibito' (白い恋人), also as the birthplace of miso ramen. The Kouraku Ramen Meitengai in Susukino district, an alley lined with many miso ramen restaurants since 1951. After its demolition due to plans for the Sapporo Olympics, the Ganso Sapporo Ramen Yokocho was established in the same place. It attracts many tourists throughout the year. From the year 1966, a food company named Sanyo Foods began to sell instant ramen under the brand name "Sapporo Ichiban".
Haskap, a local variety of edible honeysuckle, similar to blueberries, is a specialty in Sapporo. Other specialty dishes of Sapporo are soup curry, a soupy curry made with vegetables and chicken or other meats, and jingisukan, a barbecued lamb dish, named for Genghis Khan. Sapporo Sweets is a confectionery using many ingredients from Hokkaido and the Sapporo Sweets Competition is held annually. Sapporo is also well known for fresh seafood including salmon, sea urchin and crab. Crab in particular is famed. Many types of crab are harvested and served seasonally in Sapporo like the Horsehair crab, Snow crab, King crab, and Hanasaki crab with numerous dishes revolving around them.


=== Sports ===

The Sapporo Dome was constructed in 2001 and currently is the host to the local soccer team, Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo, the baseball team Hokkaido Nippon-Ham Fighters and the basketball team Levanga Hokkaido.
Sapporo was selected to be the host of the 5th Winter Olympics scheduled on February 3 to 12, 1940, but Japan had to give the Games back to the IOC, after the Second Sino-Japanese War broke out in 1937.
In 1972, Sapporo hosted the 11th Winter Olympics. Some structures built for Olympic events remain in use today, including the ski jumps at Miyanomori and Okurayama. After considering a bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics, Olympic representatives in Sapporo have said that the city is considering a bid for the 2030 Winter Olympics. The city predicts it may cost as much as 456.5 billion yen ($4.3 billion) to host the games and is planning to have 90 percent of the facilities within half an hour of the Olympic village, according to a report published 12 May 2016. The Alpen course would be in Niseko, the world's second-snowiest resort, while the village would be next to the Sapporo Dome, the report said. The plans were presented to the Japanese Olympic Committee on 8 November 2016. In 2002, Sapporo hosted three group matches of the FIFA World Cup at the Sapporo Dome. In 2006, Sapporo hosted some games of the 2006 Basketball World Championship and also for the 2006 Women's Volleyball World Championship. In 2007, Sapporo hosted the FIS Nordic World Ski Championships at the Sapporo Dome, Miyanomori ski jump, Okurayama ski jump, and the Shirahatayama cross country course. It has been host city of two Asian Winter Games and hosted the 2017 Asian Winter Games with Obihiro. Sapporo will also host some games during the 2019 Rugby World Cup.
Skiing remains a major sport in Sapporo with almost all children skiing as a part of the school curriculum. Okurayama Elementary School is unusual in having its own ski hill and ski jumping hill on the school grounds. Within the city are commercial ski hills including Moiwayama, Bankeiyama, KobaWorld, Sapporo Teine and Fu's.
Many sports stadiums and domes are located in Sapporo, and some of them have been designated as venues of sports competitions. The Sapporo Community Dome, also known by its nickname "Tsu-Dome", has hosted the Golden Market, a huge flea market event which is usually held twice a year, along with some sports events. The Makomanai Ice Arena, in Makomanai Park, was one of the venues of the Sapporo Olympics in 1972. It was renamed the Makomanai Sekisuiheim Ice Arena in 2007, when Sekisui Chemical Co., Ltd., acquired naming rights and renamed the arena after their real estate brand. Other large sports venues include the Makomanai Open Stadium, Tsukisamu Dome, Maruyama Baseball Stadium, and the Hokkaido Prefectural Sports Center.
Toyota Big Air is a major international snowboarding event held annually in Sapporo Dome. As one of the richest events of its kind in the world, it draws many of the world's best snowboarders.


==== Professional sport teams ====
J.League – Hokkaido Consadole Sapporo (J1 in 1998, 2001–2002, 2008, 2012, 2017–present; J2 in 1999–2000, 2003–2007, 2009–2011, 2013–2016) .
NPB – Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters in Pacific League


== Demographics ==
The city has an estimated population of 1,957,914 as of May 31, 2019 and a population density of 1,746 persons per km² (4,500 persons per mi²). The total area is 1,121.26 km2 (432.92 sq mi).


== Transportation ==

Sapporo has one streetcar line, three JR Hokkaido lines, three subway lines and JR Bus, Chuo Bus and other bus lines. Sapporo Subway trains have rubber-tyred wheels.


=== Rapid transit ===
Sapporo Municipal Subway
Sapporo Streetcar
Mount Moiwa Ropeway
Teineyama Ropeway


=== Rail ===
JR Hokkaido Stations in Sapporo
Hakodate Line: (Zenibako) – Hoshimi – Hoshioki – Inaho – Teine – Inazumi Kōen – Hassamu – Hassamu Chūō – Kotoni – Sōen – Sapporo – Naebo – Shiroishi – Atsubetsu – Shinrinkōen – (Ōasa)
Chitose Line: Heiwa – Shin Sapporo – Kami Nopporo – (Kita-Hiroshima)
Sasshō Line (Gakuentoshi Line): Sōen – Hachiken – Shinkawa – Shinkotoni – Taihei – Yurigahara – Shinoro – Takuhoku – Ainosato Kyōikudai – Ainosato Kōen – (Ishikari Futomi)


=== Air ===
The Sapporo area is served by two airports: Okadama Airport, which offers regional flights within Hokkaido, and New Chitose Airport, a larger international airport located in the city of Chitose 30 miles (48 km) away connected by regular rapid trains taking around 40 minutes. The Sapporo-Tokyo route between New Chitose and Haneda is one of the busiest in the world.


=== Airport shuttle, tour and charter bus service ===
An airport shuttle bus servicing all hotels in Sapporo operates every day of the year. SkyExpress was founded in 2005 and also provides transport to and from various ski resorts throughout Hokkaido, including Niseko.


== Education ==


=== Universities ===


==== National ====
Hokkaido University
Hokkaido University of EducationSee Japanese national university


==== Public ====
Sapporo Medical University
Sapporo City University


==== Private ====
Sapporo University
Hokusei Gakuen University
Hokkai School of Commerce
Hokkai Gakuen University

Tenshi College
Health Sciences University of Hokkaido

Hokkaido University of Science
Koen Gakuen Women's Junior College

Hokkaido College of Pharmacy
Sapporo University of Health Sciences
Japan Health Care College


=== Primary and secondary schools ===

Sapporo Odori High School provides Japanese-language classes to foreign and Japanese returnee students, and the school has special admissions quotas for these groups.The city has two private international schools:

Hokkaido International School
Hokkaido Korean Primary, Middle and High School (North Korean school)


== Twin towns – sister cities ==

Sapporo has twinning relationships with several cities worldwide.
 Portland, Oregon, United States, since 1959
 Munich, Bavaria, Germany, since 1972
 Shenyang, Liaoning, China, since 1980
 Novosibirsk, Russia, since 1990
 Daejeon, South Korea, since 2010
 Chiclayo, Peru

text.quote: Aquarium featuring numerous ocean-life exhibits & events, including penguin, dolphin & seal shows.
trip: Given Otaru is a very small city in Hokkaido, it's unrealistic to expect a very cool aquarium. Frankly, having its own aquarium is already amazing. The closest encounter one can get:- - winter in snow, penguins walking next to you. - dolphin show with dolphin only 3m away. -

This place definitely isn’t what we expected. On entry there is 3 large turtles in a tiny pool. One of them didn’t move the whole time and another kept banging up against the wall. The dolphins were kept in what looked like a standard pool. They kept swimming fast in circles.
Here you can see penguin dolphins bear and many more. Its very cheap to see those animals. They got timing for the show. Make sure you chrck it first bfore going there.

I hope we could spend more time here, but it closed one hour earlier in winter. We were able to see seal feeding, penguin waling, and dolphin show. They were awesome! You got to see these amazing animals very closely. Plan at least 3 hours here and you won't regret.

Otaru Aquarium is small and bit outdated but has interesting attractions like pinguin parade, unique local fish, kids can touch octopus, walrus show and much more. Make sure to check the show timetable before you come! Notes: - During rainy day the walk to aquarium can be

no ferry service during winter season else it will be more enlightening. we took a bus from the Otaru Station. About 30min bus ride. the place was very small and kinda run down. if not for the show, u can cover the place in an hour. there is a restaurant there but it closes

text.wiki:
List of defunct railway companies in Japan lists defunct Japanese railway operators.  The list includes all types of railways, such as handcars, horsecars, trams, light railways, heavy rails, freight rails, industrial railways, monorails, new transit systems, or funiculars.  Some companies are still active in other businesses, such as bus operation.  Translated names might be tentative.  "Former names" include those of preceding operators not directly related to their successors.
The list omits these types of operators:

Type 1: Direct predecessor of surviving railway operator. (e.g. Meguro Kamata Electric Railway, the current Tokyu Corporation.)
Type 2: Operator with lines largely succeeded by surviving railway operator. (e.g. Kaetsunō Railway, whose lines succeeded by Manyōsen.)
Type 3: Operator that was merged by surviving railway operator, Type 1, or Type 2. (e.g. Sanyō Railway, later merged into Japanese National Railways, which was later succeeded by Japan Railways Group Companies.)
Type 4: Planned line that was never built.

text.quote: Popular destination offering 2 Japanese- & Western-style hot-spring baths with scenic valley views.
trip: 定山渓グランドホテル瑞苑の前の道路を西に１分で着きました。定山渓温泉のなかでは少し奥のほうにあるので、観光案内所からは歩いて１０数分かかります。
定山渓温泉の日帰り入浴施設で、露天風呂有り・天然温泉で探したところ、こちらの湯の花がヒットしました。 駐車場はかなり広く、札幌市内からも送迎バスが運行されていて、曜日・時間帯によってはかなり混みそうです。 ホームページで紹介されていた洞窟風呂は日替りで浴場が変わるため入れず残念でした。
入湯料850円と大型日帰り温泉にしては高くはないがビーバー？のキャラがいたるところにありかなり子供っぽい。露天風呂の寝湯の真ん中にも石像が鎮座。洞窟風呂は青いライトがあやしい。もう少し和風寄りの方が良いかと。
小樽にもあるチェーンの入浴施設で定山渓温泉の国道から少し入っとところに広大な駐車場を持つ温泉。広い店内にはゲームや卓球台まであり一日いることもできるかも。風呂は広く露天風呂もよいがコンクリのどこにでもある日帰り風呂と同じ。二階に休憩と食事ができる大広間がある。地下鉄駅から無料送迎バスまである
渓流を眺めながら露天風呂に入ることができます。お風呂上がりには、二階の大広間で、のんびりすることができます。
札幌からかっぱライナーの温泉券付きチケットを使って行きました。ホテルに囲まれている中で一つだけ温泉施設があったので利用。思ったより空いていて観光客は少なく地元の方の中でゆっくり楽しめました。サウナやマッサージなど色々な湯があり、雪の中での露天風呂は最高の思い出になりました！二階にはひろーい御食事処もあり、値段も良心的。ゆっくりできます。

text.wiki:
Noboribetsu (登別市, Noboribetsu-shi, Ainu: nupur-pet) is a city in Iburi Subprefecture, Hokkaido, Japan. Part of Shikotsu-Toya National Park, it is southwest of Sapporo, west of Tomakomai and northeast of Hakodate.
As of September 2016, the city has an estimated population of 49,523, and a population density of 230 persons per km². The total area is 212.11 km².
The city office is in Horobetsu. The town of Noboribetsu is at the mouth of the Noboribetsu river and is therefore a much narrower area.


== Geography ==
The mountains dominate the west and north while the plains dominate around five km within the coastline. There are three towns along the Pacific Ocean: from northeast to southwest, Noboribetsu, Horobetsu and Washibetsu. These betsu are derived from "river" in the Ainu language. Noboribetsu is on the Noboribetsu River. Horobetsu and Washibetsu are on the Iburi-horobetsu River and the Washibetsu River respectively.


=== Origin of Name ===
The name, Noboribetsu, derives from an Ainu word, nupur-pet, which means dark-colored river; the kanji 登別, meaning "climbing different", are used for their phonetic value only, and have no relation to the original meaning.


== History ==
1919: Horobetsu village was founded.
1951: Horobetsu village became Horobetsu town.
1961: Horobetsu town renamed to Noboribetsu town.
1970: Noboribetsu town became Noboribetsu city.


== Education ==


=== High school ===
Hokkaido Noboribetsu Seiryo High School (登別市立西陵中学校)


=== Secondary school ===
Hokkaido Noboribetsu Akebi Secondary School (北海道登別明日中等教育学校)


== Transportation ==
Muroran Main Line: Washibetsu - Horobetsu - Tomiura - Noboribetsu
Hokkaido Expressway: Noboribetsu-Muroran IC - Tomiura PA - Noboribetsu-Higashi IC
Route 36


== Sightseeing ==

6 km inland from Noboribetsu City in the river valley is the smaller town of Noboribetsu-onsen (登別温泉). The town has a range of onsen for bathing as well as other hot springs formed from different minerals for scenic viewing, and is also known for its bear park. Noboribetsu-onsen is one of many well-known resorts in Japan, with many hotels and ryokan, and is the largest "hot spring town" in Hokkaido.


== Twin cities ==


=== International ===
 Faaborg-Midtfyn Municipality, Denmark
 Saipan, United States
 Guangzhou, Guangdong, China


=== Domestic ===
Shiroishi, Miyagi
Ebina, Kanagawa


== References ==


== External links ==
Official Website (in Japanese)
noboribetsu-spa

Went as a day trip from Sapporo. Few hiking trails that are pretty peaceful compared to the crowded entrance areas. Nice footbath hot spring to relax the tired feet along the path.
Great place to visit if your in the area. The smell of Sulfur over there is quite something, try to wear non slip footwear as some of the path is quite slippery due to the ice.

went to visit this place during winter and a bit later in the afternoon, we got to see the rock formations with and without the lights along the pathways. it was beautiful and a nice place to have a bit of a walk. however, if you can't stand the smell of sulfur, please avoid

Carpark cost y500, but no entrance fee to the hell valley. Various treks available around the place. But you can take good pic within 15 min walk from entrance Clean toilets and rest stop

This is not a very big place to explore. The walk will last less than 30 minutes. Do wear enough if you are travelling during winter. Is a must to visit the nearby onsen for an authentic hot bath to wrap up the visit.

These vents are not unique, but still quite interesting. What I enjoyed most were the walks around the area. There are quite a few walks that you can do from there. You can walk to Oyunuma Pond and Lake Shikotsu, and even take a foot bath in the stream.
The title speaks it ALL. a very nice location NOT to be missed. we were there in early winter (November) and managed to catch snow fall there. i reckoned it would be nice during other seasons too.
Rotten Egg smell emitting from the cracks of the crater. Amazing view if this is your first time seeing an active volcano. Near to the town and easily accessible by walk.
Scenically, it is unique. Not often one can see a steaming valley. It's a main site to visit while in Noboribetsu so we went there. It is not overwhelming, but pretty cool.

Weather (near zero degree Celsius) was great and enjoyable for a morning walk and climb in winter wear yet not sweating. Good exercise to start the day. There was not much crowd in the morning. The tour buses started to arrive around 1pm and the area was packed in no time.
Very busy in late October with autumn foliage visitors but a few hours is well spent in the area at any time of the year to see the splendid geothermal features.

We took the Limited Hokuto Express from Sapporo Station to Noboribetsu to visit the famous Oyunuma hot spring river. Our fare is covered by the Hokkaido flexible 4 days pass. The journey from Sapporo Station took about 1 hr 30 minutes. Once we got off the train at

I live at the nearby hotel so i can walk to Jogokudani at night and the path is beautifully well lit. It is my exercise after eating a heavy dinner. The place look deserted but safe to walk around. The tranquility and peace are felt without the busyness of tourists during the
Had no idea Japan had such diverse & unique landscape Hell Valley was totally worth a visit beautiful Onsen town & don’t forget to try the local spicy noodles

Lovely place to visit during autumn. The smoking Valley with the colourful backdrop makes it a perfect place for lots of photo. Parking is easy, just nearby for 500 yen. A lot of easy trails to bring u to diff observation deck. Be sure to spend 2hr there

Worth to take close look at the hot spring vents but note the sulphuric smell for those who might be allergic. The colour, order and the surrounding heat provides a unique experience for those who have never seen volcanic terrain.
A good place to go if you are nearby... you will see smoke from coming out from volcanic rocks... and from here you can make your way to see the hot spring too..
Worth walking around and seeing the landscape and the volcanic vents. Very scenic. Well maintained walkways.
Filled with sulphuric smell, very interesting place. Nearby many hotels. Worth to take a look to see where does all the onsen water come from
Okayama crater is the sulphuric hot area worth walk on the long walking trail. Alternative , one drives to the Okayama parking area to view it . Worth a visit

This is the well known Hell Valley which steam rises from the mountains and hot water bubbles up from the Tessen Ike geyser. Japanese demon statues are everywhere to decorate this area and make it looks like a hell. But you can't jump into the natural hot spring pool for

Worth a visit and hike on walkways. Its so magical of the nature The sulphur smell is so strong. Also enjoyed to dip my feet in the running stream “foot bath” - a great experience There are some restaurants nearby. We had lunch at a lamb restaurant. It was so good.
Fun time at this beautiful volcanic landscape with our 2 kids. They really enjoyed strolling along the park and my 2 years old kept mentioning about volcano after we're back from this trip.

I walk from Daiichi takimotokan for my morning walk. It is good because it has up and down trails. There are lots of birds singing. The place looked safe for early morning risers. The scenery is amazing.

This place doesn't need any further explanation as many reviews are out there. Hell Valley it is called for its heat that came out from the burning ground and the overall landscape of smokes like hell. Pretty interesting place to visit with some nice spots. A lot of walking is

The writer bought the return bus ticket at the Noboribetsu JR station for 620JPY and left the bus at Noboribetsu Onsen stop. You could reach this attraction after about 5 minutes of walk.

Nature at its finest! Worth a visit to see this active site, especially with all the snow around. It is still fairly safe to walk around, the paths are well defined.

Night walk is special with may tourists gone. The smell is 'Hell' ...but then we are in Hell Valley. Noboribetsu is quite 'dead' at night in winter. Nothing spectacular, just a nice, peaceful walk after dinner.

Beautiful views, lovely boardwalk (be careful in snow conditions though as it can be slippery) and a lovely hike up if you have the energy to view the two lakes. The boardwalk is where most tourists on tour buses will visit. It can get crowded. However, the hike up into the

Natural hot steam escaping from the valley with yellowy gray volcanic gas seeping from the surface of the rocks. This makes the whole place smell strongly of sulfur and gives it an image like that of hell. The valley is a 450-meter-diameter mouth of a volcano, which produces

If you go there in winter, it will be a very relaxing stroll but once you start climbing the steps up the hills, you will have to be careful of the slippery ice on the steps. Walk in the snow and not on ice. There will be a natural smell of sulphur because that place is famous

Nice and natural landscape, lots of tour visitors when we're there, freezing cold at winter time. Remember to bring face mask if can't stand the smell.

Took a morning walk. Easy access from hotels in the onsen area. The autumn leaves were beautiful at this time of the year. Can get crowded with tourist buses. The place is good for a short visit like a morning walk that we took.
This place, though a natural landscape, is just worth to spend 15mins and you can move on. See pics for what it is worth The demons statues are much more interesting.

A stopover for most tours when visiting Noboribetsu. The Jigokudani - Hell's valley. The start point for the hot springs in the area. Hotels in the area are quickly taken up by the locals. The short 45 mins walking trail can be challenging during winter when it is covered
Nice views but some parts of the path are covered with snow and ice. Difficult to walk and surprisingly cold for a hot springs area!
A must go place if you're here. Magnificent view and do admire the works from mother nature! Do take a slow walk to explore deeper into the park.
This place resemble a hell valley. Steam coming up from the ground. Nice place to take some photo. Many tourist.
This place is all about walking - lots of it. You get up close to the wonder of Mother Nature. Strong sense of sulphur in the air.
Amazing view and very natural nice sight seeing. But need to walk via path way where us wet and slippery during winter time . Not suggest old folk due to walk way didn't provide many road light.

Jigokudani was quite a sight. Though it's not quite as colourful in the winter, the landscape was still an incredible view and something worth seeing. Be careful of the wooden slope/steps when you're there — they can be rather slippery with the ice that forms during winter. The

you see hot steam coming up at a distance, and hot water streams over which broadwalks are erected. You can't actually see lava. and the sulphuric smell is mild, compared to say Blue fire Ijen in Surabaya. But snow and steam make an interesting compostion.

Noboribetsu is a small town and one of its most popular tourist places is Jigokudani. It's only a very short walk from Takinoya, the hotel where my friend and I are staying. It's quite a nice walk given the weather was good. Otherwise, apart from the special landscape and the

The air is pungent of sulfur and cool minerals, the colors of the valley recede from deep black, to red, orange and cool tones of blues, whites and green yellows. Pools steam around you as you walk down the boardwalk, large rock formations are gothic like, and you feel a kind of

We were lucky, experienced the first snow. Despite the snow, rain and cold, it was enjoyable. I think the rain diluted the smell a lot. Be careful of the slippery wooden steps path. It was not possible to walk to the Oyunnama Brook Natural Footbath due to the cold weather,

I took the train from Sapporo early in the morning, took me about an hour an a half to get to Noboribetsu! Then took the bus from the train station to Noboribetsu Onsen! Got to the Hell Valley right after the rain, so the smoke was so clear and the place looked pretty magical! I

This was my second visit to this place. It looks more beautiful in Autumn with red, golden and yellow leave. Whoever travel to southern part of Hokkaido, should visit this place and try the onsen. It was a wonderful experience and you would like it.

Hints of Yellowstone, but with the culture of Japan. See it at dusk when the sunset hits the yellow sulfur stones, and also in the mornings. The colours will amaze you. Visit in the autumn and the hills behind will add spectacular colours to your photos.

AKA Hell Valley, is a denuded hot water valley at the north end of the Noboribetsu hot spring community. It has a boardwalk where tourists can walk amongst steam vents and sulfur smells into the middle of the valley, where an intermittent geyser, Tessen Ike, is located. There
Went there with tour group. This place is packed with tourists like me viewing the sulfurous steam coming out from the ground! Whole place smelled funny too😖
我不下地獄 誰下地獄！ 沒想到地獄谷山上有大湯沼等遊點 Somehow, I did not know that there are several more scenes are up there. It's definitely a good idea to visit other scenes on the way to mountain top

If u have seen other hell valleys in Japan eg the one near Hakone area, this one is not that different though u can get quite close to it. Good viewing platforms and good contrast of landscape versus the sky.

If you like nature, I would make sure you stop and spend some time walking around. I believe parking is 500 yen. There are multiple trails that can be taken. We didn't make it to the natural foot bath, unfortunately. Lots of photo opportunities and lots of pretty nature to
Was fortunate to be here when the weather was beautiful. Managed to take a few good shots. The pathway can be difficult to walk so wear proper footwear.

This place is easily access by Donan Bus (pay by cash only) from Noboribetsu Station. Get off at Noboribetsu Onsen Station and walk up the hill for 15-20 mins to the valley. The highlight of the place is the geyser fountain which located at the center of the valley. It takes 5
Several trails of walking path. Expect strong sulphur smell and steamy vent. You may follow the trail up to Oyunuma Brook Natural Footbath where you can dip your feet. Wear a good walking shoes.

Jigokudani shows the power of volcano activities. It is special to one who never see this before. However it is not special to me as I'm from a place with lots of hot springs. I suggest tourists should go here in the evening for the special scene and the bridge. Good for taking

Noboribetsu Hell Valley (Jigokudani) Come to Hell Valley to experience the hot steam vents, sulphurous streams and volcanic terrains. You can walk on the wooden walkways to explore the hot pool, sulphurous stream. According to my wife, this place is less smoky compared to some

We can say amazing a one word that will define this place. You can reach this place by taking public transport from noboribetsu station in 30 minutes, then start walking from bus stop to around 500 meters to see Jigokudani known as hell valley. you can smell a lot of sulfur

Even though we often try to avoid touristy places, this was one of our highlights. It was spectacular how you can walk "above" the volcanic craters on a footpath and observe the hot, coloured water, the steam coming ouf of the rocks and the different colours and shapes of the
Awesome view and something unique to see. The steamy vents and sulfuric smell was strong. A must go if you are going noboribetsu.
definitely worth a visit. the natural foot bath is easily accessible on foot. after the rain, the hiking trails can be quite muddy so wear proper hiking shoes

The entire area provides you a stunning view of an volcanic area. From the smell, you know the volcanic activity is active though not violent. There are many walking trails to visit various spots. Some are just very short and easy for ordinary people.

There was only an loutdoor carpark outside the entrance 500¥ per entry, all around the whole street no parking therefore you have to park your car in this carpark then walking around Souvenir shop, drug shop, convenient shop, restaurant, hotel & etc. Only around 5 parking slots

The signboard of 'Jigokudani' can be seen about 5 mins walk from the main street. From there, you can decide which trail you want to walk. Do wear a comfortable shoes for this walking trail. There are a few nice photo spot, so do look out for them on the map.

This was a real WOW despite my already having visited South Island in New Zealand, Grand Canyon in US, Siem Reap in Cambodia, Lake District in UK, Alps in Europe. Such unique landscape experience that was made so accessible to visitors of all ages.

Hell Valley as its known is a spectacular place that has hot steam vents, sulfurous streams & other geothermal activity. You can't escape the smell of sulfur as you come up to the start of the area. Coming from a country that doesn't have any volcanoes it was interesting &

The walk out to Jigokudani (translation:Hell Valley) is quite easy and well worth it to see the source of the onsen hot springs of Noboribetsu. If you enjoy hiking like we do you can continue onward to other trails to explore the local nature and wildlife. I also recommend

You can definitely smell the sulphur before you see the valley. Very strong smell. You can also feel the heat when you get closer as well. It's a good experience to walk around the area and experience the smell and the heat.

When we arrived, it was windy and the geothermal hot spring was steaming up and made the whole area smoky. We walked a short distance along the trail and stopped at the lookout point. Observing its beautiful natural view of boiling and bubbling water which make people imagine

there seems to be many of these dotted all around japan - all having the same sulphuric smelling gases spewing out of the ground. the interesting part about this one was that it is actually quite big and you can spend easily 1-2 hours walking along one of the trails deeper in.

They call it Hell Valley to obvious reasons. The smell of sulphur can be suffocating at the start but you will soon get use to it. Dress light as you will feel like you 're in a sauna with the summer heat and hot steam from the valley. Worth a visit just to feel what hell is
Not far from hotel, walking to Hell Valley. A good place to visit since there is no much things to see except onsen. Strong sulfur smell but bearable. Good place for taking photos as well.

It was a beautiful experience walking through Hell's Valley. The sight of volcanic gases coming out of the ground and the smell of sulphur is quite strong. We went to the crater observatory and it was an amazing sight, something i have not seen before. Great experience and worth
Well, when you've enjoyed the onsen, why don't take a 30mins walk there? Although I didn't think it's special it's still worth you to pay a visit to see the valley.

There were directions and signs about where to go and what to see. The broad walk allows people of all ages to walk around easily. The Yukijin firework at night was amazing, but it was in June and July only. If you have not visited other Hell Valleys, it is worth visiting.

Really beautiful landscape with the boiling water on the ground and steam in the air. Breathtaking scenery and very good spot for photographs. Visited the valley during winter and the steps are a little slippery. Not suitable for older visitors in winter as it's quite dangerous

The sulphur hot springs are spectacular, with lots of steam and sulphur smells. Several walking routes around the area. In June, the forests are very green and lush. Worthwhile spending some time exploring the forest trails.
A wonderful trip. Tried the natural foot bath while visiting. It is only a short trip, and we got to see a lot of steam and natural Sulphur deposits.
Drob by to enjoy sights of sulphur hot springs, a good walk in the greens and a good foot soak. Only parking payable at one time fee 500yen for multiple parking areas.

The sulfur was bearable. It always rain there. So be prepared. Weather was good. We had good fun trekking there and soaking in the footbath. Bring a small towel, if you intend to do so. The view is really one of a kind. I have never seen anything like this before.

It's amazing to see Nature at work. Hot steam sulphur coming out from the valley naturally, even when it's raining heavily! This Hell valley is a big place. Expect alot of "hiking." Understand from the main entrance parking attendant there are 3 different entrances! It's

Besides admiring the extraordinary view of the mountain, I was most captivated by the walking trails where the steps are well kept. Put on a good pair of walking/ jogging shoes and off we go to burn off the extra pounds we have put on savouring the delectable donburi and

Hell Valley is one of the attractions to visit in Noboribetsu. The attraction is free. The hell valley consists of a few areas which are at walking distance. Map is available at the main entrance & the rest are japanese signages at the road side. There are different platforms of
It was quite amazing to see steaming and bubbling geysers. The air was filled with the smell of Sulphur. This was an eye opener and valuable geography lesson for my teenager.

Enjoyed exploring the various pathways in the park. Well-marked and easy to navigate. Plenty of information (in Japanese) on flora and insects in various places. Great place to bring families. Most accessible on foot except for Mt Hiyori Lookout.

A must see when visiting Noboribetsu. The higher platform provide a bird eye view of the valley. Good place to take a pana view. Free of charge to see. The only charges applied when parking involved. Friendly car park attendance ever helping tourist. Lots of visiors during

We visited Jigokudani in winter time in February. The sulfur smell is not that bad/strong; and the paths are all well maintained. Just be careful during winter time as it can get quite slippery. The landscape of the valleys covered with snow mixed with the hot steam coming

Interesting views of volcanic activity, primarily stand and sulphur vents. Numerous walking paths to choose from, depending on how far you want to walk. The sulphur smell is not too strong and bearable without a mask. Within walking distance from all the hotels in the main

Nothing can take your breath away like nature's beauty....this volcanic crater with its steaming waters and sulphurous fumes is located about 1 1/2 hours drive from Sapporo....went with family and when one climbs the steps to the lake it actually looks like its Japanese
great sightseeing in noboribetsu onsen area, nothing much. an hour hike along with mountain views and hot spring views. if you love nature its your destination

Also known as Hell's Valley, Jigokudani is a place worth to go if you visit Hokkaido or you want to see a close-up volcano. It was really amazing to be able to see the hot stream and volcanic gases coming out from its ground. However, the strong smell of the sulfur may make one

Jigokudani is part of the Shikotsu-Toya National Park. The walking trail with the various lookout points were good. Walking paths were well laid and well maintained, kudos to the administration team! The trail includes the Oyunuma Pathways that lead to the Oyunuma lookout point.

The first time we were here, it was during winter time and the weather was bitter cold. We went back on April 2017, still very cold but managed to stay here for about an hour. It is very nice and picturesque. It is also very near the hotel where we stayed in. If you go

we dont get to see such places often so it was pretty interesting to view this place but unfortunately it was raining pretty heavily, otherwise we would have climbed up to see the other side of the place. the area smells like sulfur and had hot steam coming up from the ground,
Took a morning from the hotel and reached Jigokundani. A picture tells a thousand words. So the best way is to enjoy viewing the photos.

Jigoku-Dani looks majestic. There is a distinct sulphur smell, which is detectable but not too distressing. From Noboribetsu JR Station, take a bus. Some buses stop at N11 Noboribetsu Onsen, which is the entrance where you can get tourist information, but is some distance away

Spent about 3 hours here. Make sure you walk as many trails as possible to get different views of the hell valley. We also trek another 15mins towards Oyunuma pond which is another beautiful sight. For Pokémon go players: many pokestops here too. You can find Farfetch here.

Worth dropping by. I didn't do all the trails, as the day of my visit had a wind chill of 3 degrees celsius - an irony to its name. But, the little I saw left a memorable impression. So if you're coming in Spring and would love to explore, be sure to dress accordingly.
Dubbed as Hell's Valley, Jigokudani is a must go place in Noboribetsu. The smell of sulphur might be uncomfortable for certain people but the long walk is worthy.
Besides the hell valley, do take troll along the various footpaths, one leads to a smokey crater pond which is really cool.

A very scenic hike at a natural attraction and we'd agree with all the positive comments before us. The start of the suggested route is very well paved and toddler friendly but on route to the natural foot bath, the path gets quite steep very quickly. We made the mistake of
We were a bit disappointed that the nature foot bath is closed until further notice due to recent eruption. Anyway we did enjoy the breathtaking display of hot steam vents.

Was there beginning of May. There is a lot of walking along the trail so it is better to wear suitable walking shoes. Put on a good pair of sunglasses when it is bright. It was a good walk. Unfortunately, the footbath soaking section was closed when we were there. The

It is about 1.5 hour train ride from Sapporo to Noboribetsu. Jigokudani is a unique, picturesque and somewhat mysterious landscape. The area smells strongly of sulphur. There are several walking trails to see the hot springs in different spots. Lots of walking, depending on how
The main attraction of Noboribetsu where it attracts many tourists every day. If you have time, hike around the hill to see the other side of the valley.

Smell of sulfur, yellow hot spring and mountains, steam make you dream of hell. A 10 minutes walking around this hell valley can give you a unforgettable experience. It is quite easy to walk and enjoy unless you have a baby.

The only natural attraction in Noboribetsu, good for an hour hiking, free of charge. Nice landscape but not amazing. Only gas emitted from the geyers. Onoyuma pool is worth the hike over the hill for a pictorial photo.

It's the most famous attraction in this small town. Actually not much you can do in this town, so I bet this is a place everyone would go. Within a walking distance from the main street of it. The landscape is very unique. But a bit smelly to some people. You can also walk

Great introduction to sulphur hot springs. The smell is not so bad and you don't smell it after a while. It snowed while we were there so it was really beautiful. Had a bit of problem finding it initially as the signs were not really clear but found it with google maps. Just
Extremely cool place. Tons of geyers, clouds of steam and hot water. A hike to the footbath is well worth it.

Just about 90 min from Sapporo by express train Hokuto view was spectakuler after walking around the Valley we an make free footbath in natur small river with hot Water from the mountain was very Good or take a bath - onsen in some hotel a Public bath

This attraction was free of charge and one can leisurely stroll through it at any pace. There are many areas for pictures and walking trails that bring you close up to the sulphur blow holes. Nice to appreciate the history of noboribetsu and how it became famous for its hot

Hell Valley is what brings tourists to Noboribetsu. The hell valley is magnificent and mysterious at the same time. Only one track is opened during winter. Nice easy walk but the ground might be slippery in winter.

Jigokudani is an active volcanic crater at Noboribetsu. Its a must see place when you visited Noboribetsu. It gives you a mystical aura as it means Hell's Valley in Japanese. Try strolling all around the place to see all interesting statues.

Certainly a different view and wroth a few photos. It's not large and the fumes aren't overwhelming. No black hardboiled eggs here though (for those who've had them in Hakone). Visit if you're in the neighbourhood and have time to pass, but don't make it the central point of
A place must visit at Noboribetsu, the fantastic unforgettable scenery, will never forget this place....

Its a must go when you visit Noboribetsu. Smoke everywhere around the hill and mountain. Although the strong and unpleasant smell of sulphur, you will still be wondering why the area is like this??? When you gradually walk your way up to the hill top, you realise that its really

It didn't have much bad smell from sulphur : ) The scene is nice that is really worth to visit! It must be praised that in the gift shop, which is located in the entrance. It has free service to borrow rain boots for traveler. Reason why I emphasised is because in winter time,

The Jigokudani is the source of much of the onsen water in Noboribetsu. Right when we stepped out of the car, it smelled strongly of sulfur due to the volcanic activity but you get used to it quickly. Some beautiful landscapes in the valley that make for great photo
The view relieved my stress when I went there. You wont get tired of it. A must-see place in Hokkaido. Just an hour bus away from the airport.

We visited Jigokudani on a wintry Feb afternoon when it was snowing and foggy. Trails were icy and a lot of the snow-bound trails were closed. I can imagine this place being a nice easy hike in better days. Even then, it was crowded with several tourist bus loads of people.
Like the topic, It's slippery, I've been there in stormy and snowy season. Luckily It's windy and just wait for the cloud to be blown away. The view and scenic is wonderful.

Good to see this natural phenomenon and landscape. We visited during winter so beware of the slippery steps/path. It was overflowing with mainland Chinese tourists at this time of year which detracted from the overall experience. Originally wanted to go back at night with all
Beautiful view of natural hot spring! The walk up and down Jigokudani can be slippery due to the snow but the view is well worth every fall!

Quite disappointed by this attraction. Had hoards of China tourists swarming the area so was not such a great place to visit. The nearby untouched trails with unadulterated snowy landscapes proved to be a more enjoyable trek. Beware of the slippery steps if you do visit this
You can see the springhead of Noboribetsu hot spring. The hot spring flows steaming and being formed like a stream. This valley is near to Mahoroba Hotel, where you can enjoy hot spring baths.

Since Noboribetsu is famous of their natural hot spring, this is the place you must have visited when you are here. It shows you the original source where the onsen come from and how did it form by volcanoes around Hokkaido. Entrance fee is free, but be careful during snowing
The geyser was phenomenal and the scenery of the steaming slopes was one and only. But becareful of the icy slippery slopes. Good shoes is a must.
It takes roughly around 1-2 hrs to complete the walk. You can smell sulphur along the way, it's quite beautiful as we don't get to see it in our country.

We had wanted to visit this place since last year but could not make it as the journey by train to and fro Sapporo Station would have taken about 4.5 hours including the journey from Noboribetsu to the onsen area where the Hell Valley is located, and the train fare costs ¥4480

Apart from the onsen, the thermal activity area of Jigokudani (or Hell Valley in ENglish) is the reason we came here. Nothing much to see but mostly for photo opportunity. Those coming with tour normally won't stay long, so the inner part of this area which is very beautiful
A wonderful and slippery walk to take on your day trip. You can also go here at sundown; the lamps will light up and the valley actually looks like hell.
It smells a little bit, but you really see exactly what you hoped to see according to the pictures on internet! Close to the hotel areas.
We visited in winter when the paths were slippery. The area is well worth exploring - nature is truly amazing! Car parking cost 500 yen.
This reminds me of a yellow stone, but with more pungent smell. The trail around the valley was covered in snow, but the valley itself steamed with sulfonic vapor. This was quite new.

Aside from visiting the steaming valley, we also spent about 2 hours hiking the surrounding paths which are well mapped out and lead to some interesting locations. It does not require a high degree of fitness and is a good reward for the effort.

We walked around the standard path walked by other tourists, we did not explore further up the hill so not sure if we would change our rating of average for this place. Based on what we saw and experienced, this place is interesting if you haven't seen "smoke" coming out from

Visited this place in December. The whole Noboribetsu was covered with white snow including Jigokudani. It was very cold and strong wind. Advised to put on more layers and keep yourself warm if you are planning to visit during these few days or probably next couple of months. I

Went there for a short hike. I think the best time to go there should be in late Nov-Dec when the leaves turn red as it would be very beautiful. My 2.5 hours was well spent walking around and visiting all the nice spots within the area.
I really enjoyed the walk at Jigokudani, it was a beautiful site and a really picturesque place for great photos!
This is the very reason why you are visiting Noboribetsu Onsen. The hot spring water is flowing down from here. The view is very scenic. Thumbs up.

Despite cold and snowy weather and our feet were already soaked from the morning, we decided to press on with Hell Valley. It didn't disappoint us at all. Great landscape and scenery and the trails are rather easy. Some parts are slippery but should be fine if one just proceed

Otherwise known as Hell Valley to us tourists, this place should warrant a visit when you go to Noboribetsu. Our hotel was just nearby, and this was the last stop before we went to the hotel. The whole place reeks of sulphur smell, and we didn't stay too long as we did not know
Nice views all around. There're Onsens everywhere nearby the area and you could go up to any of them after a long hike around "Hell Valley".
The hot spring valley lives up to its name. The view is gorgeous and lots of picture spots. Can walk around the park to explore the beautiful surroundings. Easy to drive up and locate.

The air was filled with smell of sulphur. My little one called it smelly valley. Interesting walk but be careful as some parts of the walkway were slippery due to ice. Put on crampons if u had bought them. Otherwise walk slowly, hold on to the wooden handrails.
Lovable view with the nice colours in Autumn period. Red and yellow leafs make the valley more beautiful.
Pretty cool to be so close to a active volcano our hotel is right next to this attraction kids had fun

Short walk from Noboribetsu-onsen station. If you like to go for foot bath, be prepared to walk a bit further. A round trip to footbath might take less than 1 hour (exclude soaking time) Slippery during winter, buy cheap rubber crampons than can be fixed on to any adult size

Nature at its best. Don't miss this attraction if you are visiting Noboribetsu. 1. Natural wonder Sulphuric air. Vapours all around. Hot springs. Rock formation. Vegetation. Uphill, downhill. You have it all. It's really quite spectacular. Geography enthusiasts will love the

Go visit Jigokudani and marvel at nature's power. However, make sure to bring or buy anti-skids for your footwear because it gets pretty slippery especially since the trails are hilly and mostly snow-covered. If you have kids, provide them with anti-skids too.
The hell valley is just l0 mins on foot from our hotel. I was awed by the natural landscape and scenic view. It is a must go attraction if you are in noboribetsu.

It was near sun set when we visited in Dec and the view of the valley was great with rays of sun shinning on its valley. The emission of sulphur was not too disturbing and I found this valley much more beautiful than the one near Mt Fuji. There are different paths for you to
A wonderful place to stroll. Take in the surphurous smell in the air. Avoid the tourist crowds and be marveled at the power of nature. Go to various observatory points there to have different views.

A fantastic view and a must visit. People get to experience where the hot spring originate from. I was there with my family and we walked up the stairs. Note that it can be tiring as it is uphill. however the further you walk, there is nothing much.

Hell valley is quite a long drive from downtown Sapporo. It was a bright and sunny day as we were led to the view deck of the attraction. Rising smoke was clearly visible from the valley below. A typical day here would have included a hike all around the valley. Because of a
Though the smell of sulphur was extremely strong! But the walk through the park has lots of surprise where many pots of boiling point was spotted.

Like going back in time, go for an explore and find nice quiet spots + i highly recomend paying 1500 yen to go to onsens in hotel Dai-ichi Takimotokan (10+ different types, 1 outside) which overlook the volcanic springs .. one of the most amazing places i went to in Japan. Nuff
Nice place, new experience, good for family trip, beatiful nature, sulfur smell is not that bad, clean
Great for a morning hike and trek. Simple and a good variety of trails. Each leading to a breathtaking view/sight. It gets dark early, and gets pretty scary late
It is free admission. Parking fee is 500 yens for two locations. This is the main tourist attraction in this area.

A well known hot spring area with a "hell" like environment. The air is full of typical hot spring smell with a lot of yellowing sulfur spots all over the valley. It's a nice place fir family visiting.

This is my first time being upclose with geyser. The uneven landscape, coupled by steaming geyser and hot spring lake is breathtaking. Walking trail offers visitors upclose look at the geysers and wells. The trail is open till late (even after dark) although best to catch it

It's a very impressive place with quite a bit of things to do if you're into easy hikes and hot springs. You can spend a good two days here experiencing the hot springs, which are cheaper than most of Japan. Most of the tourists here are Chinese on bus tours, so that might be a

A volcanic area with steam vents coming out of craters. So beautiful and awesome. Not a difficult hike at all. We went in early November and it was drizzling when we came but the sun came out later. I suggest going there early on a weekday if you don't like the crowds. We

Jigokudani aka The Hell's Valley is a prominent tourist attraction in Noboribetsu, well-known for its hot spring and is Noboribetsu's gem, a 24-acre smoking crater of geothermal activity, created by a volcanic eruption 20,000 years ago. The view of the crater is amazing.
Must see even if you don't want to hike for too long! Just visit the entrance and be awed by the bubbling water.
This place offers good tracking path for a nice scenic walk. The sulphur smell may be slightly strong so if you don't like rotten egg smell be prepared for it.

I was told that we were going to Hell Valley and that's because it's hot with hot geysers and sulphur fumes and that was exactly what I saw. Everything was kind of either yellow or white with cloudy puffs of sulphur fumes but at this time of the year there was also green,
One of the biggest sources for the area. You can observe the environment due to volcanic activities, but overall sight-view is not that spectacular.

We came here in early November. Miscalculated the dates a bit thus temperature was around 5 degree. But we managed to see the wonderful autumn Colours here and the next morning, it snowed for a couple of hours. Two seasons within two days. The onsen here just made the whole

It was a nice place to see since it was close to our hotel. The park was well kept and the visitor station was clean and accessible. The colors of fall were just starting to be visible and maybe if it was more in the fall/winter, the leaves and colors may be more spectacular to

Due to volcanic activities, this place gives out hot steam with sulfuric smell. Stroll slowly around and enjoy the unique scenery. There is a man-made bridge over the rocks, so it is safe to walk around.

This attraction is walk through an array of sulphur pits and smallish geysers. The constant stream of sulpher and steam are both auditory and visual reminders of how seismically interesting the whole area is. There are constructed timber ways that provide different views of

It's called Hell's Valley. Constant volcanic action spewed steam and the smell of sulfur is omnipresent. But the colors of Autumm are simply breathtaking. Very busy area and not easy to get pictures without unwanted tourists but since when is Hokkaido without tourists, hordes of

Easy and free to see this volcanic nature if you happened to be in Noboribetsu and could stand strong 'sulfur' smell. I didn't like it so just had a brief experience and quick look before leaving the place.
It is one of the most charming place in Hokkaido. The autumn colours and the clouds of hairsprings made this place magical. There is pathway where anyone can walk.

Smells of sulfur of course, if you can't take it probably best to give a miss. A few simple places to walk to and see, foot paths can be slippery when wet. Good to see but not somewhere you can spend a lot time at unless you do take the full walking experience thru the hills.

We walked from our Ryokan. It took about 15mins, entrance wise is free. The sulphur smell was not as bad as I thought. And thats lot of tourists when we visited. There is a souvenir shop at the entrance near the parking area. This is a stop on bus tours, so it is possible it
Cooling weather together with some incredible views of the hot spring. Worth a visit! You will feel the smell of sulphur which is emitted naturally from the hot spring.

Easy access to this place via bus from Noboribetsu train station, (but watch out for the return buses, there are very few in the evening)! Entry is free, which was both surprising and wonderful. The walks are short, one over a boarded walkway to the centre of the valley, and

You can easily walk along "hell's valley" and see some spectacular sites. This shows how the volcanic activity created these hot springs. The hot water underground must be what feeds the onsen hot springs. it is located in the town of Noboribetsu and an easy walk.

Went there as a day trip and ended up wanting to stay the night there. Beautiful volcanic landscape! It was fun trying to find all the demon statues scattered around and during the evening the trails are lit up! Noboribetsu is also a famous onsen resort, my skin never felt

We visited this National Park in autumn so it was beautiful to see the autumn leaves falling from the trees as you walk through the park. Pros: Free entry to the park. There were a few walking trails which were all very easy and safe for everyone (including children and
After transfer of flight , Enroute to this place of interests to view the panoramic view of this place. Very beautiful and certainly impressed by the nature

This place is IDEAL for mild hikers and people who enjoy nature, although it probably has heaps of locals and tourists alike, with the amount of coach buses that were parked there when we visited. It was surrounded by so many things to explore and was a good mild hiking place as
If you are there for hot spring, then this place is a must. It is just a 5-10min walk from Hotel Noboberitsu Manseikaku. There are also a few shops along the way selling souvenirs.
wont recommend to go this place during raining time coz you can discover some routes along the hell mountain to see the lake nearby since the routes were shut while raining.
Wonderful to visit. There is a walkway up to an intermittent geyser. It is a little bit small scale of Yellow Stone Park of the US, but has a definite character of its own.

A first rate geothermal area. Walk all the way out on all of the overlooks. Walk back down to town. Take in the welcome trolls. There is also an active geyser next to one of the hotels that is managed by building an enclosure over it. We've never seen that before...
You can go hiking, the scenery is not so beautiful but rather strange, it gives you the "end of the world" feeling. The scenery is like from some future movies.

It's really relaxing. The views are not too attractive. There are quite a few trails going up the hill. Saw a snake passing in front of me. I guess the sulphur is not strong enough to kill it. The hike was not too difficult. Spent a couple of hours there.

Peculiar place where you can see Vulcan lakes, natural spring hot water. All sites around are reachable with easy rail in the forest. Perfect to spent 4h in the middle of nature
A few walking trail to discover around the area. Do visit the Oyuma foot bath along the way. Nice experience.

We walk the park during the morning, and it was hot, but the other trails are tree covered and very nice. Make sure to wear walking/hiking shoes. There are trails with dirt, gravel, tree stumps, stairs..etc. Don't stop at this main attraction only, go on all the little hiking

Didn't expect this coming... I really enjoyed walking the trail around this place! It's quite beautiful. Make sure to wear comfy shoes as you might walk longer than you'd think.

Worth a visit for about two to three hours . Admission is free. Parking is 500 yen per entry. There are many walks within this attraction. We took the walk to the foot bath . Took 2.6 km of walking up and down steps and uneven ground to reach this place but well worth the walk.
It's incredible landscape. Worth to see. Smelt strong sulfur. My friend and I did some trail walking. Just followed the signs. It was very good exercise.

I recommend to see this attraction. It's beautiful and you can smell sulfur gas from steam. Enjoy taking photos around the place and I'm not suggest you to wear high-heeled shoe but canvas shoe is good to go.

A tourist attraction in noboribetsu. You can smell the sulfur from afar. even from the sewer sometimes the gas would go out and u can smell it on the street.

Interesting place to see. Quite a few different trekking route throughout the area, easy trekking even for kids. A few nice photo shoot locations with interesting background. good place to go.

Interesting stop offering a massive track and views of the sulphur pools and heat from the steam. The smell can be a little overpowering when up close to the pools but will still recommend a stop if on the way, just to see the magnificence of the place.

Went on a rainy day which made the steam even more dramatic. Easy walking around and you can watch the water gradually boiling in the middle of the pool. Nice.

The strong smell of sulfur hits you immediately when you get out of the car and is present in the area. There are clearly signed walkways in Hell Valley and the surrounding area. Car parking is available for JPY500 for the day. This area is definitely worth a visit.

Good for first time visit. Just to get a sense of what this is place is famous for. Many good picture moments. Personally I prefer the other lookout to Jigokudani itself.

Stunning winter landscape in Hell Valley. We spend a few hours walking around, and it was very beautiful and stark at the same time. Definitely a must see if you're in Noboribetsu.

Really amazing to see so much smoke being emitted from the ground. Will definitely visit this place again in winter! 😂 Curious how the cold temperatures will affect the smoke hehe.

a must go place in noboribetsu. you can smell the onsens and the view from the mountain is good and fresh air. a little walk is good

Hell valley when translated. Lots of sulphur spots. Quite an unusual sight and historical one too. In summer, there are even parades or events that you can view...

On the end of Onsen Street . Suggest visit the Visitor Centre first to watch the documentary before the walk . There are free rental of boots if needed . Few spots for photography Worth a visit

Amazing view of mountain with hot water evaporated though the air. Good for walking till the end of path.
